Over 48 other industrialised countries, including Japan and Germany, have already introduced second-tier patent systems. Overseas experience suggests that the innovation patent should provide better access to intellectual property rights and foster innovation by local enterprises.

para.inline: Other amendments to the Patents Act

speech.para: This bill will also move many of the fee payment requirements from the Patents Act to the regulations to enable this administrative function to be handled more efficiently by the Patent Office. This will enable greater flexibility in handling these administrative functions in the rapidly changing e-commerce environment.

The final objective of this bill is to introduce a number of minor amendments, some of which are technical in nature. These amendments remove a number of potential ambiguities and minor inconsistencies in the act.

I believe that this bill reflects the government's commitment to providing Australia with a strong intellectual property system that meets the needs of Australians. The innovation patent will provide a greater incentive for Australians, particularly individuals and small and medium business enterprises, to invest in innovation and the marketing of their good ideas. The amendments to the fee payment provisions of the act will enable the government to provide a modern fee payment system for users of the patent system.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Slipper, and read a first time.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2000 which is now before the House contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. Most of the amendments have been previously tabled in this House as customs tariff proposals and now require incorporation in the Customs Tariff Act. Therefore, I will only outline the major amendments at this time.
Schedule one is operative from 15 December 1999 and removes the customs duty on 268 nuisance tariff items.
Nuisance tariff items attract a duty of five per cent or less, each raise less than $100,000 in annual revenue and represent goods where there are few or no local producers.
These reductions in tariff rates lower business input costs which in turn enable Australian manufacturers to be more competitive in world trade.

Schedule 2 imposes an excise equivalent duty on imported chemical grade toluene, benzene, xylenes and mixed alkylbenzenes from 10 March 2000. The imposition of the duty on these products combats duty evasion through the illegal blending of petroleum products with toluene, a product which had not previously been subject to an excise equivalent duty.

The effect of these amendments is to close off this avenue of illicit activity. While there was no evidence that chemicals other than toluene were being used in fuel substitution activity, there was the potential for this to occur, particularly if this duty was not imposed.
Regulations and administrative measures have been implemented to ensure that legitimate users of these chemicals are not disadvantaged.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: EXCISE TARIFF PROPOSAL NO. 3 (2000)CUSTOMS TARIFF PROPOSAL NO. 4 (2000)

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 (2000)
Customs Tariff Proposal No. 4 (2000)

speech.para: The tariff proposals which I have just tabled contain alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1995.

Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 (2000) and Customs Tariff Proposal No. 4 (2000) formally place before parliament changes to the excise and customs duty on fuel. The policy document, Tax reform: not a new tax, a new tax system,outlined the government's commitment to maintain pump prices after the introduction of the GST.
Under the new arrangements to be introduced on 1 July 2000, excise and customs duty will be reduced for unleaded petrol, leaded petrol, diesel and other fuel used in internal combustion engines.
The measures outlined in this tariff proposal in conjunction with the Fuel Sales GrantScheme will assist in maintaining fuel prices following the introduction of the GST.
A summary of the alterations contained in these proposals has been prepared and is being circulated.
I commend the proposals.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: Customs Tariff Proposal No. 5 (2000)

speech.para: Customs Tariff Proposal No. 5 (2000), which I have just tabled, contains alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. These changes relate to a number of matters.

Firstly, on 21 June, the Minister for Trade, Mr Vaile, and the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin, jointly announced that a settlement had been reached with the United States of America in relation to the Howe Leather dispute. Part of that settlement involves Australia reducing the customs duty on 30 tariff items from five per cent to free from 1 July 2000.

This proposal gives effect to those agreed duty reductions. The second amendment relates to the preferential tariff treatment for developing countries, which has had longstanding bipartisan support in Australia. The United Nations reviews its list of designated least developed countries from time to time to ensure that the changing economic and development circumstances of individual countries are taken into account. Following such a review, both Angola and Madagascar have been added to the least developed countries list. This proposal makes the required changes to part 3 of schedule 1 of the Customs Tariff Act to reflect the designation of these two countries. A further change acknowledges the renaming of Zaire as the Democratic Republic of Congo. The effect of the amendments will be to accord a tariff margin of five per cent where available over the general rate of duty to Australia's imports from Angola and Madagascar.

The final amendment involves item 54 in schedule 4 of the tariff act, which relates to the textiles, clothing and footwear import credit scheme. The administrative arrangements for the scheme provide transitional arrangements whereby import credits earned under the scheme may be used up until 30 December 2001. The current wording of item 54, however, allows credits to be used only up until 30 June 2000. Item 54 is therefore being amended to reflect the administrative arrangements. A summary of the alterations contained in this proposal is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (VEGETABLE LEVY) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 21 June, on motion by Mr Truss:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment (Vegetable Levy) Bill 2000 is a minor piece of legislation that corrects an anomaly which has grown up around the vegetable levy first introduced in March 1996 at a level of half a per cent on the value at the point of sale. An anomaly grew up here because some farmers were value adding to their produce and the value at the point of sale was larger for them than other farmers. Of course, they were caught paying a higher amount of levy.

speech.para: This situation was remedied in the 1999 legislation which consolidated the levies. However, from 1996 to 1999 some growers were caught in this anomalous situation. So this piece of legislation seeks to amend that situation and to give farmers who were adversely—or you could say `inequitably'—affected in a minor way the opportunity to have that situation redressed. The opposition supports the bill advanced by the government and we hope for a speedy passage through the parliament.

I note that this anomaly involves a small number of producers. Indeed, we can identify one and perhaps some others at this point in time. We have not been able to find out who the lucky producer is whose situation is being addressed by a specific piece of legislation. It could be in the honourable member for Mallee's electorate—I am not quite sure. I understand that this producer was value adding to his cucumbers and then selling them pickled to the McDonald's chain, but was caught out by the anomaly of this situation.

talk.start.para: —Do you like gherkins?
—The honourable member for Richmond seated opposite loves McDonald's—especially hamburgers sold in caravan parks.
—Most of the time now he looks like he is sucking on a lemon.

—He could well be. I understand that the minister has sucked on the GST lemon and has found it to be a very bitter taste indeed. As the farming community finds out the adverse impacts of the GST on them, it will be an even more bitter fruit for the minister to swallow.

speech.para: I have a personal interest in this industry, and I should declare that upfront. I am the son of a Western District dairy farmer. We had a mixed farm in the Western District of Victoria where we grew onions and potatoes on those rich volcanic soils, as well as milking cows. In the area I was raised, onions, potatoes, pumpkins and peas were basically the staple diet of the farming community. Of course, in those days there were many jobs that spun off from vegetable production, but those jobs are no longer there. We have seen the same sort of structural adjustment take place in the vegetable industry as has taken place in the dairy industry, with a consequent decline in the number of producers as well as the jobs that spin off from that rural production in the value adding chain, the transport chain and elsewhere.

I think one of the unique features of this industry is its diversity. If you go to any farming community in the rich fertile soil areas, you will invariably see some vegetable production. Just scanning through the statistics you can see it is the everyday vegetables that Australians consume that are the subject of the levy that is the focus of this legislation today—vegetables such as asparagus, beans, beetroot, broccoli, cabbages, capsicums, chillies, peppers, carrots, cauliflower, celery, cucumbers, peas, lettuces, marrows, squash, zucchini—that would be a bit foreign, of course, to the minister opposite—melons, mushrooms, onions, pumpkins, potatoes, sweet corn and tomatoes. I have probably left out a few, but it is a very diverse industry. One of the interesting features of the diversity of this industry is the large number of small growers and their geographical spread throughout regional communities in Australia.

We have seen changing patterns of production and they are reflected in the production statistics for this industry. Over 50 per cent of the production in the vegetable industry comes out of Queensland and Victoria. But it is an interesting situation when you get to exports, in that Western Australia and Tasmania are the main states involved in the export of vegetables from Australia. We have seen not only the diversity in the range of products produced by the vegetable industry in rural Australia but also a changing pattern of production. We are seeing now an increased production of Asian vegetables for a very strong domestic market, which has fed off the back of the immigration program over the last decade. Given that strong domestic production base, we are now starting to see a very interesting and growing export industry in the Asian vegetables market.

You would be surprised, Mr Deputy Speaker, at the amount of vegetable production that is taking place in my own electorate, in the Geelong region. My electorate is renowned for its production of cars, textiles, petroleum and aluminium and we often overlook the contribution to the regional economy that comes from vegetable production. For example, at Batesford there is a very small but very productive valley engaged in the production of vegetables. At Lara there is burgeoning production in Asian vegetables, which is becoming a very prominent industry in that area. It is small scale, quite labour intensive and very important to the local economy. A traditionally very strong vegetable growing area of Victoria and Australia is the Bellarine Peninsula, where we have the production of potatoes, onions, broccoli and other such crops.

We have great plans and great hopes for the expansion of the vegetable industry in my electorate. Avalon airport lies at the juxtaposition of some very important transport assets in Victoria—the Princes Highway, the port of Geelong and the national standard gauge all run very close to Avalon airport. Some six or seven years ago we mounted a very strong proposal to develop this airport as a dedicated airfreight centre for the export of vegetables, as well as flowers and aquaculture products. That project never came to fruition because the government privatised Avalon at the time. While we have seen some employment gains there, we have seen nothing like the employment that would bring back the jobs to the Geelong region that were there before this government came to office. At the stroke of a pen, they got rid of ASTAAS and, with it, 450 highly skilled jobs. That was going to be the core of the development at Avalon, with a dedicated airfreight capacity being developed so that we could, downstream, link primary industry, as well as the flower and aquaculture industries, into a very significant exporting effort from that facility.

If it did become a dedicated freight facility, we would see a very significant increase in vegetable production in the Geelong region. I would certainly sound a word of caution to local government authorities to make sure that they protect the land base in the Geelong region so that, if Avalon were to realise the expectations we have for it, the capacity would be there to increase our vegetable production significantly. Sadly, that project has stalled with the privatisation of Avalon airport. That was a decision taken by this government. But I do have strong hope because we now have a state Labor government in Victoria with a very strong focus on developing regional infrastructure and the fresh food and food processing industries in Victoria. I am very hopeful that the Victorian Deputy Premier and Treasurer, John Brumby, who has a deep understanding of the requirements of regional Australia, will turn the state government's eye and energies to getting this particular project off the ground because, in Geelong, it has the potential to shift the economic base of the region, not away from cars and textiles but towards a very strong underpinning for the local economy. In that particular development the vegetable industry will play a very important role. We cannot understate the importance of the vegetable industry to rural and regional Australia. As I have said before, it is a small-scale industry that is very labour-intensive and there are very strong spin-offs for other businesses that support vegetable production, such as the chemical industry, the transport industry, marketers, et cetera.

One very important aspect of this industry is that it lends itself to value adding close to the source of production, and indeed this will be a very important focus for policy of a future Labor government. We differ from the National Party in this respect. The Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party is on the public record as saying that economic development in the rural sector is best propelled by simply adding to the quality of the bulk cargo that goes through the port. There is nothing wrong with that particular philosophy, but it should not be seen in isolation. What we really need to develop is a value adding capacity that creates jobs in rural and regional Australia. The vegetable industry offers us not only great export potential but a great capacity to value add close to the source of production and, in a very significant way, to stimulate the economic development of local communities.

If you look at the statistics on this particular industry and see the trends that are occurring, the total volume of fresh vegetable exports for the top five—onions, cauliflower, broccoli, carrots and asparagus—reached 150,000 tonnes in 1998-99, with a value of $157 million. The exports of all fresh vegetables were estimated to be in the region of 22 per cent of all Australian vegetable production in 1999. It is an industry that is export orientated and we hope to expand that.

As I read through the development plans for the food industry, all the state Labor governments focus very heavily on the vegetable industry and on value adding to vegetables to stimulate jobs and to stimulate wealth production in rural and regional areas. Malaysia, Singapore and Japan are our major markets for the outputs of this particular industry but, even so, the barriers to entry in many of these countries—and these are our trading partners—are quite high. For example, if this industry wants to export vegetables to the Philippines, it faces not only high tariff levels but also a very strict regime of import restrictions. Thailand imposes tariffs of 60 per cent on imported vegetables. Chinese Taipei has relatively high import duties on onions, carrots, cauliflowers and broccoli, ranging from 32.5 per cent to 40 per cent. These are all significant barriers to the export of vegetables from Australia. Like many other rural industries, the vegetable industry is relying for expansion on a successful effort by the Australian government to lever open market access—to give them greater market opportunities in these countries. If we could achieve a substantial lowering of tariffs in these communities, there would be flow-on effects in Australia in the improved market access we could obtain and the expanded production and job creation that would flow from that.

I notice out in the public arena that there is significant debate at the moment on trade policy, and of course we do go through this debate from time to time in the Labor Party and, I would imagine, in the coalition as well. The issue of free and fair trade is debated quite hotly within the ranks of the Labor Party, as it is in the general community, but the sorts of tariff levels that I have indicated are barriers for the export of Australian vegetable products. It would be a very tough task for Australia to argue for a significant lowering of tariff barriers in Chinese Taipei and the Philippines while at the same time arguing for an increase in other tariffs because of labour standards and environmental issues.

I am not playing down the importance of those issues—they have to be considered in all fora throughout the world to achieve greater justice for workers in these countries and greater protection for the environment—but we do have to be very careful in this debate because we have a rural industry that has great potential for export, and that potential will be realised only if we are able to achieve a significant lowering of the tariff barriers in many of our trading partners. The industry is undergoing some interesting structural changes as far as its institutional arrangements are concerned. Quite recently the Horticulture Australia council had its inaugural meeting as the national representative body for horticulture throughout Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, coming from a farming area and having a deep acquaintance with the affairs of rural Australia, you might appreciate just how difficult it is to get horticultural industries together—to get vegetable producers with citrus producers, and so on—but they have over a long period of time considered this issue and, I think quite rightly, concluded that there are some issues at the national level that are best addressed by a peak body. I congratulate all involved with the process that has brought them to the point where we will have a national peak body that will be able to articulate on behalf of the vegetable industry and other horticultural industries some of the key issues facing those and other rural industries today.

This is a very important industry in Australian agriculture, and it does disappoint me when the government presents itself as a great supporter of the vegetable industry and then puts an impost like the GST on it. Recently I came across some correspondence from the seed potato industry of Victoria. They are very concerned about the advice that they received from the Australian Taxation Office on the implementation of the GST. This particular industry is located mainly in Victoria—85 per cent of it is in Victoria—and the growers are represented by Seed Potatoes Victoria. This organisation represents 106 certified seed potato growers in that state, which is 100 per cent membership of certified seed growers. This industry produces 35,000 tonnes of certified seed annually. It has a farm gate return of $16 million, of which $1½ million is export. Production is expanding at around three to four per cent annually and the growth in exports, although it is off a low base, is around 25 per cent annually.

When Seed Potatoes Victoria went to the Australian Taxation Office to get advice on whether their product would be GST free, they got an initial indication from the Taxation Office that it would be. Of course, they notified their growers, who made their plans and structured their enterprises accordingly. Then the Australian Taxation Office started notifying individual growers that the product would be GSTable. The implications are quite devastating for the certified seed industry. It has the potential to divert demand into the uncertified seed area and to destroy this growing industry—a very important industry not only to Victoria but also to other regional communities around Australia. This highlights the administrative confusion surrounding the introduction of this tax and, if you like, the betrayal of the rural sector—I use those words guardedly, but I think it is betrayal. We have seen the betrayal on fuel and we now have potato growers and other vegetable growers, like other rural businesses, saddled with the enormous compliance costs associated with this GST—a tax that they do not want and which may not be of benefit to them in the long run. This particular measure has the potential to destroy this very specialised and growing area of vegetable production. It is a problem that we have highlighted in the media in the hope that we can lend support to the industry to get their case heard in the bowels of government. Here we have a new tax being introduced and suddenly people are waking up to the administrative confusion and the enormous cost of compliance, which is now falling on potato growers, as it is on other vegetable growers in this industry.

This particular legislation is a minor piece of legislation, but it is important to the grower or growers—there may be some others—who might be brought within the ambit of this legislation. We understand that it is a small financial outlay—very small indeed. The opposition will be supporting the speedy passage of this legislation through the parliament.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to have the opportunity—albeit that I will be fairly brief—to support the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment (Vegetable Levy) Bill 2000. I tend to disagree a little bit with the member for Corio's comments, although I welcome the opposition's support for the bill. Whilst it might be a fairly minor matter in terms of the overall big picture that the parliament generally presides over, to the five vegetable producers that I am aware of who will benefit under this scheme it is a very important piece of legislation. This legislation shows that the parliament is interested in establishing and reinforcing equity. In the current arrangements, which this bill seeks to adjust, growers who did all the things that we challenge them to do—that is, to value add to their product and then send it into the market—had the levy paid in terms of the value added price of the commodity they were producing, whereas the levy is intended to apply only to fresh vegetables, which is the lesser cost when supplied into the market as a fresh commodity.

speech.para: There has been an enormous amount of discussion with the industry. Whilst it was one grower—I understand a person who produces pickles—who raised this matter, I think it gives the community out there some confidence that the parliament is interested in restoring equity. Included in that group of what I understand to be five vegetable growers around Australia who are, at this stage, engaged in value adding, are two very large vegetable growers in the district of Wemen in my constituency. One of those growers is a producer of carrots. It is very refreshing to go to this particular property and see around 1,500 acres of carrots being grown with the help of modern computer-aided irrigation systems. Rather than just supplying fresh carrots in a range of sizes into the market, the grower has risen to the challenge and is now juicing his carrots. It is a very impressive operation. I was fortunate in January this year to take the Deputy Prime Minister to visit that particular property, and he was suitably impressed. The grower has been able to take the opportunity to export, particularly into the Asian market and, more particularly, into the Japanese market where carrot juice is a sought-after item. So I am very pleased to see the government responding in this very positive way. I congratulate the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry for bringing this legislation to the chamber.

The subject of levies is always a difficult one for horticultural growers to come to grips with. It has been a struggle for me over the years, with a constituency which is very much dependent upon the development of horticulture—it is the big economic driver, particularly in the northern regions of the Mallee associated with the Murray River and irrigation—to encourage disparate growers who are busy doing their own thing to act together, to have the confidence to reinvest in their industry in a corporate sense.

A few years ago we worked very hard to establish a levy for table grape growers who are scattered right around the nation from Western Australia, up to the Northern Territory and along the Murray River. It is a booming industry offering enormous opportunity for economic development. If you visit the districts of Wemen and Robinvale on the Victorian side of the Murray, you will see that fresh grape production is very much a part of the employment and local economy of those regions. Sadly, it was not possible to get all disparate groups around the nation together, to have the confidence to say, `Yes, we have enough confidence in our industry to recommend to the government that we have a levy.' Work on table grapes will continue. The growers in my region are very keen to have access to a fund that can be matched with government support and do all the very necessary research into the appropriate varieties, what the market is thinking, what is in the minds of consumers and also research into the elements of market development and promotion.

The vegetable industry, to which the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment (Vegetable Levy) Bill 2000 refers, is very much an infant industry and provides a great opportunity for us in Australia. In 1996, Australian vegetable production in gross value was $1.6 billion. In four years, that has grown to over $2 billion. The great opportunity is in the export sector, which is steadily growing. From 1990 to 1997, the value of horticulture in general—which includes nuts, vegetables and fresh fruit—was $680 million. That is already nudging $1 billion of export opportunity. I was a bit disappointed that the member for Corio took the opportunity to attack the government's tax reform direction because it is those very exporters whom tax reform is designed to assist. That $1 billion of horticultural exports goes onto the international market which is extremely aggressive. Like most commodities produced in primary industry, the $4 billion in toto of cascading domestic taxes on growers' backs reduce their capacity to be competitive in that international market. That is one of the very important elements of what tax reform is about. In addition, removal of 24c a litre on diesel will do very much to reduce freight costs to get those commodities to very important ports and on their way to international markets.

Many of my growers will be asking questions about how this legislation applies. I have had interest from one grower who was very worried about retrospectivity. He misunderstood that this is one piece of legislation where retrospectivity will work in his favour. No doubt he will enjoy a small but welcome refund for excess levies he has been paying over the period, which this legislation seeks to adjust. I understand that the total refund is something like $5,000. I am very pleased that the minister considers this so important that he is prepared to go to those measures. The cost of preparing the legislation and for parliament to consider the bill might be well in excess of that, but parliament is interested in equity. It is interested in ensuring that growers who make the investment, value add and sell their value added commodity into the market are not disadvantaged by those growers who are still just supplying fresh commodities. I can assure growers that the administrative burden will be no more substantial than what is currently required. My congratulations to the minister. I thank him for considering this legislation and the interests of my vegetable growing constituency. I look forward to the bill's speedy passage and invite all members to give it their wholesome support.

talk.start.para: —I will take only a few minutes of the House's time. As has been stated already, the opposition supports the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment (Vegetable Levy) Bill 2000. Like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I represent an electorate where agriculture and horticulture are very important. However, many farmers are diversifying. No doubt this will accelerate, particularly in New South Wales where we are going to see massive changes to the dairy industry. I would like to mention a branch of the agriculture industry which is growing rapidly in my area, and I know it is also growing in the Page electorate, that is, aquaculture. Aquaculture offers a great deal to farmers through diversification. I now have former dairy farmers in the Gloucester area growing silver perch, former professional fishermen growing snapper at Hawks Nest, farmers growing yabbies in the Karuah-Booral-Stroud area and a farmer growing barramundi at Bobs Farm. I would like to point out to the minister the anomalies in the tax treatment of these people. It is an anomaly which is being overlooked.

speech.para: Over recent days, I have spoken to fishermen—catchers of wild fish and fish farmers. If a professional fishermen submits live lobsters and live crabs to a market, there is no GST. There is a market for live fish and these people have developed the means for getting fish to the market live in the freshest state. These fish are not going to be on-grown; they are going to be eaten. The restaurant trade wants to say, `We have the freshest fish.' However, there is GST on those fresh fish. I am pleased the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry is in the chamber. He always responds to these things. I suggest that he takes that matter back to cabinet to see what he can do because there is a premium for the best quality. That is what Australia has built its agricultural and horticultural reputation on. These people are now being penalised because they have done that. One fellow from Tasmania said to me yesterday, `If I send my fish to the Sydney market dead, they are worth nothing. Sending them there live is the only way I can sell them. If I send them there dead, there is no GST, but if I send them there live, I am paying a GST on them.'

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank members who have contributed to this debate on the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment (Vegetable Levy) Bill 2000, although I think some of the comments have strayed a little distance away from vegetables. I would like to take up briefly the comments made by the previous speaker, the member for Paterson. I agree wholeheartedly with him that aquaculture has enormous potential in Australia. It is my view that it is potentially the next boom industry for Australia. In fact, it has the potential of wine—to grow and be one of our most significant national industries. It is not just an industry that is going to be located offshore; quite a lot of it can potentially occur inland and even indoors as technology develops. Aquaculture is an important industry and that is the reason why the government has recently announced the Aquaculture Action Agenda. Advertisements appeared in the paper last week inviting people from that industry to become involved in the committees that are going to drive this action agenda, because we want to put in place an appropriate mechanism to encourage this industry to expand and to reach its real potential.

speech.para: There were a number of comments in relation to taxation issues. I am certainly aware of the issue raised by the honourable member for Paterson. Unfortunately, when you have an arrangement—again as a result of the deal with the Democrats—that makes food GST free, difficult lines have to be drawn. I can acknowledge the anomaly that the member refers to. However, if we were to head in the other direction and make those fish GST free, then you would have the difficulty of differentiating between those fish and goldfish at the other end of the extreme or others that were going to be traded and would go into hatcheries. Difficulties arise wherever you draw the line in that regard. I think we all know about tax systems and indeed our own GST that is coming up. Nearly all of the problems we have arise as a result of exemptions. If you had no exemptions at all, the legislation would be one-tenth as thick as it is and most of the problems would disappear. I acknowledge that those sorts of issues do exist, but they are exceptionally difficult to address. I thank the honourable member for raising this issue.

I thank also the honourable member for Mallee, who has referred to the details of this legislation and acknowledged that a couple of the handful of people who are actually going to benefit from this bill come from his electorate. This bill is a pretty good example of the whole of the nation stopping to help a small number of people, probably less than five, who have been caught up in an anomaly. It does not involve very much money, but it does involve the implementation of justice in this particular issue. As the honourable member for Mallee said, it does effectively apply in arrears. In fact, it only deals with the levy between 1 March 1996 and 30 June 1999, and ensures that vegetable producers are not disadvantaged in that period.

The vegetable levy was introduced on 1 March 1996. The levy is imposed on vegetables that are either sold or used in the production of other goods. An issue arose where growers or processors and other vertically integrated operations were unfairly paying a higher assessment of levy when there was no sale or, at the time, any simple means to value the vegetables prior to processing. The bill amends the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Vegetables) Regulations to clarify the rate of levy intended to be struck on vegetables that were grown and processed by the producer between 1 March 1996 and 30 June 1999. It deals with the way in which the levy is calculated during that period. It does not apply after 1 July 1999 because the arrangements changed and the levy is now imposed under schedule 15 of the Primary Industries (Excise) Levies Act 1999 and that assessment arrangement is unaffected by the bill. There is no additional administrative burden; there are only a small number of refunds involved and the quantity of money involved will be quite small.

The legislation does correct an anomaly. I thank honourable members for their contribution to this debate and assure them and the House that the government is committed to working with the vegetable industry to ensure that it is also able to achieve its potential to grow and expand. It is a significant industry. It is a significant employer. The great thing about industries like vegetables and horticulture generally is that those jobs are in rural and regional Australia. They are jobs that contribute mightily to our national economy. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Truss) read a third time.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT AND HERITAGE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Dr Stone:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 seeks to regulate the dumping of waste at sea by limiting the quantity and toxicity of dumped material. Its main purpose is to update sea dumping practices, and to accord with the 1996 Protocol to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matters 1972, and the government's Australia's Ocean Policy.

speech.para: The sea is a huge and valuable asset to the whole people of this earth, and especially to the 17 million Australians in this land. We are one of the few nations surrounded by sea. Our enormous coastline bequeaths to us a duty and responsibility in regard to one of the largest areas of sea that comes under the jurisdiction of any nation on earth. Because of this, we have a leadership role to play in regard to our use and protection of the sea. The sea is a treasure chest. It provides an abundance of renewable food to the whole earth, a bounty of fuel and energy, recreation of great joy to millions of people, wildlife of great variety, and a medium for cheap transport and international trade. Because of this we must value and protect the sea to ensure that its benefits continue to flow as generously in the future as they have in the past.

The eastern side of my electorate of Hughes, from Bundeena to Coalcliffe, meets the foreshores of the Pacific Ocean. From the cliffs of the Royal National Park down to Stanwell Tops on the southern, windswept edge of Sydney, where Lawrence Hargraves first articulated his principles of flight, there are spectacular views of the ocean and coastline. Consequently, many who live in this picturesque part of Australia have a heightened awareness of and a close identification with the sea, if only for recreational purposes. They are acutely aware of the practical effects when the sea becomes polluted. If materials are dumped at sea, offshore from my electorate, they would directly impact the environment in a way that immediately makes people aware of the problem, and the need for effective preventive measures. They are aware not only of pollution occurring at sea but also of pollution spilling from the land.

People who use the coastline soon become aware that sea pollution not only affects the fragile, natural environment but directly affects human health as well. Most Sydneysiders, for example, are well aware that surfing in water that contains marine fuel oil, whether inadvertently spilled or deliberately dumped at sea, can be a real health hazard, particularly if it is ingested or adheres to the eyes or eyelids. Compared to marine animals, humans spend only a brief time in recreation immersed in the sea, and they consume only a fraction of their food from the sea. With this in mind, it is easy to comprehend the devastating effect that pollution has on marine animals that are totally dependent upon the marine environment.

Recreational fishermen are aware that sewage outfalls can produce a hazardous as well as a plentiful catch. The northern boundary of my electorate is bounded by the broad waters of the Georges River, which up until recently was one of the world's best oyster producing estuaries. This was an important industry that gave the region part of its early identity and history, and has suffered because of the lowering standards of estuarine water quality brought about by pollution of its waterways. It should also be remembered that Australia's marine -based industries were valued in 1994 at $30 billion. Emerging marine industries such as aquaculture, pharmaceuticals and biotechnology provide opportunities for our future. This great public asset requires healthy marine ecosystems and protection of its biodiversity. It also demands our focused attention on its protection and survival.

Australia is a nation that is a major producer of commodity exports that must be transported by sea. Clear access to commodity terminals is an economic necessity essential to Australia's future economic prosperity. Vessels must have ready and safe access to deep ports and berths, and this often means approaching and entering waterways affected by rivers and tides, and the movement of silt and sand. To keep them clear and safe requires the dredging of vast quantities of materials that must be relocated. Approximately six million tonnes of dredge spoil are dumped in Australian waters each year, the major part of which is uncontaminated. The main relocation or dumping areas are in the Sydney coastal region, the Pilbara in Western Australia and the mid to north coast of Queensland.

Until very recently, the sea was regarded as a convenient rubbish dump. Its vastness lulled people into believing that its capacity to dispose of human and industrial waste in an uncontrolled manner was inexhaustible. All this began to change in the 1960s, and in 1972 the international Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, otherwise known as the London convention, drew the world's attention to a potential environmental disaster of truly global dimensions. The challenge facing all peoples now became how to use the sea and reap its benefits, while protecting its fragile ecological balance, and respecting its capacity to forgive our indifference and neglect.

The sea has also been treated as a free resource, and regarded as a free market, by those who could access it. Unfortunately, this has ripple effects. For example, those who have dumped at sea have obtained the benefit of a free resource, the dumping site. However, the cost has been borne by other users such as fishermen, who have found their free resource depleted as a result of pollution caused by dumping. This consequent market failure will be addressed by regulating the quantity and toxicity of material dumped. The limitation of sea dumping from the land will bring it into line with existing government policies on land based waste management and waste minimisation.

There have been a number of policy developments that have led to this bill. In 1992, the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio adopted agenda 21, the blueprint for ecologically sustainable development and the targeting of issues such as waste reduction, waste management and ecological sustainability. This was followed in 1994 by the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. As I mentioned earlier, in 1996 the protocol to the London convention came into being.

In 1998, to mark the International Year of the Sea, the government released Australia's Ocean Policy. This policy statement included commitments to ratify the 1996 protocol to the London convention and implement the total ban on industrial waste dumping at sea. It included a commitment to amend legislation to place beyond doubt the regulation of artificial reef construction to protect the marine environment from pollution. It also sought to prevent hazards in the sea for navigation, commercial fishing and divers through conditions attached to permits under the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. Prior to the 1996 protocol, one of the limitations of the London convention, and in turn the Sea Dumping Act, was that they addressed what could be termed sea-borne dumping. They do not deal with material dumped from a land source or operational discharges from ships, nor do they cover the offshore processing of seabed mineral resources.

The 1996 protocol is intended to replace the convention's list of banned substances with a very restricted list of substances that may be dumped at sea with a permit. This eliminates the long list of possible substances that could be dumped by default, because they were not identified as excluded substances. This is a strong precautionary measure that this bill will provide. Substances that may be dumped under the 1996 protocol are dredged material; sewage sludge; fish waste, or material resulting from industrial fish processing operations; vessels and platforms or other man-made structures at sea; inert inorganic geological material; organic material of natural origin; and bulky items primarily comprising iron, steel, concrete and similarly unharmful materials, if generated at locations such as small islands with isolated communities having no practicable access to disposal options other than dumping.

These items may be dumped at sea but only after issue of a permit. Before this can be done, they must be subject to a thorough waste assessment. The 1996 protocol also provides for the polluter pays principle, and this could be incorporated by using a sliding scale of fees based on contamination levels in sediments, quantities, and the sensitivity of the dump site. Applicants for permits will have to undertake a waste audit and formulate alternative waste management strategies. In some cases this could lead to better solutions than sea dumping. Port authorities may find it more economically viable to treat and sell some of their dredged sediments as landfill. The decision to grant a permit under the sea dumping act can trigger the application of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. This is a valuable safeguard and check on the use of permits.

A second objective of this bill is to amend the Sea Installations Act 1987 to remove the prohibitions on issuing, and varying, a permit that would authorise a sea installation to be located partly within and partly outside an area of Commonwealth waters adjacent to state coastal waters. I remind the House that Commonwealth waters commence three nautical miles out from the shoreline and extend out to the outermost limits of Australian waters. The waters within the three nautical mile boundary are state coastal waters. A sea installation is defined as any man-made structure that when in, or brought into, physical contact with the seabed, or when floating, can be used for an environment related activity. However, it generally does not include fishing installations, some exploration installations, such as pipelines used by the petroleum industry, defence installations and some cable installations.

This bill will have a practical application to the proposed Basslink Interconnector cable that will link Tasmania to the national electricity market by means of a submarine electricity cable across Bass Strait. At present, the Sea Installations Act prohibits the issuing of a permit that would authorise a sea installation such as the Basslink Interconnector to be located partly within and partly outside Commonwealth waters. If passed, this bill will allow a permit to be issued, which in turn will trigger the Environment Protection Act and the Commonwealth's involvement in the environmental impact assessment of the proposed cable link. As our national anthem reminds us, `our land is girt by sea'. I support this bill as it will help to ensure good environmental practice in regard to dumping at sea and the installation of man-made structures across the seabed. It will thereby help to hand on to future generations a huge, sustainable resource and a national treasure chest—our healthy oceans. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —As the previous speaker, the member for Hughes, has outlined, the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 proposes amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. They aim to implement the Protocol to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter 1972, known as the London convention, and will ensure that commitments set out in the government's Australian Oceans Policy are fulfilled. As the Bills Digest advises us:

quote.para: Australia's implementation of the 1996 Protocol to the London Convention is a positive development, as are the proposed amendments increasing the penalties for contraventions of the Sea Dumping Act. Changes such as the curtailing of the Defence Forces exemption are not likely to unduly burden the Defence Department, as the Defence Forces have voluntarily complied with the Sea Dumping Act.(39) The inclusion of Australia's exclusive economic zone around Antarctica is also a positive development. However, the possibility of sea dumping permits being granted for that area, may, for some, be a matter of concern. Under proposed section 19(8A), permits could only be granted in relation to the Antarctic area if dumping was consistent with Australia's international obligations under various Antarctic treaties. For example, dumping may not be consistent with Australia's obligations under the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty of 1 December 1959, which addresses, amongst other things, disposal of waste at sea ...

speech.para: For the majority of my contribution to this debate I want to talk about waste from fishing vessels and the impact that this waste potentially has on the environment. I want to refer particularly to an area in the Gulf of Carpentaria in north-east Arnhem Land and the role being played by an indigenous organisation in a proposed indigenous protected area at Nanydjaka, or Cape Arnhem. This is important, Mr Deputy Speaker, because, as I will retail to you, this organisation is monitoring the impact on the turtle population principally in that region of waste material primarily from fishing vessels. The organisation is doing this because of its interest in the area becoming an indigenous protected area. It is one of three indigenous protected area, or IPA, proposals in the Northern Territory under active consideration by the government. The Cape Arnhem project is being put forward by the Yolngu, or indigenous land owners, of north-east Arnhem land.

Nanydjaka is a coastal area of thousands of hectares that comprises spectacular coastal scenery, a very rich biodiversity of land and marine species and a living cultural tradition that is exemplified in a large number of sacred sites complexes and also a rich oral tradition. Nanydjaka is also of significance to many of the Balanda, or non-indigenous people, in the region because, even given the limits imposed by sacred sites protection requirements, it is a significant recreational area. Reconciling recreational needs with protecting the cultural and environmental significance of the area is a major preoccupation of the landowners' own land management agency—the Dhimurru Land Management Agency—and they have had some success in achieving this with limited resources. Dhimurru has also been active in monitoring the impact of offshore fishing activity on local wildlife, particularly marine turtles, as I said earlier.

I have been asked by Dhimurru's senior ranger, Nanikiya Mununggiritj, to place on record the Yolngu landowners' appreciation of the support and cooperation they have had from the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Robert Hill. I am informed that in several meetings and workshops, including the most recent in the remote northern part of South Australia, Senator Hill has accorded prime consideration to the wishes of landowners in determining the future regime of this highly significant area, and that is an important recognition.

In recent weeks, I visited the Dhimurru Land Management Corporation and the area which it looks after. We flew in a helicopter along the coast of Cape Arnhem, and what we saw was not that pleasant. We saw a large amount of waste material from commercial fishing vessels, which operate primarily in the Gulf of Carpentaria, and we saw large numbers of nets washed up on the beaches. As I said, the Dhimurru Land Management Corporation sees as one of its responsibilities monitoring the impact of these activities on the turtle population. People from Dhimurru fly at a very low level in their helicopter, and they locate these nets which are scattered up and down the beaches and come in with the incoming tides. Often they will see entangled in the nets turtles and other marine life. This issue is very important to the Yolngu people, and indeed it is very important to the Australian community generally. It shows that we have yet to come to terms with our responsibilities in managing this part of Australia's coastline.

In terms of the ability to do the necessary monitoring of the impact on the local environment of these sorts of activities, not only of offshore fishing but also of recreational activities on the land, there are a number of matters which need to be talked about, particularly as the creation of an indigenous protected area, as is being proposed, relies on the cooperation of different levels of government. It is very clear that the community that are involved, the Yolngu people, believe that they have had that cooperation from Senator Hill.

The government says that it is committed to supporting IPAs, indigenous protected areas, through the Natural Heritage Trust as part of a comprehensive, adequate and representative national reserve system. Precise funding details are hard to find, but it is clear that the IPA program suffers from having very little established funding and no commitment to continuing funding for recurrent management costs after the end of 2002. This risks compromising the other aim of the IPAs: encouraging cooperative action between the community and the different levels of government. The really big question is: what happens to IPAs after the Natural Heritage Trust funding runs out in June 2002? Where is the money to come from? It certainly will not come from the sale of Telstra. No commitment to funding means that organisations like Dhimurru have to stagger along as best they can on their own resources and project grant funding. The landowners themselves have provided a substantial proportion of Dhimurru's funding since it was established in 1992. Further financial support has also come through the corporate sector in the form of contributions from the local mining company, Nabalco, and it is important that we acknowledge that contribution. Dhimurru is also developing income generating opportunities, but these funding sources do not meet recurrent operating costs. The IPA program is an important opportunity to bridge the gap.

Uncertainty over continuing funding also means that organisations may need all levels of government to act with a degree of altruism, which is often difficult to find. Dhimurru has had, by and large, a good working relationship with the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission that was originally premised on a cooperative approach. This relationship, involving regional environmental monitoring and other collaborative conservation activities, has apparently fallen foul of the current Northern Territory government's political agenda. In the course of negotiations on the IPA, Dhimurru has invited the Northern Territory government to re-establish a ranger presence in north-east Arnhem Land. This collaborative management support has been requested by the landowners, through Dhimurru, in recognition of the assistance that the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission can provide in areas such as environmental monitoring and rehabilitation, visitor management and cultural recording and protection. In fact, the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission master plan notes an institutional commitment to investigating new and innovative management arrangements with indigenous landowners beyond the context of the old formal joint management model.

But there appears to be limited commitment to this concept in the Northern Territory government's negotiations on the Dhimurru IPA. The Northern Territory government made a cabinet decision to withdraw ranger support in 1998, and it will not reinstate that support unless, as part of the IPA negotiations, Dhimurru and its landowner constituents agree to a joint management arrangement. The Northern Territory minister responsible, the Northern Territory Deputy Chief Minister, will not budge on this and says that anything less is unsatisfactory. This has not been part of Dhimurru's agenda. Dhimurru has successfully managed Nanydjaka's impressive array of cultural and natural resources in the past without the Northern Territory's involvement, and it has not asked the Northern Territory for any direct financial support.

This is not an issue of Dhimurru versus the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission. What is being asked of the commission is to go against its own master plan and insist on one way, only, of acting cooperatively with Dhimurru. The real issue is that without ranger support the entire population of the region—which includes about 5,000 `Balanda' or non-indigenous Australians—have no access to the Parks and Wildlife Commission for its normal statutory enforcement and monitoring activities, for example, crocodile patrols and the like. The Northern Territory government is holding the entire population to ransom because it cannot get Dhimurru to roll over and accept total direction, reduced control and a figurehead role on a management board. The Northern Territory government approach is not in the spirit of the development of IPAs as envisaged by Labor when it introduced them. The Northern Territory government might hide behind its `territory rights' argument, but this is a matter of the National Estate and the desire of the Yolngu landowners of Nanydjaka to share their precious resource with the nation.

We should not underestimate how important this issue is. Whilst we will hear stories of dumping material in the seaways that are frequented by large numbers of commercial shipping, we do not hear a lot of what happens in regional parts of Australia where there are not high intensity or highly visible commercial fleets. What is clear, in the case of north-east Arnhem Land and indeed, I believe, in the Gulf of Carpentaria, is that there is a great deal more to be done in terms of learning about the environment and the impact that waste material that has come from fishing fleets within the region has on that environment. Having witnessed the work which is being done by Dhimurru in relation to monitoring sea turtle populations and the impact that waste material from fishing fleets has had and is having on those populations, in my view it is extremely important that we do something to address the concerns which have been raised by the Dhimurru Land Management Corporation and in particular their concerns about the lack of progress in the development of an indigenous protected area agreement because of the intransigence of the Northern Territory government. I think this is an important piece of legislation but, as I have pointed out, we should not be misled into believing that this legislation alone will deal with many of the significant issues that are involved in waste material from offshore vessels in international waters and the impact the waste material has on our immediate environment.

talk.start.para: —This Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 contains amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 and the Sea Installations Act 1987. It will provide for significant penalties for the dumping at sea of harmful material which would do damage to a sensitive environment. Representing as I do the glorious north including Mackay and the Whitsundays, where the tourist industry on both island and mainland resorts relies on the clean, clear ocean and the Great Barrier Reef, I have a great interest in ensuring that unique and precious environment is protected. The commitment of the government and the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator the Hon. Robert Hill, to the protection of our marine environment is evident from the measures proposed in this bill. Under these amendments, a person convicted of dumping seriously harmful material, including radioactive material, will face penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine of up to $210,000. Lesser offences will attract penalties of up to two years imprisonment and a fine of up to $55,000 or imprisonment for one year with a fine of up to $27,500.

speech.para: The flexibility of the proposed legislation is underscored by the fact that the minister will be given a greater discretion to recommend the prescription of material as `seriously harmful material'. This will allow the minister to be satisfied that such a material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment, even if there is no conclusive evidence of a causal relationship between the dumping of the material and harm to the marine environment. Clearly, this will allow an immediate response in the event of a perceived risk and will not allow potential polluters to resort to the strategem of pseudoscientific studies and other deliberate delaying tactics. Minister Hill's commitment to protection of the marine environment, which this bill reflects, has been previously demonstrated in regard to an issue which arose in my electorate, the proposed aquaculture development at Armstrong Beach near Mackay, in the Sarina shire. I believe it is important that the history of this saga, and the minister's careful and thoughtful response to a clearly perceived need, be documented. It was an example of how concerned the minister and the government are that sensible environmental measures be put in place. It also illustrates how important it is to the minister and the government that potentially affected local communities are allowed to participate in the process of determining the progress of developments.

May I give a little history? In 1998, a Taiwanese developer, Goldiland Pty Ltd, proposed a large-scale prawn farming project at Armstrong Beach. The local community was concerned about the likely loss of amenity and the risk of pollution to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. A licence for the project was granted by the Beattie ALP state government on the basis of a report prepared by a consultant to the developer, Kuruma Australia Pty Ltd, a company now known as Pacific Aquaculture and Environment Pty Ltd. In a letter to me dated 14 January 1999, the state Minister for Environment and Heritage and Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Rod Welford, blandly informed me:

quote.para: Any inconsistencies found in the report were resolved prior to granting of the licence.

speech.para: If only that had been so. The state Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Henry Palaszczuk, advised me by a letter dated 24 December 1998 that the proposed project had been through what he called `a formal application process', which had resulted in land use approval from the relevant shire council, environmental authority from the Department of the Environment and Heritage, in-principle approval for a permit to remove, destroy or damage marine plants, and an in-principle approval for an aquaculture licence from the Department of Primary Industries. Quite clearly, the two Queensland ALP ministers simply signed off on the project, regardless of the views of the local people concerned. In fact, Mr Welford advised me in a letter dated 5 January 1999:

quote.para: The land is owned by Sarina Shire Council such that use of aquaculture is `as of right', thus no environmental impact statement was required under the Local Government (Planning and Environment) Act 1990, which was in force at the time of the application. There is no formal requirement in this circumstances for public consultation by the proponent.

speech.para: Understandably, the local community at Armstrong Beach and Freshwater Point were not impressed by this casual dismissal of their very real concerns. In a letter to the Sarina Shire Council, the secretary of the local progress association, Mr Graham Jones, made the point:

quote.para: Once again, the community has been denied a fully open, transparent process. We are of the opinion this will not change. Our community is unreservedly and fully committed to stopping the proposed aquaculture project.

speech.para: Mr Jones said the progress association rejected the public consultation process and the environmental impact statement. He continued:

quote.para: Accordingly, we continue to strongly endorse Federal Government initiatives, espousing the highest legal, moral and political means effecting implementation and enforcement of legislation to protect our immediate environment and those of national significance.

speech.para: The developer and its environmental consultant tried to head off local concerns—most forcefully shown at a well-attended rally of irate local people—and put a copy of the environmental impact statement on public view. This was followed by the hardly surprising statement by the consultant that only four submissions had been made. An Armstrong Beach resident, Mr Wally Keating, in a letter to the Daily Mercury in Mackay, expressed the reasons for this seemingly inexplicable lack of local interest. He wrote:

quote.para: Members of the public should know that the copy of the impact statement was placed at the Sarina Shire Council's chambers with viewing limited to the hours between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday to Friday. No member of the public was allowed to take the one copy available home overnight nor was photocopying allowed. Viewing restrictions severely restricted public access to the relevant data.

speech.para: In fact, as this letter demonstrates, this public consultation process was little more than a charade. On 23 June 1999 I wrote to Armstrong Beach residents, reporting to them on the outcome of my efforts on their behalf. In that letter I said:

quote.para: As you will see from the attached correspondence to and from the State Minister for Environment and Primary Industry, the Beattie Government has signed off completely on this project and regrettably left the people of Armstrong Beach without any recourse to the State Government. I must reiterate that the regulation of such developments is a State Government responsibility and it is regrettable the Beattie Government has shirked this responsibility.

speech.para: I continued in that letter:

quote.para: You have requested action through section 66-2(E) of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority Act. I have on several occasions through Senator Hill's office and the Authority asked for an opinion on the applicability of this section to the unfolding events at Armstrong Beach and have been advised that it does not apply in these circumstances.

speech.para: I undertook also in that letter to keep pursuing the matter, and Senator Hill showed a most sympathetic understanding of local concerns. After a great deal of work involving many meetings with Senator Hill's office, a consideration of the circumstances at Armstong Beach and a wider consideration of what might be termed `industry issues', Minister Hill announced on 22 February this year new aquaculture regulations made under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975. It is significant that when making this announcement Minister Hill said:

quote.para: The need for a Commonwealth safety net has been highlighted by the Armstrong Beach aquaculture proposal near Mackay. In that case, although the waste would have flowed into the marine park, the Queensland Government approved the project without a proper environmental assessment.

speech.para: His statement continued:

quote.para: The new regulations under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act will close a loophole in the Queensland legislation. This has allowed some environmentally significant aquaculture developments adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef to avoid requirements for a full and transparent environmental assessment.

speech.para: Under these regulations, warmly received by the local community at Armstrong Beach, a rigorous and transparent environmental assessment will be required before any permit decision is made. A permit from the marine park authority will not be required for existing aquaculture operations, nor will the regulations apply to any other industry. The claims by the Premier Mr Beattie that sugarcane growing and other agricultural operations would be affected by these regulations was, as usual, simple scaremongering. In fact, the regulations will allow for the development of responsible aquaculture projects while protecting the Great Barrier Reef. The gaping deficiencies in the Queensland legislation provided no assurance that a credible public environmental impact assessment would be conducted before permit decisions were made. There was no assurance that the potential impacts on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park would be assessed, even if any assessment of a project was made. There was no assurance that appropriate conditions would be met and then monitored and enforced effectively.

Until Minister Hill and the federal government took their decisive action, alerted by the Armstrong Beach community, there was a very real potential, because of sloppy and inadequate Queensland legislation, of significant and widespread damage to the marine environment of the Great Barrier Reef. It is quite extraordinary that the Labor Party makes such a song and dance about protecting the environment and respecting the legitimate wishes of concerned communities when the people of Armstrong Beach were treated in such a dismissive, shoddy and disgraceful way. The Queensland Labor Party government should hang its head in abject shame over this appalling episode. On behalf of the residents of Armstrong Beach I express my thanks to Minister Hill and his staff for their continued concern over this matter. Even the Australian Prawn Farmers Association has recognised that the Queensland legislation was deficient. In a statement the association said:

quote.para: It is clear that there is a flaw in the existing approvals process, in particular in those shires along the Queensland coastline where large scale aquaculture developments are an as of right activity, such as the Armstrong Beach aquaculture proposal. In this particular instance, the community proponent and the industry generally have been let down by the laws of the land.

speech.para: `Hear, hear!' to that. It is important that the scope and the impact of those regulations be understood. Now the Armstrong Beach proposal and projects like it will be subjected to a public assessment process. The regulations have been drafted to provide protection for the Great Barrier Reef without causing undue impact on the expanding aquaculture industry. We are very supportive of the aquaculture industry, which supplies local jobs and certainly helps to supplement and protect the wild stocks of prawns. The regulations in place will only apply to discharges of aquaculture waste that could potentially pollute the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in a manner that is harmful to the animals and plants of the park. In relation to these discharges, the regulations will require a permit to be obtained from the marine park authority if the Queensland legislation has failed to adequately protect the reef. As I have said before, existing operators will not require a permit. Instead, the Queensland government is proposing a review of all existing licences for aquaculture facilities with amendment to existing licences where necessary.

Although somewhat belated and half-hearted, this review is welcomed in the clear recognition that nothing would have been done by the Queensland Labor government if the Commonwealth had not acted in the positive way that it did. The regulations will also provide for a formal transparent process for accrediting Queensland legislation when it is upgraded to overcome the obvious existing deficiencies.

In terms of future aquaculture projects and significant expansions of existing facilities, a permit is required from the marine park authority only if the state permit has not been obtained under an accredited regime. This is not a matter of the federal government overriding or overarching the responsibilities of the states. Constitutionally, the management of the park and of land based activities belongs to Queensland. However, in instances where the state government have plainly shirked their responsibilities to the marine park, the tourism industry and obviously local communities, it is appropriate that the federal government direct any future regulations until the state can step in and assume their responsibilities once more. Some of the misunderstandings that have arisen over the regulations also need to be clarified. They do not apply to any industry other than aquaculture. They do not impose an application fee of $64,000, as has been said by the Premier; they do not extend the marine park inland by 40 kilometres, which in itself would be quite extraordinary; and they do recognise that discharges of aquaculture waste into creeks or rivers up to five kilometres from the coast may pollute the marine park. There is a recognition that most existing aquaculture operators are responsible. Only last year in my area of Mackay one of the aquaculture operators received a national environment award for a sensitive and commonsense approach to the environment in that area.

In closing, what began as a small local protest against the approvals handed out by an uncaring and disinterested state Labor government has resulted in a significant new protection for our Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I again thank the minister, Senator Hill, and in doing so I also place on the record the tremendous privilege I feel in being the member of parliament that represents the Armstrong Beach community. They worked very hard as a small, isolated community to bring about what really was a tremendous change in both federal and state approaches to consultation with local communities and also to sensitive protection of the marine park. I also want to note the assistance given to us by the Mackay Conservation Group and Mr Ian Sutton, and most particularly the Armstrong Beach Progress Association, a group of local citizens that found themselves faced with a foreign developer, a state government that had simply signed off on a project and signed off on the local community. They took their battle to the highest levels of the land and succeeded. I wish them well and look forward to working with the Armstrong Beach community again.
Debate (on motion by Mr Albanese) adjourned.
