talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr BROUGH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be disagreed to.

speech.para: The Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Legislation Amendment (Miscellaneous Matters) Bill 2000 is a positive measure introduced by the Howard government to help with portability of some social security and veterans affairs matters. I call on the opposition to withdraw these amendments so that this portability can actually move forward. I remind honourable members that the simplification of the portability provisions will benefit around 90,000 Australians. Many benefits that are not portable or that have very limited portability at present will become portable for 26 weeks, simply meaning that an individual who has these benefits in hand can leave the country for that period of time without losing the assistance. Ancillary benefits such as rent assistance and pharmaceutical allowance will become portable for the very first time. I know from practical experience in my electorate office that this is a very important issue, particularly for some of the elderly in our electorates. Simplification will reduce red tape and improve service delivery. However, simplification can benefit customers only if the new rules are consistent. As it currently stands we have some which are 52 weeks and some which are 13 weeks. This collapses all these benefits into 26 weeks so that the uniformity is clearly understood by those who, for whatever reason, find themselves leaving the country.

The new standard of 26-week portability is far longer than the majority of customers need. The median overseas absence of social security customers is in fact only around 14 weeks. The community would rightly question a policy that allows beneficiaries not being paid in respect of the permanent contingencies of life to remain overseas for an extended period of time. The proposed changes to the bill do undermine the purpose of simplification. This purpose was acknowledged as commendable. For that reason the government rejects the opposition's amendments as put.

talk.start.para: —It is a shame the government has not had a closer look at Labor's amendments to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Legislation Amendment (Miscellaneous Matters) Bill 2000. If this bill is held up it will be because the government is unwilling to protect the entitlements of age pensioners, widows and people with disabilities. These are the people who will have reduced portability as a result of the changes the government is seeking to make and they are the reason Labor has moved these amendments. Many of the people affected by these mean-spirited changes to the legislation spend all their working lives contributing to Australia's economic growth. The majority of age pensioners affected are migrants who have worked hard for decades and have embraced Australia as their home. It will be a grave injustice if these people are prevented from being able to enjoy their retirement by spending extended periods of time in their country of birth.

speech.para: Labor support those measures in this bill that will see people gain additional entitlements to allowances. We are keen to see these new entitlements delivered, but we do not want to see that paid off by reductions elsewhere. Labor's amendments have been carefully constructed not to upset the beneficial measures in this bill relating to portability. We have not breached the process of simplification being undertaken by the government in relation to portability. The government are locating portability rules centrally to assist decision making. Our amendments do not change this process. The government are not moving to a system where every recipient will have identical entitlements. There remain different conditions for different classes of recipient.

Within that framework, Labor have sought to amend the bill to protect existing conditions where they are to be diminished. Welfare Rights made a submission to the Senate committee, which I commend to the House. Their submission indicated that there are even likely to be savings to the government in some cases where existing portability is retained. This is because some social security recipients will ultimately draw their pensions from other countries whereas if they were asked to remain in Australia through stricter portability rules they would be drawing payments from here and, therefore, at a cost to the Australian taxpayer.

I would hope that on financial grounds or any other grounds, the government's intentions are not far from Labor's when it comes to portability. We are not talking about a great number of people. Many of the people we are trying to protect are receiving pensions that will cease to exist in a matter of a few years. We should also be realistic about the fact that not many pensioners have the financial wherewithal to travel overseas. For these reasons, generous portability arrangements are a small entitlement. But that does not diminish the importance of having a flexible mechanism that allows people with sick or dying relatives or with a chronic illness themselves the flexibility to travel overseas for extended periods. There seems little point in the government not agreeing to meet us halfway on this issue. Our amendments are not designed to frustrate the government or delay this bill. Our intention is to ensure that, in an otherwise positive bill, some individuals are not hurt in the process.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr BROUGH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —I will just clarify the situation with regard to three positions that the opposition have put. The first position was that the simplification of portability is a savings measure. This is not correct. Portability simplification is fiscally neutral. The savings from the international payment measure flow from the extension of the requirements to claim a comparable foreign payment to non-agreement countries.

speech.para: The second position was that shortening the portability period for DSP will mean customers seeking medical treatment overseas will be cut off after 26 weeks. Once again, this is not correct. Before going overseas, a DSP recipient undergoes a medical examination and is assessed as either severely disabled or non-severely disabled. People who seek medical treatment overseas of a kind not available in Australia would likely be assessed as severely disabled and thus eligible for indefinite portability; or, if a DSP customer fell seriously ill whilst overseas, they would very likely be eligible for an extension to the portability period.

The third position put by the opposition was that the shortening of the non-proportional period from 12 months to 26 weeks would `work as a disincentive to people wanting to resettle in their country of origin'. Once again, this is not correct. Under Australian social security agreements with the major migrant source countries, the portable rate for permanent absences starts immediately. This has not had any effect on the number of people wanting to settle in agreement countries. The availability of ancillary payments for the first 26 weeks will assist many migrants while they are making up their mind whether to resettle in their country of origin.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT AND HERITAGE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —The Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 implements the 1996 Protocol to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Waste and Other Matter 1972, the protocol to the so-called London convention. The legislation also increases penalties for illegal sea dumping. I would like to congratulate the government because this bill represents a shift away from treating our oceans like rubbish tips, something that we have done for our 200 years of European settlement of this continent. Short-sightedness is an easy option for the global community and has been an easy option for years—that is, to pollute our oceans. There has been an attitude of out of sight, out of mind. Wherever an Australian government makes progress on protecting the environment, it should be applauded. I take this opportunity to applaud the government for this legislation.

speech.para: More broadly, it has been the disposition of the Australian people over the years to, in effect, trade an environmental debt for an economic debt. I believe it is important that we consider the trade-offs here. Too often decisions have been made which have said, `Look, we need to ensure that the national economic debt does not rise' and in the process decisions have been made that effectively degrade the environment with attendant clean-up costs being deferred to future generations. That is no more nor less than simply substituting an environmental debt for an economic debt with the long-term attendant economic consequences; it is simply putting off the economic cost of the environmental decisions. It is not as if our economic debt is small—it is already in excess of $240,000 million. I just say in passing that from next Saturday, 1 July, the cost of running the Prime Minister's debt truck will rise as the Prime Minister breaks his promise that petrol prices will not rise under the GST.

One of the reasons decision makers over the last 200 years in this continent have been able to effectively substitute an environmental debt for an economic debt is that an economic debt is easy to quantify in dollars and cents and is done regularly by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. An environmental debt is far more difficult to quantify and may not even be apparent initially. So short-sighted decisions can and have been made in the past on this basis.

There have been some encouraging signs over the last 15 years that the environment is moving from the periphery to the mainstream of public debate. That is a good thing, and I think most Australians would agree. If we go back to the mid-1980s, specifically 1986 and 1987, a number of key decisions were made that I believe marked the watershed in Australian thinking and attitudes toward the environment. In my state of Queensland the Wet Tropics, a world heritage area, was listed. This followed an authorisation by the then premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, of a road being constructed through the Daintree rainforest. It caused a public outcry and, in an unintended way, from the point of view of the decision makers, led to a strong community impetus to the protection of not only that section of that rainforest but also the entire Wet Tropics world heritage area. Under the previous Labor government led by Prime Minister Bob Hawke, the Wet Tropics was listed on the world heritage list.

The next major decision that was made pretty much at the same time was the addition of stage 2 of Kakadu National Park to the world heritage list. Another decision also in that same period of 1986-87 was the conducting of an inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern forests of Tasmania, which ultimately led to the world heritage listing of a very large additional portion of those forests.

Finally in that period, in terms of the big decisions, there were proposals to mine Shelburne Bay, again in my state of Queensland, for silica—that is, essentially for making glass. A lot of angst was felt by the government of the day and they told the Japanese proponents of the Shelburne Bay mining proposal that it would not go ahead. It was a fairly courageous decision, because at that time the dollar was fairly weak and this was seen as perhaps sending the wrong signal to international markets about Australia's commitment to ongoing economic development. The Hawke government displayed courage in making the judgment in that it is important in that case not to trade an environmental debt for a potential economic debt.

Shortly thereafter, there was global controversy over whether countries or members of the international Antarctic convention—the international Antarctic community, if you like—should sign a minerals convention which would have allowed, under some fairly strict guidelines, the mining of minerals in Antarctica. Again the decision was made under the leadership of Prime Minister Bob Hawke, to be one out on this, although very powerful countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom were strong advocates for signing the convention. He was advised by the then Department of Foreign Affairs that it would be very poor diplomacy to buck the system and disagree with the United States and the United Kingdom and European countries on this matter. He nevertheless did so and, with the support of Jacques Cousteau, set about convincing the French that it would be a smart thing on their part not to sign the minerals convention. One thing led to another, because he did convince the French that it would not be a good thing to sign the minerals convention and slowly but surely the momentum gathered and other countries were convinced that it would not be sensible or wise for the long-term future of our planet to sign the convention.

As a result, ultimately in a meeting with then Senator Al Gore in the United States, in which I had the privilege of participating, then Prime Minister Hawke convinced Senator Gore that the American position was wrong. Senator Gore to his credit took that forward through the processes in the United States Congress and ultimately the United States changed its position and agreed with Australia, as did the United Kingdom, and the convention was not signed. As a result the fragile environment of the Antarctic has been protected, at least for many years, from the risk of mining.

I say all that, because it was a period when courage was required on the part of Australian policy makers and then Prime Minister Bob Hawke, his cabinet and the entire federal parliamentary Labor Party displayed that sort of courage.

talk.start.para: —A good Prime Minister.

—He was a good Prime Minister. In 1989 there was a further development on the environment and that was the release of a major report and a set of policy commitments, Our Country Our Future, again by Prime Minister Bob Hawke. The then primary industries minister, John Kerin, labelled it WGES—the world's greatest environment statement. I remember Bob Hawke saying, `Now, listen, we don't want to talk up expectations on this,' and then John called it the world's greatest environment statement, so expectations were raised. But a lot of those expectations were met when that report was released. It received very favourable community support.

speech.para: The centrepiece of Our Country Our Future was a decade of land care. This commitment to a decade of land care marked a shift in public policy making and thinking from individual land use issues such as Tasmanian forests, Kakadu, Shelburne Bay and the Wet Tropics of North Queensland to a broader philosophical commitment to the environment—that is, we need to do things using a holistic approach instead of exclusively concentrating on individual land use issues. It was a very exciting period and I was very happy to have been part of that as the Prime Minister's economic and environmental adviser at the time.

The next phase in the development of public policy thinking was the ecologically sustainable development process, the ESD process. In December 1989 a meeting was organised involving the Prime Minister. It was attended by the following people, many of whom have become very familiar names: Lauchlan McIntosh, who was the head of the Australian Mining Industry Council; Rob Bain, head of the National Association of Forest Industries; Phillip Toyne, Executive Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation; Judy Lambert, the Director of the Wilderness Society; and Simon Crean, the head of the ACTU at the time. This small meeting involving Prime Minister Hawke and relevant ministers initiated what came to be known as the national ESD process, a roundtable process. The table became very large and very round because I think there were 70 to 90 participants towards the end of that process producing various ESD reports.

The purpose of the process was to change the way policy makers and community leaders think about the environment. Some people were somewhat dismayed that it did not come up with a whole lot of policy recommendations that could be implemented immediately. But the point of the exercise was to get people from usually opposing sides of an argument, traditional rivals and antagonists, around the table so that they could better understand each other's perspective and perhaps engender into all relevant public policy making a concern about the environment and an understanding about the impact of public policy decisions on the environment. It is a fact that many forest disputes were subsequently settled under the ESD principles that came about as a result of this lengthy ESD process. In Queensland, for example, just recently the Beattie government brokered a deal on the future of native forests that has been warmly and strongly supported by the industry, by the conservation movement and by the relevant union, the Australian Workers Union.

talk.start.para: —A very good union.
—A very good union. The honourable member for Bowman is a very close and strong supporter of that union, as I am.

speech.para: So we have seen the incorporation of the ESD principles into practical policy making. There are still ongoing forestry debates in other parts of Australia, and I will say something more about that shortly, but I believe that we are moving forward on the whole forest issue. It has been helped in a significant way by the adoption of principles of ecologically sustainable development.

I believe now the time has come to renew the philosophical commitment of public policy makers to the environment. I say that in a bipartisan way because it is not inevitable in my view that the environment must be a partisan issue. It has the potential to be an issue on which we can all agree. I would like to see the further development of thinking on the environment proceed along those lines. There are plenty of things to divide the parliamentary Labor Party from the coalition parties—we do not have to go around looking for them; we naturally divide on a whole range of issues, whether they be industrial relations issues, taxation issues, commitment to public hospitals and so on—but it does not necessarily mean that we have to have a different approach to the environment. I call on the coalition and our own party to see if we cannot strive for some sort of bipartisan approach to tackling future environmental problems.

I believe that one of the highest priorities emerging from any renewed commitment of that kind should be the rehabilitation of the Murray-Darling basin. It is ironic that the launch of the document that I referred to earlier—Our Country Our Future—was on one of the tributaries in the Murray-Darling basin. Many people will remember the graphic pictures of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke with his arm around then environment minister Graham Richardson, with the shadowy, scary figures of all the dead trees. They had been killed by waterlogging. That was a result of human impact on the Murray-Darling basin. Over the 10 or 11 years since the launch of that document, I believe we have gone backwards in relation to the Murray-Darling basin. It has not got healthier; in fact, it has got sicker. The ultimate cost that our negligence of the Murray-Darling basin will impose on the Australian community could be very large indeed. Already those costs are being visited upon us through waterlogging, salinity and the deteriorating quality of the water that comes out at the other end, particularly for South Australians who have to drink it, as a result of all the intrusions along the way.

I also believe that the cotton industry is a major thirsty new user of the river system and it is contributing to the degradation of that river system. I point out that of course that would be upsetting for the conservationists but it is also very upsetting for the downstream users. I went back to my home town of Baradine over the Easter break and met a friend of mine named Kimmy Myers for the first time in 27 years. Kimmy Myers is no conservationist but he is very upset with the cotton industry. We used to go to the Barwon River and catch yellow-belly. Well, it is very hard to catch yellow-belly in the Murray-Darling system nowadays. The reasons are the introduction of European carp, which is a problem in many of our waterways, but also—Kimmy complained about this—the cotton industry. It uses up so much water and the water quality is such that the poor old yellow-belly cannot survive. They are very few and far between. They are a natural species and delicious to eat and great for kids to catch but that is an opportunity that seems to have passed us by, and a very human and simple manifestation of the sorts of problems that we are creating for the Murray-Darling basin. It seems to me that this basin is dying and we need to do a lot more in terms of policy involvement in that area.

Having said that, I consider that environmental progress is being made on a number of fronts. I will use some examples. Australia has more than 10 world heritage sites. In fact, I have lost count in the last couple of years as another couple have been added. That puts Australia in front in terms of international efforts to protect the environment. I think we have more world heritage sites than any other country. Even though they are not all looked after to the extent that we would like, our management of world heritage sites is better than in a lot of countries. We now have a greater commitment to land care. That is a pervasive issue. It is terrific to see that more farmers now are much more conscious of the impact of their farming practices on land quality and soil degradation. Overall, I think that farmers are trying to be more careful, but unfortunately in my own state of Queensland we still have major land clearing problems.

Sydney Harbour is a lot cleaner than it was 10 years ago. I went fishing with former Prime Minister Bob Hawke last Sunday and we caught four fish at the bottom of his jetty in Northbridge. They looked pretty healthy to me, as did the water. Many forest disputes are not settled, but they can be settled and I am hopeful that they will be. Our national park estate and the broader conservation estate are larger than they were 10 years ago. Air quality overall is probably improving as heavy industries are moving out of our major urban areas. Also, although there are a lot more cars, the new cars that are coming on the road are a lot cleaner.

There have been successes and there has been progress but there are many great challenges in front of us. I believe that, if we work together as a parliament, we can achieve great things for the environment. This legislation is a further instalment on improvements in the environment. It does represent far-sightedness on the part of policy makers in ensuring that our seas and oceans are cleaner. So I congratulate the government on that and I look forward to a renewed philosophical commitment from this parliament to the protection of Australia's wonderful natural environment.

talk.start.para: —I would like to follow on from the remarks made by my colleague in relation to ongoing thought and commitment to the development of Australia's heritage and environment issues. I will signal a couple of areas that remain of concern to me and I urge the government to pay more attention to them.

speech.para: The first point—I believe this is a matter where the chickens are very much coming home to roost for the government—is that from the proceeds of the first tranche of the sale of Telstra the government, at the time, announced the world's greatest heritage fund, the Natural Heritage Trust—$1 billion of it. Those of us who understand these things and know how to read a budget statement properly said at the outset, `Hang on, what you have done here is added up over five years $1 billion worth of spending. But, by the way, you have made cuts here to programs that were ongoing in the budget, funded as recurrent funding.' A classic one was the funding of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission—cut back. Programs like Landcare—cut back. Programs for some of the river strategies that the member for Rankin was talking about a minute ago were cut back and all replaced with the Natural Heritage Trust. Fine, who cares where the dollars come from? The point is that at the end of that five-year program these well-established recurrent programs in the budget are gone. What has to happen instead is that you have to go to the Treasurer and ask for funding for a whole new program, except you have not got another sale of Telstra to fund it. Having made all these concessions to get the GST through, all of a sudden the government has to work out where the dollars are in its budget to support the ongoing environment and heritage allocations. That issue will come to the fore in the next 18 months as we lead up to the federal election, because, having let those programs go, they cannot be that easily written back in.

What has happened to the Murray-Darling Commission? We now have the National Farmers Federation saying that we need a rescue package for the Murray-Darling. They are assessing that the rescue package will cost of the order of $64 billion—to fix up something that every one of us has known. The first day I was sent out to teach as a high school teacher near Kerang in northern Victoria—30 years ago—I could not believe the salt and the water that I could see lying around the paddocks—and I was a city slicker! Farming practices have changed. We have come to understand what has happened to the Murray cod, the yellow-belly and other species. But now the Farmers Federation is calling for somebody to come up with $64 billion to fix the problem. I find it astounding that Australia has let itself get to this situation especially when we had the Prime Minister securing the support of the Democrats for both the GST and the sale of the first third of Telstra for the world's greatest heritage fund—and here we are going further and further down the gurgler in a major national project such as the restoration of the Murray-Darling basin. I think that needs to be understood in the rawness in which I have outlined it.

I turn now to the issue of forestry. I recently participated in a trade delegation to South American and Latin American countries. We visited several countries. One experience still has me standing here with my ears ringing and my head shaking in wonderment. We arrived in Uruguay—

talk.start.para: —It is a wonderful place.
—It is. The wife of the member for Lowe, Mr Murphy, who is next to me, is from Uruguay. She is a lovely lady.

speech.para: We arrived in Uruguay, jumped in the car and headed to Montevideo, the capital city. The car trip from the airport to the city is about 20 kilometres. It is a beautiful drive along the coastal region, but before you reach the coastal strip you drive through eucalypt forests. I was sitting in the car looking out the window thinking, `Am I seeing what I think I am seeing? Am I seeing gum trees in Uruguay?' I asked the driver, `Are they gum trees?' He said, `Yes, we got them from Australia.'

I went to lunch with a number of ministers. I was sitting next to the industry minister and I said, `By the way, what's with all the gum trees?' Herein lies the rub, Mr Deputy Speaker. He said, `We identified 15 years ago that there would be a shortage in the world of quality timber for woodchips, paper and other resources and we analysed what would be the best tree. We selected a number of Australian eucalypts and began planting plantations 15 years ago to move into the gap we knew would exist in the world trade for that product.' I sat there and thought, `We have spent 15 years of public energy in a battle with the timber industry, a battle in government over woodchips, a battle over access to public forests—15 years in energy and intellect and have gone just about nowhere—while smarter countries have said, “Hey, let's start planting trees; let's start reforestation; let's start building for the future of this industry.' I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, have not only a very deep-seated interest in the topic but also a sadness in your heart at the absurdity of the debate that has gone on in Australia for the last 15 years. It is a debate that for all the time I have been here sums up what Australia has become.

Within weeks of becoming the new government in 1996, this government introduced legislation to remove the ceiling on woodchip exports from Australia. The only tool the federal government had to lever the industry with was to say, `Unless you plant plantations, unless you start reforestation, we will not approve these woodchip exports.' The conservatives erased it from the legislation within weeks of becoming the government. What has happened in Australia since? The industry has gone flat out in its continuing fight for access to public forests and has done next to nothing in planting plantations and broadening the base of reforestation. When I got out of the plane in Uruguay and I saw these smart people growing Australian eucalypts, I thought `What on earth are we about?'

I call again in this parliament for the people who are involved in this debate to understand that the fight is not about access to public forest. All our energy and all our resources should be going to reforestation—sensibly and profitably—of Australia's land mass, because this is a big future industry. Other countries can see it; why can't we?

Just to conclude on this point, Mr Deputy Speaker, I might say that I was thrilled to see the change of government in Victoria, because the previous state government in Victoria had so bastardised the national forest agreement between the federal government and the state government that the Liberal minister for the forests here, Wilson Tuckey, had himself taken over the process of auditing what was going on in Victoria because he did not trust what he was being told by the Victorians. What has now just recently been signed between the federal government and the state government is the regional forest agreement covering the forest area in my electorate, which I have been highly supportive of. I am now saying to both ministers, the federal minister—and I expect I will be saying it to a Labor federal minister in about 18 months time—and the state minister: do not trust these bureaucrats and forest managers underneath this agreement, because I have evidence that they are already beginning to white-ant the agreement that has been made between the federal minister and the state minister. The shadow minister for forestry, Mr Ferguson, who is present in the chamber at the moment, is well informed on the fact that it is all very well for ministers and governments to make agreements but, if the forest managers underneath decide they want to do their own thing, it can gather pretty serious momentum. So I am just putting a little yardstick out there that I am supportive of the agreement that has been made between the Commonwealth and Victoria in the regional forest agreement, but I am asking both ministers to make sure that they stay right on the wheel of this and particularly right on the wheel of the commitments regarding investment in plantation and investment in reafforestation, because they are the bits of the agreement that I think are starting to fall off the cart already. I am certainly not going to stand by and watch that.

I believe the nation has been sold a pup with the greatest environment program of all time, the Natural Heritage Trust; the chickens are going to come home to roost on that, as they are on a lot of other things. I am saying that the Murray-Darling basin, in particular, has to be the environmental priority of both federal and state governments involved in this, because even the National Farmers Federation has said it is a $64 billion problem. For all the energy we have put into the waterfront, the Industry Commission only ever said the waterfront was a $1 billion problem. This is a $64 billion problem—64 times that of the waterfront. If Mr Reith thinks he wants to do something about something valuable, then it is the Murray-Darling basin.

I conclude by calling on both the federal and state ministers involved in the Victorian Regional Forest Agreement to keep a particular focus on the commitments regarding reafforestation and plantation. I thank you for the opportunity to make this contribution.

talk.start.para: —The Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 is being implemented in conformance with Australia's obligations under international law for the ratification of an international instrument to which Australia is a signatory. The relevant international instrument in this case is the 1996 protocol to the London convention. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 and bring our domestic legislation into line with this international instrument.

speech.para: I am deeply disturbed by this bill and the genre of bills we increasingly see being presented by the government. What is clearly apparent is a direction by this government to the release and privatisation of all aspects of social existence, including environmental, social and cultural spheres, which are supposed to be sacrosanct, that is, above private ownership or control. This bill superficially appears uncontentious until we take a closer look. The convention that this bill seeks to ratify in domestic law is in itself a good thing. The dumping of waste into the sea has caused predictable and foreseeable damage to the global environment on an unprecedented scale. Many of us in this House are at least partially aware of these impacts. They need not be mentioned in any detail here, save to say that we are all disgusted as we look on helplessly at environmental harm such as a spoiled beach or a tainted landscape. We envisage a vision of clean living waters and a restorative balance between man's use on the one hand and a sustainable balance of all life on the other hand.

That is largely the problem with this bill. It is the fact that this type of pollution, waste dumping at sea, is conspicuous, predictable, foreseeable and direct. Therefore, it is inconceivable that the precautionary principle could possibly be absent in this bill. Only earlier this week I questioned the ethics of this government legislating an amendment to immigration law on parent visas where the government was simply unwilling to admit to itself the logical consequences of actions. It is clear that the government is repeatedly and recklessly continuing its blundering, ill-conceived and rushed agenda of pushing through legislation without recourse or due consideration to that legislation's impact on the broader law, that admixture of a bill in the context of the whole law, including federal, state and territory law, the common law and administrative and procedural laws. It is in the admixture of laws that the problems begin and where the public will suffer an ill-conceived law in its broader context.

The bill is seriously flawed. It is a classical case of the biblical warning: by doing good, they shall do much evil. What is the good of which I speak and what are the evils? The good is the ratification of Australia's international obligations into domestic law. Further, this ratification of the anti sea dumping legislation would not, I dare say, be opposed by any in this House. The evils are twofold: one, the denial of accountability of corporations to the public interest; two, the denial of Australia's obligations to ratify the precautionary principle and ecologically sustainable development legislation at every relevant opportunity.

While the subject of this bill is superficially uncontentious, the administrative and legal ramifications contained in the bill are highly disturbing, as I have said, and must be addressed. I draw to the attention of this House the definition of `seriously harmful material' found in item 14 of schedule 1 of the bill. Item 14 in turn refers the reader to item 77. It is worth reciting the comments found in Parliamentary Library Bills Digest No. 48 1999-2000, which states:

quote.para: Item 14 defines “seriously harmful material” as radioactive material, or any other material prescribed as such by the regulations.

Item 77 inserts new subsection 14 (3) into the Act which ensures that before a regulation prescribes material as “seriously harmful material” for the purposes of subsection 4(1), the Minister must be satisfied that the material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment. This limitation on the kinds of material that may be prescribed as “seriously harmful material” does not appear to incorporate the precautionary principle.

speech.para: The gist of these items is that the definition of what substances are included in the definition of what is defined as seriously harmful material carries with it stronger regulation, including more stringent penalties. As item 77 says, the limitation of the kinds of material that may be so classified does not appear to incorporate the precautionary principle. Therefore, I am compelled to defend the public interest against this government's law-making, which is predicated on the privatisation of the public interest, the wholesale attempt to sell and own moral goods which cannot be bought or sold.

What are those moral goods, Mr Deputy Speaker? They include intangibles such as biodiversity, intergenerational equity, clean air, water and environment, this government's sovereignty, the government's role as custodial trustees of the environment, cultural heritage, environmental heritage, and social heritage. Many more could be added, but these are the most important issues surrounding the impact of items 14 and 77. The list is important because it identifies the intangibles that are being dismissed by the effect of bills such as this. It is for this reason that I am compelled to restate the precautionary principle in this House, for it is the precautionary principle and everything that it enshrines as an ethic that is itself under attack by bills of this kind. However, this government has seen fit to abandon both the public interest but, more importantly, the role of this government as advocates of the public interest by explicit abrogation. There are many excellent definitions of the precautionary principle but I prefer the statutory definition contained in subsection 6(2)(a) of the New South Wales act titled Protection of the Environment Administration Act 1991. Section 61(2) says:

quote.para: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a), ecologically sustainable development requires the effective integration of economic and environmental considerations in decision-making processes. Ecologically sustainable development can be achieved through the implementation of the following principles and programs:

(a) The precautionary principle - namely, that if there are threats of serious or irreversible environmental damage, lack of full scientific certainty should not be used as a reason for postponing measures to present environmental degradation. In the application of the precautionary principle, public and private decisions should be guided by:
(i) careful evaluation to avoid, wherever practicable, serious or irreversible damage to the environment, and
(ii) an assessment of the risk-weighted consequences of various options.

speech.para: It seems clear to me that this government is adamant about implementing its campaign of selective amnesia when it suits itself to deny its obligations to embed the precautionary principle into domestic law. Before addressing the absence of the precautionary principle in this bill, I will address the assertion that section 18 of the sea dumping act allows the minister to require the applicant for a permit to enter into an agreement that includes provisions such as that the applicant will undertake research or analysis relating to the effect that the proposed dumping might have on the marine environment. In the main, I question whether a discretionary power in the hands of the minister is sufficient to fulfil our obligations to implement the precautionary principle.

This bill appears to be but part of a broader strategy by the government. The strategy seeks to pander to the corporate world. This corporate world has sought to privatise every aspect of human existence: our ability to think—through monopolistic media control; and our environment in all its manifestations, including the natural environment, the cultural environment and the social environment. Everything is being reduced to a mere commodity. Everything has a price. This is the philosophy of economic liberalism, the bastard child of utilitarianism, of which I have spoken in this House before. The denial of basic rules against the onslaught of corporate conduct is a trademark of this government as they pander to the vested interests of the corporate world. For it is the utilitarian ethic, that defective ethic of the want based perspective, which has reduced everything to a commodity. According to the ethic that aims for the good of the most but not all for most of the time, there are winners and losers. More sinisterly, there are losers that are intangible, the unrepresented elements of our society that do not vote. I speak of the intrinsic rights of existence, the right of other life forms to exist, the rights of nature to exist and the right of biodiversity in all its manifestations to exist.

That is not to deny the utility we as human beings enjoy from the attainment of clean air and water or the very existence of a food cycle on this planet. It is the realm of the technocentrists who assert that, so long as we find a technological remedy to the fulfilment of some utilitarian outcome such as food production, we can dispense with nature absolute. This is the reasoning behind genetically modified foods. It is equally defective. But I raise this analogy in order to highlight the logical consequences of the ethics imbued in this bill through the denial of the operation of the precautionary principle. This is the policy rationale of such policies as the multilateral agreement on investment, MAI. It is the reason why there were such violent protests in Seattle in the United States of America this year that it caused the entire collapse of that conference.

People around the world are increasingly aware of subtleties of legislation such as the one put before this House today. This bill seeks to give the impression that it is fulfilling a noble obligation of ratifying a United Nations convention whilst, in fact, divesting government statutory powers to intervene through denying application of the precautionary principle in their conduct.

I can recount many examples where this government has directly divested itself of legal powers and placed corporations above the law. I am particularly reminded of the Telecommunications Act 1996 as I say this. In that act, especially at section 360, this government gives rights to three telecommunications corporations exclusively beyond the rights of every other person, corporate or otherwise. Taxation laws are another example, including the corporate enjoyment of taxation breaks and the pandering of this government to the excessive demands of corporations.

This week in parliament we heard the Prime Minister make repeated demands on the petrol companies to honour their commitments to pass on petrol price falls to the customer, but to no avail. The petrol company spin doctors have had their way, replete with the corporate attitude of `you try and make me'. Any attempt to deal with the corporate world is typically met with the response, `We will get up and leave' or `We will just not invest in you'. Threats of Australia being a pariah state by the corporate world are well known—the banana republic.

So we engage in adjusting our economy to appease the infinite greed that attends to the corporates' desires. I can only be convinced that the new taxation system is a direct result of corporate demands for an economy that best suits their needs. In the late 1990s, we narrowly escaped the ratification of the MAI. The MAI was the last straw in a full-scale assault similar to the insidious attack being made here today in this bill. This bill is a small slice of the MAI agenda in that it seeks to exculpate a corporation from liability if the precautionary principle is breached. The MAI is itself comatose, but the agenda of the MAI and its corporate lobby continues unabated. The only thing that has changed is that the MAI agenda has moved from the OECD to the World Trade Organisation. In all material respects, the agenda remains the same. What is the agenda? It is a privatisation of everything. It is the reduction of everything, including the environment itself, to a mere commodity.

I now wish to move on to some examples of the logical consequences of this utilitarian ethic born of its liberalist roots. These are a few home grown examples from my electorate of Lowe. An examination of the issues affecting the electorate of Lowe shows that the recognition of this approach by this government in pandering to the corporate world and globalisation lies at the root of the evils befalling our community. I first raise the example of Sydney airport and the operation of runway movements. Here is an example of what happens when government acts in a private way and how the community reacted to this conduct, in this case by taking the matter to the Federal Court on administrative grounds. In that case, the government considered it proper to exempt from the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 certain proposed Commonwealth actions relating to the use of runways at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and the flight paths of aircraft taking off from or landing at the airport. The action also involved the decision of the then minister for the environment to exempt this action from the approved procedures under the act.

A second local example includes the implementation of the dreaded precision radar monitor system. This system has been universally condemned by the public interest, represented in the Sydney Airport Community Forum. Motion after motion has unanimously called for its repeal. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has repeatedly ignored the emphatic and declaratory objections made by SACF in the public interest and favoured the corporates with a vested interest.

A third example includes the proposed construction of a mobile telephone tower in the suburb of Concord, which lies in the heart of my electorate. In this case, strong community protests raised the possibility that such a tower can produce constant exposure to low level radiation that may be harmful to human health. The debate at the public meeting on 9 March 2000 on the Concord mobile phone tower issue revolved around the precautionary principle. Until then, the corporation responsible for the tower, who were present at the meeting, were doing the usual spin doctor stuff. However, at the mention of the precautionary principle to the so-called independent consultant, a major fracas broke out. The consultant argued, inter alia, that the principle did not apply because there was no foreseeable risk. At least the principle was considered to apply but was just considered irrelevant for lack of identifiable harm.
The whole point in this bill is that we are dealing with known or knowable harm. I recite from the New South Wales legislation:

quote.para: If there are threats of serious or irreversible environmental damage, lack of full scientific certainty should not be used as a reason for postponing measures to prevent environmental degradation.

speech.para: Thus, the precautionary principle anticipates harm that may lack full scientific certainty and seeks to prevent it. The precautionary principle transcends empirical proof. The subject of this bill, namely, dumping of waste, including radioactive waste, into the sea is, in terms of environmental degradation, much more scientifically certain than electromagnetic radiation.

Waste is relatively easy to identify and monitor; so too are its harmful impacts at once immediate and conspicuous. For these reasons, the subject of this bill is an obvious candidate for the application of the precautionary principle. If ever there were a subject relevant to the good application of the precautionary principle, then it is before us today. To deny the application of the precautionary principle in this bill is to have the following consequences. The corporation is absolved of liability or adherence to the precautionary principle, as indicated in subsection 6(2)(a) of the Protection of the Environment Administration Act. The precautionary principle is a component of the broader ethic known as ecologically sustainable development. To eliminate the application of the precautionary principle to this bill therefore fundamentally compromises this bill's application of the ethics contained in ESD, which Australia is also bound to implement through the ratification of domestic laws consistent with the several international instruments to which we have become a signatory. To deny the operation of the precautionary principle eliminates liability in the hands of the corporates who would seek to use the amendments found in items 14 and 77 in a way that denies culpability for failing to postpone measures to militate against the harm that may be caused.

I remind this House of why the precautionary principle exists. This principle and its capital ethic, ESD, were espoused in the classical text on environmental ethics and in such texts as the Brundtland report. The basis for such policy is founded on the recognition that true environmental protection is only achieved through preventative measures. That is, it is rarely possible to restore a work of God in nature once it is destroyed. It is easy to destroy a thing of nature; it is almost impossible to ever restore a thing, once destroyed. It is this paramount and right reasoning that compels the application of the precautionary principle. To ignore this principle denies the possibility of arresting or of postponing measures before the event occurs. This is especially true of water pollution, where the effects of such pollution can be not only catastrophic for the ecology, but also horrendously difficult to fix or ameliorate after the event.

When I review the broader body of pollution law in the Commonwealth jurisdiction and the states and territories, certain hurdles always present themselves. You must not only prove a pollution event occurred; you must also show a causal link. You must show a nexus between the actuating event and the pollution. You must show a connection between the person committing the offence, the pollution and the harm. I say all this with the greatest of respect to my Victorian colleagues, who I understand still enjoy laws that entertain a notion of absolute liability in environmental law. But I stand to be corrected on this point and would welcome further comment from any Victorian member of this House to clarify the point.

I conclude with this warning to the government: you cannot escape the watchful eye of the public who are now very aware of the encroaching and cumulative influence of these laws. In particular, it is now clear that this government has an agenda of globalisation that seeks to diminish and ultimately eradicate sovereignty of Australia through laws such as those contained in this bill. These laws seek to diminish powers held in the public interest. Specifically, the denial of any power to apply the precautionary principle in this aspect of pollution law is a further reduction of powers in the hands of the public interest in dealing with preventative environmental powers that could be invoked to prevent environmental degradation. In doing so, this bill seeks to weaken government and devolve its responsibilities in guarding the public interest in the most critical aspect of environmental protection.

Like the Concord mobile telephone tower saga that I referred to a moment ago and the lack of scientific certainty in showing the risk, it often comes down to the opinion of the experts. Adolf Hitler is sometimes credited as having said that the experts were people who told him what he could not do. Adolf Hitler was your classic consequentialist. He asserted at Nuremberg that a bird flies because it is a bird. Put another way, because a man can do a thing, therefore he must do a thing. This is the reasoning behind the denial of the precautionary principle. It asserts that the lack of a scientific report that demonstrates a nebulous but feasible new link between cause and effect means that the cause or actuating event may be done without legal repercussions or liability. This is exactly the type of event which the precautionary principle seeks to avoid.

The immorality of this event is found in the philosophically illogical basis for the existence of the amendments contained in items 14 and 77. That is, logic permits the testing of validity of new enlightened conclusions reached from premises which we currently do not possess. The denial of being allowed to construct reasoning in this way is tantamount to intellectual hijacking. This line of reasoning asserts that, because we as yet do not know a thing exists, we conclude that it does not exist. The argument of not making the precautionary principle explicit in this bill rests on similar empiricist reasoning that, if something cannot be proved empirically, it is presumed to not exist and may therefore be disregarded. It is this line of false reasoning that results in liberalism being the morally bankrupt philosophy that it is and the reasoning from the political party in this House, which is the namesake of that philosophy. For these reasons I urge the minister for the environment, Senator Robert Hill, to explicitly incorporate the precautionary principle in this bill.

talk.start.para: — I refer to Australian adherence to changes in international understandings legislated for in 1996. Perhaps this focuses the light on a few of the realities of the environmental debate. This legislation really stems from negotiations in 1971 and the whole movement to international concern about our waterways, including the impact that dumping has on sea life, the impact it has on industries that are dependent upon the sea, et cetera. Since 1971 we have seen that to achieve a balance in international negotiations requires a degree of give and take by a number of countries, all with different interests, to reach an understanding. At the same time, the balance of forces in the international debate—the environmental movement, its strength, and the question of the growth of scientific evidence and knowledge—come into play in moving the international community towards what I see as advances in this area.

speech.para: There is another focus. I refer to an article by Rachelle Baird in the Environment and Planning Journal, volume 53 of June 1998. She refers to what this country confronts in many other areas of international law. The reality for our region is that traditionally while we have been a pacemaker in regards to adherence to these conventions we are in a zone of the world where essentially adherence is not as great as it might be in western Europe and North America. It is interesting to note that in our region Japan and China are the only signatories to the convention and that in the Pacific, as far as I understand from that article, Australia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and the Solomons are the only other adherents. The reality we face in this area is that, whilst Australia has been at the forefront in getting international controls over dumping at sea, our region is characterised by a significant number of nations who do not have the resources to adhere to these conventions and, in some cases, lack the political will to be involved.

The situation is that there has been a growth of international pressure and knowledge. Historically, the original convention, stemming from those 1971 negotiations and introduced in 1972, was essentially an agreement that sought to limit dumping. It did not seek to move towards total banning of a large number of substances. It had a system of permits. In some cases there were total bans, except for trace elements. In other cases there was a list of materials, outlined in an annex, that could be dumped at sea. Obviously, with the growth of pressure and the growth of interest and knowledge, the world has moved to a situation which says that in the light of our development that is not good enough. In that period the only substances that were banned were organohomogene compounds, mercury, mercury compounds, cadmium, high level radioactive waste, et cetera. The agreement in 1996 to change this legislation reflected that international pressure. We have had instances in the North Sea where there have been massive arguments over the question of oil installations.

This bill provides for the movement towards outright incineration bans. Once again, that was not the original intention of the signatories. A summary of the intention of this bill is given in the article I cited earlier. Rachelle Baird states:

quote.para: It is intended that in time the protocol will replace the London convention. To facilitate a smooth transition to more prescriptive provisions of the protocol a maximum five-year phase-in period is allowed for states to comply. To receive the benefit of this transitional period a state must notify the secretary general of the IMO of the reasons why it is not able to comply with specific provisions of the protocol.

speech.para: The bill provides for a five-year phase-in period and encouragement throughout the whole thrust of these measures to seek alternatives. Essentially, while countries and states in our region that lack the facilities to fully implement the requirements of this legislation and conventions can be given exemptions and exceptions, before dumping there has to be a thorough assessment of the waste prevention audit and management options, specifications and characteristics of the materials sought to be dumped. They must come forward and give very concrete reasons as to why they are unable to do so.

The legislation widens Australia's exclusive economic zone. The coverage of the bill extends to Antarctica's far reaches and obviously the opposition is supportive of that move to further applicability of the bans on dumping. I reiterate that there is a stress on seeking alternatives and looking for technological advances.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member for Reid will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—I inform the House that it is my intention to issue a writ on Friday, 30 June 2000 for the election of a member to serve for the electoral division of Isaacs, in the state of Victoria, in the place of Mr Gregory Stuart Wilton. The dates in connection with the by-election are fixed as follows: the issue of writ—Friday, 30 June 2000; close of rolls—Friday, 7 July 2000; date of nominations—Thursday, 13 July 2000; date of polling—Saturday, 12 August 2000; and return of the writ—on or before Sunday, 8 October 2000.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer you to your 7.30 Report interview regarding National Textiles on 8 February, where you stated, `I've kept at arms length from the issue', and your statement to the House on 15 February that, prior to meeting with workers on 4 February, you were not aware of having received any advice on the issue. Isn't it a fact that your senior economic adviser, Peter Crone, discussed the government bailout with National Textiles administrator John Starr on 22 January, only one day after the workers' employment was terminated and two days after the Stock Exchange was notified? When did contact between your office and the administrator commence? What instructions did you give to Peter Crone? What discussions did you subsequently conduct with him on this matter? Will you now inform the House: what did you know, and when did you know it?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —This question is in the true newspaper following style of the Labor Party, based on a report in the Sydney Morning Herald about freedom of information. The documents released to the Sydney Morning Herald do not shed any further light on this issue—no further light at all. There was contact between my office and the administrator of National Textiles. There is nothing unusual about that. It has happened in relation to Oakdale and other matters. It is entirely consistent with that practice. It remains the case the Labor Party is unhappy that we bailed out ordinary Australian workers. Nothing that you can say is going to alter that fact. Through the good officers of the workers' friend, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business—the battlers' mate behind me here—we have been able to put in place a scheme, and your crowd in New South Wales are too mean to supplement it.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Would the Prime Minister inform the House of changes in Australia's taxation system that will be in place when the House next sits in August?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I would like to inform the House and the Australian people of something new—there will be a change to our tax system on Saturday. This is a generational change that this country has needed for at least a quarter of a century. It is a change that will immeasurably strengthen the Australian economy. It is a change that will reduce the income tax burden of every Australian taxpayer. It is a change that will reduce business costs. It is a change that will reduce the cost of fuel in country Australia because it will reduce diesel by 24c a litre.

answer.para: There is one thing about which the Australian public can be of no doubt—and it will have a very important influence in defining the long-term impact of this change politically, as well as economically and socially—the people who have fought against very difficult odds on many occasions to bring Australia the tax reform it so badly needed are the members of the Liberal and National parties. We are the people who have fought for the national interest. We are the people who have taken the risks. We are the people who have been prepared to confront the generational need for taxation reform. It will forever be to the credit of the Liberal and National parties that they fought to put in place a taxation system which will guarantee, in a way that no other national government has ever guaranteed, the necessary revenue to the states of Australia so that they can fund the roads, the schools, the police, the hospitals and all the other daily services that Australians have a right to expect from their state governments. Everybody in this parliament knows that the premiers conferences, whether under Malcolm Fraser's prime ministership, Bob Hawke's prime ministership, Paul Keating's prime ministership or my own, degenerate into ridiculous wrangling and farcical exchanges. Decade after decade, premiers have come to Canberra and said, `We want a new financial deal.' Prime Minister after Prime Minister has shirked the responsibility of giving them that new deal. That dereliction of responsibility ended with this government. We took a decision two years ago to give the states of Australia a better financial deal. Despite the political posturing of the Labor premiers, they have welcomed it with great glee and great alacrity because it will give them the financial sinews of war they do not now have. I look forward with keen anticipation to Saturday. I look forward to the weeks and months that follow. The Leader of the Opposition cannot make up his mind whether it will be instantaneous disaster or a slow burn. At the beginning of the year, the world was going to come to an end on 1 July, but a few days ago the Leader of the Opposition said that 1 July would be the best day.

I say in this parliament to the people of Australia, as I will say to them tonight in my address to the nation, that we have taken this decision because we believe it will strengthen the Australian nation. It will make us a stronger economy. It will make us more competitive. It will give us a fairer taxation system. It will deliver the revenue underpinning for the states to provide essential services. It will end an archaic wholesale sales tax system. Overall, this represents the biggest beneficial change that a government can make to the economy of Australia. I invite the Australian people to give it their support, to give it the fair go it deserves. I have no doubt that, when we return in six or seven weeks time, it will begin to dawn on the Australian Labor Party that there is a point at which the Australian people will tolerate negativity and scaremongering no more. All the Labor Party has done is engage in absolutely destructive negativity. That is easy. You have had your easy hits. You have had your salad days in attacking it. From Saturday it will start to turn around, and the Australian people will realise the courage that this government has displayed. The Australian people will over time embrace the change that has been made.

Before I conclude this answer, I would like to place on the record my particular thanks to all of my colleagues for the help they have given me. Most particularly I want to single out for special praise the work of the Treasurer, who has done an absolutely fantastic job in relation to this. He is vastly into detail. The personal commitment he has given to it has been absolutely exemplary. I record my gratitude to my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Federal Parliamentary Liberal Party and Treasurer of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I want to ask the honourable the Prime Minister a question in relation to his overall responsibility for the human rights record of the government. Is the Prime Minister aware that more than 1,700 people have been granted genuine refugee status by Australia's determination system but have only been granted a three-year temporary visa? Is he aware of the tough conditions imposed on those receiving this temporary visa, including the provision that they cannot unite with their spouse and children for at least three years and up to five years? Given the Prime Minister's stated belief in the sanctity of the family, will the Prime Minister respond to the pleas of organisations such as the Refugee Council of Australia, and act to remove these cruel and inhumane provisions in the three-year visa?
—I call the minister.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is a question that concerns the whole of the government in Australia's human rights record. It is not a question just for the minister for immigration. The Prime Minister should answer this question.

—The member for Calwell, who has had lengthier service in this House than most members, is aware that the Prime Minister has acted within the standing orders, and I recognise the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —In response to the honourable member for Calwell's question, let me outline that I made the announcement two days ago that, after due consideration of the claims of those who had arrived unlawfully in Australia—which, I might say, took longer than I would have liked, but was hampered very much by the fact that before they arrived in Australia many of them had disposed of documentation that might have assisted us in dealing with those issues—many had been found to have a well-founded fear of persecution in their home country and no other protection available to them. That puts them in the same situation as some 14 million other people around the world who have been found to be refugees. There is in Australia a very generous program—in fact, the largest program in the world per capita—to assist refugees with resettlement in Australia. Those places, which we allocate in concert with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, go to people who are judged to be in the most deserving situation, where they have no prospect of returning home, no safe place to stay and have an immediate and compelling need for resettlement. Those who come to Australia unlawfully, often bypassing situations in which they can be safe—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The whole question of whether refugees are unlawful has been rejected by the United Nations, Amnesty International and other bodies. People who arrive as refugees are not unlawful. The description of them as unlawful is—
—The member for Calwell will resume his seat. His point of order is not valid by any standard. The minister was responding to the question asked, and I invite him to continue.

—The point I was making is this. It might satisfy the honourable member for Calwell to know that some of the people who arrive in Australia unlawfully may later be found to be a refugee and then have a lawful entitlement to be here, but that does not mean that they did not arrive in Australia unlawfully. These people came to Australia unlawfully, bypassing other situations in which they could be safe, in many circumstances leaving situations where they had already been safe and have denied people who have a compelling need for a refugee place of that opportunity. We cannot walk away from our international obligations, but to leave in place incentives that would encourage people to come here, at risk to their own lives and at great danger and great cost, would, on our part, be highly irresponsible. One of the significant pull factors for people who were thinking about engaging upon those journeys to Australia was the fact that they got a permanent resident outcome if they were found to be refugees under the arrangements that were in place before. That was the outcome. Now they get a temporary entry permit, which honours our international obligation. Temporary entry holders do not get a family reunion entitlement. They do not get an Australian travel document to come and go from Australia at will, which numbers of permanent entry holders have been prepared to do, even though they were found to be refugees.

answer.para: The parliament agreed that the rules in relation to people who arrive unlawfully and establish refugee status should change and it was to reduce the pull factors to make Australia a less attractive destination. To unwind those measures now would only serve to send a signal to those people who are engaged in this insidious people trafficking business—the same sorts of people we saw involved in that practice in the United Kingdom—to continue to profiteer from this gruesome trade. We will not be a party to unwinding the measures that are designed to deal with that issue.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Given the introduction of the new tax system on 1 July with benefits for families, farmers and right through to rail, is the Prime Minister aware of any alternative plans to move Australia forward?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I say to my colleague and friend the member for Farrer that the short answer to the question is no, but I know the honourable member would be a tad disappointed if I were so dismissive. Let me simply expand a bit by recalling what I said in answer to the first question, that we will go away for six or seven weeks and, when we all come back, the new system will be in operation. Of course, another event will occur while we are aware, that is, the biennial National Conference of the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party will have a great opportunity to work out what its alternative taxation policy is. No doubt when we return the Leader of the Opposition will unveil, during his numerous matters of public importance, why it is that the Australian people should embrace the alternative policy of the ALP. They criticise and obstruct what we try to do for the sake of a vote but not for the sake of the country. They say they are going to roll back the GST, but they do not specify where and how. They propose changes, but they do say that in essence they are going to keep the GST.

answer.para: The new taxation system will move Australia forward in a quite significant way. The kind of rolling back that Labor propose will only add complexity and difficulty to the new system. Over the last two years, the Labor Party have attacked the government in a quite mindless and opportunistic way. We had an outstanding example of it this morning. There is an allegation that a hacker has entered one of the systems associated with the introduction of the new system. What does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition do? In that true, national interest style for which he is renowned, does he go on radio and say, `Notwithstanding my opposition to the government's policy, I denounce the illegal practice of hacking'? Oh, no. He immediately says, `Oh, this is another opportunity to belt the government. This is another opportunity to blame it on the government.' That is absolutely and completely irresponsible and it is completely of a piece with the opportunistic attitude that this opposition, particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, has taken.

It is easy to criticise, it is easy to obstruct and it is easy to point score, but it is a lot harder to present generational taxation reform. When we return after the six- or seven-week break, I am quite certain that every member on this side of the House will look forward with great interest to hearing from the Leader of the Opposition his alternative plan. I have no doubt that they will discuss it at their national conference. They will have all the geniuses of the Labor Party gathered in Hobart. They will have all of their advisers. They will have their outgoing national president, although I think most of us over here rather like Barry in preference to Della Bosca. We will be waiting with bated breath to hear the new policy. When the Leader of the Opposition comes back, we will have our plan, endorsed by the people and introduced against great odds, pitted against their alternative and the Australian people will watch that debate with intense interest. If it is conducted in a spirited, constructive fashion, it can only be for the benefit of the Australian community.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister, and I refer to his botched visit to a bottle shop earlier today. Prime Minister, now that you have demonstrated that your claims on the GST impact on packaged liquor do not add up, will you be visiting a pub on Saturday to explain how your promise on the price of ordinary beer does not add up either?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I do not normally share my social plans with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, but it is an interesting suggestion. I have had quite a lot of offers as far as Saturday is concerned. I am sure I will have an opportunity to savour some of the local brew. I am rather pleased that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has asked me a question because only yesterday the Australian Hotels Association released their recommended prices. I read a report in the Adelaide Advertiser of a lady running a hotel in Glenelg. The thrust of what she had to say was, `Oh, gee, we have seen the AHA price lists and they are nowhere near as bad as we were told.' I wonder who told them they were worse than what they have turned out to be. It would not be Simon, would it?

answer.para: Government members—No.

talk.start.para: —No! Isn't that uncharitable of him? In other words, the Australian Hotels Association has not only caught Simon out telling whoppers—
—The Prime Minister will refer to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition by his title.

—Not only was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, to give him his formal title, caught telling whoppers and porkies on this subject but it also has a tad dented the credibility of the breweries in Australia, which have been running these ads and making all sorts of shameful allegations about the Treasurer, not to say the absolutely absurd allegations they have been making about me.
—I will deal with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition if he defies the chair.

—What the AHA price list says, interestingly enough, is that price increases were significantly below the claims being made by the breweries and significantly below the claims being made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. What the lady running the hotel in Glenelg said was, `I cannot understand what all the fuss is about. The customers are really quite happy.' She said, `This thing will come and go,' without so much as a blink in the drinking habits of her patrons. The good news for them is that the prices have not gone up by as much as the Labor Party has scared them into believing. Fancy scaring the working men and women of Australia into believing that beer would go up by more than it will in reality. What an absolutely outrageous thing for the Australian Labor Party to do. Not only is beer not going up by the amount of eight or nine per cent that they talked about but also the working men and women of Australia will have additional dollars in their pockets to buy even more beers. I have no doubt that beer sales in Australia will be completely uninterrupted by the arrival of the new taxation system.

—Mr Speaker, my question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House recent economic indicators on the state of the Australian economy? In light of recent economic data, what are the future prospects for continued strong growth?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr COSTELLO
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Cook for his question. I can inform him that the ABS job vacancies, which were released today, rose another two per cent in seasonally adjusted terms for the June quarter. That followed a 9.3 per cent growth in the last quarter. The skill vacancy survey, also released today, showed that skill vacancies rose by 1.5 per cent in June and are 15.8 per cent higher than a year ago. The unemployment rate is forecast by the government to fall to around 6¼ per cent by June of next year. This is the lowest unemployment rate in a decade. Since the coalition came to office, around 712,000 new jobs have been created. So far this year, 100,000 new jobs have been created in the Australian economy.

answer.para: The exceptional performance of the Australian economy has been recognised internationally.
