subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Living Standards

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Brand proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The government's responsibility for imposing a tax change which will adversely affect the living standards of ordinary Australian Families and workers, including through its botched implementation.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talker.name: Beazley, Kim, MP
Mr BEAZLEY
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition

talk.start.para: —With so much gravel rash across the government frontbench today, it is a great shame that the delightful nurse is leaving the precincts of this parliament because her services will be sorely needed for the next day or two. Those paroxysms of self-praise that we heard from this government reflect the fact that, if there is no-one else to blow your trumpet, you might as well blow it yourself. There is no-one else in this country blowing a trumpet for the government on this issue, at this time, knowing what is ahead of them with the implementation of this GST.

speech.para: That historical rewrite from the Leader of the House that we heard on the subject of the so-called 22-year commitment of the Prime Minister to the implementation of a goods and services tax—a value added tax—in this country would be a little more convincing if there had not been a little history between 1978 and now. That little history includes the 1996 election when the so-called honest and devoted commitment of the Prime Minister reflected itself in this way. I had occasion to refer to it in parliament yesterday and I will refer to it again here. I refer particularly to the following interview he had in Newcastle with Mickey, the presenter:

quote.para: Howard: Can I look you straight in the eye and say this, that if I state before an election that we're not going to do something and say it in concrete terms, I mean it. One of the worst things about politics in Australia at the moment is that the public doesn't believe what its political leaders say. Now I'm telling you ...
Presenter: But you had the wrong bloke flogging it before. I mean, John Hewson wasn't good at selling the GST.
Howard: Mickey, it's not on the agenda, full stop.
Presenter: Would you like it to be?
Howard: No, it's not on the agenda, full stop. Just not there. Vamoose. Kaput.
Presenter: Well it would be political suicide, unfortunately. This is a little touchy. God, I wish I'd been the man to flog that ...

Howard: I'm just telling you what is on the agenda, and what's not, and that's not. I say to the people of Australia, there will be no GST, that it is not on our agenda and I mean it. It's not, you know tiny ...
Presenter: Cross your heart, type stuff?

Howard: Look, it's absolute...and you know, you could bring me back here after the election when we've won and you can ask me again, you can ask me again in two years' time and you will find that I've kept my word on that.

speech.para: The problem for the Prime Minister is this: when the Prime Minister says it is good for families, they do not believe him. When the Prime Minister says it is good for small business, they do not believe him. When the Prime Minister says it is good for the country, they do not believe him because they no longer believe the word of the Prime Minister—it has been so grievously abused on so many occasions over the last three years.

That crazed triumphalism of the frontbench on the government side during today's proceedings represents nothing more than that Monty Pythonperformance by the Black Knight. As he jumps around in that armour, waving swords, first one arm goes, then another arm goes, then the leg goes. `I'm really having a terrific time,' says the Black Knight. `I challenge you to fight after fight.' It had about as much rationale behind it as that. Of course, what it and so much of their question time performance over these last 18 months have covered is the fact that, when people go for detail, when people want to understand what is really happening to them with the GST, they get evasion. They are getting evasion from the government, they are getting evasion from the tax office, they are getting evasion from all those charged with the responsibility of implementing this tax. There are thousands and thousands of unanswered questions as far as small business is concerned and, as far as the general public is concerned, the answers that they are getting now from this government are causing them a great deal of concern.

We have had the Treasurer missing from his responsibilities to run his Taxation Office as breaches of privacy have occurred affecting the records of thousands of people in small business. We have had a tax office coming up with a survey that showed that one-third of its officials could not answer the questions. We have had the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, Joe Hockey, boasting that there are 2,000 people out there to answer questions for the ACCC. Those are merely price monitors, and we find out that those actually engaged in the enforcement of the issue of price gouging constitute 99. We have had one piece of botching after another. We have had the child-care arrangements botched so that over the next couple of weeks people are going to be charged up to $122 more for their child-care per week, per child, and they are expected to carry that. The centres, which operate on a knife edge, are expected to carry the consequences of that for the next couple of weeks.

The problem is this, Mr Absent Prime Minister: so many people comprehend that what they are being sold here is a pup, that they are now the people who are responsible for collecting and paying the tax, they are the people whose needs and concerns ought to have been cared for and, as far as they are concerned, the Treasurer absents himself for a week. The Prime Minister—he does not join him in absenteeism, because the Treasurer is going to hang around for next week—absents himself for a week afterwards. This is extraordinary behaviour on the cusp of the introduction of a new tax system. It produces massive changes in the lives of people, and those who are responsible for it at the top, who are presiding over botch after botch, will not accept the responsibility of it by being able to keep themselves in this country for even just two weeks.

One of the things that we are going to be doing during the next 18 months is ploughing our way through the implementation of this GST, getting to understand its ramifications for all Australian people. We will be getting to understand the ramifications of it for the elderly in this society who are getting a four per cent tick-up in the pension to deal with a 10 per cent GST, two per cent of which is effectively being withdrawn in March. We have a view that it is quite possible that this will not be a substantial enough recompense for them. We also note the situation of families because, when we have been able to get answers, we have seen, for example, that middle income Australian families, in a set of circumstances which probably apply to at least some 150,000, are going to be materially worse off because of the changes in the social security arrangements.

Then we come to today. I want to go through some of these figures for the benefit of the House. They were alluded to by our health spokesperson, the member for Jagajaga. As much as the government would like the GST compensation package to be seen in isolation from the effect that we have seen on interest rates, in isolation from the effect that we have seen in the child-care area and in isolation from their other decisions and their other botches, ordinary Australian families, who will have to live it, will not see it in isolation. We have seen one of the campaigns of the government—the `run for cover' campaign, the `you will be devastated' campaign, `the health of your family will suffer if you do not join private health cover' campaign, which has been running alongside the `unchain my heart' campaign in relation to the goods and services tax. What do we find? I will take the figures for New South Wales—and, remember, we are going on minimal cover in each of these figures—even though the Victorian figures are much worse. If you happen to be a single person on $30,000 a year—and, remember, these are the people who have been cajoled most actively into the system—you get GST compensation of $16 a week, but the cost of that health insurance if you join a fund is $11.

Let me go to dual income families with two children, again in New South Wales. We are dealing with an income split of $6,733 and children between the ages of five and 12. If they have a family income of $45,000 a year—and this is a very typical situation we are now dealing with—they get GST compensation of $29. The cost of health insurance for them is $26, so they now have $3, if they follow the government's advertising campaign, to pay for all the things that will happen in relation to the GST. Let me take another dual income family, again in New South Wales. In this case the family has teenage children. Let me take them on an income of $40,000 a year. Currently they will enjoy $20 compensation for the GST. The cost of their health insurance will be $26, so they will be net to the bad $6 due to the impact of the GST and the implications of it for them. Let me take them at an income of $45,000. They will have $23 in compensation for the GST. The cost of health insurance will be $26, meaning they will lose $3 because of the total effect of the movement between the two. Recollect that we are talking here about some 800,000 who are alleged to have joined—they have taken up the offer—private health funds. We are not dealing with a minor class of people here; we are dealing with 800,000 people. Then there is the situation being experienced by small business. They think that if they have a business number, that is the end of the story. No, it is not the end of the story. The story as far as small business is concerned is implementing the detail of the GST, on which they get no accurate advice from the Australian Taxation Office but face grave penalties if they fail in their performance over the next six to 12 months.

When you start going through all of those areas relating to the compensation package, when you go through the confusion that is out there, particularly in those areas where they are facing enormous complexity in the tax, like those who are handling the situation with regard to food, and for families that are going to experience a totally new cost structure in their lives, particularly when they have additional children, and when you look at the situation of families as they confront the circumstances of going into private health cover and the position of pensioners who are not appropriately covered, what is the sensible course of action for an opposition? The sensible course of action for an opposition is to make absolutely certain that they have the clearest fix on each one of these issues as they prepare their roll-back of the GST.

Do not think for one moment that we support a goods and services tax; but, unlike this government, we have some concern for the people who are responsible for implementing it and some concern for the people who will experience it. As we start to roll back the most unfair shift in the Australian tax burden ever—as we move to deal with that—we are going to make our decisions based on the fullest possible information that we can get. So do not worry about this. We are going to roll back your GST. In rolling back your GST, we are going to have an accurate fix on the costs, an accurate fix on the principal problems and a firm commitment to simplicity. We are going to take full advantage of the time that is available to us before the next election. Unlike those who have lied to the Australian people so persistently, we are going to produce a clear-cut, fully costed coverage of roll-back. But I can tell you one thing that we can undertake right now. We will not be rolling it forward. If the states ask for the rate to be raised or if the states ask for food to be included, we will say no. An easy enough question for the government to answer is: will they? If the states ask them for that, will they? No, they will not because they want the GST rolled forward. That is what they want—a GST rolled forward. We will be rolling it back, properly considered. We will be rolling it back, properly afforded. They will be at the next election without commitments on rolling it forward. It will be interesting to hear what the minister has to say about that in reply. (Time expired)

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr REITH
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —We have just heard the climax of one of the most contemptible campaigns ever run by an opposition in the history of the Federation. There is nothing more contemptible than a leader of the opposition who is opposed publicly to a policy which he knows in his heart of hearts is the right thing to do for this country. There is nothing more negative, there is nothing more opportunistic, there is nothing weaker, than a leader of the opposition who stands here opposed to a change to the tax system which on Saturday he is going to be publicly supporting. There is nothing more pathetic than a leader of the opposition who when Keating was running the Treasury was in favour of tax reform but now is opposed to it because he thinks there is a grubby vote in it. This is the politics of opportunism. This is the politics of doing what you think is good for the Labor Party and putting to the side the national interest. This is the political party that claims to be in favour of looking after workers but does not have what it takes to stand for a policy that actually will deliver real benefits to workers.

speech.para: As the new tax system comes into operation on 1 July it brings to a culmination a campaign of genuine reform of Australia's taxation system that has been going on for decades. I have been publicly supporting this campaign to fix up Australia's tax system for over 10 years. For me personally, when the new tax system comes into operation on 1 July it will be one of those occasions when you say to yourself, `Well, for all the ups and downs of politics, it is worth making a contribution when you know you have made your small contribution to ensuring that Australia has a better tax system.' It is not as if there has been an intellectual debate about whether or not this is a good idea. This has been a good idea for over 20 years.

talk.start.para: —Oh!

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition scoffs. Quite frankly, how pathetic. This is really the low of the low. He himself was a senior member of the former Labor government when that government at an earlier time was in fact in favour of this reform.
—I wasn't.
—You were a member of that government.
—I wasn't a member of it. Get your facts right.
—In 1985 you may not have been here, but you were a member of a Labor government that supported tax reform because they knew it was right. This is what Paul Keating had to say back in 1985:

quote.para: It is now well recognised that the Australian tax system is unfair. It is also widely appreciated that it encourages inefficiency and is extraordinarily complex. Clearly there is a need for action, for reform. We must stop dealing with symptoms. The tax laws are in need of radical surgery. We must commit ourselves to three propositions: the tax base must be broadened; the ideals of tax reform require us to commit ourselves to lower marginal tax rates; and we should attempt to use the tax system to solve every problem that looks too difficult to solve in some other way.

There are three main advantages of consumption tax. First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly ridden wholesale sales tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions and fails to tax the services sector. Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose. Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax, and that provides a useful net dividend for distribution to the rest of the community.

speech.para: Those words said 15 years ago are still true. Some people ask whether the pace of change is too fast in Australia. I say it has been too slow. In fact, go back to the 1970s: it was quite clear we needed to reform the tax system. These fraudulent claims we have from the opposition that this system is not fair are easily refuted by the facts—facts which they themselves have publicly advanced. This is what I find so galling about this campaign. Even the Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows what a fraudulent campaign he is running. It is sickening to the body politic that you have a significant issue where we genuinely need change—and anybody who has ever looked at the tax system knows that fact—and you find somebody trying to score a cheap political point. It is really pathetic.

When I was looking through some notes last night for what I might say today—I thought it was going to be a censure motion but they sort of ran out of puff during question time—I pulled this out of the Australian from back in 1996. This is what they said back in 1996:

quote.para: According to the bureau—

speech.para: that is the Australian Bureau of Statistics—

quote.para: the poorest 10 per cent of households were paying out as much as 14.2 per cent of their income as indirect taxes in 1984 when the comparable figure among the top 10 per cent of households was as low as 6.3.

speech.para: This is in respect basically of wholesale sales tax and other indirect taxes. People on low incomes were paying 14 per cent of their income in indirect taxes, but people on high incomes were paying only 6.3 per cent. That was 1984. Then it says:

quote.para: A decade later the lowest income group laboured under a more severe indirect tax burden, with 22 per cent of their income being paid out as indirect taxes in 1993-94.

speech.para: And at the top end, for the people on the high incomes, they enjoyed a reduced indirect tax impost at some 5.7 per cent of their household incomes. It says:

quote.para: The average indirect tax burden among all households had barely moved between the early 80s and the early 90s, rising only slightly from 8.3 to 8.5 per cent.

speech.para: So the total amount collected had not changed much, it is just that the people on low incomes were paying a lot more. It continues:

quote.para: The period under study stretches from before the former Labor government pushed for and then abandoned the broad-based indirect tax proposal in 1985 to the Coalition's failed 1993 election campaign bid for a new GST.

During the period examined by the ABS, the overall burden of indirect taxes remained almost constant but its impact was shifted significantly to hit the pockets of low income households more severely.

speech.para: The Labor Party says this system is unfair. Let us stand back and look at the system we are getting rid of. This system we are getting rid of is not just unfair today but is becoming progressively more unfair on low income people. It is a regressive tax system.

Just to highlight the inanity of Labor's campaign, having been in favour of this in 1985, when we advocated it in 1993 they opposed it. Then, after the election, what did they do? They had promised income tax cuts; that was their sort of populist push. They abandoned the income tax cuts and, having opposed the GST, they put up indirect taxes. In other words, over that 10-year period indirect taxation had become more regressive and when we tried to fix it the Labor Party ran a populist campaign against us and then they themselves made it worse again. That is one of the worst examples of political hypocrisy I have ever known. There are a lot of things the Labor Party say which I do not mind putting up with—it is part of the game, I suppose—but this was the lowest of the low. For the last 10 years they have known that this country needed sensible reform and they have just gone for the cheap political point every last time—the lowest campaign we have ever seen sustained in Australian politics. Even today the Leader of the Opposition starts with a sickening deception. Do you know what that deception is?

talk.start.para: —Like petrol won't go up?
—You really are pathetic. You are a pathetic creature.
—Pathetic? The Prime Minister said it!

—You really are one of the lowest we have seen as a shadow Treasurer, because you are not prepared to actually debate the issues. I will tell you why he was deceptive when he started today: he omitted to state a simple fact—that is, in the 1998 election campaign we went to the Australian people and said to them honestly, `This is what we're going to do.'
—Honestly?
—Yes, we told people what we were going to do.
—No, you didn't.

—We had the guts to tell people that this tax system needed to change for the sake of future generations. We had the guts to tell people that we should stop taxing our exports, because it was costing us jobs and meant that we were exporting jobs. We had the guts to tell people that you cannot run a tax system where the average person is paying 50 cents in the dollar for every hour of overtime. We had the guts to stand up and say that it is about time we stopped penalising Australian producers and giving a tax benefit to imports. In all my public career people have come up and said to me, `Why is it that great Australian manufacturing names have closed their operations and gone offshore and started importing stuff back into Australia?' One of the reasons which everybody has known—even the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has known—is that we have been crazy enough in this country to run a tax system that says, `If you are an importer, we give you effectively a tax advantage, but, if you want to give somebody a job in Australia, we are going to impose a tax disadvantage on you compared to imports.' No-one in their right mind would support that system except the Labor Party, because they think there is a cheap political point that they can make against a party advocating sensible reform.

speech.para: Today I want to pay tribute particularly to John Howard. You can go all the way back to 1978, when he was the Treasurer. He at least knew what had to be done and he was prepared to do something about it. He went to the cabinet and said that there ought to be a review of the tax system. Ultimately, the idea was rejected in 1979. But after the 1980 election he went again and said, `I think there ought to be a review of the tax system,' and he announced one. It was rejected in February 1981. But did he give in? Did he say, `Oh, well, I've been beaten so I'll just give up'? No. He knew it was in the country's best interests, so he persevered and in 1984 it was part of the coalition's policy. People often say that the 1993 Fightback policy was the first time anybody had advocated a new tax going into a federal election. That is not actually right; it was first advocated in 1984. The reason it was not a big political issue in the campaign in 1984 was that Hawkie was going to have a summit and he could not rule anything out. That is the reason it was not a big issue in 1984: he knew that it was an issue that they would need to address. When it came to the summit and the time leading up to the summit, what a contrast the behaviour of the Prime Minister was compared to the behaviour today of the opposition.

talk.start.para: —What he said back in 1985, when he had that political temptation which you have fallen for—which you have grabbed with both hands, I should say—when he was presented with the political temptation of running a scare campaign about a new tax on booties and the like, was this:

quote.para: I think the public is tired of automatic opposition.

speech.para: He recognised the scare campaign that was then available to us—I was here then—and he said:

quote.para: It is very easy to talk about a 15 per cent tax on babies' booties but parts of what the government has in mind are very much in line with what we have been advocating.

speech.para: And I do not mind saying that it was politically difficult for him not to run a scare campaign against Keating's proposal then, because there were some on our own side that were urging him to do it and were criticising him for the fact that he did not take a golden opportunity to make the most of his political opportunities. Why didn't he? Because he knew what the national interest was; he knew that this country one day would have to face the fact that we could no longer have a tax system that was introduced in 1930 as a temporary measure and which virtually every other country in the Western world—in fact, in the world, full stop—has since abandoned except Botswana and Swaziland. But Botswana has recently announced they are going to have a GST.

talk.start.para: —It may not be original but I tell you what: it is a reality. When you stand in a moment and when your deception starts, what you ought to say is, `I stand to speak on behalf of the Australian Labor Party and the people of Swaziland, who still think it is a good idea.' When you have your national conference at the end of July, the only people who will be advocating a wholesale sales tax will be the Labor Party and the Swaziland government. You ought to get a guest speaker out and get them to tell you how great it is and how keen you would be to go back to it.

speech.para: People like Neil Warren, David Voss and the small business consultative committee—many people in the community—have worked for this. They have worked for it because this is in the national interest. This is the biggest income tax cut in Australia's history taking billions of dollars off our businesses, which will mean more jobs and more investment. I am proud to be a member of a government that knows what is in the country's best interests, is prepared to make things happen and is prepared to make changes for the national good so that our children and grandchildren will grow up in an economy which is modern, which is competitive and which will give them a chance of a job and opportunities in the future. This opposition is a national disgrace, the worst opposition we have had since World War II. It deserves to be condemned. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It has been another day of continuing farce and chaos on the GST—farce from France, and where is the Treasurer defending it? We saw him over at the OECD ringing his little bell to tell people who he was—`I'm Peter Costello; I'm Treasurer of Australia'—but where is he here? We have got a bell for him today, and we challenge him to come in. It is a bell with a dog on a tuckerbox—and well may it be, because it will be his epitaph. This is a Treasurer and this is a Prime Minister who are a disgrace to their office, because they have proposed a tax on which they have deceived people all around the country and they will not come into this place to defend it.

speech.para: We saw the Treasurer today say, `What do I have to do to get a question?' The answer is: don't go to Paris. Stay here. Don't expect to come back on this day and to be asked a question, when you were not here for a week to deal with the mess that you left. The mess you left began on Thursday night, as you were sitting in 1A sipping French champagne on the Qantas flight out, when you hand-passed your petrol decision to your Acting Treasurer, John Fahey—a decision which involved the Treasurer breaching his commitment to the Australian people. I will remind the House as to what that was in relation to the price of petrol: a guarantee he and the Prime Minister gave that the GST would not increase the price of petrol. This was the mechanism by which they were going to deliver it; this was the Treasurer on 25 November last year:

quote.para: ... when you equalise out the tax arrangements, you get the same amount of revenue anyway. The excise comes down and the 10 per cent goes back up. It is the same amount of tax.

speech.para: Do you understand the words `same amount of tax'? On Thursday night on his way out of the country, the Treasurer reduced the excise by 6.7c a litre but put the GST up by 8.2c a litre. Some motorists will fill their tanks to capacity on Friday and will try to keep away from petrol bowsers until their tanks run out. But, come Saturday, when their petrol runs out every motorist in this country will be paying 1½c a litre on every litre of petrol purchased forever, courtesy of this government and its broken promise—a government that cannot be trusted, a government whose credibility is in tatters, a government whose Treasurer and Prime Minister will not come into this House.

Today the continuing farce and chaos associated with this GST was evidenced by the fact that the government allowed privacy to be hacked in this country. On Saturday the GST will hack into families. Saturday is the beginning of the GST. John Howard wants you to think that it is the end of it, and we even heard the Deputy Prime Minister say that we will be out of time on Saturday in relation to the GST. Do not believe them: it is only the beginning. As it is the beginning, where will this courageous Prime Minister who deceived himself back into office be? He will be flying to London. So we have a Treasurer in Paris in the final week of implementation with chaos all around the place and a Prime Minister heading off to London—heading off for celebrations for our Federation which should be held here. We have a Prime Minister fleeing the country because of the mess that he has created.

We got a little bit of a curtain-raiser today as to how this GST will apply from Saturday. The Prime Minister tried to organise a stunt in a liquor store in Canberra, of all places. We know he is fond of liquor stores because he has invested in a large new fridge for Kirribilli House, courtesy of the taxpayers, with a padlock on it. So he likes buying it but not sharing it, this Prime Minister of ours! He was at the liquor store today essentially to try to prove this point: when you buy liquor in a bottle shop, the price difference pre-GST and post-GST will be minuscule. There he was, going down the aisle and picking up ordinary workers' drinks like Johnnie Walker Red Label or Black Label whisky—I am not too sure which one it was in his case. He went past the wine of his staffer Mr O'Leary's brother, despite the fact that his office likes looking after brothers! The Prime Minister and his staffer are into brotherly love—fraternité, they call it in France, Treasurer. When the Prime Minister got the post-GST receipt, he said, `This looks good—it is $20 less.' The trouble is, in the first instance they had rung up the Johnnie Walker whisky twice. When that was taken account of, the price went up by $4. The Prime Minister's problem is that Johnny Howard got tripped up on the Johnnie Walker! What he proved today is what every Australian family will prove on Saturday and thereafter: the GST just does not add up for them. Just as it did not add up for the Prime Minister, the GST will not add up for Australian families.

I issue another challenge to the Prime Minister today: is he going to turn up to a pub on Saturday with people drinking ordinary beer, which is going up between eight and nine per cent because the government have doubled the excise on beer? The government were not content with just putting it up on petrol; they have doubled it on beer. Will he be in the pub, showing how he has dishonoured that promise? His promise on ordinary beer was that it would go up by only 1.9 per cent; it is going up almost four times that, and people will know it on Saturday.

But it is not the only thing they will know on Saturday, for which today was just the curtain-raiser. Come Saturday, this is how the GST will affect your first day. The papers will have GST added to them—in some cases, more than 10 per cent. When you go to that hole in the wall to get your cash out, you may find that the bank fees have increased—if not on Saturday, then subsequently. Drop the kids off at the local pool and you will have to pay more money to get them in. If you are dropping them off for music lessons, that will be copping the GST as well. If you have got the gardener coming in, then the GST is on that. The light lunch on the way to the afternoon entertainment will also have GST on it. Footy tickets have the full 10 per cent on them in Melbourne, and the movies have about the same.

If they go on public transport, that is going up far more than the government ever let on. If you have the humble meat pie in the afternoon, that is going to be taxed and, if you have that beer, it is going up by four times what the Prime Minister said. On the way home, you pick up the video that has the GST on it and the takeaway food that cops the GST. You sink back into your chair at home and add it up, and you say to John Howard, `I'm not thanking you, Prime Minister.' You might remember that is what he said on the 7.30 Report on 8 February: `But in the end, the public will thank us for doing what is right for Australia.' Well, this tax is not right for ordinary working people, because the government has deceived them about it. I make this point: it does not stop on Saturday. As you are sitting back there, with the electricity and the gas on, the new GST meter is ticking over—because all those charges, whenever you have to pay the bill subsequently, will cop the GST. Electricity, gas, insurance and repairs on the family home are going to cop the 10 per cent.

That is just people as consumers. What about small business? Saturday is not the end of it; it is just the beginning. For the rest of their lives, they will be John Howard's tax collectors. For the rest of their lives, they will be collecting the GST. And this from the Prime Minister who says, `It'll be all over Saturday.' This is why we have said this is an issue that will slow burn, because this impact will continue to be felt. What we have done to date is expose the deceit. It has been exposed on so many fronts that the government is too embarrassed to come in and defend it. Let no-one believe that this is an issue that is going to go away on Saturday. The sky may not fall in on Saturday. Chicken Little may survive, but it will be a slow cooking Chicken Little. If it is cooked and hot then it cops the GST but if it cools down it does not! So out with the thermometers to test where this is going, because the slow burn and the temperature check is going to be the basis upon which this community judges this government, a government that has deceived its way into office, that has made an unfair tax and created chaos in the process. It is a government that should be condemned for it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What we have heard today from this carping Labor opposition is a bit like a dog between four trees, because it does not have a leg to stand on. The Labor Party know we need this tax reform and they have not had the guts to support a reform that we all know the country needs and demands. They have come in here, day after day, week after week and month after month, opposing what we all know will produce growth in our economy, fairness to all groups in Australia and a choice for all Australians. Will they get rid of it? Of course not, because they know it is the right thing for Australia but they will not admit it. Four Senate committees of this parliament that sat for four months each for a total of 16 months of inquiry into this tax reform showed that there was not one group of Australians, apart from the tax dodgers, that would be worse off or adversely affected—as this childish motion from the Labor Party suggests. In other words, every Australian group would be better off as a result of this courageous tax reform. Families will be better off, farmers will be better off and business will be better off. Yet the Labor Party, with no thought for the future of this country, no plan for the future and no idea where they are going, can only get up here under a weak leader to oppose what we all know is good for this country.

speech.para: As a new member of this parliament, it has been sickening for me to see the political games that the Labor Party plays in the name of opposition. As a new member of parliament, it has been sickening for me to see the hypocrisy and humbug shown by this Labor Party, not only on this issue but on many others before this parliament. The Labor Party has been a disgrace and will get its just deserts. We could all have played games on financial deregulation when we were in opposition but we did not, because we knew it was in the best interests of this country. We could have played games on tariff reform when we were in opposition but we did not, because we knew it was in the best interests of this country. We could have played games when the Labor Party proposed the GST in 1985 but we did not, because we were honest about what is good for this country. Yet here we have the Labor Party which, in opposition, plays games because it is opportunistic and does not care about the future of this country. The message I get from listening to the community is that they are sick of this Labor Party and frustrated with an outdated and unfair tax system and anticipate the arrival of a new tax system which will bring about real and beneficial changes.

We all know that some prices will rise, some prices will fall and others will stay about the same. Do we ever hear about that from the Labor Party? Of course not. We all know that every Australian taxpayer will receive a tax cut to help them through the expected cost of living increase. Do we ever hear about that from the Labor Party? Of course not. We all know that we will be delivering the largest tax cuts in Australia's history—some $12 billion in tax cuts—for every taxpayer in Australia. Do we ever hear about that from the Labor Party? Of course not. We all know that and we also know that we will be delivering extra social security that outstrips the cost of living increase by at least another two per cent, making all those on pensions at least two per cent better off. But do we hear that from the Labor Party? Of course not. We all know that we will deliver up to $2,000 to self-funded retirees. But do we hear that from the Labor Party? Of course not. We all know that we will deliver $7,000 to first home buyers. But do we hear that from the Labor Party? Of course not. All we hear from the Labor Party is pink shirts, cereal packets and hot pies, without mentioning that those minor items benefit from the new tax system by ridding us of Labor's wholesale sales tax system that is embedded into the costs of both production and delivery.

Here is the crux of those reforms, Mr Speaker. I can tell you and those sitting opposite that the people in country areas already know how delivery costs will come down in the country. We know that when 24c a litre comes off the cost of diesel it will result in cheaper transport costs for our goods that we produce and cheaper transport costs for all the products that we buy. The reduced transport costs will filter through our economy, and that will benefit all of us.

The savings do not stop there. All registered businesses in Australia will get their fuel 10 per cent cheaper with their GST input credits. It is worth remembering that all business, all employees and all employers will benefit from this tax system. But it will not only be on their fuel. No longer will they have to pay Labor's 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on batteries, or Labor's 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on tyres, or Labor's 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on spare parts. The average truck rig now spends $1,700 a week paying Labor's wholesale sales tax. Most of that is saved under A New Tax System.

Cars will be cheaper by getting rid of Labor's wholesale sales tax on cars—that is, a 22 per cent wholesale sales tax for the honour of buying a new car. From the time the metal is mined to the rubber for the tyres extracted, to the paint on the vehicles and the paperwork produced and so on, there are about 20,000 transactions in the production of a car. Labor's wholesale sales tax was imposed on most of these transactions. But that will all be removed now. This clearly shows how Labor's wholesale sales tax system is a tax on production and a tax on employment.

We know that a tax on consumption, where people have a choice, is a much fairer system. We remove $11 billion of taxes off the shoulders of our exporters. We remove $4,500 billion of taxes off the shoulders of our farmers. We remove $3.5 billion in excise off the shoulders of our transport industry and $12 billion in personal income tax off the shoulders of our taxpayers. We know the average farm will be better off by at least $7,000 each year. I am proud to represent the farmers in Australia. I am privileged to represent many farmers in my seat of Barker. We know that the transport industry, which is so important to the economy in Barker and the rest of Australia, will benefit from these tax reforms.

My electorate of Barker, which covers some 54,000 square kilometres, is the third most rural seat in Australia. Voters in my electorate will remember that the Labor Party wants to keep the present overtaxed regime for transport operators. They will remember that Labor wants to stop most Australians from receiving our tax cuts. They will remember that Labor wants to keep our overtaxed marine operators. They will remember that Labor wants to keep our overtaxed rail operators. They will remember that Labor wants to overtax our country citizens. They will remember that Labor wants to take away the increases in benefits that we will deliver to our less well-off citizens. They will also remember that Labor wants to stop us delivering cheaper food to all our citizens as a result of the cost savings and cheaper transport.

Labor have become irrelevant to political debate in Australia. Labor have become the fairies at the bottom of the garden, a party without policy, a party without principles and a party without practical answers. The Labor humbug knows no end on this issue. They know that by the time we sit next, in August, this Labor humbug will account for nothing because Australia will wake up this Saturday and know that the sky has not fallen in. One wonders if the Labor Party in Australia asked their Labour counterparts in New Zealand why they introduced the GST system. Have they asked the Labour Prime Minister of New Zealand, Helen Clark, why she will not roll back the GST? Have the Australian Labor Party asked the British Labour Party Prime Minister why he does not want to roll back the GST equivalent, the VAT? Have the Australian Labor Party sent all their tax policy makers, if they have any, to Swaziland, the only country in the world that still wants to keep a wholesale sales tax system? Even their former like-minded colleagues in Botswana can now see the sense of a GST type system.

We all know that the only labour party in the world that wants to roll back the GST is the Australian Labor Party. The Labor Party hate the GST so much that if they get the chance of government they will keep the GST. They conveniently forget that they condemn the Australian workers to high inflation, high interest rates, high unemployment and lower living standards. They also conveniently forget that they condemn the Australian worker to 23 per cent interest rates and 17 per cent housing loan rates.

The outcomes from this government prove that we look after the worker far better than do the Labor Party, and we are proud of it. The outcomes from this government prove that we manage the economy and the worker's welfare, and we are proud of it. We are the only people in this parliament with the vision for the future, the courage to implement it and the people to support it.
