talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Navy Ammunitioning Facility, Twofold Bay, NSW.

speech.para: The Department of Defence proposes to construct a Royal Australian Navy ammunitioning facility at Twofold Bay near Eden, New South Wales, in the electorate of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Nairn, to support ammunitioning and de-ammunitioning of ships of the Royal Australian Navy. The proposed ammunitioning facility will provide for the Royal Australian Navy's long-term east coast ammunitioning requirements following the closure of the previous arrangements in Sydney Harbour in December last year. The facilities at Homebush closed to make way for the Sydney 2000 Olympics.

The Commonwealth-owned port at Point Wilson is currently being used for interim ammunitioning of Royal Australian Navy ships until permanent arrangements are in place. Point Wilson would not be suitable for ammunitioning Navy ships in the longer term due to the additional steaming time from Sydney Harbour and the Navy exercise area and associated costs, and the requirement to upgrade the Point Wilson infrastructure. Point Wilson is nearing the end of its economic life and would require a considerable upgrade to extend its life for 30 years. The cost of upgrading Point Wilson was estimated to be $72.27 million compared with $40 million for the proposed facility at Twofold Bay. The Department of Defence investigated numerous locations on the east coast to find a site that is operationally and technically feasible and environmentally suitable. Following that investigation, a detailed proposal has been developed for Twofold Bay and an environmental impact statement has been completed.

An environmental impact statement was prepared for the proposal to meet the requirements of the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979. The environmental impact statement was exhibited for public comment in November-December last year. A supplementary report to the draft environmental impact statement incorporating the issues arising from public submissions was submitted to Environment Australia. The environmental impact statement demonstrates that there are no environmental impediments to proceeding with the proposal and that the proposed facility can be constructed and operated so as to have minimal environmental impacts. The environmental impact statement has received clearance from the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill.

The Twofold Bay site meets technical and environmental requirements and is operationally and economically preferable to Point Wilson. The wharf at Twofold Bay will be used by the Royal Australian Navy for between 45 and 70 days per year and will be available for commercial use the rest of the time. The state and local governments have indicated strong support for the proposal as commercial use of the wharf is expected to create employment opportunities in the Eden area. The main components of the facility are a wharf, jetty and a land-based depot. The New South Wales government is planning to develop an area adjacent to the jetty head for commercial stockpiles of timber products and other compatible industries should the proposal proceed.

I would also like, in the chamber, to recognise the strong support for this proposal given by my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Nairn. The estimated out-turn cost of the proposal is $40 million and, subject to parliamentary approval, construction will start early in the year 2001 and be completed by early to mid-2002.

In its report, the committee has recommended that this project proceed. The Department of Defence agrees with the recommendations of the committee and has advised that the recommendations set out in the environmental assessment report will be implemented. At this stage, I would like to thank the committee for its support and I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I also would like to speak in support of this motion for this particular project to be carried out at Twofold Bay in Eden in my electorate. Back in 1996 when I was elected as the member for Eden-Monaro, this project was going to Point Wilson in Victoria following a decision made by the previous Labor government. Many people from the region believed that Point Wilson was not the appropriate location for this particular facility. Certainly there has always been strong support for the project to be in the Eden region, a more sensible location given that all of the ships will be involved in ammunitioning and de-ammunitioning trials off the coast of New South Wales much closer to Eden than the very long distance that they would have to go to Point Wilson.

speech.para: Fortunately, in the way the parliament works here, major projects such as this are scrutinised by the Public Works Committee. That was done in this case. The Public Works Committee at the time—which was chaired by the now Minister for Forestry and Conservation, the member for O'Connor, Mr Tuckey, and the deputy chair, the member for Throsby, Mr Hollis—saw that Point Wilson was not appropriate. It was obvious from Navy support as well that a more logical location was Eden. The committee consequently reported that Point Wilson should not be the location for this project and that Eden would be a more appropriate location. Consequently, the Public Works Committee—now chaired by the honourable member for Pearce, Mrs Moylan, with the member for Throsby still a member but not the deputy chair any more—went through the processes of public hearings, et cetera. Also, a very extensive environmental impact study was carried out. Consequently, we had the report to the parliament a couple of days ago recommending that this project should proceed.

There is very strong support for this project in the region; there always has been. It was seen as an appropriate project from the point of view of not only the Navy but also the community, which was very interested in a multipurpose wharf being constructed as part of the project. The wharf will be needed between only 45 and 70 days a year, as indicated by the parliamentary secretary in his motion. That means the wharf will be available for a very extensive part of the year for other, commercial, activities.

A number of studies have been done prior to Defence making this decision. It is always very difficult in some areas to get new projects up when the facility needed for them is not there. The fact that this wharf can be built as part of the Defence facility will activate a lot more interest in the Eden area as a potential export location, and not only there, but right throughout the south-east of New South Wales and parts of Victoria. The nearest locations for a reasonable deepwater port are a long way to the north, in Port Kembla or Sydney, or a long way to the south, down from Melbourne. Having that multipurpose wharf is a great excitement for the region because it could stimulate all sorts of new activity.

We have already seen a number of applications lodged under the Eden Region Adjustment Package—which was put in place after the closure of the Heinz cannery just one year ago—that look towards the potential of a multipurpose wharf. I think that is very exciting for the region. In fact, we announced last week some successful applicants under the Eden Region Adjustment Package, which was well received in this region. The announcement this week by the Public Works Committee and now this expediency motion in the parliament to get this project under way will be well received right throughout my electorate, particularly in the Eden region. I am very pleased that after four years of pretty hard work by a lot of people, we come to this day—

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Parliamentary Secretary. I certainly have worked hard on this, but I have had great support from the community and many other people. I thank all the members of the Public Works Committee very much for their support on this. Defence have also done an excellent job in putting together this project. I congratulate them on it. It is a great day. We thank you very much and look forward to this project getting under way as soon as possible.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Defence Science and Technology Organisation Rationalisation Project, Melbourne.

speech.para: The Department of Defence proposes to rationalise and consolidate the Melbourne facilities of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation is part of the Department of Defence. It conducts research and advises on the application of science and technology best suited to Australia's defence and security needs.

The Aeronautical and Maritime Research Laboratory is one of the two major research laboratories in the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, and currently operates from a number of sites throughout Australia. Its two principal sites are both located in Melbourne—one at Fishermens Bend and the other at Maribyrnong. The current dual site arrangement presents significant operational and cost inefficiencies and also impacts on the quality and the efficiency of the research and development activities undertaken by the laboratory. This proposal will lead to a reduction in operational costs and enhanced effectiveness of the research program. At the same time, it will allow for the reduction in property holdings by a rationalisation to the Fishermens Bend site.

The first main component of the project is relocation and consolidation of existing capabilities. The project includes new and refurbished facilities to relocate and to consolidate the following existing research activities: maritime platforms, combatant protection and nutrition, and science corporate management. The second is integrated technologies. The proposal also includes initiatives which result in integrated common technologies across the following areas: nuclear, biological and chemical protection investigation, mechanical testing and advanced composites fabrication.

The third is other enhanced capabilities. The following enhanced capabilities are also proposed as part of the AMRL investment: new airframes and engines division research thrusts; large scale maritime and aircraft structures testing; on site conference capability; thermal testing; and structural component holding. The estimated out-turn cost of the proposal is $56.171 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction will start in the middle of the year and be completed some 2½ years later. In its report, the committee has recommended that this project proceed. The Department of Defence agrees with the recommendations of the committee. I would like to thank the committee for its support and to commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak on this motion as the recommendation of the committee to rationalise these two sites does significantly affect my electorate. The electorate of Gellibrand is home to the Maribyrnong site of AMRL. Certainly I am very sad to be speaking to this motion today because it does signal the end of a very long history that DSTO has had with the Maribyrnong site and with my electorate of Gellibrand. I am also sad because it does, of course, mean that there are large numbers of jobs that will be leaving my electorate, and that is something that has been ongoing through the Defence rationalisation. At times in the history of the electorate of Gellibrand there have been thousands of people employed by the defence department in various ways, and we will be sad to lose some of those last few jobs in the area. In these circumstances I would like to take this opportunity to publicly acknowledge those thousands of people who have worked over many years at the Maribyrnong site, particularly some of the absolutely great scientists who are known to have come from the Maribyrnong site and AMRL. I think it is appropriate that I take this opportunity to record our appreciation of their service.

speech.para: I am, however, aware that the committee has made a unanimous decision, which they regard as being in the best interests of the nation as a whole. While there will be some pain from the decision in my electorate, I know that a sensible recommendation has been made for the future of DSTO. I am very pleased that a number of recommendations I made in a submission to the committee have been picked up in the report of the committee, including a recognition of the great historical importance of this site and its significance within the development of defence in Australia, particularly within the area. I would note as well that the report does not link any rationalisation that will occur as a result of the government's acceptance of these recommendations to the sale of the site. There is no earmarking for use of the money from the future sale of this site. I think it is important for the future because, obviously, there will be a debate about how this site should be developed and where the proceeds or part of the proceeds of the sale should go.

Just briefly, because I know we do not have a lot of time, it does mean that the question of the decontamination of the whole Defence estate at Maribyrnong and its future sale is growing closer. The specific recommendations that the committee picked up as a result of my submission and that of the city of Maribyrnong are that the extensive consultation required for the sale of such property should commence and that they consult widely with the community, with council and, obviously, with me as a representative of the area. But a very important recommendation I am pleased the government has indicated it will pick up is the encouragement of the defence department to engage a heritage architect to survey the historical, natural and indigenous aspects, including the industrial history, of this site. I urge the government to instruct the department to do this as quickly as possible because, although the sale of this site will not be for some time, significant planning is required and I think the Commonwealth has an extensive role to play in preparing the site for sale. We know that there is still one remaining organisation that employs a few hundred people at the site. That number will reduce over the coming months. I urge the government to take account of the view that the site as a whole has great significance, that it needs to be treated as a whole and that it undertakes the heritage study and a number of other issues that the committee has picked up as quickly as possible to make sure that, when the sale occurs, there has been proper consultation and a detailed process.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Mr SLIPPER,MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: RAAF Base Edinburgh, Redevelopment Stage 1, Adelaide.

speech.para: The Department of Defence proposes to undertake a redevelopment in the technical area at RAAF Base Edinburgh, near Adelaide in South Australia. The most significant role for RAAF Base Edinburgh is to support the maritime patrol group, which operates the P3 Orion maritime patrol and reconnaissance aircraft. The base also provides guidelines technical support for the aircraft research and development unit. The proposed scope of works is in direct support of this role and comprises several elements.

New facilities for the aircraft research unit, known as ARDU, are proposed. The role of this unit is to extend the capabilities of Australian Defence Force aerospace systems. Tasks undertaken are mainly in the advanced technology area and entail applied research, engineering development, test and evaluation and electronic warfare operational support. Many of these activities it undertakes are in facilities that were constructed in the 1940s. They are not suitable for the function or are remote from the aircraft hangar and are in urgent need of replacement. In addition, it is proposed to provide aircraft shelters for six aircraft, additional electrical power in an existing aircraft hangar, some additional workshop and shelter facilities and relocation of a test rig. The progression of this element of the works will enable the disposal of Defence property and would lead to efficiencies by co-locating the unit near its hangar and its client base.

A new logistics facility is proposed. This will accommodate warehousing and administrative functions for procurement, stock control and other functions in support of defence units in the state of South Australia. The administrative area will accommodate some 72 personnel, and the warehouse will be some 6,300 square metres in area. The proposed new facility is to be constructed in the technical area of Edinburgh, where the high use clients are located. The facilities will replace an old, existing warehouse that is located off base and the controlling administrative facilities, which are also remote from the main client base. The provision of these facilities will reduce leasing costs and lead to efficiencies by the collocation of personnel and the facilities they use.

New facilities are proposed for the Marine Patrol Logistics Management Squadron, which comprises some 142 personnel. This unit is responsible for the logistics management of the P3 Orion weapons system as well as aircraft life support logistics management for all Australian Defence Force life support systems. The unit is currently located in facilities constructed in 1942 and has expanded into temporary prefabricated buildings. These facilities are also remote from the technical area and their main client base, which includes personnel to be accommodated in the proposed new logistics complex. To gain the benefits of shared areas, it is proposed to co-locate this unit in a common logistics facility. An upgrade of the engineering services infrastructure, mainly in the technical area of the base, is proposed. The basic engineering services at RAAF Base Edinburgh date from the time each area was developed, generally in the 1940s and the 1950s.

Although some improvements have taken place, the systems are in need of replacement as they have reached their capacity and are increasingly unreliable, and major repairs and replacement of deteriorated systems are necessary. Additional change rooms and ablution facilities are also proposed to address current shortfalls in the general technical area. It is proposed to demolish vacated facilities, many containing asbestos. These facilities are surplus to requirements. The estimated out-turn cost of the proposal is $37.7 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction will commence in mid-2001 and will be completed by April 2003. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Mr SLIPPER,MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Fitout of new leased premises for the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Belconnen, ACT.

speech.para: The Australian Bureau of Statistics proposes to fit out new leased premises at Belconnen, in the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Bureau of Statistics is Australia's official statistical agency. Its mission is to assist and encourage informed decision making, research and discussion within government and the community. It provides a high quality, objective and responsive national service.

The central office of the Australian Bureau of Statistics has been housed in the Cameron Offices complex at Belconnen in the Australian Capital Territory since completion of the building in the mid-1970s. More than 20 years experience as tenants in the building has revealed inherent limitations in building layouts, and shortcomings in the building fabric, services and amenities. A proposal to improve the short-term situation of the Australian Bureau of Statistics was developed and submitted to the Public Works Committee before the government decided to secure new accommodation for the ABS when selling Belconnen properties in the Commonwealth property estate for redevelopment by the private sector.

In December 1997, my colleague the Minister for Finance and Administration announced that the Commonwealth would market test the refurbishment of the Benjamin Offices, the demolition of the Cameron Offices and the provision of new or refurbished accommodation for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Department of Finance and Administration made a public call for expressions of interest from potential purchasers and developers interested in purchasing the Belconnen and Cameron offices site, redeveloping the sites to provide modern office accommodation for existing tenants, or redeveloping the existing sites to provide facilities other than office accommodation in the Belconnen precinct.

The outcome of a lengthy selection process was the acceptance by the Department of Finance and Administration of a development proposal that will include the partial demolition of the Cameron Offices and the construction of a new purpose designed building for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Australian Bureau of Statistics will be the sole tenant in the new building, with an initial lease term of 15 years and options to twice renew the lease for two further terms of five years. The proposal covers the fit-out of the leased premises as offices for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Approximately 35,300 square metres of floor space will be fitted out to commercial office standards and the special operating requirements of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The accommodation will provide the staff of the central office of the Australian Bureau of Statistics with a work environment that is more functionally effective and space efficient.

The project developer has provided the Australian Bureau of Statistics with a guaranteed maximum price for the fit-out, based on the fit-out brief, of $22.8 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, this fit-out project will be fully integrated with the construction of the new building, under the management of the project developer, to maximise cost savings and to minimise construction time. Fit-out works will commence on site in December 2000 for completion in March 2002. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Mr SLIPPER,MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: CSIRO Energy Centre at Steel River, Newcastle, NSW.

speech.para: The CSIRO proposes to construct a new research laboratory complex to be known as the CSIRO Energy Centre and to be located at Steel River Eco-Industrial Park at Newcastle, in the state of New South Wales. The proposed works will provide new research and support facilities for the CSIRO Division of Energy Technology, capable of accommodating a total of 110 research and support staff. Existing staff will transfer from accommodation at North Ryde and Lucas Heights, also in New South Wales, and new staff will be appointed to expand research activities.

The research resources of the division are presently located on four sites in three states: North Ryde, New South Wales—the division headquarters; Lucas Heights, New South Wales; Pinjarra Hills, Queensland—the Queensland Centre for Advanced Technology; and Clayton, Victoria. The CSIRO proposes to terminate all of the division's operations at the North Ryde site and relocate all activities to the `centre'. Research associated with most of the pilot scale energy projects presently undertaken at Lucas Heights will also be relocated. The establishment of the CSIRO Energy Centre in Newcastle will provide a focal point for research excellence, particularly in the fields of cost competitive and environmentally acceptable coal production, sustainable energy—including energy storage and renewable energy—and the environmental impacts of energy, particularly those associated with greenhouse gas emissions.

The CSIRO Energy Centre will provide a venue for collaboration between the CSIRO, universities—particularly the University of Newcastle—government agencies, resource companies and associated technology suppliers and providers in Australian energy industries. This centre will include chemistry and dry laboratories, equipment and instrument rooms, offices for management, administration and senior research staff, and other research related work areas. Amenities will include a display space highlighting advances in energy technologies, an auditorium, meeting rooms, library and a canteen. It will also incorporate large process bays. These are high, open-plan industrial type buildings for research conducted at a semi-industrial pilot scale. Research support areas such as stores, workshops and sample preparation areas will be provided. The proposed development will also include site works, roadworks, hardstands, car parking, engineering and communication services and landscaping. The CSIRO Energy Centre will uniquely demonstrate leading edge but commercially practical examples of reduction in building energy demand and environmentally realistic energy supply options.

The establishment of the CSIRO Energy Centre in Newcastle will provide benefits to current and potential customers of CSIRO, to the Newcastle region and to CSIRO staff. Customer benefits of the relocation include: better access to world-class facilities for conducting research into energy generation using hybrid energy systems; closer collaboration with existing power generation and coal companies which are located in the Newcastle region; scope to demonstrate the capabilities of new energy technologies and how they can be integrated into existing energy supply systems; and the possibility of working with small and medium companies in a technology park environment at the Steel River site as these companies emerge to develop new products for the sustainable energy market. Benefits to the Newcastle region will be threefold. Economic benefits will consist of the initial construction cost of the buildings and the ongoing direct and multiplier benefits of the salary and operating cost of the division. Social benefits will arise from the jobs created during the construction phase and the injection of a trained work force into the region's growing knowledge economy. Environmental benefits will include the opportunity to demonstrate energy efficient building construction techniques and leading edge energy generation within the same complex. Community consultation with local councillors and residents has been continuous.

A number of community presentations seeking input have been made and further presentations are proposed for August or September. Local councillors, led by the lord mayor, have been extremely supportive of the proposal. Staff benefits will include a new focused working environment and new capabilities, together with lower cost housing, reduced commuting times and increased amenity as a result of the regional environment. Formal consultation has taken place with all staff, the majority of whom are happy to relocate. There has been no vocal dissent from staff. The CSIRO has secured sufficient land on the Steel River Eco-Industrial Park to accommodate its anticipated requirements for the proposal and for further second stage development. The estimated turnout cost of the proposal is $28 million, of which $10 million will be provided as a grant by the New South Wales government. Subject to parliamentary approval, tenders are scheduled to be called in early 2001, with completion of the works by mid-2002.
I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I would like to join with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration in offering my support for this motion to refer this matter to the Public Works Committee. Members will be aware that, in the wake of the termination of steel making in Newcastle, Newcastle's strengths in science and research are becoming more important and certainly more visible. The CSIRO decision to engage itself with the Newcastle community in the lead-up to this decision and the determination to locate their energy centre has been excellent. Newcastle provides a base for the power station industry in New South Wales and, therefore, largely the energy industry. The Newcastle university has extremely strong research skills in energy and related fields, as do other organisations—in particular, of course, the BHP's research centre laboratories. This provides a natural synergy for the CSIRO in establishing its new centre, and I am absolutely confident that this particular facility will have enormous national significance.

speech.para: CSIRO's submission to the Public Works Committee is comprehensive and highlights the matters raised by the parliamentary secretary. It particularly provides a focal point for research excellence in the field of environmentally acceptable fossil fuel research and development, sustainable energy and the environmental impacts of energy. The building will incorporate in a number of forms passive energy features for the conservation of energy, including: optimum orientation for heating and cooling; the maximum use of daylight; high efficiency artificial light fixtures; maximum use of natural ventilation; underfloor airconditioning and low velocity air plenum; variable speed pumps and fans; and dedicated energy management. It is estimated that the energy used by the building will be one-third to a half of that of a conventional building providing the same space. I think that demonstration in itself will be extremely important for the building and housing industries in the years ahead. The building will also incorporate a number of active energy systems ranging from fuel cells to wind turbines, photovoltaic arrays, natural gas turbine and battery power storage. The building will contain, as I have stated, a range of energy features to conserve energy and a range of energy generators of various kinds.

The CSIRO, particularly Mr John Wright and his team, have been excellent in their liaison with my community and the broader community in the Hunter. This project has very strong state government support, as indicated by their financial support. It also has very strong community and local government support. The three tiers of government working together on this project have been laudable and it is a model which we hope to use in future.

In referring the matter to the Public Works Committee, I offer committee members every encouragement to visit Newcastle, to examine the site where this facility will be located. Steel River site has great potential for our national development and this is the first major project going into that park. I am aware that the committee is hardworking with a great deal on its plate, but I am sure they would find a visit to Newcastle interesting. To allow the Newcastle community to express itself in a more formal and closer up sense on this project would be appreciated. It is with great pleasure and a great deal of optimism that I support this motion. I have every confidence in the committee in the work that lies ahead of it.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of mixed residential dwellings at block 87, section 24, Stirling in the Australian Capital Territory.

speech.para: The Defence Housing Authority proposes the construction of 50 mixed residential dwellings in the Canberra suburb of Stirling. The role of the Defence Housing Authority is to provide suitable housing to meet the operational needs of the Australian Defence Force and the requirements of the Department of Defence. The Defence Housing Authority satisfies Defence accommodation requirements by a mixture of spot purchase, direct leasing and development and construction.

At present, Canberra is home to some 1,800 Defence families. Around 1,300 of these families are housed in Defence Housing Authority managed houses with the remainder of the requirement met by use of short-term leases and payment of rental allowance at additional expense to the government. There are few suitable established residences available for `spot' purchase in conveniently located suburbs and the rental market is very tight. The development and construction option is also somewhat constrained. Overall, land supply is limited, particularly in the established suburbs of Canberra.

In recognition of the importance to Canberra of the Defence Housing Authority's investment in housing in the Australian Capital Territory, the ACT government agreed, in December 1999, to offer the Defence Housing Authority an undeveloped site in the suburb of Stirling. The land is well suited to this defence need. The proposal is to develop housing for Defence families in a quality urban design development. These residences will provide the level of amenity suitable for middle to senior ranking officers in a location that is ideally situated to support defence facilities in the ACT.

The development will take the form of a subdivision of a site that will create 50 dwellings comprising a mixture of detached housing, townhouses and courtyard housing. The mix will cater for a range of group rank entitlements and provide a reasonable choice for families with different preferences and lifestyle requirements. The proposed project will have a positive effect on the local economy during the construction period, with up to 150 persons working directly on the site and many more off-site supplying material, plant and equipment. Construction of an additional 50 houses in Stirling will provide a boost for local businesses.

This project will make a contribution to the ACT government's commitment to high quality urban renewal in the older areas of Canberra, where existing social and physical infrastructure would benefit from new families and quality housing. The estimated out-turn cost of the proposal is $11.5 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is expected to commence in October 2000, with completion of the works by the end of June 2001. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —It gives me pleasure to speak on this motion. I will take the opportunity to make a couple of important points in relation to the development. Whilst the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration has not made direct mention of the location of this development in relation to the co-location of Joint Services College in Weston, there is a very distinct connection between the two projects. I have had the pleasure of attending at least one public meeting that I can recall, conducted by the local Weston Creek Community Council earlier this year, where the issue was discussed. The potential for this particular project was outlined to the local community and related very directly to the co-location of the Joint Services College at Weston, a project which I have previously spoken about in this House and have welcomed very warmly from my electorate's point of view.

speech.para: I want to make a couple of points in a constructive way. In my opinion, as the local member, the development is very welcome. I know that discussions that have been held within the local community, in general terms, have been positive but I do need to note for the sake of those people who hold a particular position that there is a small number of local residents who have outlined some concerns, not about the project itself but about some ramifications that could be felt within the local region, particularly in the relationship to road safety and road access to the area. I know that this subject has been brought up in those local community meetings, with some gusto at times.

I would like to point out to the parliamentary secretary—and I am sure it will be carried out—the need for the Commonwealth, through the Defence Housing Authority, to work in close conjunction with the ACT authorities to ensure that, wherever that responsibility falls, the costs lay and the need ends, those particular aspects of the project are attended to to allow a seamless and trouble free adoption of this particular project. It is welcome. Weston Creek, where Stirling is located, is an area that has been there for some years now, and the injection of families and economy through a housing development of this kind is obviously going to be very welcome. I know that the local schools in the area are not at all unhappy to see this happening. I am sure that it is safe to say with no risk that the local small businesses are also going to be very happy to see a project of this kind undertaken. I am sure that those people who are welcoming it, as I am, are doing it in the same light as they did when the Joint Services College announcement was made. I would like to reiterate that there are some, to us maybe minor but to the people who live there relatively major, considerations that need to be worked on in relation to road access and road safety. I do not know whether the Joint Public Works Committee are going to have the opportunity to visit the area to have a look at this project, but seeing as it is only just down the road I would like to encourage them to do so so that they can actually see the point that I am making.

Putting that traffic issue aside, I think this is a very good project. It is going to offer an injection into the housing industry here in the post-GST rush period which may also prove to be quite timely as well, particularly when we consider that so many of our building industry people in the past year or two have been finding greener pastures in Sydney, where something big is happening in September. I would like to thank the parliamentary secretary for his advice of this issue to me earlier today. I acknowledge that quite happily. I do wish the project every success and I do look forward particularly to seeing a collegiate approach between the Commonwealth and the ACT government authorities in relation to all or any of those issues that I have raised that may be of concern to the local community. I would like to reiterate that this is a welcome project that we do encourage.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Canberra for her contribution. I want to assure her, as she in fact said, that there has been widespread consultation in the local community. The Stirling development proposals have been published in local newspapers and publicised in the Canberra Times, and public meetings have been held. The issues raised at the public meetings and subsequently have mainly concerned traffic arrangements, which are being addressed in conjunction with the ACT Department of Urban Services. There has been widespread consultation with large numbers of organisations, none of which are opposed to the development proposal. My understanding is that local residents have raised their concerns over increased vehicular traffic and the need for traffic calming arrangements on adjacent streets. These issues will be addressed in the design of the Stirling development and in conjunction with ACT roads and traffic section and ACTION.

debateinfo.title: NEW BUSINESS TAX SYSTEM (INTEGRITY MEASURES) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Bill returned from the Senate, with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
Senate's amendments—

quote.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 5 (line 35) to page 6 (line 4), omit subsection (4), substitute:
(4) The rule in subsection (2) does not apply to a *business activity for an income year if:
(a) the activity is a *primary production business, or a *professional arts business; and
(b) your assessable income for that year (except any *net capital gain) from other sources that do not relate to that activity is less than $40,000.
(5) A professional arts business is a *business you carry on as:
(a) the author of a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work; or

subdebate.1.para: Note: The expression “author” is a technical term from copyright law. In general, the “author” of a musical work is its composer and the “author” of an artistic work is the artist, sculptor or photographer who created it.

quote.para: (b) a *performing artist; or
(c) a *production associate.
(2) Schedule 1, page 11 (after line 3), after item 3, insert:
Insert:
professional arts business has the meaning given by section 35-10.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: In the other place, the Australian Democrats moved an amendment to provide an exemption from the operation of the non-commercial losses measure included in the New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000. The government supports that amendment. The exemption will apply to individuals carrying on a professional arts business whose assessable income from sources other than their professional arts business in that year is less than $40,000, excluding net capital gains.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

talk.start.para: —The $40,000 threshold for artists, as with that applying to primary producers, will not be indexed. The passage of this bill today will mean that important integrity measures recommended by the Ralph Review of Business Taxation, and accepted by the government, will become law. These integrity measures are part of the government's broader business tax reforms, which include capital gains tax cuts, company tax cuts, scrip for scrip roll-over relief and refunds of imputation credits.

—On the last occasion this bill, the New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000, was before the House, the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, Mr McGauran, sneered at my comment that both he and I had been the subject of thousands of representations from artists who were concerned about the way in which these particular measures would affect those who quite legitimately were pursuing their interests as artists and who were not, under any plausible understanding of the nature of this legislation, the intended targets of its attempt to prevent the exploitation of loopholes for tax avoidance.

speech.para: The opposition made the point that artists in Australia occupy a particularly significant role culturally but they are not well remunerated. The average income that artists receive is less than $20,000. There are various figures that are canvassed. Some suggest that the average income of those who are professionally engaged in the arts is as low as something just over $10,000, but certainly it is less than $20,000. The inevitable practice of people seeking entry to the arts is that they are forced to take second jobs whilst they seek to obtain recognition within their profession. It is common for those who wish to be painters, artists, dancers, whatever you wish, to take jobs washing dishes, working in restaurants, tutoring in art schools—a range of different employment occupations—so that they can sustain their burning ambition to enter the lexicon of the Australian arts world and become recognised as a star within it. Many will not succeed, but that dream, that vision, is what sustains them and what sustains us as a community. Their success or failure either enhances us or diminishes us. This legislation, unamended, would have diminished Australia and would have diminished the way in which artists are entitled to the respect of their fellow Australians. The amendments that we foreshadowed we would be supporting when the bill came before the Senate are now passed.

In these circumstances, of course, there was always a contest to claim credit for forcing the government into the backflip that it has now undertaken. I think it is proper to recognise that the first person to speak out loudly and publicly in relation to this matter was Senator Bob Brown. His representation on behalf of artists was important in terms of changing the public dynamics, but the suggestion by him at one point that Labor was uninterested in this matter I reject entirely. When you ask whether the Labor Party is in favour of artists, it is like asking whether a zebra has stripes, or whether a tiger has an appetite for flesh or is a vegetarian. Of course a tiger has an appetite for flesh. Is the Labor Party keen in supporting artists? Yes, of course it is.

talk.start.para: —Does a Liberal have family trusts?

—It is the same issue. The Labor Party has always been the party that has committed itself to the importance of the arts, not only for cultural reasons in our community, not only for the vibrancy that they bring to our community but also because of the economic advantages which they lead Australia towards. As we increasingly become a knowledge based nation where education and the arts will contribute towards our economic success, the importance of the arts increases, not diminishes. The legislation as proposed by this government would have driven out of practice many people who we need to thrive in order that we are both a thriving community culturally and economically. In the end, the Democrats came to the party and moved away from the deal they had secured with the government on the GST and now seek their place in the sun also. Fine, and we all accept that that is in the nature of politics. The last people who should get any credit in this process are the government, whose minister sat at the table when this bill was being debated sneering at the representations that were being pressed on his party. They have been forced now in the Senate to a humiliating backdown, which we welcome. (Time expired)

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —Very briefly, the honourable member for Denison noted that the average income of artists is less than $40,000 in many cases, and this will mean that they will benefit from the exemption that the government has agreed to. As I said earlier, the government is pleased that this bill will pass, including the provisions relating to artists.

—In supporting these amendments pertaining to artists, I want to draw attention to the debate in the other place on this particular legislation, the New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000. In his contribution to the second reading debate on the bill in the Senate on Tuesday, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Cook, said, among other things:

quote.para: I want to say that the farming exemption here has some merit. But the objection I have to it is that it still allows wealthy lawyers, doctors or stockbrokers who have a hobby farm in the country valued in excess of half a million dollars or have assets other than their motor vehicles on their property in excess of $100,000 to escape the provisions of this bill. But struggling small farmers that do not meet that qualification are caught. There ought to be some regard for the equity element of that issue.

speech.para: I realise there are four hurdles over which those people have to jump, but during the same debate Senator Woodley, for the Democrats, also stated:

quote.para: As they stand, I am concerned these `integrity measures' will penalise many genuine small farming enterprises, but allow many of the `hobby farmers' they supposedly target, to continue to deduct farm-losses from off-farm income.

speech.para: Unfortunately, while at least some in the Labor Party and the Democrats now realise the problems inherent in this bill, here we have amendments not addressing those issues at all but addressing only the interests of artists by expanding them to the $40,000 off-farm income limit. While now acknowledging the flaws in the bill, both the opposition and the Democrats seem resigned to its passage. The Labor Party is resigned to passing it because it is apparently compelled to do so after signing on blindly to the Ralph package, signing on without even sighting this and the other integrity measures. Despite all the rhetoric and talk of country Labor, when this bill was debated in this place I do not recall one word from Labor raising concerns about the possible impact of this bill on regional communities, nor was there a word about its potential impacts on the environment—impacts I brought to the attention of the Senate committee a week or so ago and which were noted by Senator Watson, I think it was, as significant.

I wonder whether any of the parties who have considered this have seen how many members of the genuine farming community work off farm—carting hay, harvesting, teaching, nursing, working in factories or whatever—pumping much of that money back into their properties. I asked the minister a question about this very issue yesterday and I have sent him details of one case, at his invitation, which quite clearly, in my estimation, shows that a genuine fourth generation—not third as I said—young farmer trying to get a property up and running so he can turn that into his full-time venture—almost going to sleep on the assembly line at the Uncle Ben petfood factory, I might say, while trying to generate the income flow to keep that property viable—is reliant on the tax write-offs—and not for a lifestyle purpose, as the hobby farmer buying a half a million dollar property at Bowral might enjoy in those shires that have those four per cent of properties that are over the half a million dollar valuation in Australia. So there are a huge number of people out there affected. There are rural supply businesses who have come to me with the sorts of figures that show how they expect to be severely impacted by this.

There is a major environmental problem out there with serrated tussock in the tablelands. The irony of this is that this legislation, in my estimation, is going to assist purchasing for non-active involvement in farming by people coming out of tax avoidance situations in city employ. They are not doing a dashed thing about that serrated tussock problem on those properties, whereas one particular small property owner who has brought this problem to my attention has brought home to me that his part-time off-farm work is in fact a weed spraying business which generates more than the $40,000 a year and yet he, too, on his small property is, he believes, not able to meet the requirements of this. I realise there are start-up provisions in here for smaller operations, smaller orchards and so on. But, in terms of long-lasting farms run by third or fourth generation farmers, there is real concern that there are many people out there who are legitimate in their endeavours in primary production but are going to be wiped off the slate by this particular legislation. I would ask the minister at the table to respond to those points. In fact, I ask if there has been any response from the minister for agriculture's office on the particular case I drew to his attention yesterday.

talk.start.para: —There are a number of particular points that I should address simply to conclude. Firstly, there have been a substantial number of representations from artists seeking assurances that the amendments that we would be supporting would cover not just visual artists but the range of those in other creative activity—writers, musicians, performing artists and the like. The amendments actually do achieve that objective, and that is a very important objective. There have also been representations that the $40,000 limit that applies to the income level against which art losses could be written off should be indexed. That has not been picked up in this legislation, so obviously it will be important for a future Labor government to watch this carefully to see that the real value of this exemption is not eroded over time. That is a matter on which I am certain those in the artistic community will continue to make representations, to both the current government and to Labor, when it forms government after the next election.

speech.para: Finally, might I say that one of the disappointing ironies of this whole debate was that, on the same day that the Prime Minister spoke announcing the composition of a new council to look at the status of artists and to respond to the findings of the Saatchi inquiry—commissioned by the Australia Council into the way in which the arts were perceived by Australians—and indicating the importance of the creative enterprises to his government, outside there had to be a demonstration of those in practice in the arts who had not yet received any undertaking from the government that their concerns in relation to this legislation would be addressed. And I have no doubt whatsoever that, had it not been for the views of the alternative government—the Labor Party—indicating that we were proposing to support changes in this area and that there was a Senate majority that would force the changes that have now come forward, this government would never have moved from its initial position in relation to this legislation.

The proof of the pudding was plain when the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, with no seeming regard to the irony of his position, belittled the number of representations that he had received in relation to this matter when the matter was before the House. The combined effect of the lobbying of those in the creative communities and the fact that there was a united front among the opposition parties—the alternative government, the Labor Party, and the Greens and the Democrats—forced the government to have this rethink. The government should get no cheer on this from anyone in the community. It is simply a recognition of the political facts of life that the Senate would not have passed its legislation in the form it proposed it. We welcome the fact that the legislation will be proceeding in its amended form, and we say to the government that it needs to listen much more carefully to the communities that will be affected by its tax legislation before it acts. This is just one more example of unintended, adverse consequences not being faced up to by a government that has not been prepared to accept that its legislative agenda is going to cost many millions of Australians dearly. Australians will pay dearly as the government seeks to introduce this destructive and stupid agenda of tax changes against the commitments it made prior to the last election. It was deceitful. A remedy has been achieved for this particular problem, but this legislation will do nothing about the larger damage to the arts community caused by the GST—additional costs that the arts community will bear and additional expenses that will be passed on to patrons of the arts. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to add a few quick words to put on record my concerns. The regional impact of the New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000 has not been properly considered, notwithstanding the amendments that we are considering here. As Treasury stated in the Senate committee inquiry, they have not looked beyond the integrity aspects of this bill. The environmental and social consequences were, it appears, a mystery to them. But a tax does not exist solely in an economy; it exists in a society—a society where people have planned their lives in reliance on the current arrangements. As I said, this concerns people who have been farmers over many generations; in fact, a fourth generation farmer has brought his concerns about this to me.

speech.para: The government has recognised that with the GST—but not, it seems, with these measures—people plan their lives on the proposed arrangements and so on. But, in this case, people are caught by an existing set of plans that involves their families and their off-farm income and that will mean that they will not qualify, they believe, under the so-called hobby farm arrangement. I also note that when the Prime Minister made his tour of regional Australia earlier this year he gave an assurance that from that point on all government policies would be tested for their regional impact prior to becoming law. I am not satisfied that this has happened in this case, particularly in reference to the points that I have been making. We may not be talking about megabucks, but we are talking about many people's lives, not only the lives of those in the primary sector but the lives of all those people who provide services to those currently accessing the deductions. I ask all members from regional areas this: when the property prices in your areas drop as a consequence of this, when your rural supplies stores come complaining about further drops in sales, will you tell them how you did not even read the bill, how you did not speak to the debate and how you just sat where you were told and let this slide through?

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —In my earlier presentation, I pointed out that the government is pleased that New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000, including the provisions relating to artists, will pass. I do not intend to comment further on the remarks made by the honourable member for Denison. The government's commitment in this area is well known, and we are particularly pleased with the arrangements which have been entered into and which will pass into law with the passage of this legislation.

speech.para: The bill before the chamber deals with the issue of non-commercial losses and is in line with the recommendations of the review of business tax. The review recommended the criteria which were included in the bill, and I note in relation to the contribution made by the honourable member for Calare that only businesses can offset their losses against other income such as wages and value. Farmers who are not in business do not have access to this. I might also say that, in recognition of the fact that many farmers work off farm while genuinely seeking to pursue farming, they will be exempt from the provisions where they have off-farm income of less than $40,000.

The honourable member for Denison bleated about Australia's new tax system, which was voted for by the Australian people at the last election. In just about 30 hours time, this new tax system will come in. It is very important that all of us focus on the fact that the Australian people have voted for this. The government is implementing its mandate, and, come Saturday, there will be $12 billion of tax cuts, with over 80 per cent of Australians paying no more than 30 cents in the dollar. Labor's wholesale sales tax and a number of other taxes will be scrapped. There will be boosts in pensions and benefits. There will be compensation for retirees. In effect, Australia will be a whole lot better off come 1 July because we are the government which was prepared to do something that should have happened very many years ago. I commend the motion to the chamber.

talk.start.para: —The New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000 contains some provisions that will have an adverse impact on the rural sector. It is another example of the government bringing legislation into this House the implications of which have not been thought through clearly. I commend the honourable member for Calare for the work that he has done in alerting the farming community in his electorate—and across Australia—to the provisions of this bill and how they are going to adversely affect the farming community.
—Why did you sign off on it?

—The simple explanation is this: this is a part of the government's taxation measures in total. We went to the Australian community at the last election opposing the GST and we made that opposition quite plain. When it came to the business taxation area, we have simply said to the government, `This is your work and at the end of the day you have to bear the responsibility for the implications involved with your legislation.'

speech.para: We have here a situation where the government has introduced measures that may well penalise genuine farmers who are forced, by the nature of their enterprises and the state of their industry, to seek off-farm income. We know that this is a government that has curtailed the opportunities of farmers, their spouses and their family members to obtain meaningful off-farm income, with the cuts to services that have taken place in rural and regional Australia since this government was elected. There has been a massive assault on rural and regional Australia. There has been a significant curtailment of stable job opportunities in those sectors of the rural and regional economy where farmers, their spouses and their family members could gain some meaningful work and be remunerated in a substantial way. Indeed, when you look at the structure of farming today in Australia you will see that this particular sector forms a very important part of the overall stability of rural Australia and plays a very important part in keeping people on their farms, until either those farms are restructured or better times appear in their industry.

We can appreciate the arguments that have been mounted by the government because we know that in the past these sorts of measures have been used by some people in the community to minimise their tax. The government having brought this particular legislation into being must bear the consequence that it will curtail the opportunity of many people on farm to earn an off-farm income and keep their farming enterprises operational. It is very clear in the sum total of measures in the new tax package that the farming community is going to be adversely affected, both on the GST side and on the business taxation side. But I say to the honourable member for Calare and I say to the honourable members opposite: this is the government's own work and it will be held responsible for it by those people in the farming community that are caught in this legislation and by the rural sector generally.

talk.start.para: —Before I conclude, I should also recognise the important role that was played by a number of arts organisations in the campaign that secured passage of these amendments. Firstly, I understand the Australia Council made representations to the government, quietly behind the scenes, and unfortunately was not listened to. Then there were the public campaigns. They were sponsored in the first place by NAVA, the National Association of the Visual Arts, and they certainly drew together a large coalition of artists who were very concerned about the impact of the proposed amendments on their practice. This was enhanced by the work of the Arts Law Centre. The Arts Law Centre proposed a number of specific amendments and liaised with the various parties in the Senate and me to seek our support of those measures. A draft originating from the Arts Law Centre was finally the basis for the amendments we have before us today. Then there was the Australian Society of Authors and a number of other arts organisations of a traditional nature. A specific new organisation was established to fight this campaign, called WAAR. I think it is an acronym for Writers, Artists Against Ralph. I had better check that because I am doing this off the top of my head. They organised a number of rallies and people like Parr and Cullen, prominent Australian artists in the visual field, spoke at those rallies together with new and rising artists who will make their mark in Australia in the future because of the fact that this campaign was successful. Many of those people who were demonstrating in Sydney, Brisbane, outside the parliament here and in other capital cities would have been forced out of the industry but for the success of this campaign.

speech.para: Finally, I might say that the nature of this campaign demonstrates a subtle shift in the way that politics is conducted. If you had read the newspapers you would hardly have known that there was an issue of public importance in contention in the public sphere. These issues were mentioned a couple of times in the inner pages of some of our metropolitan papers. But if you were to simply judge the importance of an issue by the amount of publicity it received on television and radio and in the press, you would have thought that this issue was inconsequential. It was not. It was because this campaign was mounted through the Internet. We all received thousands and thousands of representations through that means. The network of interested parties, including these different organisations—NAVA, the Arts Law Centre, WAAR, the Australian Society of Authors—created through email, and the pressure they were able to secure through their collective working together, is an interesting thing for us to reflect on. We realise that there are new and novel ways in which the democratic process is actually working in our society.

However, it does have some downsides. In a sense, this campaign was a subterranean one, and that took it out of the gaze of the larger public. Whilst I think this was an entirely beneficial and beneficent campaign, you can imagine a campaign with less noble motives also being conducted in a similar way. We should reflect on the fact that you can bring tremendous pressure to bear through modern communications without ever appearing in a substantial way in the free-to-air media or in the newspapers—the places where we normally get our news.

I recognise and respect the work of those people. While this may not mark the first such occasion, as there may have been previous occasions when similar campaigns were conducted in this way, it certainly marks a coming of age of the campaigning impact of the new technologies. All the individuals associated with it should be congratulated. (Time expired)

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —On a number of occasions I thought that this debate on the New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000 was going to conclude. I found the thoughtful pontification by the honourable member for Denison on the democratic process at this late hour most interesting. Perhaps the honourable member may consider that he is being paid by the word.

speech.para: In conclusion, I want to stress that, as I have mentioned before, farmers with less than $40,000 in off-farm income will not be affected by the measure. This means that a farming partnership—for example, a husband and wife—could in each case earn $40,000 from off-farm work without having to meet any of the other criteria in the bill. The criteria in the bill are based on the Ralph review recommendations, and they include start-up provisions as well as criteria relating to turnover, assets and property. It should also be noted that the commissioner can take into account special circumstances which are beyond the control of the taxpayer, such as drought and flood. I commend the amendments to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —As required by resolutions of the House, I table copies of notifications of alterations of interests and a statement of registrable interests received during the period 17 April 2000 to 28 June 2000.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT AND HERITAGE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —As I indicated before question time, the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 legislation seeks to legislate in relation to the 1996 protocol to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter. This stems from Australia's 1985 ratification of the London convention. The main aspects of the bill, as indicated before, are a search for alternatives, a new stress on technology to counter the need for dumping, and some recognition of the difficulties of island states such as Kiribati, Tuvalu and Nauru, which would find it very difficult to fully implement this change.

speech.para: The main fundamental alteration is the drift towards banning substances. Originally in the 1973 agreement there were various levels of warrants or permission for dumping. It has been understood in the interim period that a number of materials that were previously allowed cannot be diluted. There was a concept that some things would be diluted if you dumped them in the ocean, and so things like asbestos, car tyres, et cetera, were allowed. This legislation, and the protocol itself, turn the emphasis very strongly away from those specific dumping and general permits to say that essentially the materials that should be allowed to be dumped should be listed. The protocol speaks of dredge material, sewerage sludge, fish waste or material resulting from industrial fish processing, et cetera—ad nauseam. They are specifically listed, thus obviously implying that those not listed cannot be dumped.

I will not reiterate at great length the Labor Party's main points of objection to this bill. We fundamentally support the need to initiate into Australian legislation the understandings of this convention, but Labor has stressed a number of points. The first point is the concern that, if we do not clearly delineate exactly what can be utilised for the construction of artificial reefs, that might provide a loophole. The second point is—and I notice that the member for Lowe very heavily concentrated on this in his contribution to this debate—the question of the precautionary principle. That says that essentially activities should be prevented where it appears that wastes are likely to cause harm, even if at this stage in the history of technological and scientific knowledge we cannot fully prove that it will be harmful. There should still be an emphasis on precaution, care and concern about possibilities, rather than, as this bill says—as I understand it—that the minister will make a decision as to whether it is specifically harmful. They are the main two emphases of the Labor Party's questioning of this legislation.

I now turn to the contribution of the member for Rankin. He obviously has had a long-term involvement in environmental matters. He proffered the hope that in this area of environment we could perhaps be non-partisan and deal with these matters in an objective and rational fashion. I cannot be as confident as he is about the coalition's attitude and their search for genuine bipartisanship in this field. Even at a time when the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation are coming together about the question of salinity and deforestation, I do not think we can have the same confidence in the government and its attitude.

I particularly note a speech by Senator Hill on 30 March this year to the Financial Review's third annual emissions conference. At that conference, Senator Hill, who has had quite a few defeats in the government's engine room over environmental matters—most recently over his attempt to bring in triggers—was at pains to damp down the industrial push about the Kyoto protocol. The current Prime Minister has been doing his impersonation of Horatio Bottomley, running around with the flag in jingoistic fashion and relying on false nationalism, saying, `We are the strongest government in the world. We are going to preserve every job. We will take no cognisance of our international responsibilities. We will not worry about climate change.' He is not going to worry about emissions as long as he can run around and pretend to people that Australia can close its eyes and that he can claim, using that very false nationalism, that his preoccupation is with jobs.

The problem now is that the government's ridiculous position, which has misled the public and industry, has reached a stage where some sectors of industry actually think that the government can further roll back the Kyoto protocol. In a speech on 30 March, Senator Hill stated:

quote.para: ... the Howard government worked very hard to ensure that the Kyoto Protocol gave recognition to Australia's special circumstances.

speech.para: He continued to recommend ratification of the Kyoto protocol because if it failed another process would transpire and there:

quote.para: ... would be no guarantee that this new process would take into account our national circumstances in the way we were able to achieve in Kyoto.

speech.para: Senator Hill was trying to get the message across that, just because the Prime Minister carries on about how strong his government is in ignoring an international crisis in climate change and the scientific evidence that has been marshalled around that matter, at the end of the day Kyoto cannot be rolled back any further and the heightened expectations of Australian industry getting their own way in an even more naked way will not happen.

As I said, I cannot be confident, like the member for Rankin, that this government has much interest in environmental matters. At the next election, I am sure that we will not have the ACF wandering around forests hand in hand with Senator Kemp and Senator Hill.

talk.start.para: —What a horrible thought!

—A horrible thought, indeed. But I can assure you it will not be happening. Since the 1996 election, that close relationship has disappeared. It is a very sorry day that, while the ACF and NFF can get together, this government is totally repudiated by the Australian environmental movement. I noticed in the last budget figures indicated that there would be a very extreme and dramatic drop this year in environmental expenditure on oceans in all portfolios, from a figure of about $295 million to a figure of only $148 million in the next financial year. When this false nirvana of NHT money disappears, the situation will further deteriorate to a figure of only $81 million in 2002-03.

speech.para: So, whilst we recognise that this government is implementing the protocol and going in the right direction, the overall attitude towards environmental matters is clearly displayed by that funding level. So we have a government—I am afraid to tell the member for Rankin—that I cannot see moving in a direction of bipartisan support for environmental issues in this country. The evidence in regard to budgetary matters is pretty clear. Tying down the urgent environmental needs of this country to whether Telstra is sold is really typical of a very unfortunate attitude. We regard this legislation as going in the direction of recognising mounting international knowledge in this area. We should emphasise that this is the kind of cooperative international effort that some people, for base political reasons, often try to undermine.

The fact is that this country needs these kinds of conventions on whaling and on a variety of other environmental issues. But, as we saw in the run-up to our recent election, some people just push for the lowest common denominator and denigrate international understanding and international agreements. We saw that particularly over the CROC which led, of course, to the parliamentary Treaties Committee revealing that people basically went out there and tried to fool the Australian public that we could not have international cooperation or agreement, et cetera.

This bill is a very clear indication of what can be gained. It has come, as I say, from work commencing in 1971. It is an urgent need for this government to persuade a number of other countries in our region to come on board, because not only in this area but in immigration and a whole lot of other areas our region is probably the worst in the world for adherence and agreement to and ratification of these conventions. I commend the bill, with the qualifications on the issues of artificial reefs and the need for the precautionary principle.

talk.start.para: —We on this side of the House welcome the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 because it provides some protection for our fragile marine and ocean environment. This legislation is a step in the right direction, although it should have been a bigger step and it should have been taken sooner. The government launched its ocean policy in 1998 in the International Year of the Ocean. It has taken from 1998 until now to translate that policy into legislation. That is a long time. I would have thought it could have happened much sooner.

speech.para: The bill amends the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 to implement the 1996 protocol to the 1972 International Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter and it also amends the Sea Installations Act 1987. This legislation clarifies the Commonwealth's responsibility for regulating the construction of artificial reefs. It applies the act to exclusive economic zones, revises defence penalties and exemptions, and provides for some stronger penalties, which is good. Basically, it imposes tighter regulations on dumping at sea and defines artificial reefs.

I have some concerns about these issues, in particular artificial reefs and the fact that the definition of artificial reef does not go far enough. That in itself could be used for dumping in the ocean things that should not be there, such as pollutants; a number of substances or items could be deemed to be being used to set up an artificial reef when in actual fact it is simply a case of disposing of some unwanted material.
