Over the years, we have come to realise just how important the ocean is to our environment. Our environment and the protection and preservation of it are essential if we as a country are to grow. We cannot separate environmental and economic issues. There are enormous costs to our community and the world as a whole if we degrade our environment. Australia is an island nation and the oceans are very important to our survival. So much of our lives revolves around the oceans. They are important for tourism, recreation and transport. Over the years we have moved from the `solution for pollution is dilution' idea to one where we realise that you cannot dump just anything in the ocean. We have accepted the fact that there are certainly some materials that should never ever find their way into our oceans. I think the legislation identifies those items quite effectively.

One of the problems with this legislation is the absence of the adoption of the precautionary principle. It really worries me, and I think the government should revisit that matter. Whilst I commend the government for introducing this legislation, I do have some serious concerns. In its budget the government actually cut spending on the environment across all portfolios by $150 million. I believe environmental spending will continue to fall until 2004, when the Natural Heritage Trust funds run out. If the government has a true commitment to our environment, it would not be cutting funding to it. It is of great concern to me and to a number of people in the community.

We cannot remove shipping from the threat to our oceans. One of the greatest threats to our coastal and marine environment comes from unseaworthy, unsafe foreign ships with unqualified and poorly trained crews. This government is moving to liberalise cabotage restrictions and the lowering of the application fees for unlicensed vessels engaged in Australian coastal trade. This poses a real threat to our oceans. The changes that this government is looking at bringing in through amendments to the Navigation Act really put the environment and the safety of our seas at risk. The government plans to make it easier for ships of shame, which my predecessor, Peter Morris, so ably and accurately identified in a report to this House, to operate in Australian waters. They are ships like the MV Erika. The Erika was a 25-year-old tanker that broke in two off the French coast on 12 December last year, spilling some 15,000 tonnes of thick, offensive and destructive fuel oil along 400 kilometres of the French coast, severely damaging fishing grounds, beaches, headlands and tourist facilities. It is a disaster that is still causing economic and environmental damage to coastal France. The Erika was registered under a shonky flag obtained in Malta, I think. The Erika had corrosion problems three years ago. It had concealed ownership and its sinking caused an uproar in France. These are the types of ships that the government will allow to operate along the Australian coastline. Imagine the damage it would cause to our beaches and to the Great Barrier Reef if the same thing were to occur here.

I want to bring things into a local perspective. In the Shortland electorate we have the MV Wallarah, which carries coal from the Moonee colliery at Catherine Hill Bay to the port of Newcastle. I ask: what if the Wallarah was replaced with one of these ships of shame, a flag of convenience ship, taking coal from Catherine Hill Bay to Newcastle? If an accident were to occur think of the devastation and pollution that would cause to our beautiful oceans and to beaches such as Catherine Hill Bay, Caves Beach, Blacksmiths, Redhead—all those superb beaches along the coast. I think a failure to recognise the potential that ocean pollution can cause to our coastline by these ships is one area that the government needs to address. I had a look at the Lloyd's List of 27 June, which said:

quote.para: A grim winter off the Cape of Storms, with a capsize sunk in shallow water off Cape Town and every prospect that she will break up and cause serious local pollution from 1,300 tons of heavy oil in her bunker tanks. The South Africans will be getting somewhat tired of this growing casualty list off their coasts.

speech.para: This is happening throughout the world. It is happening because these ships are poorly maintained, are unseaworthy and have untrained crews. This government, far from moving to provide protection to our oceans, is moving away from providing that protection around the Australian coastline.

In a survey of more than 200 Perth households, the strong view was that we need a coastal service that is serviced by Australian operated and owned ships rather than foreign owned ships, and that it was not in Australia's interest to have Australian ships replaced by these foreign ships. The people in the survey were not willing to place the control of these ships in foreign hands. The highest level of concern about these flag of convenience ships was the potential environmental threat that poorly maintained and crewed vessels present for the environment. These flag of convenience ships have been repeatedly shown to operate under extremely poor standards of seaworthiness, thereby jeopardising the marine environment. Appalling conditions exist for the crew, with consequences for their health and safety. The ships are poorly maintained and give out toxic emissions. Invariably they dump the kind of waste into our oceans that this legislation seeks to prevent.

The ships are operated by Third World crews with questionable competency, which presents a serious threat to our marine environment. The protection of our coastal environment cannot be ensured through legislation in isolation. The government must address the shipping issue. It must strengthen, not weaken, the legislation affecting the shipping industry. The government is going soft on the inspection of foreign ships in its manic pursuit and persecution of seafarers and their families, and this is at the expense of our marine environment.

In the few minutes that remain, I will concentrate on a local issue in the Shortland electorate. For those people who do not know it, the Shortland electorate is a coastal electorate situated between the ocean, Lake Macquarie and the Tuggerah Lake system and Munmorah Lake.

talk.start.para: —It's a beautiful electorate.

—A beautiful electorate, as my colleague the member for Dobell so aptly interjects. It is an area that he is very familiar with because our electorates are adjoining. Lake Macquarie has been under extreme pressure. It has been severely degraded, and sedimentation has been a problem. Industrial waste has been going into the lake, and there has been seagrass damage.

speech.para: In 1998 we had an environmental forum at Lake Macquarie. Out of that, Premier Bob Carr agreed to set up a task force. From that, all government departments and all interest groups in the area came together with the local councils of Lake Macquarie and Wyong to develop a plan to ensure the ongoing health of that lake. The Carr government has contributed many millions of dollars, and the only contribution that we have had from the federal government has been $500,000—on the eve of the last council elections—for some walkways around the lake. No prize for guessing why that was given! The area of Belmont Wetlands connects the ocean and the lake. Numerous appeals have been made to the federal government to commit some money to the restoration of that area and to ensure that we have a healthy ocean and a healthy lake within that area. So far, the government has failed to assist in any way.

A number of Landcare groups are working in the area, and they have been feeling very discouraged in recent times. These Landcare groups work to restore the dunes. They work on the edge of the ocean and are involved in a number of ocean restoration programs in the area. They have been very discouraged recently because they have been forced to take out ABN numbers so they can accept donations of trees from industry groups and people in the community. If they do not take out an ABN number, they lose 48.5 cents in the dollar of the donations that are made to their group.

These are not the actions of a government committed to the environment. These are not the actions of a government that wants a healthy environment or a government that wants to protect our environment. We all know just how important the protection of our environment is. We must ensure the protection of all of our environment—our land, our air and our oceans—because it is essential if we are to survive as a nation and a planet.

The government is to be congratulated for introducing this legislation. Although it does not go far enough, and it fails to cover all the issues that impact on the health of our oceans and marine life, it is a step in the right direction. I sincerely hope that in the ensuing months the government does address the issues that I outlined in relation to the ships that they are encouraging to operate along our coastlines. I believe it is essential for our environment that this practice be discouraged and, if there are any amendments to the Navigation Act, that they strengthen the regulations rather than water them down.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.29 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak tonight on the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 because it is so critical to the future of Australia, to our people and to our industries. It is part of a suite of legislation that is designed to protect the marine environment, and is based on international protocols to which Australia is signatory.

speech.para: Our oceans, of course, know no boundaries. This is a truly global responsibility and, therefore, has to be taken extremely seriously. I guess the first question is: why do we need legislation of this kind? Firstly, because our marine environment, including the oceans, the seas and the adjacent coastal areas, are part of an integrated whole. We cannot look after one bit; we have to look after the lot. Our oceans are an essential component of our global life support system. Indeed, they are a positive asset, being a source of food for animals and people and a source of medicines, and they are important, too, in thermal regulation—just to mention a few functions they perform. Of course, the resources and habitats are very important for human settlements, development and indigenous peoples and local subsistence. Half of the world's population lives within 60 kilometres of a shoreline, and that could rise, we are told, to three-quarters by the year 2020. It is already higher in Australia. Some 86 per cent in 1991 lived within 60 kilometres of a shoreline, and that has rapidly increased in non-metropolitan Australia. So these are very significant problems for us. Our exclusive economic zone—otherwise known as our EEZ—is of vital importance because it allows states to manage and develop resources, particularly in fishing but in other areas as well, for their people.

Our oceans are in a very bad way. They are treated as garbage dumps by a lot of people, whether that is from land sources, from the air in the form of gases and aerosol particles, or from dredging and shipping. Historically, the ocean has been seen as able to absorb those insults. We now know, of course, that it cannot. The current approaches to the management of coastal and marine resources show that we clearly do not have sustainable programs. Our oceans are being rapidly degraded and eroded in many parts of the world. This degradation results from a wide range of land and sea sources; indeed, land based sources contribute 70 per cent to marine pollution. Unfortunately we have no global scheme and few regional and national programs to address marine pollution from land based sources. Every bit of clearing, for example, contributes to it. The contaminants include things we are familiar with: sewage, nutrients, synthetic organic compounds, sediments, litter and plastics, metals, radionuclides, oil hydrocarbons and various other types of hydrocarbons. And we know that toxic chemicals accumulate in food chains. I am sure any of us could take a walk along a beach anywhere in this country and sadly find the refuse of our habitation. Activities on land, including human settlements, various forms of land use, construction of coastal infrastructure, agriculture, forestry, urban development, tourism and industry, contribute to the pollution of our oceans. Coastal erosion and siltation are of particular concern. We also need to be worried about the health effects, for instance, of algae poisoned seafood, which produces many illnesses and deaths. Untreated sewage, as we know, is a health hazard.

As well as this land based degradation, there is a problem with sea based degradation, and that is what this legislation deals with. Maritime transport and dumping at sea cause problems for all of us. It is estimated that 150,000 tonnes of plastic are put into the ocean yearly from the fishing industry in the form of plastic net and line and there are also countless plastic containers washing up on our shores. In addition to that—something that is less visible—approximately 600,000 tonnes of oil each year from normal shipping operations alone ends up in our oceans and, on top of that, there is the land based pollution, accidents and illegal discharges. So that is a total of over three million tonnes of oil every year. We have seen in the last decade a substantial expansion of fisheries on the high seas. They now make up five per cent of total world landings.

I think everyone would agree that our management of these international waters is inadequate in every respect—for example, some resources are overutilised and there is unregulated fishing, about which there has been a lot of publicity here in Australia. There is overcapitalisation—too many ships; excessive fleet sizes; vessels reflagging to escape controls, and I will talk a bit more about that in a moment. Further, there is insufficiently selective gear which picks up everything, not just the fish to be caught, unreliable databases and lack of sufficient cooperation between various states and nations, particularly for highly migratory species and stocks that straddle various regions. Where fisheries fall within a national jurisdiction there are still problems of overfishing, unauthorised incursions by foreign fleets and the ecosystem degradation that I talked about. Our coral reefs and other marine coastal habitats—for instance mangroves and estuaries—are under particular stress because, as we now know, they are vulnerable and sensitive to climate and atmospheric changes. Small increases in sea levels, for instance, have the potential to cause significant damage to small islands and low lying coasts, particularly in our region. We are also well aware of the fact that increased ultraviolet radiation from ozone depletion could affect our marine environments.

We are not doing nearly enough about all of these problems. This legislation, I will acknowledge, makes a small contribution to dealing with these problems. As members would be aware, this bill amends the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. It implements the 1996 protocol to the 1972 Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, sometimes known as the London protocol. It extends coverage to the exclusive economic zone. It revises offences, penalties and exemptions. All of these changes are welcome. However, there is one thing it does not do: it does not define dumping. From discussions with staff at the library it is quite clear that it is not included in the act and probably needs to be in due course. It is in the protocol but it is not clearly defined in this. It is a companion to legislation with controls discharge and dumping from ships, which is also very important. It does not include, as the other legislation does, oily waste discharge and disposal of sewage, garbage and food scraps. That is covered in the Protection of the Sea (Prevention and Pollution from Ships) Act 1983, which implements Australia's international obligations under the 1973 Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships and its 1978 protocol, MARPOL. All these things sound very worthy, but they fall far short of what is required.

Interestingly, while making these laudable changes—signing up to conventions which the government purports not to like and passing legislation to give effect to them—at the same time they are undermining their own efforts and contributing to the problem by what is a very short-sighted shipping policy in Australia. We are seeing here right now, at the same time as this legislation is passing, the destruction of the Australian shipping industry: the axing of funding which made the merchant fleet competitive and legislation which revokes ILO conventions, permitting foreign vessels carrying out our coastal trade to do so without mandatory safety checks. It is replacing Australian ships by single voyage permits and increasing the proportion of ships under flags of convenience, which already dominate export trade. This is a serious problem not just for Australia but for the rest of the world.

These conventions and enforcement in this legislation are only as good as the commitment and surveillance provided by the governments which ratify them. Otherwise, they are just so many words. They are also only as good as the capacity of governments to determine liability for breaches and their willingness to impose effective penalties. On all those fronts, not only this government is lacking but many other governments as well.

In the case of our oceans, part of the problem is the proliferation of flag of convenience vessels, as they are known, which render such conventions effectively meaningless. Most members will be aware that flag of convenience ships fly the flag of a country other than the country of ownership. They are very attractive because they are cheap to register, there are low or no taxes, they can employ low paid labour and they avoid pollution and safety standards. So every time we hand over an Australian flag ship to a flag of convenience, we drop standards significantly. The number of these flag of convenience vessels has accelerated dramatically since World War II, particularly in the last 20 or so years. I think it is fair to describe the owners of these vessels as the buccaneers of the 20th and 21st centuries. It is a great global shame.

The number of flag of convenience registers is growing, where there is no genuine link between the real owner and the flag of the vessel. That is contrary to provisions of UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. There are poor safety and training standards, if any. There are no restrictions on the nationalities of crews and that causes severe communication problems, and hence accidents. These registers are often not even run from the countries nominated. For example, the Liberian register is run from a United States company.

There has been a significant increase in the number of these registers. In 1980, there were 11 registers; now there are 27 and more are interested. The vessels that are registered under these flags of convenience—and there is a lot of information available for those who care to look—pay minimum wages, in many cases starvation wages. There is no union scrutiny of wages and conditions. In many cases, they violate basic human rights. There are appalling living standards and working conditions for crews. Indeed, some have described them as `floating slave ships'. They are older than the average age of the world fleet and they break up more readily. They pose risk to life and limb.

Most members might be aware of the fact that there are 2,000 deaths at sea a year and a lot of injuries, frequently without any compensation because you cannot trace the owners. Even when newer vessels are registered, they are often built to minimum standards and become structurally unsound more rapidly. Forty-six per cent of all losses at sea are due to just eight flag of convenience registers. A lot of this may be due to human error because the crews are overworked. It is quite clear from inspections that some do not even get enough food and clean drinking water. That is why some of them jump over the side and risk their lives. The Institute of London Underwriters report in 1994 said:

quote.para: Yet again the same flags account for losses well above their share of world shipping, Panama, Malta, Cyprus, St Vincent and Grenadines being the most significant.

speech.para: You will see that list or something like it come up year after year. These flags of convenience pose a significant threat to our environment, which this legislation and others like it in the suite can do nothing about. They are often involved in major break ups. In my own state, the Kirki and the Sainko Harvest threatened the coast of Western Australia with oil and superphosphate respectively. What goes on in international waters is out of sight of the regulators and there is nobody in these flags of convenience countries to care. While the international instruments which are worthy set a comprehensive framework for prevention, reduction and control of degradation of our marine environment from sea based activities, it all depends on flag states discharging their obligations and exercising effective control over vessels which fly their flag. Clearly, in these flags of convenience, they do not.

Shipowners can get away with dumping various prohibited substances, breaches regarding ballast, oily bilge water, garbage and sewage, and they simply throw the dead cattle and sheep overboard. Prosecutions by either the host country or the country of register simply do not occur because these flags of convenience registers do not enforce regulations even when they are signatories. They do not have the resources to begin with.

Our ability to enforce standards depends on adequate surveillance and willingness to prosecute. Even in a country like Australia, that does not happen as often as it should. To give a recent example, the Joint Spirit, a ship that docked in Adelaide, was photographed dumping waste over the side of the ship. This apparently included sewage bilge and engine room sludge. The local union representatives were approached by a sailor from the ship, a Chinese engineering student, who said he was specifically instructed to make pipe work modifications to enable the waste to be dumped in this way. He said the waste was dumped outside Adelaide's harbour about an hour before the ship docked. This ship is not old; it was only a couple of years old at the time of the incident. When it was inspected by AMSA, they said that they could find no evidence that there had been illegal dumping and cleared it to leave port. The sailor, brave man that he was, was threatened and had to stay in Adelaide fearing his life would be in danger because of the action he had taken. So not only did we not protect the environment; we did not protect the sailor.

The Joint Spirit is a classic flag of convenience vessel, jointly owned, flying under Panama's flag. It had actually been to Australia before with a Filipino crew. On inspection they were found to be keeping two sets of books. The crew were not receiving proper wages, as was claimed. Because of Australian cabotage arrangements, when they were caught out they had to make back payments. What happened to the Filipino crew? They lost their jobs and they were replaced with a Chinese crew. They, too, were later found to have been underpaid and therefore needed back pay. It should not come as a surprise to us that such shipping operations would also be breaking every rule in the book as far as environmental controls were concerned. The dumping of waste in these cases is a cost cutting measure. They save the company the cost of having the waste removed and transported from the ship while in port, for example.

Similarly, a lot of the larger ships failed to follow correct procedures for the dumping of bilge water in order to cut costs. They have to take on water to stabilise the vessel for ocean travel after off-loading their cargo. This water, called bilge, is supposed to be progressively changed over the voyage to prevent the transport of ocean life into new environments, where they may become a pest and threaten local ecosystems. We know that that has failed because we have a lot of those pests in our waters right now, and they are a threat to our fishing industry and to aquaculture. The changing of bilge actually requires the ships to slow down a bit—to lose time and, therefore, money. They are simply not doing it, and no-one is enforcing it. Some ships have been known not to change their bilge until reaching port, and then they simply dump it. That practice has been documented as the most likely cause of the outbreak of tiger mussel infestation in the port of Darwin, a mussel which is known to establish itself as a pest at the expense of the local environment. It has caused an environmental catastrophe in the Canadian lakes, for example. In the 1980s, a poisonous dinoflagellate was introduced through bilge waters into Tasmanian waters. This organism, when consumed by shellfish, turns into a deadly toxin for humans.

We are not doing nearly as well as we think we are in these areas. The protection of Australian shipping, in my view, goes hand in hand with the protection of Australia's marine environment. We can turn our backs and say, `It doesn't matter. If these other countries, the flag registers, are not doing their job, that is not our business.' It is very much our business. Their flag of convenience system has been described as an institutionalised system for the negation of international law. It simply enables nations to avoid their responsibilities. It also poses a threat to the marine environment and to the sustainable utilisation of marine living resources and our fisheries in particular. Even the OECD agree—and they are always in favour of competition and driving down prices—saying that this creates unfair competition and distortion because it means that these companies can avoid reasonable and agreed standards for the pay and conditions of seafarers and for the protection of the environment. Of course it is cheaper to do that. Then they compete with the flag vessels of other nations, which have to meet these standards, and lo and behold they can do it more cheaply. There are some people who benefit from that in the short term, but in the long term none of us wins.

What we have seen recently is a rapid increase in these flag of convenience vessels, particularly in unregulated international fishing. It is spilling into the fishing industry as well, driving out our fishing fleet and our capacity to earn a living. When governments such as this one—and there has clearly been an attempt to do this—sign up and legislate to penalise sea dumping and marine pollution, which we all agree should be done, and at the same time encourage and allow the proliferation of flags of convenience, they make a mockery of these agreements and laws. It is very cynical. We will not have a fleet. We can simply pass on all of these responsibilities to others. We can also stand by and not enforce them, and I suspect that that is happening in some cases as well.

The granting of single voyage permits, which are only supposed to be supplied on occasions when there is not a suitable vessel available, increased from 421 in 1995-96 to 704 in 1998-99. All of our Australian flagships, our coastal ships, are required to fulfil high safety and environmental standards. Every time we push them into flags of convenience, they drop in standard. We cannot inspect every one of them every minute of the day. AMSA's random inspections cannot possibly be as effective on ships making these so-called one-off journeys as on Australian shipping lines. So we are forgoing very significant opportunities to improve our marine environment by handing over our coastal shipping and standing back and watching international shipping standards sink lower and lower and lower. No amount of legislation and no amount of treaty signing will substitute for a decent shipping policy.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —in reply—In summing up this debate that we have been having in relation to the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000, let me thank all of the contributors. While we have heard a lot of words, some of them indicate that members on the opposition side do not fully understand the content of the bill and the amendments. It was pleasing to hear of strong support for the government in what it is attempting to do to make sure that our magnificent economic zone and our marine environment are protected. The bill includes amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 and the Sea Installations Act 1987. Some of the items of the bill, which originated in the Senate, were amended by the Senate, and these amendments relate to the sea dumping act. I will go further into explaining why we have not necessarily supported all of those amendments that have come through to us from the Senate. I should add that, while the government is willing to support some of these amendments, there are others which we quite clearly cannot.

speech.para: As presented and read a first time in the Senate, the bill included an amendment to the sea dumping act to provide a limitation of liability in favour of the Commonwealth and officers exercising powers under that act for negligent acts or omissions exercised in good faith that may arise in respect of an authorisation under that act in respect of an artificial reef. This amendment was intended to address a risk that was identified in legal advice provided to the Department of the Environment and Heritage. That advice stated that an officer exercising powers under the act may be held liable in negligence for loss or injury incurred in respect of an artificial reef. Further, in circumstances where an officer was found liable, it would be incurred personally rather than on behalf of the Commonwealth.

I note that this exemption, if enacted as was originally proposed, would have applied in respect of not all negligent acts or omissions but rather only those acts or omissions that were exercised in good faith. The Senate, however, with the support of the opposition and the Democrats, amended the bill by revising this provision to expressly provide that the exemption did not apply in respect of negligent acts or omissions. The government sees no point in having the Senate again consider the provision as originally proposed. However, the department has received further legal advice that, if the provision is enacted as currently proposed, there is a risk that it will be interpreted as providing an exemption in respect of some of the liability that may be known at law. Accordingly, and as the government did not intend to provide an exemption other than in respect of the identified category of negligence, the government proposes to further amend the bill to omit the proposed provision in its entirety. This will ensure that there is no uncertainty regarding the intention of the parliament in this regard, while giving effect to the Senate's intention in adopting the amendments as it did.

With the support of the Democrats, the Senate also adopted an opposition amendment to the bill to revise the limitation governing the prescription of material as seriously harmful material. Under the amended sea dumping act, there will be a tiered penalty structure provided in respect of the primary offence provisions. The primary offence provisions will relate to unlawful dumping into the sea, incineration at sea, loading or dumping for incineration at sea, export for dumping or incineration at sea, artificial reef placements and conduct of a responsible person in circumstances where one of the above offences is committed. The penalty that may be imposed upon conviction for one of these primary offences will depend on the nature of the material used in the commission of the offence. Where the commission of a primary offence involved the use of seriously harmful material, the penalty that may be imposed will be up to 10 years imprisonment, a fine of 2,000 penalty units, which is currently approximately $210,000, or both. Where the commission of a primary offence involved the use of material that includes non-annex 1 material, that is, material that may not be considered for dumping under the 1996 protocol to the London convention, the penalty that may be imposed will be up to two years imprisonment, a fine of 500 penalty units, currently approximately $55,000, or both. In any case involving the commission of a primary offence, that is, where annex 1 material is used, or possibly where there is no evidence as to the nature of the material used, the penalty that may be imposed will be up to one year imprisonment, a fine of 250 penalty units, currently approximately $27,500, or both.

Seriously harmful material would be defined in the act under item 15 to include radioactive material, which is currently defined in the act's section 4(1), and any other material prescribed by the regulations to be seriously harmful material. As the use of seriously harmful material in the commission of a primary offence may attract the most severe penalty that can be imposed under the amendment act, it was intended that only those materials that are likely to cause serious harm to the marine environment would be included in that category. Accordingly, the bill as presented and read a first time in the Senate included a provision to place a limit on the prescription by regulation of material as seriously harmful material. That proposed subsection basically provided that, before the Governor-General may make a regulation prescribing that material as seriously harmful material, the minister must be satisfied that the material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment.

However, the member for Wills and the member for Lowe agreed with Senator Bolkus, who during the debate in the Senate claimed that this provision was inconsistent with the precautionary approach as enunciated in article 3.1 of the protocol. Article 3.1 of the protocol provides that in implementing this protocol contracting parties shall apply a precautionary approach to environmental protection from dumping of wastes or other matter whereby appropriate preventive measures are taken when there is reason to believe that wastes or other matter introduced into the marine environment are likely to cause harm, even when there is no conclusive evidence to prove a causal relation between inputs and their effects. So it is difficult to see how the provision as was proposed is inconsistent with this precautionary approach. It was saying that in respect of something that is already prohibited we will impose the harshest penalties in those cases where the impacts are the worst. There is no question that the precautionary approach has been adopted; the action is outright prohibited. There can be no greater exercise of a precautionary approach. We wish to determine the extent of the penalty to be imposed in the case of unlawful activities.

Nonetheless, the Senate adopted the opposition amendment to this item. In short, the revised provision as presented to this House now provides that, before the Governor-General may make a regulation prescribing the material as seriously harmful material, the minister must apply the precautionary approach contained in article 3 of the protocol. This revised provision is, in the government's view, unclear and is an inappropriate application of the precautionary approach. Legal advice obtained by the department has indicated that this provision, if enacted, is likely to give rise to legal uncertainty. It is clear from Senator Bolkus's statement during debate of the bill in the Senate that in moving this opposition amendment he envisaged that the revised provision would allow the minister to authorise the prescription of material as seriously harmful material in circumstances where there was no scientific evidence that the introduction of that material into the marine environment would be detrimental. Leaving aside that the government questions the appropriateness of such a concept in these circumstances, the government is not convinced that such interpretation would necessarily prevail if this provision as currently proposed were left to a court to interpret. Therefore, to provide greater certainty the government is proposing further amendments to this item.

Secondly, in line with Senator Bartlett's comments during debate of the bill in the Senate in which he put the idea of a compromise between the proposed tests, the government's amendments also incorporate the appropriate aspects of the precautionary approach as enunciated in article 3.1 of the protocol. The proposed new subsection 41(3) will thus provide that the minister must be satisfied that material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment before the Governor-General may make a regulation prescribing that material as seriously harmful. This new subsection is intended to ensure that only those materials capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment are prescribed as seriously harmful material, thereby potentially attracting the most severe penalties under the act when used in the commission of a primary offence. The proposed new subsection 41(4) is intended to broaden the scope of the test provided in subsection (3) by applying the identified relevant aspects of the precautionary approach as provided in article 3.1 of the protocol. It will grant the minister a greater discretion to recommend the prescription of material as seriously harmful material by allowing him or her to be satisfied that a material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment notwithstanding that there may be no conclusive evidence of a causal relationship between input of that material and serious harm to that environment.

The proposed new subsection 41(5) is intended to require the minister to have regard to the identified relevant aspects of the precautionary approach, as provided in article 3.1 of the protocol, when considering whether to prescribe material as seriously harmful material. It will require the minister to have regard to the principle that material should be prescribed as seriously harmful if there is reason to believe that the material is likely to cause serious harm to the marine environment, notwithstanding that there may be no conclusive evidence of a causal relationship between input of that material into the marine environment and serious harm to that environment. It is the government's view that this amendment will overcome the legal uncertainty of the provision as currently proposed in the bill by providing a clear and appropriate test in respect of the prescription of material as seriously harmful material which also incorporates a precautionary approach.

Many of the opposition speakers in this debate were also concerned about artificial reefs and their construction and the protection of the environment. The government does not intend to oppose in this House the amendments made by the Senate in respect of the definition of artificial reefs. However, it is important to address the misconception that the member for Wills and his Labor colleague in the Senate, Senator Bolkus, seem to have in respect of these amendments. Earlier in this debate, the member for Wills stated:

quote.para: The definition of artificial reefs should limit artificial reef placement to the dumping of controlled materials as defined under the legislation.

speech.para: And further:

quote.para: I note in relation to these amendments ... concerning the definition of `artificial reefs', that by not limiting the definition of artificial reef to a controlled substance a potential loophole exists to allow dumping of material other than that allowed under the protocol.

speech.para: The protocol excludes from the definition of dumping the placement of matter for a purpose other than mere disposal thereof, being a placement that is not contrary to the aims of the protocol. This is an exception that has been recognised in the bill. The definition of artificial reef placement which will be inserted by item (5) provides:

quote.para: Artificial reef placement means a placement of any controlled material into the sea for the purposes of creating an artificial reef, being a placement that is not contrary to the aims of the protocol.

speech.para: Accordingly, the placement of material which was deemed to be a placement contrary to the aims of the protocol—for example, on the basis that the introduction of that material into the marine environment would be severely detrimental—would amount to dumping under the amended sea dumping act. It is another proposition entirely, however—and one clearly not intended by the protocol—to say that it is only those materials within an annex 1 of the protocol—that is, only those materials permitted to be considered for dumping—that should be used in the construction of artificial reefs.

Even so, the amendments by the Senate that substituted the term `controlled material' for `any matter or thing' in respect of references to `artificial reefs' will not, as the member for Wills has stated, have the impact of restricting artificial reef placements to only those substances permitted to be dumped under the protocol. As is clear from the bill and the explanatory memorandum, the terms `controlled material' and `any matter or thing' are both intended to include all substances that could possibly be dumped or placed respectively. It was intended that no substance or matter or structure or formation would fall outside the ambit of these terms. If a vessel were dumped at sea, it would be `controlled material' for the purposes of the sea dumping act. If instead that same vessel were placed for the purpose of creating an artificial reef, it would be `any matter or thing' for the purposes of that act. Accordingly the government concedes—and did so during the debate in the Senate—that the use of these terms in the manner originally proposed would not have had any real practical legal significance. Rather, the distinction was originally made, as was explained in the original explanatory memorandum, in an attempt to make it clear that the creation of artificial reefs and dumping are two entirely separate activities—the former not being prima facie within the ambit of the protocol, whereas the latter being so.

In respect of the construction of artificial reefs, the government has not to date, under the London convention—and will not in the future under the protocol—allowed placement to occur as a means of subverting or frustrating the rules concerning dumping. On the contrary, the government will provide through this bill an appropriate legislative framework to ensure that that does not occur. Specifically, the definition of `artificial reef placement' in line with the protocol excludes as dumping activities contrary to the aims of that international instrument.

The member for Fremantle was concerned that dumping was not defined in the act. Quite clearly, it is: dumping is defined in the protocol, and therefore the act. In fact, section 4(4) basically states that definitions in the protocol apply to the act, so she need not be concerned, and dumping is specifically defined in article 1.4 of the protocol. In conclusion, the member for Scullin requested confirmation that it was indeed the case that land based sources of marine pollution including end of pipe disposal did not come within the ambit of the protocol. That is in fact the case. It is only disposal from vessels, aircraft and platforms that that instrument deals with. This is a very important amendment bill. It is one that makes sure that we can have continued control over possible future contaminants and the harm that might come to our ocean environment. I commend this bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 1 and 2:

quote.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 77, page 26 (line 26) to page 27 (line 13), omit the item.
(2) Schedule 1, item 78, page 27 (lines 16 to 20), omit subsection (3), substitute:

(3) Before the Governor-General makes a regulation prescribing material for the purposes of paragraph (b) of the definition of seriously harmful material in subsection 4(1), the Minister must be satisfied that the material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment.

(4) The Minister may be satisfied that material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment even though there is no conclusive evidence to prove a causal relationship between the input of the material into the marine environment and serious harm to the marine environment.

(5) For the purposes of subsection (3), the Minister must have regard to the principle that material should be prescribed as seriously harmful material if there is reason to believe that the material is likely to cause serious harm to the marine environment even though there is no conclusive evidence to prove a causal relationship between the input of the material into the marine environment and serious harm to the marine environment.

speech.para: I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: —In concluding the second reading debate, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage foreshadowed several things in the government amendments. Amendment 1 is to omit the item which deals with protection against legal action; the opposition had raised a concern in the previous debate that the exemption from legal action should not apply to negligent acts. Government amendment 2 omits a subsection and substitutes in its place a provision that, before the Governor-General can make regulations concerning the definition of `seriously harmful material', the minister has to be satisfied that the material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment. As the parliamentary secretary indicated, the government appears to be looking at a compromise outcome, one which is different from its original proposition but is also different from the amendment which we had moved which specified that the minister ought to follow the precautionary approach as set out in article 3 of the relevant protocol.

speech.para: These are quite complex amendments, and we appreciate the fact that the parliamentary secretary has provided quite detailed material in support of them. In those circumstances, I will be reserving the opposition's position concerning these amendments while we have the opportunity to consider them between here and the Senate so that we can arrive at a more detailed conclusion. Material has been put forward in support of the government's position. I think that both sides are anxious to ensure that there is appropriate protection against the kind of sea dumping and the damage to the marine environment that it causes. We are just as anxious as the government to ensure that there is not legal uncertainty as a result of the drafting of the legislation, so obviously we want to consider this issue and have a look at the words which the government has now used in these amendments.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Health Legislation Amendment (Gap Cover Schemes) Bill 2000

motion.para: That standing order 103 (new business) be suspended for this sitting.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 22 June, on motion by Dr Stone:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition takes the question of the greenhouse response of Australia very seriously. This is a matter which the world as a whole has had occasion to consider a number of times now, most recently in Kyoto. The opposition shares the concern that all Australians have for the environment, particularly over the very serious threat of anthropogenic change from greenhouse effects and the way in which that will impact on the global climate over the next several hundred years. This is one of the first major long-term climatic and environmental problems that the world has had to deal with, and obviously our response to it will be very important, not so much for our generation but for the generations to come, because climate change is a slow and insidious process which can have a cumulative effect on the climate over many years. Those who look for immediate changes in the climate, those who look for a clear and present danger, will be disappointed; they will not find the immediate signal that they seek. That does not mean that we should ignore this problem, because there are many long-term changes to the climate which will gradually change the way the climate responds, particularly to more serious and unique events. The average temperature is projected to change by only a few degrees over a matter of 50 to 100 years if we have a `business as usual' scenario. While that may at first seem like a relatively small change, given the changes we all experience from summer to winter and from Australia to, say, Europe or Canada, the reality is that, once you start to change those averages, the ways in which the climate responds in the context of more significant events, like serious storms, hurricanes, tornadoes, snow storms, droughts—which are of more concern to Australia—and long-term hot summers, also change. Those kinds of changes will occur in the long term, and we will see an increased frequency of those kinds of events as the average temperatures move up under greenhouse induced climate change.

speech.para: Of course, there is a very serious issue to be dealt with in public policy terms in response to that potential environmental change. My first comment in relation to this Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 must be to express the opposition's concern that the government has taken so long to debate these matters internally and so long to present the legislation to the House that we are confronted in the House of Representatives with a situation where this bill was first introduced last Thursday. Today, a week later, the House is in the process of finalising its business and preparing to rise for a winter break period. The House of Representatives is therefore, at the request of the government, constrained to consider a matter of this seriousness within a period of a few days. In the context of the seriousness of this legislation and the impact that it will potentially have not only on the environment but also on the economy, these issues are far too important to be rushed through this House in a period of days. The opposition has had inadequate opportunity to deal properly with this serious legislation in the normal parliamentary way that we are given the courtesy of in the usual circumstances. Therefore, the comments that I will make this evening on behalf of the opposition will be to reserve our final position on this until the matter has arrived in the Senate, when at least we will have had a reasonable period to review the precise terms of the legislation, to consult with affected parties and to reach a proper decision within our own internal processes. I do not think this is unreasonable, given the detail that we are asked to grapple with and the stage the parliamentary sittings are now at. However, I do have a number of detailed comments in relation to the legislation. The fact is the concept has been around for quite some time now. Certainly, the public policy issues which are at large in relation to this debate have been discussed. We do not intend to oppose legislation, but the terms of our support for this bill will be conveyed to the parliament in the course of the forthcoming Senate debate.

Kyoto was the first real attempt by the world community, in the sense of a legally binding treaty that nation states might sign up to and reach consensus on as to the public policy measures they would individually and collectively take, to address the greenhouse problem. But of course we do not yet know all of the science behind the greenhouse issue. This is one of the concerns we have to take into account when formulating a legislative response at this early stage of the scientific inquiry. It is very clear from the science that the CO2 concentration in the global atmosphere has been rising steadily since the Industrial Revolution. That is incontrovertible. The CSIRO and the Antarctic Division, with data from the Antarctic ice cores, and the Russians and Canadians, with the work they have done in the Arctic ice cores, have been able to take the research back many hundreds of thousands of years. They have detailed records from the trapped air within those cores of the CO2 concentration going back many hundreds of thousands of years—and we hope even further than that in the future. We are also able, from detailed studies of plant fossils and even air trapped in amber, to make predictions and assumptions about the CO2 concentration of gases in the air millions of years back. So we understand the way in which CO2 concentrations have changed over time. That is not in debate in the modern period of human history, and certainly there is ample scientific evidence to support the view that a greenhouse effect will achieve global warming. That is why we can all live on the planet now, why there is water vapour in our atmosphere, and liquid water in our oceans and when we turn on the tap at home. Without that greenhouse effect, this happy state of affairs would not prevail on the planet. A runaway greenhouse effect has the consequences that seem to prevail on Venus, for example, which has 600 degree Celsius temperatures at ground level and where molten lead would flow like water. I suspect that is not an outcome which any of us would wish for our own home in the solar system. Fortunately, even with business as usual under the greenhouse scenario, that is not an immediate prospect. But we can see where failure to accommodate a greenhouse policy will take the planet in the long term, and it is not in a very healthy direction.

While the science remains undefined, not only is the risk of the adverse consequences, which many in the scientific and environmental community have spoken about, less than clearly defined but there is also increased risk from things like feedback loops. The North Atlantic conveyor belt in the North Atlantic Ocean, which conveys water and air temperature across Europe, might for example under some conditions of average temperature be induced to shut down. We might see a situation in which the Pacific water currents, which are very important for Australia's long-term climate and for the long-term health of our farming communities, under some circumstances of temperature change might be induced through a feedback mechanism to simply shut down and not start up again. There are adequate geological historical records to support these kinds of changes and feedback mechanisms, and we are far from certain about the way in which they will impact on the climate. The change could be either way, but it is a risk I suggest we really do not want to experiment with.

The other issue is to what extent increased CO2 will promote plant growth and forest growth, locking up more carbon and acting as a natural carbon `sink', and to what extent it will promote plankton growth in the ocean, again locking up carbon in the long term, thus reducing through another feedback mechanism the long-term increase in CO2. These effects, particularly the feedback effects, can be very uncertain and so we have to take great care in public policy to ensure that we do not, through inattention now and lack of certainty now, lock the planet into a change that we will find much harder to reverse later. This also applies to the economics, of course, because if we make some changes now we can probably make them in a more gradual and less costly, even beneficial, way and ensure that later changes do not have to be so dramatic and cause such serious economic dislocation in communities around the world.

We must not look at just CO2 because there are a total of six greenhouse gases, including methane and a number of the chlorofluorocarbons which were covered by the Montreal protocol. All of those gases contribute to global warming. Methane is a far more serious contributor to global warming than CO2 on a molecule by molecule basis but, because CO2 is generated by the burning of fossil fuels, obviously that is the major volume contributor to the greenhouse problem and that is the one which we would turn our attention to first. But we should not ignore the contribution of methane, particularly in Australia where we have a large number of farm animals and other animals who contribute through their daily activities to the methane problem. Obviously, that needs to be looked at as well, and there is some CSIRO research which I might speak of later which can address those kinds of questions.

Given all of those implications both scientific and economic, we need to know a lot more about this problem when we take very significant decisions and make legal changes which impact on the economy and the quality of life of our constituents and indeed the world as a whole. We need to know exactly where the CO2 is coming from, we need to know in what proportions and we certainly need to know what the cost-benefit analysis is in relation to reducing CO2 from any of its potential sources. Quite clearly, if there are straightforward low cost ways of reducing CO2 emissions, those are the ways we should look to first. We should not look to the more expensive option first when we can make significant gains through modest changes which are of low cost.

I think that is a very elementary proposition. However, it is not a proposition which comes through in this legislation. I think that is a serious flaw in the way in which the government has presented this bill and the associated explanatory memorandum. There is very little supporting material to really bring to the attention of the parliament and the people the view that the government has examined in detail what the implications are of each of the projected changes in CO2 or the mechanisms that the government is proposing and what contribution each of the alternative and renewable energies that the government is promoting by this legislation might make to CO2 reduction, what the cost per tonne of CO2 avoided would be in each of those cases and what the long-term economic analysis is in relation to the totality of this proposed change.

We have had some difficulty lately extracting economic modelling from the government in the context of petrol price changes and the GST. Petrol is quite relevant to this legislation. Again the government refers extensively to economic modelling in the explanatory memorandum, but very little detail of that is provided. At one point it suggests that the cost of carbon dioxide per tonne avoided would be in the order of $90. If this is true and applies across the board to the proposal, that is very expensive carbon dioxide indeed. There are other ways of reducing CO2 which would cost far less than $90.

We have to examine this legislation from the perspective of what it is setting out to achieve, what its objective is. That may seem a trite question. What this bill is meant to address might seem obvious to honourable members—and perhaps it is to the government—but I suggest it is not. The bill is simply looking at promoting renewable energy. That is the title of the bill and that is the straight effect of it. It provides a financial subsidy to renewable energy. It does not specify which forms of renewable energy. It is not biased in support of any of those forms of renewable energy and, indeed, it makes something of a virtue of that lack of bias. But it does not tell us what the CO2 changes will be as a result of this legislation. It would be impossible, given the lack of specificity in the proposal over any of its 10- or 20-year projected lifespan, to work out just what the CO2 benefits or costs would be. That is simply entirely lacking from this legislation. I think that is quite critical given that the sole purpose of this bill should be to ensure that less CO2 goes into the atmosphere as a result of Australia's economic and cultural activity over the next 10 or 20 years. That should be the objective of this bill. It should be titled the `CO2 reduction bill'. That would be a far more relevant title and one which conveyed the objective of the legislation and the reason for this community to sink so many hundreds of millions of dollars into this proposal. That would be far more communicative and it would set us all on the right track.

The opposition fully support renewable energy. We all understand the benefits of solar energy, wind energy and hydro-electricity in Tasmania. I have been encouraged by my friend and colleague Sid Sidebottom, the member for Braddon, in recent months as to the value of Tasmania's hydro-electricity generation to the Tasmanian economy and the contribution that it can make to the Australian economy as a whole. It, of course, does not generate any carbon dioxide in the generation phase. There is the potential to improve that hydro-electricity generating capacity, generate yet more electricity, and connect that to the Australian grid as a whole and to do so in a way that generates no CO2. The member for Braddon is also very strong in his support, as I am sure he will tell the House himself shortly, of the proposed wind farms in Tasmania. Tasmania has that opportunity through its Hydro Electricity Commission and the fact that it is sited in one of the windiest parts of the world—I am not sure whether that is good for its tourism or not, but certainly some parts of Tasmania's mainland are subject to very substantial winds. Those places would be well suited to wind farm energy.

Those are two very realistic propositions—wind energy in Tasmania and improving the efficiency of hydro-electricity generation in Tasmania and possibly in some modest way extending that hydro-electricity capacity. Does this bill favour those areas of renewable energy? No, not particularly. If you analyse the bill, the likely end result of this legislation if passed in its present form is support for biomass and the energy that can be generated from biomass. Why is that? Because biomass is the cheapest available renewable electricity generator. Given the technology neutral, market-driven approach of this legislation, that will lead directly to massive support and financial support for biomass. Has the government reached the conclusion that biomass is the best way to generate renewable energy in this country over the next two decades? Has the government decided that this will lead to the greatest enhancement of our technological capacity and of our manufacturing capacity and lead to the greatest potential for exports to other countries like the United States, Europe or developing countries? Has the government made this reasoned decision? No, I am afraid it has not. Sadly, that is entirely lacking from this proposition.

Biomass is something that environmentalists often question. The reality is that it is a burning proposition: you have to burn or ferment biomass to produce energy. That often produces air pollution and it also produces carbon dioxide, but, hopefully, that is negated when the next round of crops are grown for the next round of biomass. While biomass has niche market potential, I would suggest to the House that it is by far the least likely contributor to an advanced, technological, export-driven economy for Australia in the year 2010 or 2020. Yet wind, solar or hydro-electricity might well be.

The government is going to sink hundreds of millions—perhaps billions—of dollars into this. Analysis by the Electricity Supply Association of Australia, which computed the likely cost of this based on the penalty cost of $40 a megawatt hour, showed that the likely cost of this over the next 10 to 20 years would be of the order of $5 billion. That is the capital cost which people will have to sink into this kind of investment. Even the government admits to a direct cost over the next 10 years of some $250 million. It also admits that its figures are far from clearly defined.

The consequence of this is that, under the kind of funding which the community will put forward for this legislation, we could have had specific and targeted investments in research and development for solar, wind and hydro-electricity improvements of the kind that I have spoken about. We could have had targeted investment in fuel cells or the ethanol substitution option. Those things will all be largely negated by the market because the market will, logically and properly, go for the cheapest available option—which, as I said, is biomass. We have no certainty that the most appropriate investments will be made in this context. The market will invest in the obvious way that the market should invest—in the cheapest proposition. Only society as a whole can direct investment into that which is likely to be to the best long-term advantage of the community as a whole.

Renewable energy has a very long history throughout the world. It is not the first time that we have sought to support it through subsidies. Indeed, the United States have a history of quite massive support for different kinds of energy. Many honourable members would not support the massive investment by the US in nuclear power, for example, but that is only sustained by US government investment. The US have also invested heavily in solar, wind, biomass and a range of other renewable technologies. They have yet to get those to the point where the market will sustain them. There is no immediate prospect of that being the case.

Unfortunately, these things are always just around the corner, and it can always be said that just a little more taxpayer support will push them over the edge and make them viable. I am quite sure that eventually wind energy, in the first instance, will be there—it is almost there and it has been almost there for quite a long time. Certainly hydro is already there; that is without question and we can make significant gains by increasing its efficiency—so that is taken as read. Some targeted investment in R&D might well push, say, wind generators over the edge into commercial viability, but a simple market based subsidy may not have that effect. In the interests of Tasmania and in the interests of those who want to see a high-tech manufacturing capacity in this context, we need to consider some different approaches.

Solar is more problematic again in the immediate future. The reality is that we have reached some barriers at approximately 30 per cent conversion efficiency. Australians are at the forefront of this research. I visited the facility of those who won the Australia Prize some years ago. In this country, we have done some fantastic research both in low-grade solar water heating, which I think should be used much more widely in this country, and in photovoltaic cells, which convert sunlight directly into electricity but have a limited efficiency. At this stage, their efficiency is such that the cost factor is far too high.

The other issue with renewables in this context is that, while the price of renewables has fallen as technology has improved and become more cost effective, so has the price of fossil fuels. So we have seen dramatic falls—subject to the price of oil going up and down, as we know, from time to time—but if one looks across the board at the fossil fuels we use to generate power, the price of coal and natural gas has declined, supply has increased and the known and probable reserves continue to rise. So, far from being in a position where these commodities are fast running out, the reality is that our reserves are becoming ever larger. Technology is continually improving the efficiency with which we burn those fossil fuels. The harsh reality is that as renewables have become cheaper and potentially more attractive, so traditional fuels have also become cheaper and technology has made them more attractive by reducing the pollution component from the fossil fuels that we now use.

The prospect is that in the next 10 to 15 years we will even see zero emission coal plants. The prospect is that, again with some targeted investment in R&D, we will have coal plants that emit no nitrous oxides, no sulfur dioxides and which are particulate free—a very significant advance over what we have now. While it may seem absurd to speak of environmentally responsible coal, the reality is that that will be available to us in the near future. Given that the vast majority of our electricity is generated by coal and gas, and that this will be so no matter what happens with the government's legislation, even if it were fully taken up and fully used, the reality is that the vast majority of the CO2 from electricity generation in this country will still continue to come from coal and gas because they will remain far and away the most cost-effective generators of electricity.

We should be looking at ways of making those sources more CO2 friendly and reducing the CO2 emissions—not only the nitrous oxide, sulfur dioxide and particulates but also, particularly in this context, the CO2 emissions—from those plants. While it is difficult to do with coal, the reality is that the shift to gas is a very important trend. Despite the billions of dollars which the United States has invested over the last few decades or longer in alternative and renewable energies, the one energy source which has emerged as the clear winner in the United States, and also in Australia in recent times, has been the once source of energy which the US government did not support—indeed, it even constrained it by price controls at the wellhead—and that is natural gas.

The reality is that the use of natural gas in the United States and Australia is charging ahead. It is a good job that it is because gas is far less CO2 intensive than coal. It generates perhaps half the CO2 of a coal-fired power plant and does so with much less pollution. Clearly, the potential for natural gas is something that the whole system missed—which one has the potential to do when one supports energy from an ideological bias and not from a clear, scientific, environmental and close economic analysis of what the costs and benefits to society would be. That is an approach that I strongly commend to the House in this context.

If one were to look at that, one would look, in the near term at least, at ways of improving the efficiency of our coal powered plants and at ways of using the very massive resources of both brown and black coal which this country has, and ensuring they are economically available to us. The future wealth of this country will depend very much on our ability to generate cost-effective energy. It makes no sense to take energy intensive applications like the refining of light metals in Gladstone—which I recently had the opportunity to examine—the aluminium and potential magnesium refining industries, because they are enormous users of energy and, therefore, generators de facto of CO2. If those plants were transferred to non-annex 1 countries—to, say, our neighbours in this region or Qatar or some of the other countries which have cheap supplies of natural gas, as we do—then certainly the world would not be the winner because the same or more CO2 would be generated and the same or more pollution would likely be generated and Australia's economy would be very significantly the loser. That is not an option I want to see from this kind of legislation.

The reality is that exporting carbon in that way, because we are forced to make changes to the cost structure of our electricity generation, is far from effective. What much of this legislation ignores is the opportunity of sequestration. There is much debate in the global community at the moment about the extent to which carbon sinks and carbon emission trading and sequestration should be allowed to meet Kyoto objectives. If we allow unrestrained emissions trading, particularly with the former Soviet Union bloc countries, then the United States in particular will meet most of its obligations under Kyoto—if it were ever to sign up to them—by buying cheap permits from the former Soviet Union. It would not, in fact, reduce its own CO2 emissions, which is hardly a net benefit to the environment. These are the kinds of issues which we are forced to address but which this legislation and the government's analysis simply do not address.

The other reality is to shift our energy generation economy towards gas—which I see as something the government and the parliament should in a bipartisan way support—and to promote our great natural gas industry from the Timor Gap and PNG from which, potentially, gas could come by pipeline down the east coast of Australia. There are, too, of course, the enormous fields of the North West Shelf and down the coast of Western Australia to the Gorgon fields, and many others of which, I am sure, our colleagues from Western Australia will wish to extol the virtues. I have had the pleasure of visiting the Western Australian fields on several occasions and I know they are extremely well managed. The activities of companies seeking to develop those fields—while they have their own commercial interests well at heart, I am sure, and the interests of their shareholders as the law requires—will benefit the global economy and the Australian economy, and we should allow them to do it.

So what of the option of choosing an often discussed renewable energy, such as biomass, and supporting that? I am not opposed to biomass per se; one should not interpret my comments to be against biomass or against renewable energy, because I am not. Obviously, to the extent to which it can be properly utilised in the right context it makes great sense. In many cases biomass, because of its unique regional location, will make a contribution to regional economies which are not easily supplied from the national grid but have the availability of cheap and readily available bio-fuels and can take advantage of the heat that is co-generated along with the electricity. In those sorts of situations, we should indeed be taking advantage of biomass. But to mandate that across the whole economy at enormous cost to the economy as a whole, without looking at the alternatives which might well channel research and development funds into targeted investments in the most appropriate technologies, is very short-sighted. It is not a sensible response to greenhouse and not a sensible response to Kyoto, but merely a short-term, knee-jerk reaction by this government seeking political favour in a context where it sees that it needs green credentials.

Unfortunately, in the final analysis, this is far from a green credential and it is far from an economic credential. I am very surprised that the business community have not addressed it more substantially because they and the work force of Australia are potentially the losers from this if costs are directed in the wrong way and if we do not take proper advantage of the technology which is available. So I say let us look very closely at this legislation over the next six to eight weeks. Since the government does not want to give the House of Representatives time to do it, let the Senate examine it closely, and let us—

talk.start.para: —We are doing it.

—A week for legislation like this, Minister? I suspect you would not have been so relaxed if you had had to do the GST overnight. The reality is that this legislation does not precisely target what it should be targeting. What I want it to target is greenhouse gas reductions in the most cost-effective and environmentally appropriate way for this country. That is the target we should all be here to agree on and meet. Unfortunately, it is not the primary target of this bill, and I ask the government to reconsider that over the winter break so that we can have a more considered position when the parliament next has the opportunity to review this legislation. The opposition will support its passage this evening because that is the only reasonable thing to do, but we reserve our detailed response for the Senate. (Time expired)

—The Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 is part of a range of very worthy measures by the government in tackling the global problem of the greenhouse effect. The harnessing of renewable energies is a challenge that we must address now. Australia's commitment under the Kyoto protocol is a target of greenhouse gas emissions of just eight per cent above 1990 levels, which is effectively a 30 per cent reduction over this period to 2008-12 on current emissions projections.

speech.para: Naturally, after that deadline, we can expect even tougher targets on reducing greenhouse gases. Australia is a relatively small producer of greenhouse gases. The largest culprit is the United States; the next biggest is Russia and the other former republics of the Soviet Union; and the third biggest is all the developing countries combined. The latter is largely due to Third World slash and burn agriculture. I think this should always be taken into consideration when Australia enters into any agreements.

It is of interest that ozone forms in the earth's atmosphere through the action of sunlight on oxygen. In the late 1970s, scientists working in Antarctica detected periodic loss of ozone in this layer above that continent. Similar studies have found a problem in the Arctic. The destruction of the ozone layer will aggravate our global warming problems because of the increase in solar radiation reaching the earth.

So is there evidence of global warming? I guess that is the ultimate question. The answer is definitely yes. As the previous speaker said, as carbon dioxide and methane gas increase in the atmosphere, more radiated heat from the earth is trapped close to the ground. This forms the troposphere, close to the ground. If this is the case, the upper atmosphere would get less heat and would cool. The mesosphere, which is this upper atmosphere, is 50 to 90 kilometres up and has been cooling at a degree every year for the past 30 years—10 times faster than predicted. This cooling also occurs, albeit not as rapidly, in the stratosphere, where the ozone layer is. Global warming is occurring. The ice particles inside the polar stratospheric cloud form below negative 80 degrees Centigrade, speeding up the damage caused by the ozone depleting chemicals. Aggravating the whole effect are the rising world temperatures warming the tropical oceans, heating up the troposphere above and increasing the temperature difference between the tropics and poles.
