This speeds up the strong winter wind known as the polar night jet, which encircles the Arctic in the lower stratosphere, isolating this region even further and causing new rapid depletion of ozone above this region. We know this phenomenon also occurs in the Antarctic.

Sceptics who need a little tangible evidence of the greenhouse effect should take a look at our neighbour Venus. This planet has nearly the same mass and the same size as Earth, and although it is closer to the sun, Venus has dense clouds so it actually absorbs less sunlight than Earth. The surface temperature on Venus, however, is a rather toasty 470 degrees Centigrade. This is caused by the huge amounts of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere—in other words, the greenhouse effect. This is what can happen to the Earth if there is an increase in greenhouse gases to this level. With an increasing population on our planet, we are pumping out more greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide into the atmosphere with the burning of fossil fuels and the destruction of forests. The actual figure is thought to be around seven billion tonnes of CO2 a year. As an aside, we often hear that the solution to reducing greenhouse gases is to plant more forests. This will help as long as the trees are growing, but then you have the problem of what to do with the fully matured ones. A fully grown tree will release CO2 into the environment disproportionately to its carbon trapping. A more efficient way of trapping CO2 is to plant more of what are known as C4, or carbon 4, type plants. These are plants like sugarcane and the grass family.

We all know that plants use a process of photosynthesis to absorb light. But photosynthesis is actually quite inefficient. Normal forestry plants, for example, only absorb 0.2 per cent of light as chemical energy. C4 plants like sugarcane, however, are more efficient and around eight per cent of the light absorbed by the plant is preserved as chemical energy. This energy can then be used to trap CO2 with minimal release. I am sure the member for Kennedy will explain the biomass energy potential of this.

talk.start.para: —We are talking about the member for Kennedy and hot air, are we?
—Sugarcane.
—CO2.

—Will you behave. The future will see if we can bio-engineer this into forestry to make C3 plants as efficient as C4. Electricity generation makes up the largest proportion of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions, and in the next 10 years it will make up 41 per cent of our total emissions. Renewable energy as a source of electricity, however, contributes little to the greenhouse effect. The Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 and the associated Renewable Energy (Electricity) (Charge) Bill 2000 are just two of many greenhouse response measures that will help us meet our Kyoto commitments. This should result in the reduction of 5.5 million tonnes of greenhouse gases by 2010. The previous speaker did not know that. This measure will create an instant market demand for renewable energy while leaving it up to the various sellers of renewable energy to vie for business by being as competitive as possible.

speech.para: Under this legislation, wholesale buyers of electricity will be required to purchase additional renewable energy through trading renewable energy certificates. The number of certificates they must purchase will depend upon their projected market share of electricity purchases on liable grids. Their proportion of market share will then equate to their proportion of the target set for that year. The Australian target will reach 9,500 gigawatt hours of renewable energy by 2010. This is the equivalent to twice the renewable energy output of the Snowy Mountains hydroelectric scheme. If the buyer does not meet their particular target, they will be liable for a renewable energy charge. However, if the buyer is able to meet their shortfall over the next three-year period, they will be able to redeem that penalty. This approach is one of the first of its kind for a renewable energy scheme and represents around $2 billion in investment in renewable energy over the next 10 years.

If the targets are met over the next 10 years, and this is a very significant point about this legislation, the amount of renewable energy used in Australia compared with fossil fuels would have gone from 10.5 per cent of all energy used in 1997 to 12.5 per cent in 2010. This is significant because, if this legislation is not passed, our consumption of renewable energy will in fact decline. A Renewable Energy Regulator, appointed by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, will be created in order to oversee this scheme. This country already has many innovative sources of renewable energy, and it is worth noting that Tasmania, our smallest state, currently generates more than half of this nation's renewable energy.

Companies are now investing in renewable energy sources in anticipation of energy certificates. Eligible renewable energy sources include solar—and Australia is still a world leader in solar technology, particularly in photovoltaics—wind, tidal, hydro, and biofuels such as landfill gas, biogas, biomass and waste by-products from agricultural industries. We are also world leaders. The Howard government has taken a leading role in greenhouse response programs, with funding commitments now totalling nearly $1 billion over the next five years. This includes a very worthy funding allocation from the budget of $21 million for greenhouse science and about $400 million to assist with the commercialisationand application of renewable energy technologies.

There are challenges. As yet, wave energy conversion to electricity has not been commercially viable, but there are solutions. On the 20th of this month, the Howard government announced the funding of a feasibility study into the Derby Tidal Energy Project in my state of Western Australia. I know that the member for Kalgoorlie is speaking on this bill today, and this project would be situated in his electorate. His efforts so far on this project have been marvellous. Tidal power has been used for many centuries, through the effects of the sun and the moon upon the earth causing a gravitational pull which results in the tidal movements we observe. It was used to pump all of London's water supply until 1824. If you have ever visited the north-west town of Derby, you will know that they have some pretty amazing tides. In fact, its deep inlets and bays, coupled with tides of some 10 metres, makes it one of the best locations in the world for a power station.

The proposed tidal power station would generate 48 megawatts with the double basin scheme—one with a high water level and one with a low level, providing power around the clock. The station would reduce emissions of carbon dioxide by 150,000 tonnes and would help Australia meet its Kyoto obligations by reducing emissions by two per cent by 2010. In fact, the station would supply 50 per cent of WA's needs to meet this agreement in power. The lake that will be created by the upper basin will promote such economic generating activities as tourism, aquaculture, fishing, and power generation for the mining industry. The $1 million commitment for the feasibility study from the federal government is a welcome indication that it is serious about harnessing renewable energy. It has the potential to put Australia at the forefront oftidal power technology, but we have only a small window of opportunity to get it right. I personally call on the Western Australian government to wait until this feasibility study has been completed before they make any commitment to a fossil-fuel substitute. The previous speaker, the member for Bonython, mentioned natural gas. Natural gas is terrific. In WA we have a problem—about 11 per cent CO2 comes out of that, and we need to reinject that. That is a problem.

It is important when developing schemes like the renewable energy certificates to ensure that we offer quality alternatives to fossil fuels. If the tidal power station is built, it is estimated it would receive around $4 million a year from the renewable energy certificates that this legislation is creating. The incentives to invest and develop renewable energy in this country will be enormous. This bill also represents an incredible injection of jobs into rural areas, with estimates showing the potential for 10,000 jobs to be created around the renewable energy industry. The renewable energy certificates do not represent the least-cost method of reducing greenhouse gases in the short term but represent a long-term solution to support long-term high levels of emissions reduction.

The United Kingdom's levy system on renewable energy has shown that, over time, the costs of generating electricity from a renewable energy source can be brought to levels comparable with traditional energy sources. By nurturing and encouraging our renewable energy base, the Australian economy will be better placed to respond to greenhouse targets which, in the future, will place greater emphasis on renewable energy sources. It is for this reason that I fully support this bill and commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —Around the world, increasing interest in renewable energy has led to significant investment and growth over the past decade. This interest in alternative energy sources has been driven by three factors. The first one has been the desire to reduce pollution. Much of the pollution which disfigures large cities in Asia, Europe and America has as its origin traditional fossil fuels—coal and oil. Secondly, there is concern that the non-renewable energy sources are being consumed at an unsustainable rate and will run out, or that at least their scarcity will send the price up in a way which attacks our present living standards—I guess motorists are already getting an insight into the future as the Saudi oil price per barrel keeps sneaking up. They certainly do not need any help by way of increased government taxation on petrol, as we have been discussing this week.

speech.para: Increasingly dominant, however, is national and international action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The problem has led to countries such as the United States, Japan, Germany and Denmark providing government policy support for renewable energy over the past decade. The resulting growth has been impressive. For example, the average global annual sales of wind turbines over the past six years have been 40 per cent. The photovoltaic market globally has averaged 25 per cent growth over the past five years, and even more impressive are the estimates of future growth. The United Nations has forecast that renewable energy will provide 30 per cent of the world's energy by the year 2025 and some 45 per cent by the year 2050. Shell is even bolder than the United Nations, predicting a 50 per cent share by 2050. Indeed, Shell is starting to put its money where its mouth is. In 1997 it established Shell International Renewables, with a budget of some $US500 million over five years. In 1999 it opened the biggest solar panel factory in the world in Germany.

Australia is well placed to develop a world-class renewable energy industry, yielding benefits in jobs, regional development, economic growth, exports and, of course, the environment. So far, however, we have not pursued these opportunities with the sense of urgency necessary to get and stay in front of overseas competitors, such as Japan, Europe and the United States. With respect to specific opportunities for alternative energy industries, Australia has excellent credentials in the solar photovoltaic area. We have one of the world's best solar resources, we are located in the heart of the Asia-Pacific, and we have world competitive research and development and emerging new players in an established solar industry. Three of our solar research organisations are world leaders: the Photovoltaic Special Research Centre at the University of New South Wales, Pacific Solar Pty Ltd and Sustainable Technologies Australia Ltd. The manufacture of solar photovoltaic is considerable. The US solar industry predicts that the US market will grow to $2.5 billion within 10 years and that the European and Japanese markets will be similar in size. We have the potential to capture a good share of this growing market. We are the largest manufacturer of solar PV on a per capita basis in the world. Properly exploiting our competitive advantage in photovoltaics could make Australia a silicon valley of solar.

There are examples of other countries also supporting their renewable industries. We can see, for example, Japan's New Sunshine Project, which provides a capital subsidy for around 30 per cent of the cost of a solar PV system. Japan is aiming for 4,600 megawatts of solar—which is 35 times what the entire global production was back in 1997—by the year 2010. Germany offers zero interest loans as part of the government's 100,000 Solar Rooftop program. The 10-year interest free loan, with no repayments in the first two years, amounts to a 38 per cent subsidy of the total cost of a solar PV system. The European Union collectively has a target of 500,000 solar rooftops by the year 2010. Similarly, in the United States, their Million Solar Roofs initiative offers tax credits against renewable energy equipment.

Other options that are engaged in overseas include target setting, mandatory requirements for solar panels on new houses and other buildings, and allowing consumers to pay off on their electricity bill the cost of a solar panel, thereby getting around the disincentive of the up-front capital cost. The electricity cost savings mean that the solar panel pays for itself. One problem that does arise with all of this is the privatisation push for Australian power utilities. While that problem is not insurmountable, it does seem to me much more difficult for an electricity company that is geared to making profits for its shareholders to actually discourage people from using its product—much more difficult for the privately owned company than for a publicly owned authority.

On the subject of wind power, one of the attractions that ought to be pointed out is its regional development potential. The United States Department of Energy has estimated that the government's goal of providing five per cent of the nation's electricity from wind by the year 2020 will provide $US60 billion in capital investment in rural America and $US1.2 billion in new income for rural land-owners. It will also provide 80,000 new permanent jobs and save 35 million tonnes of carbon dioxide. I think that the potential for rural and regional Australia is no less real. Australia has a high quality wind resource, with the best resources located in Tasmania, south-west Western Australia, Victoria and Central New South Wales. A wind turbine manufacturing facility opened in the Latrobe Valley last year, and that is expected to create 600 or 700 regional jobs over three years. Tasmania's Hydro Electric Corporation is developing a $114 million, 76 megawatt wind farm. These are precisely the areas—the Latrobe Valley and Tasmania—that have been worst affected by globalisation in recent times. It is noteworthy that the renewable energy industries require similar skills to the mining, manufacturing and conventional energy sectors—the sectors from which jobs have been disappearing.

The country that has most effectively mobilised wind power has been Denmark. From zero at the start of the 1980s, Denmark's wind industry now has a turnover of $US1 billion, giving it 60 per cent of the world market. The industry employs 15,000 people in Denmark. In 1997 wind turbines were the country's fourth largest export commodity. This success has arisen from conscious government policy. From 1981 the Danish government set increasing domestic wind energy targets. Wind currently produces 10 per cent of Denmark's electricity, and the latest target is 50 per cent by the year 2030. The construction of wind turbines was supported by an investment subsidy which started at 30 per cent and was phased out during the 1980s. It has been replaced by a guaranteed payment for every unit of electricity generated from wind power set at a level to reflect its lack of pollution. There is also a rebate on electricity taxes. The United States has set a target of 5.5 per cent of government electricity use to come from wind power by the year 2010. Once again, I think that these are initiatives that Australia would do well to consider. A wind power industry which provides employment for steel manufacturers and electronic and engineering companies and which would require substantial apprenticeship and training programs would be a great national asset.

I will also mention the area of liquid petroleum gas. Transport fuels are responsible for over a quarter of Australia's emissions of carbon dioxide—the most significant of all greenhouse gases. While solar and wind power are the most promising means of dealing with the contribution made by our electricity consumption to the greenhouse effect, the most advanced means for dealing with the transport fuels problem is through greater use of liquid petroleum gas. The Prime Minister's 1997 pre-Kyoto conference statement on climate change sought a 15 per cent improvement in motor car fuel efficiency by 2010 compared with business as usual. LPG vehicles have up to 15 per cent less carbon dioxide emissions than the equivalent gasoline powered car, and therefore have the potential, almost single-handed, to deliver the government's target—otherwise, it is hard to see how we would get there in the time frame available. Lowered greenhouse emissions are just one of three environmental benefits we can achieve from using LPG. LPG typically has around 20 per cent less ozone forming potential than the equivalent petrol fuelled vehicle and, accordingly, less tendency to generate photochemical smog. Photochemical smog, much of which is caused by emissions from transport vehicles, is strongly linked to asthma and other bronchial disorders.

LPG has an even more impressive result for air toxics emissions—up to 80 per cent less. It is also claimed that LPG operates much more cleanly than petrol when the engine is cold. So, given the prevalence of short journeys in the city, the benefits of LPG may indeed be understated by those figures. LPG has made very solid inroads in Australia. Around half a million motorists use it, over 1,200 small businesses are engaged in LPG conversions, and virtually all Australian taxis now run on LPG. What remains needed is government commitment to promoting more LPG conversions, including rather closer price monitoring than we have seen so far from the Howard government. If we are serious about meeting our modest Kyoto commitments, we still need to deal with the up-front cost of LPG conversion, although the mechanism for doing this is not as obvious as it is for solar panels. To date, LPG has not made any inroads as a heavy vehicle fuel, for example, for buses and trucks.

Having made those general observations, I turn to the provisions of the Renewable Energy (Electricity) (Charge) Bill 2000. This bill is intended to implement the government's decision in 1997 to introduce a mandatory requirement on electricity retailers and large users to source an additional two per cent of their electricity consumption by 2010. Electricity generation is the largest single contributor to Australia's greenhouse gas emissions. In 1997, it accounted for some 35.4 per cent of total emissions. Not only is it the largest contributor to emissions but it has one of the fastest rates in emissions growth. In 2010, it is expected, for example, to account for 41 per cent of emissions. The objective of the bill is to increase the contribution of renewable energy generation to Australia's electricity supply and help support the continued growth of a vibrant renewables industry in Australia.

Whether it actually achieves this objective remains to be seen. There are doubts about its adequacy across the spectrum of stakeholders in this debate. It is therefore important that this parliament is used as a proper forum to get the legislation right. There have been many issues raised with the Labor Party by both industry and conservation groups regarding a range of concerns with the bill. We will be referring the legislation for review by the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee to allow for appropriate parliamentary assessment of the legislation. We will determine our position on the legislation once we have had an opportunity to reflect on those concerns and to consider amendments.

This bill was promised some 2½ years ago. It has been subject to internal government in-fighting which has led to the delay. The perennial divisions within the South Australian branch of the Liberal Party have been reflected in yet another Senator Minchin-Senator Hill `shoot-out' over this legislation. The measure we are talking about was first announced as part of the Prime Minister's statement back in November 1997 and formed an important part of the approach taken by the government in Kyoto. The emphasis placed on this measure in terms of our international credibility when it comes to a response on greenhouse should be put in some perspective.

Other countries have set similar targets for increasing the contribution of renewable generation to their electricity supply. The European Union has pledged to increase their overall renewable energy contribution to 12 per cent. That is a 10 per cent increase over the current contribution. I mentioned before Denmark's performance in wind power. They have a target of 12 per cent of electricity supply to be generated from renewable sources by 2005 and 100 per cent by 2050. Last week, when Greenpeace were giving evidence to the Senate inquiry into climate change, they said that, in the 2½ years that we have been talking about how to implement a two per cent target, the Danes have increased their renewable generation contribution by some three per cent. That makes our two per cent target small, but as a target we would observe that it does represent a step in the right direction.

The Labor Party supports market based approaches that encourage innovation and cost effectiveness. However, in establishing an appropriate framework for such a market based approach, we think it is essential that we do not disadvantage technologies that will be important in the longer term. We would think that this measure ought to be part of a larger overall strategy which uses both push and pull strategies, with appropriate levels of investment in research, development and commercialisation of technologies. The government's recently launched renewable energy industry action agenda represented a mix of such strategies, but was essentially a rehash of previous initiatives—virtually every measure announced by the government had already commenced. Many of these are part of the National Greenhouse Strategy or are already being pursued by industry and we would want to see a more visionary agenda from the government.

The development of a renewable energy industry enjoys widespread support around the community, despite some lack of awareness and understanding of the current contribution of renewables and their relative impact compared with fossil fuel generated electricity. For example, according to research undertaken by the New South Wales Sustainable Energy Development Authority, most people in New South Wales identify solar and hydro before coal as the most dominant source for electricity generation. That same research indicated that over two-thirds of New South Wales consumers are interested in buying their power from environmentally preferable sources. These things indicate that consumers want green power and indeed that many think they are already getting it. The Carr government's Greenpower program, now operating nationally, has further demonstrated consumer demand for renewable energy. That voluntary program has resulted in considerable interest in renewable generation capacity, which provides a sound basis for further development to meet the additional 9,500 MWh target. Interim annual targets have already been set to reach the overall two per cent increase by 2010.

One issue that has been raised is that, with existing renewable capacity, we are already over the first target set for 2001. That means that there could be less incentive to invest in new capacity in the first years of the legislation. That is an issue which might well be explored in the Senate review process. Another issue that ought to be examined closely is the level at which a penalty is set and the impact that that is going to have on the mix of technologies taken up under the measure. That is going to impact not only on whether we drive new, desirable technologies but also on where investment and job creation will occur. The sorts of technologies that result under this measure should impact across the geographic spread in terms of new investment and jobs.

There should be regional benefits arising from this legislation. It is a pity, frankly, that the National Party sees fit to play a spoiler role within the government concerning issues of greenhouse when regional Australia could well be a winner from greenhouse abatement activity. I think the National Party representatives need to realise that renewable investment should mean jobs in regional Australia. Not only does greenhouse action offer positive benefits for regional Australia but greenhouse inaction has dire consequences for regional Australia.

We saw the Senate inquiry into global warming being told very recently that CSIRO research shows water entering our rivers in the Murray-Darling basin could decrease by some 30 per cent by 2050, and we can expect an increase in the frequency and severity of droughts in south-eastern and eastern Australia. Given these things, we do have a number of concerns and we intend to canvass them in the committee process. We certainly think that there are some useful things that we can look at in terms of this legislation. We do have to understand how the challenge of climate change is going to impact on us and we do have to realise the opportunities of the future. We intend to work in terms of this legislation and our other opportunities to ensure that we do grasp and realise those opportunities of the future as well as respond to the challenge of climate change.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to stand and lend my support to the two bills under discussion this evening, the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 and the Renewable Energy (Electricity) (Charge) Bill 2000. It is a fact that the world's supply of fossil fuels will one day be exhausted through overexploitation by humankind, so I am always happy to support concrete measures which will contribute towards the lasting protection of our natural environment. The fossil fuels will not disappear during our lifetime, nor during the lives of the more youthful members of this House, but their supply will dry up sooner rather than later if alternative forms of energy generation are not encouraged and promoted by governments of today.

speech.para: These bills are vital elements of this government's push to create a competitive and sustainable renewable energy industry in Australia over the next 10 to 20 years. Over the long term, the government's efforts and initiatives to reduce the levels of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions may very well come to be regarded as the most significant achievement amongst a host of similarly notable successes. Future generations will, I believe, judge the Howard government as one of the most progressive and far-sighted in Australia's history, initiating as it has an array of much needed reforms in key socioeconomic areas. Taxation reform and health insurance reform immediately come to mind, but it remains my contention that the government's most enduring legacy will be the standard it has adopted to stimulate and encourage the development of a viable industry in the field of renewable energy generation.

These bills will enable the government to place a legal liability on retailers and wholesale purchasers of electricity to strive to meet its mandatory renewable energy target. That target is the generation of an additional 9,500 gigawatt hours of new renewable energy by the year 2010, and retailers and wholesale purchasers will be required to contribute towards this proportionate to their market share of total purchases on liable grids. To allow for increased efficiency in the management of this scheme, the government has decided that the final target of 9,500 gigawatt hours will be reached in incremental stages between next year and the year 2010, with sales on grids of more than 100 megawatts installed capacity to be liable. Moreover, should substandard operators fail or refuse to comply with these objectives, the government will be able to impose financial penalties of $40 per megawatt hour for any shortfall in generation at each stage.

Parties liable to contribute towards the mandatory renewable energy target will make their own arrangements as to how this is done in each particular instance. The Australian Greenhouse Office has provided a list of all eligible sources of renewable energy where that energy will be used for electricity generation or displacement. Those sources include solar power; wind power; the use of biofuels, such as landfill gas and biogas; and ocean, wave or tidal power.

It is true that the government is asking industry to do more than it otherwise might have been prepared to do in this area, but we do not apologise for that given the necessity of greenhouse reduction through alternative forms of energy generation. Even though greenhouse emissions from this country account for less than two per cent of the worldwide total, this government is determined that Australia will play a leading role in the preservation of a healthy, natural environment for our children and their children's children. The mandatory renewable energy target is a small though integral part of the government's overall commitment to this. Of course, in outlining an initiative of this nature, the potential is always there for the more politically opportunist members of the opposition to claim that the government is not doing enough or that the government should be setting higher targets where the very important issue of greenhouse gas reduction is concerned. However, the fact is that the generation of 9,500 gigawatt hours of renewable energy will represent a major increase in this country's output of energy of that type. Generation levels in the year 2010 will actually be 60 per cent higher than they are today.

The opposition also prides itself on the reputation it has obtained—completely unjustly, I would contend—that it is the friend of the worker. However, the cost to this country's work force of setting unrealistic targets for the reduction of greenhouse emissions over the short to medium term would be truly staggering. The Prime Minister, in his Safeguarding the Future statement to parliament in November 1997, correctly noted that energy intensive projects worth some $68 billion, mostly in export and manufacturing sectors, would be lost, along with the jobs of more than 90,000 workers in those areas, if the government was to approach this very serious issue in an unrealistic manner. It is also pertinent to point out that the government's dual focus of renewable energy generation as a method of reducing greenhouse emissions and of providing industry development will prove highly beneficial throughout this industry. The government has contributed $21 million to the creation of the Renewable Energy Innovation Investment Fund, as well as a further $10 million to showcase leading projects in areas such as tidal power, solar thermal power and photovoltaic technologies. This compares particularly favourably with the miserly $4.8 million spent by the Keating Labor government on its Renewable Energy Industry Program.

This leads me to the development taking place in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, in the far north of my electorate of Kalgoorlie. All members on this side of the House, and, I suspect, most of the Western Australian members on the other side, will know of my support for Tidal Energy Australia in its bid to supply power to the towns of Derby, Broome and Fitzroy Crossing and to the other communities along the proposed 500-kilometre West Kimberley electricity grid. At this stage I must thank the member for Moore for raising this issue also.

Tidal Energy Australia has submitted a proposal to the Western Australian state government outlining its aims to construct the world's first continuous tidal power facility at Doctor's Creek in King Sound, north of Derby. Tidal Energy Australia's proposal will allow for the construction of a 48 megawatt high basin-low basin project in what would be the largest renewable energy proposal seen in Australia to date. This project would provide enormous impetus to the government's agenda for a renewable energy industry, as its establishment would result in immediate savings of the 150,000 tonnes per year carbon dioxide emissions from existing diesel plants in the region. Its establishment would also greatly assist the Commonwealth in successfully attaining the greenhouse reduction targets which were agreed to at the Kyoto environment summit of 1997. As recently as last year, reports surfaced which suggested that greenhouse emissions from Western Australia alone were set to skyrocket over the coming decade, throwing doubt over Australia's ability to meet its targets.

I might at this stage remind the opposition of the extraordinary work of the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, who led the Australian delegation to Kyoto and succeeded in obtaining workable targets for Australia's greenhouse reduction strategy in the face of not inconsiderable opposition from the European Union. The damage to Australia's reputation as an innovator when it comes to the protection of the environment would be palpable should this country not succeed in reducing its greenhouse output by 2010.

Returning to the Kimberley tidal power project, I should highlight the many benefits renewable energy generation will provide in associated sectors for rural and regional communities. Estimates show that 10,000 jobs could be created in regional Australia in both the renewable energy industry and associated industries as a result of the implementation of the 9,500 gigawatt hour target. As many as 30 per cent of these jobs would be in areas directly related to the generation of electricity. Tidal Energy Australia principals estimate that 500 new jobs would be created in the West Kimberley simply as a result of the construction of the Doctors Creek station. The investment in infrastructure for the generation of electricity through the harnessing of tidal power would also provide an ongoing stimulus to the economies of local communities after that infrastructure becomes fully operational. Here I am referring to the increased job opportunities which would open up in industries such as hospitality and tourism, as well as in technical and trade sectors, where opportunities to participate in the management and maintenance of the facilities would abound. And all these advantages say nothing of the very real possibility that the supply of power to remote and isolated centres could be made more reliable and economically sound.

Tidal energy is not a new concept, having already addressed energy needs in France and Nova Scotia. However, the proposal for the West Kimberley is the first in the world providing continuous generation of power. The innovative technology demonstrated in such a worthwhile project would justify the confidence to construct a 500 megawatt station, providing the impetus to develop the Mitchell Plateau bauxite deposit. Low cost electricity is the key to alumina production, and clean renewable energy would fit with our Kyoto commitments. Located as the Kimberley is on the doorstep of Asia and being rich in resources, with the bonus of low energy cost, we have the potential to become a major manufacturing and population centre. This House last year endorsed a motion for Tidal Energy Australia's proposal to construct the Doctors Creek power station. That motion was moved by my colleague the member for La Trobe, well known as a long-time advocate of the benefits to be gained from this form of energy generation. My primary concern has always been to support initiatives which I know will benefit the population of the vast electorate of Kalgoorlie, so I have no hesitation in supporting the implementation of the two bills currently under discussion. For that reason, I wholeheartedly commend them to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 and related legislation is another example of the government developing legislation that is going in the right direction, but it is too little and it has taken too long to develop. The legislation puts in place the requirement for high energy users, that is large buyers of energy, to source two per cent of their energy needs from renewable sources by 2010. This was the only mandatory commitment that the government made in Kyoto, and it still has not delivered. In 1997 it said that it was going to bring in this legislation. In 1997 it said that it was going to make it a requirement for high energy users. Here we are, halfway through 2000, and still no legislation has been enacted. It really shows what sort of a commitment this government has to this type of technology, renewable energy. It really is less than inadequate. It has taken 2½ years to get to this stage and now it really has to work hard: it is desperate to push it through the House because it has promised that it will be in place by 1 January next year.

speech.para: I believe that this government should have moved a lot faster and actually shown a real commitment to introducing this two per cent requirement. In the time that it has taken to develop this legislation, Denmark has put in place a three per cent renewable requirement. I find it hard to believe that it will be really effective because the levels of penalties included in the legislation are far too low. A number of companies will opt to pay the penalties rather than invest in the technology that is needed to really meet this renewable energy requirement. Also, those companies that do meet the requirement will definitely be more inclined to invest in the cheaper technologies—biomass, technologies that use sugarcane waste and waste from saw mills, plantation forests and even woodchips. I am sure that the minister for forestry is pushing that as an option because we could hardly call woodchips a renewable source of energy.

We need legislation that is going to encourage a mix of technologies, not just a commitment to cheap options like biomass. We need legislation that will encourage companies to invest in wind, solar, tidal and all the other technologies that we have heard about here tonight. There should be a requirement to invest in technologies that are going to lead to long-term benefits and that are actually going to make a real impact in the energy industry and not opt for the short-term options that I believe this legislation will lead to.

The electricity supply industry has made a commitment to renewable energy. In fact, Pacific Power has a strong renewable group and Energy Australia has a strong commitment to developing renewable energy technologies. Both these companies have a strong Hunter base and renewable energy projects in the region. The Hunter region as a whole has made a strong commitment to renewable and sustainable industries. The industry development centre in the Hunter is giving priority to the development of sustainable energy industries with clusters concentrated on the development of environmentally friendly commercial activities.

One of the most innovative programs, and one that I would like to talk a little about, is run by Newcastle council. Australian Municipal Energy Improvement Facilities, which is a business unit of Newcastle council in the electorate of my colleague the member for Newcastle, is providing a service not only to the Hunter region but throughout the whole of Australia. The Hunter is an area that has really had to redefine the direction in which it is going and look at its whole industry base. With the closing of BHP and the downsizing of a number of heavy industries in the area, Newcastle council is showing some leadership and looking at embracing new industries and new technologies. One of those is the renewable energy technology. It is looking at picking up on the skills of all those highly skilled workers that have spent many years at BHP, workers that live in the electorates of Shortland, Paterson, Hunter and Charlton; all those very skilled workers will be able to be absorbed into all these new industries. They have even an established a centre to advise local councils throughout Australia on how to improve their energy performance.

The AMEIF business unit of Newcastle council works with local government and the residential and commercial sector to deliver results that improve energy efficiency. Therefore, it is reducing greenhouse costs, lowering energy costs and creating jobs. As for some of the costs that it has delivered to Newcastle council, it has reduced its energy cost from $1 million in 1995 to $350,000. That is a saving of some $593,000. Newcastle council is sharing this information with councils, as I have already mentioned, throughout Australia. Councils within my electorate like those of Lake Macquarie and Wyong are linking into this knowledge base that has been developed in Newcastle. It is promoting local jobs and it is a real investment in the future of a region that has really had to take a very close look at itself, look at who it is, where it wants to go, ensuring that we are prepared to embrace all the new technologies of the future. This unit supports the New South Wales and federal governments and it has a number of local partners that it is working with.

Many new projects have been fostered through this unit, and I can see that it will lead to real improvements in renewable energy and energy efficiency in the area. On Monday, 3 July there is going to be a special meeting in Newcastle, at which they are going to look at how the Newcastle-Hunter communities can work together to achieve new jobs and a healthy future through saving energy. The meeting will focus on renewable and sustainable energy options, and it shows that the Newcastle and Hunter regions are embracing the issue of renewable and new energy.

I would like to turn to Energy Australia, which was the first company in Australia to introduce a `Pure Energy' renewable energy scheme. The scheme was introduced in 1996, and it was sponsored by the Carr Labor government, which had a real commitment to renewable energy. The `Pure Energy' scheme gives Energy Australia's retail electricity customers the option of having their energy needs met from a portfolio of renewable energy sources and zero or low greenhouse gas emitting energy sources, including solar, wind, hydro and landfill gases. As I mentioned, Energy Australia first trialed the scheme in August 1996. Michael Egan, the then New South Wales Treasurer and Minister for Energy, launched the project, and it was trialed on 50,000 households in the Newcastle-Lake Macquarie area. As I said, this was the first `green' power scheme of its type in Australia. Based on the successful trial, Energy Australia expanded the scheme, offering it to all of its 1.3 million electricity customers in Sydney, in the Hunter and on the Central Coast. Since then, the number of Pure Energy customers has grown steadily. Now Energy Australia is supplying Pure Energy to more than 14,000 residential customers as well as to a large number of commercial customers, including Stadium Australia, the Olympic Coordination Authority and SOCOG.

In the relatively short time since the scheme began, Energy Australia has developed a comprehensive portfolio of renewable energy generators. One of these is the 600-kilowatt wind turbine on Kooragang Island. Located on the northern outskirts of Newcastle in the Hunter region, this turbine was commissioned in October 1997. It has been very successful, and it produces one million kilowatt hours annually, preventing the release of almost 1,000 tonnes of CO2 into the atmosphere each year. The project cost a total of $1.5 million. This shows you how Energy Australia is committing itself to the philosophy of renewable energy. It is not giving lip service to it; it is making a real and genuine commitment to renewable energy. As well as that, Energy Australia has established the Singleton Solar Photovoltaic Power Station. This, too, has been very successful. Energy Australia believes that renewable sources of energy are not capable of meeting all the energy needs of people in the Hunter. It has a place alongside coal generated electricity, which also plays a very important role in our region. Skills used in one type of energy production are also used in the other.

This shows that if a community, an area, a region, a state or a country has a commitment to do something, it can be achieved. I really do question the government's commitment in this area. I really feel that much more work needs to be done and that a far greater commitment, a real commitment, to renewable energy needs to be made by the government. The government makes a commitment and then it struggles to meet that commitment. It made a promise to introduce the two per cent requirement, and it looks like it is having difficulty keeping that promise. It has great difficulty even delivering the smallest change, the smallest improvement. If you make a commitment, you need to make a real commitment, like the one Newcastle Council made, like the projects I have told you about, like the one made by Energy Australia. It must be a commitment that is aware of technologies that exist, that complements them and that is a commitment for the future and for future technologies. The government needs to make the kind of commitment the Carr government has made in New South Wales—a commitment that has led to the development of new jobs, new technologies and hope for the future.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak on the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000. Some of us, from both sides of the House, went to listen to the Lavoisier group on global warming and CO2 in the atmosphere. The presentation by the scientist John Daly was certainly very impressive indeed. It was very hard to listen to Mr Daly without questioning the presumptions which underlie the proposal that is coming forward this evening. He presented a series of graphs on what he called `virgin sites'—that is, sites unaffected by urbanisation. An urbanised site, in contrast, has a huge warmth surrounding it. If you were driving to a big city from a country area—which I do on numerous occasions—on a clear night you can see the glow of the city for some 20 or 30 kilometres. Of course, that glow represents heat, so if your heat monitoring devices are within that glow—and most of the heat monitoring scientific sites throughout the world are—they are affected. He selected a series of sites that were not in those areas and also conformed to the very stringent requirements in the United States. He took the figures from the United States and from both of the polar caps. They indicated that the overall effect was probably a slight cooling rather than a warming.

speech.para: He indicated clearly that there undoubtedly was an increase in the CO2 in the atmosphere. There was no question about an increase in CO2, but he quoted another scientist, Dr Farquar, as saying that a doubling of CO2 has the same effect on plant life as a doubling of rainfall. In other words, it has a terrific beneficial effect as far as the growth of plants goes. Of course, CO2 is a food for plants. This correlates with a finding of the Australian Institute of Marine Science. The then director of the institute said that, whilst it is very difficult to get a clear impression of whether the seas are warming or cooling, if one had to make an assessment, the effect on the overall sea temperatures throughout the world would probably be a very slight cooling effect. But he said that it would be a very brave scientist that would commit himself to either a warming or a cooling. So I have to really question the scientific underpinning of what we are dealing with here. We have seen many of these fad sciences come and go over the last three decades in which I have been involved in public life.

talk.start.para: —Like the hydrogen car.

—I think there is hardly an inquisitive scientist in the world that does not consider that ultimately we will be running our motor vehicles on hydrogen. Whilst there may have been some humour and mirth at the mishandling of the promotion on the occasion in Queensland, there is no doubt that most intelligent commentators say that is where the basic thrust of hydrogen for our vehicles is.

speech.para: Let us judge the two per cent renewable energy source upon its merits. There is some merit in this approach. But, once again, I have to introduce this information: almost a fifth of the entire surface area of Queensland is underlain by coal—and I understand the same situation exists in New South Wales. So I really wonder whether those people that are in this House representing Queensland or for that matter New South Wales should be in the business of promoting energy that does not involve coal. If you say, `You are going to have coal-fired power stations, then you have to absorb the CO2,' for those who are not familiar with the technology at a power station, 98 to 99.9 per cent of the solid emissions can be collected by an electrolytic collector or a baghouse technology, so the solids can be dealt with fairly effectively, and the remaining problem of the CO2 emissions can be dealt with by the growing of trees, to put it at its simplest.

It rather fascinates me when we come to the area of growing trees, because we constantly get lectured by all the fad scientists and trendy politicians. A lot of ministers in the various governments throughout Australia constantly lecture us on our loss of trees and tree clearing. I cannot speak for the rest of Australia, but in the area that I represent—in the northern half of Queensland—from Townsville to the Northern Territory border, most of the area is taken up by the `great inland treeless plain', some 600 kilometres wide, stretching from this side of Hughenden to the other side of Cloncurry. That inland plain is no longer treeless. In fact, heavy infestation of six million hectares by the Acacia nilotica tree has taken place, so where we once had grassland we now have very heavily timbered areas. That has occurred effectively in the space of about the last 12 years. In addition to that, in the area between Hughenden and Townsville, a large number of the stations around Charters Towers were called downs stations because they were open, rolling country. `Downs' is the term used where you do not have trees. Those stations were all called `downs' because they were effectively treeless when European settlement started in these areas. I do not want to go into the reasons why the ecology of the area has changed and they are now very heavily timbered properties, but the fact of the matter is that where we once had open grassland we now have very heavily timbered areas.

Add together the area taken over by the Acacia nilotica tree and the natural growth of trees in these areas that were once downs country, and take into the account the huge bushfires that occurred from either mosaic burning by the first Australians or alternatively naturally occurring bushfires. One bushfire that started on the station next door to the station that I owned at the time burnt out some 80,000 acres of trees. That fire went on not for 40 kilometres but for 800 kilometres. I do not know how many trees were lost in that fire, but those trees are not now being lost. All of that area now is crisscrossed everywhere by firebreaks and there are people living there that fight those fires. The fires no longer have the incineration effect that takes out all of the trees. Put those three effects together. I do not want to go on too long on this particular aspect, but it does behove me to say that the reasons those downs stations—Burdekin Downs, Fanning Downs, et cetera—are now timbered is that there is water all over those stations and there are kangaroos and cattle that eat the grass down, so you do not have the huge fires that take out the trees. The grass competition is restricted by the animals and the trees are able to get away. They are not under the mosaic burning regime of the first Australians.

In the top half of Queensland, which is about one-sixth the surface area of Australia, we have a massive increase in the absorption of CO2—not the opposite effect at all. On the coastal plain there was rainforest which, because it was fully grown, did not absorb much carbon dioxide at all. That land has been cleared. Each year in some 100,000 hectares along the coast of North Queensland 100 tonnes of carbon dioxide is taken out of the atmosphere per hectare and converted into cattle and human beings, because it becomes sugar that is absorbed into the body of human beings or it becomes molasses that is absorbed by the cattle. The rest of it is ploughed back into the soil these days because of our trash blanketing operations, and some of that does go back into the atmosphere. So we have a huge net CO2 sink that simply was not there before. So once again I question the premises underlying this.

If we do ascribe to the theory that there is an increase in CO2 in the atmosphere—and everyone I know ascribes to that theory; and I would attribute that to some of the more industrialised countries and more urbanised areas, most certainly not the agricultural areas that country members of parliament represent—then let us have a look at the ethanol alternative. Other speakers have mentioned ethanol. It staggers the mind to understand why Australia does not have an ethanol regime. Of all the countries in the world that should have ethanol content in their fuel, this country should be first amongst them.

I do not know what the situation is with all the countries, but at the last series of seminars I went to on ethanol it was said that, for example, Brazil, France, the United States and Canada all have significant amounts of ethanol in their fuel. It varies from 22 per cent in Brazil, and that is by law, down to smaller figures for the other countries. A very large number of countries on earth already have a mandatory regime of ethanol. A little-known fact in Australia is that, if you live in an urbanised city, a metropolitan area, of Australia, your chances of dying of a lung disease are twice as high as they would be if you had that lung disease in a non-metropolitan area of Australia. That is because of the exhaust emissions from motor cars. If we move to 15 per cent ethanol in petrol, you will get a much cleaner burn and part of that problem will be significantly diminished—but certainly not eliminated. So if we move towards a 15 per cent ethanol blend that will have a very good effect on the environment.

The Brazilians are producing ethanol at this point in time for 25c a litre. We in Australia are currently paying oil companies around 35c a litre. It is an enormously attractive option at the moment just on that analysis alone. But if one considers that in 1986 the Queensland government was approached by Transfield on the basis that, when lead was taken out of petrol, very expensive additives had to be put back in to raise the octane level—the explosibility, if you like to use that expression—and if you use a 15 per cent ethanol blend, you would not need those additives. The analysis done by Wright and Killen of Texas and by Fluor Daniel of Texas—two separate leading authorities—said it ranged from being four per cent more expensive per litre to being two per cent less expensive per litre, depending upon a whole range of factors, but there was no significant increase in cost with a move to a 15 per cent blend.

To the governments who charge excise duty, we would say, `Mr Government, take the excise off.' This government in their wisdom took the excise off ethanol—and we thank them most sincerely for taking the excise off ethanol; we hope that it will be kept off ethanol. This resulted in no loss to revenue because that imported oil—and in 15 years we will be importing all of our oil into Australia; most of it now is imported petrol—will be replaced by Australian product which is produced in a plant that employs a large number of people who pay taxes. So of the $1.5 thousand million a year that will suddenly come into existence with this 15 per cent content in our oil, $500 million will go into consolidated revenue as tax revenue immediately because one in every three dollars generated is taken by the governments of Australia in tax. So there will be no loss to revenue because we will have this replacement offset. I know it is not quite that simple and it is not quite as good as I am making it out there, but let us say that one-third of the excise can be removed.

So now we have a flying start because at this point in time ethanol is cheaper than petrol. We have a second huge advantage in so far as the expensive additive—and I might add, it is a very nasty additive—can be removed and replaced with ethanol. We have the third advantage which is the flow of taxation into Australia that would not otherwise be there if this industry did not exist. Not only will that industry overcome part of the emission problems from our motor cars but on the figures that I have looked at initially—I have not been able to double-check this figure so I ask people to use it with care—that would require 60 million tonnes of cane per year.

That would be 60 million tonnes of CO2 which would be taken out of the atmosphere every year. Even in 100 years time, the growth will only be 300 million tonnes. So one-fifth of the problem, even in 100 years time, would be addressed by the growth of sugarcane. In its natural state, Australia has few trees on the land. On a hectare of land there might be 50 or 60 trees at most. Because almost all of them would be fully grown, they would take very little carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere. If you suddenly put 100 tonnes of cane a year on a hectare there would be a huge difference in the carbon dioxide sink created by the growing of that sugarcane.

In addition to all those benefits, because of the heat that is generated in a sugar mill in the creation of sugar and ethanol, each of the 29 or so sugar mills in Australia would be able to produce 50 megawatts of electricity. Even the smallest mill in Australia, the Rocky Point mill on the south coast, is producing a 50 megawatt output. The last time I looked, Queensland was producing 5,000 megawatts a year. That was its in-store capacity—so one per cent of that is coming from that tiny little south coast mill. If you have almost 30 mills generating 50 tonnes a year, you are generating some 1,500 megawatts of electricity per year. That should work out to about five per cent.

I will not be too specific, but if each of those mills does what Rocky Point is now doing and if we are growing ethanol, that would double the amount of cane and would certainly result in an increase in the number of mills. There is no doubt that five to seven per cent of Australia's entire capacity would be generated from those mills and we would be more than meeting the two per cent target. We would be meeting that target standing on our heads. In addition to that, we would have created 30,000 jobs in Australia. In addition to that, we would be cleaning up the dangerous emissions in our cities. In addition to that, we would be providing half of our sugar producers with long-term contracts at acceptable prices, which is what we enjoyed in the great days of Doug Anthony—the father of the minister in charge of the House at the present moment.

We have the opportunity to add enormously to the thrust that is coming through tonight via the ethanol alternative, which will provide cogeneration capacity—thus doubling the target we are talking about tonight. Whilst you may say that the two per cent is a small figure—I think it is an extremely high figure, frankly—it is giving the government encouragement and a pat on the back and the impetus that is needed to get private enterprise moving in that direction. We are telling the doers, shakers and movers out there, `We are on your side. We want you to head in this direction. We will do everything humanly possible to help you head in this direction.'

The enormously exciting possibility of ethanol is before Australia at the present moment. Every other country is doing it. Surely, of all the countries in the world that should be doing it, this should be the country that does it most. We keep trying to produce half our agricultural production from the Murray-Darling system, which has only 20 million megalitres of water, and we have 120 million in the Gulf country alone. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think we are going to need a bit more than renewable energy after waiting for two years and being at whatever hour we are at to deal with this, but we will do our best. On 28 April 1998, Australia signed the Kyoto protocol. This committed us to a target for national greenhouse gas emissions of eight per cent above 1990 levels by 2012. This is a 30 per cent reduction against current business as usual projections of greenhouse gas emissions. The protocol is an important and strategic decision towards globally reducing greenhouse gases, as well as contributing towards Australia meeting our agreed Kyoto targets. For this to occur we need to develop a number of measures and mechanisms which a number of speakers have referred to tonight to reduce emissions from the electricity sector—one of Australia's major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions.

speech.para: The Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 aims to establish and administer a scheme to encourage additional electricity generation from renewable energy sources. It is a means, amongst others, to reduce national greenhouse gas emissions. The problem of greenhouse gas emissions in the atmosphere is at the heart of this nation's concern to do its bit to tackle this serious global problem. As the explanatory memorandum says on page 6:

quote.para: The balance of scientific opinion supports the view that there has been a discernible and tropogenic influence on the earth's climate as a result of increasing concentrations of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The governments of developing nations consider this issue of enough concern to warrant global action to arrest greenhouse gas emissions growth.

speech.para: Australia's total emissions are estimated to grow by around 28 per cent from 1990 to 2010. The 1997 figure of 431 megatonnes was already higher as a level of emissions than the 1998 agreed emissions cap for 2008 to 2012. Curbing and reducing emissions growth will require a variety of strategies, one of which is before us today.

Electricity generation is the largest contributor to this country's greenhouse gas emissions at 35.4 per cent or 152 megatonnes of total emissions. ABARE predictions are that Australia's electricity consumption will grow by 1.7 per cent a year for the next 15 years. Obviously, curbing and reducing greenhouse gas emissions in this industry is crucial. This needs to tackle generators of fossil fuel emissions, improve current renewable energy generators such as mini hydro schemes and encourage a further take-up of renewables. The fact that further emission increases are expected in the future based on projections that coal will continue to be used as a fuel source means that a strategy mainly relying on increasing renewable energy does not tackle the fundamental issue—namely, curbing and reducing greenhouse gas emissions to meet our agreed targets of 1998.

We need a comprehensive strategy to also make fossil fuel generators of electricity more environmentally efficient and effective in minimising the CO2 emissions levels predicted to account for 41 per cent of total emissions in 2010. The explanatory memorandum recognises this. On page 6 it says:

quote.para: There is not existing legislation currently in place which directs the electricity supply industry to reduce its emissions or derive more energy from lower greenhouse gas emitting sources, and it is unlikely that significant reduction action will occur without strong Commonwealth direction.

speech.para: It is worth noting that New South Wales has included an emissions reduction requirement for electricity retailers in New South Wales, although I must add that non-compliance penalties did not exist under this scheme.

With this in mind, I wish to turn to the legislation and its intention to increase or accelerate the uptake of renewable energy in grid based power applications and to provide an ongoing base for commercially competitive renewable energy. In effect, the bill proposes a two per cent mandatory target for the uptake of renewable energy in power supplies. There are others, of course, who believe the target should be much higher, and again others who believe that it should be lower and that more priority should be put on achieving the Kyoto target by other means.

Referral of this bill to a Senate reference committee will allow some of these points of view to be more comprehensively assessed. Apart from acting as an accelerator, the bill proposes an ongoing renewable energy base for the development of commercially competitive renewable energy, as well as contributing to the development of internationally competitive industries which could participate effectively in the growing Asian and world energy markets. Fundamentally, the bill proposes that electricity retailers and other large electricity buyers will be legally required to source an additional two per cent of their electricity from renewable or specified waste product energy sources by 2010. This measure guarantees a market of 9,500 gigawatt hours per annum of additional renewable energy by 2010, with interim annual targets being phased in from 2001.

For my state of Tasmania, renewable energy products from wind and water are ideally placed to benefit from an emphasis on encouraging and promoting a greater take-up of renewable energy in power supplies, whether via this legislative strategy or other means. Tasmania provides, as other speakers have mentioned this evening, 50 per cent of existing renewables in Australia. In Tasmania, under the proposals of this bill, the Hydro Electric Corporation will be eligible to earn one renewable energy certificate, as detailed in part 2 of the bill, for every megawatt hour of new renewable energy generated. For example, energy generated from Tasmanian wind farms would be eligible to earn renewable energy certificates. In addition, existing renewable energy generators, such as the Hydro, will receive RECs, renewable energy certificates, relative to the baseline production level of 1997. Thus, efficiency upgrades of existing machinery or new minihydro schemes would be eligible to earn RECs.

Tasmania's geographic location is perfect for weather systems that bring both wind and rain to the state, and both will be harnessed to generate electricity. Contrary to what the shadow minister mentioned tonight, the wind and the rain stop on the west coast and do not impede the rest of the state. Tourists will experience beautiful weather if they come to the island. Water will become the great storage cell for wind energy, creating a massive liquid battery. As I mentioned, Tasmania currently produces over 50 per cent of Australia's renewable energy, and nearly 100 per cent of its electricity is from renewable energies. Tasmania is a significant existing generator of renewable energy. We have 27 small to medium sized hydro-electric power stations producing over 50 per cent of Australia's renewable greenhouse-friendly electricity. In 1998-99, Tasmania generated 9,863 gigawatt hours of renewable energy. Preliminary estimates by Hydro Tasmania indicate that there may be up to 2,800 gigawatt hours of additional water and wind energy that could be developed within Tasmania within 20 years.

The bulk of this new generation will most likely come from wind developments. As I pointed out in September last year in this House, the Hydro Electric Corporation of Tasmania believes that wind development in the state, particularly on the west and north-west coasts, will be the turning point for Tasmania in this century as hydro development was in the 20th century. The Hydro has already gained valuable experience in developing wind farms on King Island and has plans for extensive new developments in my electorate of Braddon on the beautiful north-west coast. In 1998 the Hydro established Tasmania's first wind farm, as I mentioned, at Huxley Hill on King Island, which is to the north-west of the Tasmanian mainland and also in my electorate of Braddon. It has three turbines with a capacity of 750 kilowatts. In its first year of operation, the farm saved the Hydro $400,000 in diesel fuel, reduced CO2 emissions by 1,900 tonnes and reduced reliance on diesel fuel by about 20 per cent. With the assistance of the Australian Greenhouse Office and its Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program, the Hydro is working on developing an integrated renewable energy system involving a mix of wind power, minihydro, pump storage, battery and inverter system, demand management and integrated system control. This will be an Australian first.

In February of this year, the Hydro presented plans for a west-north-west wind farm at historic Woolnorth. This is in the vicinity of Cape Grim where we boast the cleanest air in the world. The plan is for a three-phase project over five to seven years. In all, something like 130- to 150-megawatt production is envisaged. In addition, other sites, including Marrawah in my electorate and Granville Harbour on the rugged west coast, are being considered. The average wind speed at Granville Harbour is 7.6 metres per second at a 30-metre height; on King island, it is 9.8 metres per second at the same height. I am led to believe that Marrawah could produce 350 megawatts and Granville Harbour 140 megawatts of power.

There is great potential in the manufacture of wind technology in the state. This represents the opportunity for new industries in Tasmania in the form of blade manufacture and the manufacture of towers and plant assembly for wind turbines. In effect, technology transfer will generate jobs and, in Tasmania, this is most necessary and invaluable. Several options exist for developing a wind power manufacturing industry in Tasmania. Whatever option is chosen, manufacturing will have the obvious spin-off effects of greater employment, creation of local industry, reduction of equipment costs and an increase in the uptake of wind energy in Australia and the region.

The exciting Basslink electricity scheme is the vehicle for Hydro Tasmania and the state to be a vital and competitive player in the Australian electricity market. New markets will be opened up for our renewable electricity and new opportunities for Tasmania. Basslink is Tasmania's bridge to the national electricity market and grid. The tyranny of distance will soon become the bridge of opportunity. We can sell and export our electricity and realise the peaking potential of our hydro facilities to a national benefit. Likewise, we can import energy. The bill is one mechanism which, if used effectively, will provide a stimulus and be part of the means of placing Australia at the forefront of wind and water renewable energy development.

If members of the House would like to look at some of the submissions made by Hydro Tasmania, under the title of their booklet `Renewable Target', I will be more than happy to share it, particularly if they are interested in wind generation and plans for renewable energy along those lines. Tasmania is well placed to play its part in assisting Australia to reach its commitment to the Kyoto protocol. There are other policy options that have been adopted overseas to develop the renewable energy industry, or certain sectors of it, such as wind and water. No doubt some of these will emerge in more detail when this bill is sent off to the Senate references committee, where we can look at it in more detail and take on board a number of the options canvassed here tonight on both sides of the House.

I did mention that other policy options have been adopted overseas. Some of these include capital subsidies for part of the initial cost of renewable energy equipment, exemplified in Japan; higher payments or tax credits for the electricity produced from renewables, and examples of that can be found in Germany; direct government subsidy to the industry itself, providing zero or low interest loans—for example, over 10 years, no repayments in the first two years and fast approval processes, as in Germany with their solar PV systems; policies that support renewable energy within government operations—for example, targets, installation of renewable energy equipment, et cetera, as stipulated by government and for government departments; mandatory requirements for renewable energy equipment in government departments; tax credits against renewable energy equipment, as in the United States of America; and, finally, national targets for the generation of electricity from renewable energy as a whole, or from particular renewable energies such as in Denmark.

I will conclude by saying that I look forward to sharing with my Tasmanian colleagues, and particularly Hydro Tasmania, the uptake of even further renewable energies, the great benefits they can bring to Australia and our part in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and CO2 in the world. I am sure the world will be a better place for it, that greater jobs will be generated and that this planet will be fitter for our children and for their children in the future.

talk.start.para: —The Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 and the Renewable Energy (Electricity) (Charge) Bill 2000 are a significant step towards a cleaner, greener Australia and demonstrate this government's strong and practical commitment to meeting our obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. In fact, these bills formed an important part of the original package of measures promoted by the government in the lead-up to the Kyoto negotiations. The bills encourage businesses to pursue actions they would otherwise be unlikely to pursue without the provided incentives. At the same time, responsible limits have been placed on the financial impact of those actions on businesses in the national economy. It is a market driven and flexible approach to encourage innovation for a better environment and it illustrates in a clear and unambiguous way how this government can work cooperatively with private enterprise to obtain a wider community and international benefit.

speech.para: Under these bills, the achievement of the mandatory renewable energy target will be facilitated by a certificate trading mechanism. It is an approach that is a first for a renewable energy scheme. The approach adopted will also support the most cost-effective response, with low-cost generators being able to sell their product to parties who may have only limited renewable energy potential in their area. Allowing certificate trade will also provide substantial flexibility in the achievement of the measure, with certificates generated in years of high yield being banked to guard against the possibility that lower than average generation levels may occur in a following year.

It is envisaged there will be a substantial reduction in gases in the short term and the potential for a much greater reduction, obviously, in the longer term. Various estimates place the CO2 to be achieved through this measure between 5.5 million tonnes and seven million tonnes. It is certainly one of the largest single measures in the National Greenhouse Strategy and a major contribution towards meeting our Kyoto obligations. It is recognised that the electricity generation sector, as the largest contributor to Australia's greenhouse emission profile, must make efforts to reduce their greenhouse gas growth. The measures in these bills contribute significantly to that sector's greenhouse gas response strategies.

The longer-term nature of the measure could see even more than the 9,500 gigawatt hours of electricity generated from renewable energy sources after 2010. The significance of 9,500 gigawatt hours is shown by the fact that this is more than twice the renewable energy output of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme, or slightly more than the entire generation of Hydro Tasmania—with all due respect to the member for Braddon—which supplies most of the electricity for the state of Tasmania. This equates to a domestic electricity consumption for a city of some four million people, or about a 60 per cent increase above current renewable energy generation levels.

The investment required is between $2 billion and $3 billion in the renewable industry up to 2010, so its significance and impact cannot be understated. The Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Robert Hill, and the government have negotiated and achieved a remarkable outcome, and I am certainly pleased with the informed estimates that in excess of 10,000 jobs could be created, predominantly in regional areas, as a result of the implementation of the two per cent target. Up to 3,000 of these potentially could be directly related to energy generation. Certainly the economic benefits for regional Australia are exciting and, importantly, could well be ongoing.

It is appropriate in this debate about the important issue of renewable energy that I raise a related subject. The government's Sugar Industry Task Force hosted a seminar here in Parliament House on 1 June on the ethanol industry in Australia. Ethanol is produced from renewable resources in Australia, predominantly wheat and sugar cane. The task force hosted this seminar, which attracted an impressive number of expert contributors, to inform itself—and, by extension, the government—of the current status and the likely future of the domestic ethanol industry. Currently some 110 million litres of ethanol are produced each year in Australia, with roughly 60 million litres from sugar cane and 50 million from starch. Of that, we consume approximately 42 million litres domestically.

Ethanol has a wide application. It is used in the production of pharmaceuticals, food and beverages, chemicals, household methylated spirits, printing, paint and paint thinners, aerosols and cosmetics, and it is used in laboratories and hospitals. However, the real opportunity for growth is as an additive to fuel, with the suggested blend being anywhere between two per cent and 10 per cent.
