The current cost to supply ethanol into fuel markets in major capital cities has a variety of estimates, the highest being about 69c or 70c a litre. The Australian Biofuels Association said:

quote.para: Over the next three to five years, significant reductions in the cost of producing ethanol are anticipated due to technology advantages and innovation in the existing industry, and through the demonstration and commercialisation of new cellulose to ethanol technologies.

speech.para: There has been significant progress to date. In 1995 the government estimated the cost of delivering ethanol fuel into major city markets was 82c. Today, it is anticipated to be 69c to 70c a litre. This is certainly similar to cost trends in the United States, Canada and Brazil. However, there is an interest in the use of molasses. I must make a note that CSR use molasses for their ethanol production at Plain Creek, Sarina, which is in my electorate. This is predominantly used for alcohol production. Japanese sake comes from Queensland sugar cane, which I think is a wonderful irony, and trash from sugar cane is a by-product that is usually used as a covering on the soil. So there is a range of low-cost organic materials associated with the sugar cane industry that could be used to produce ethanol.

I must mention renewable energy in this debate. The forecast, and the best estimate, is that Australia's oil reserves will most likely be depleted within 15 to 20 years. After that, we could well be exposed to a completely volatile international oil market and all that means for the cost and reliability of fuel. As I said earlier, ethanol and other renewable fuels can be produced from both sugar cane and starch. Understandably, the focus of the Sugar Industry Task Force was on sugar.

The sugar industry is certainly going through a very difficult downturn at the moment because of poor seasons and weather conditions in the north and an oversupply of sugar worldwide from heavily subsidised producers. However, the industry sees the development of the domestic ethanol industry as a very positive move that could bring considerable financial benefits to the people and communities that rely on the sugar industry. At the seminar, the Mossman Central Mill, which is in Northern Queensland, said:

quote.para: Some new initiatives are desperately needed to restore the income of the sugar regions, who have seen their income fall from $2 billion in 1997 to about $1 billion in 2000. Without a new pathway, there will be severe disintegration along the coastal communities.

speech.para: Hypothetically, if all sugar mills in Australia not currently involved in ethanol production were to install a distillery to ferment their molasses, about 1,300 megalitres of ethanol could be produced annually.

Mossman mill provided a scenario of a legally mandated requirement for anywhere between two per cent and 10 per cent ethanol blend in all domestic fuel. It pointed out that fuel through the nearby Cairns port totalled 240 megalitres of diesel and 180 megalitres of petrol in 1999, and that, with a 10 per cent blend, the Mossman mill could provide all of those local requirements. It is really quite staggering to think that the sugar cane farms adjacent to the port could provide at a modest 10 per cent blend all of the fuel needs for that busy, active northern port. The Mossman mill went on to say:

quote.para: The regular tanker service could backload ethanol to the oil refineries for blending in the cities, rather than taking on salt water ballast, which leads to other environmental problems along the Great Barrier Reef. Most sugar ports already have bulk storage facilities for handling molasses. If this molasses is to be converted to ethanol, then those port facilities could be similarly used for the ethanol.

speech.para: Given this hypothetically mandated 10 per cent blend, the Mossman mill believes it could be ready for full ethanol production in 2001 or 2002. The announcement by the government that it will not extend the fuel excise to ethanol has been very positively received by the biofuels industry and has relieved it of a major concern. The prediction is that over the next two to five years major advances are expected in the development and commercialisation of technologies for the production of ethanol both from traditional feedstocks and from cellulose from a wide range of non-traditional biomass feedstocks. This will further accelerate an ongoing process of technical innovation and reductions in the cost of production in the biofuels industry. As I have said, the benefits of a 10 per cent or even, at a minimum, a two per cent ethanol blend in petrol or diesel have been clearly documented.

Evidence presented to the sugar task force seminar stated that the 1999 Australian passenger vehicle fleet comprised approximately 25 per cent pre-1986 vehicles using leaded petrol and 75 per cent post-1986 vehicles using unleaded petrol. When compared with the use of neat petrol, the use of a 10 per cent ethanol blend would have significant effects in regulated exhaust emissions. There would be a decrease in carbon monoxide of 32 per cent, a decrease of about 12 per cent in THC, and other significant decreases in non-regulated exhaust emissions, including butadiene, benzene, toluene and xylene. In the USA in 1999, more than 10 per cent of all gasoline contained ethanol, and fuel with a 10 per cent ethanol blend has been certified by the US Environment Protection Agency to reduce carbon monoxide emissions by up to 30 per cent.

The benefits of an ethanol blend in domestic fuel are obvious: an increased domestic market for the currently depressed grains and sugar industries, an economic boost for regional and rural areas with its resultant boost to jobs improvement, a reduced reliance on imported oil, greenhouse gas emission abatement and improved vehicle efficiency. I commend these bills to the House and ask that the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, who has demonstrated so clearly his strong commitment to renewable energy, take on board the strong case for nurturing and encouraging the domestic ethanol industry.

talk.start.para: —The Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 puts into place a commitment that the Prime Minister made way back in November 1997. Comments have been made on behalf of the opposition about the length of time it has taken for the legislation to come before us, but it is an opportunity, as has been displayed by the debate, to canvass a lot of issues surrounding matters to do with climate change and, indeed, matters to do with renewable energy itself. From the outset, I think that is a healthy thing. It is interesting that, in the dying night of this session, there should be a debate such as this, where there have been quite a range of views canvassed. I think it has been assisted by the fact that the opposition has reserved its right on this piece of legislation. We believe that putting the bill up for public scrutiny through the Senate committee system will enable the true worth of the legislation to be tested. The range of views that have been given by opposition members in contributions to this debate indicates that there is ongoing debate on this as a policy issue within the Australian Labor Party.

speech.para: It is also of interest that this debate occurs at a time when there appears to be a degree of tension within the government over matters to do with climate change and, indeed, the way in which we may or may not be able to achieve the target that was set for us at Kyoto. I am on the record as saying that I thought Australia got a very good deal at Kyoto. Often when I say that some on the opposite side think that I am actually giving them a pat on the back. Well, I do it with a little bit of irony. I believe that we were very generously done by, given the fact that we were allowed a target that was some eight per cent over our 1990 level. I know that the argument is that that still represents a 30 per cent reduction in carbon emissions on business as usual. But if we compare it to other nations, we are at the upper end of the scale for being able to increase our levels of emissions. Many of the nations who have gone within the Kyoto proposals have to have reductions of their emissions of some eight per cent.

As I have stated in other debates here, to put the level of reduction that we would need in context, it has been estimated that to get to the eight per cent level with the cut back from business as usual we would have to reduce emissions to something like the equivalent of 100 million tonnes. To put that into perspective, the evidence indicates that if we eliminated all Australian road transport, including private cars, this would in fact achieve a reduction of only 60 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent. So I acknowledge that this is not something that we can just expect to happen. That is why it is a bit disquieting that we have media reports of the type of debate that is happening at the cabinet level at the moment where it would appear that the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, is fighting an uphill battle to put in place mechanisms that he believes would allow Australia to achieve this generous target. I find it a little disquieting and disappointing that, at this late stage, when we really have to see some action, this type of debate is building up. Mr Deputy Speaker, without wishing to involve you, as the member for Cowper, too much in this debate—

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—I should hope not, Member for Scullin.

—I will try to avoid it, but as I understand it, there was a fair degree of debate about this in the National Party. This is of interest to me because there is a variance of views on the way in which primary producers can be involved in helping Australia to achieve its Kyoto target. The basis of this is that there is a variance in what people say the science is. If we backtrack just a little, we all understand that there is a lot of discussion about the science of the so-called greenhouse effect and climate change, but I think we all agree that we cannot await definitive answers. We need to take action now because, if we find some 10, 20, 30 or 40 years down the track that some of the science that people want to suggest we disbelieve was true, we will have lost that time and never make the recovery. But there is solid evidence that by changes in the way in which primary production can prioritise what is happening on the land significant gains can be made towards the reduction of carbon emissions. I think that is a very important aspect.

speech.para: Internationally, it is interesting that there are many forces such as the Green parties of Europe that have some concern when one suggests that carbon sinks and the like are a very important mechanism overall in achieving the type of carbon emission reductions that we require. In fact, the European Union is really against the type of mechanisms that Australia is trying to put in place, which I think have the full support of this side of the House—they being emissions trading—and also trying to get mechanisms about and proper definitions of what are appropriate carbon sinks. Where primary production is going to play a key role is that, in things like agroforestry, we will be able to achieve a great degree of sequestering of carbon—the jargon term—through these plantations, which will be important. As I have indicated, the added advantage is that, by having this degree of reafforestation which would lead to the type of sequestering that we are talking about, it would also have other environmental benefits, for instance, in combating salinity and other forms of land degradation. The type of reafforestation that would also be of benefit against the greenhouse effect by the locking up of carbon is very important. I think we really should be looking at the opportunities that are there for us.

That then goes to the notion of international emissions trading where we potentially have the opportunity to have other countries that are having difficulties meeting their Kyoto targets actually pay for the type of carbon sinks that Australia could put in place. I believe a lot of these mechanisms are very much a win-win situation. There are many that put the case that whilst there are small gains that can be made, if in fact the mechanisms of these two pieces of legislation that we are debating are successful—and we hold an open view about whether or not they are going to be successful—the actual effect overall is not all that great. This problem is not going to be solved by a single solution. Whilst I am of the ilk that supports Australia moving much greater than even the targets that are set by this piece of legislation about increasing our reliance on renewable energy sources, it alone is not going to be the thing that achieves the types of results that are required.

We are obviously going to have to be smarter in the way in which we use a number of the fuels that will continue to be used. We also have to look at research and development which will continue to develop more efficient ways of converting those fuel sources into energy. We have to continue the debate, to continue to look at the type of ideas that have been proposed. My colleague the honourable member for Braddon has, of course, put a very good case, being a very diligent Tasmania member, that there is great potential in Tasmania for the development of a number of things which, in particular, go to the notions here under these pieces of legislation of renewable energy. Of course, Tasmania has been renowned for hydro schemes but it is now acknowledged that some of the turbines and the type of engineering used in those schemes could be much more efficient. We want to be sure, through the mechanisms allowed in these pieces of legislation, that we can be encouraged to look at the types of things that are required, whether they be smaller turbines or whatever. I heard the honourable member for Braddon mention the development of wind technology as a source. All these things should be looked at.

For various reasons that arise at the end of sessions, I did not hear some of the contributions from the other side. I suspect the honourable member for Kalgoorlie might have touched upon tidal energy. In fact, I spoke in a short debate that we had last year on the proposal that is in his electorate. On that occasion, whilst I was trying to be careful in my comments, I noted that one of the problems is that while tidal energy has some attraction as a renewable energy, the proposal that people are looking at in Derby is problematic because it can have some very great negative environmental effects in that area. We are not just looking at notions on the basis that they are going to help in the reduction of carbon emissions and throwing away the environmental integrity of the proposals. We really have to be careful about the type of things we look at.

Indeed, if we are to achieve the types of reductions that are required, it will require a global effort. That is why I believe that, if there is this debate occurring at cabinet level, it should be resolved because Australia needs to have a position that it can then put with great confidence in the international fora that are available. If there is some doubt about our commitment to what is a very generous target that was set at Kyoto, that will be very disappointing because there are many people on the international stage who want to find excuses to walk away from this notion. I noted in the media coverage of some of the discussion at the National Party conference that one of the things that was highlighted as being important in the international politics of climate change is the result of the United States election this year. That is very clear. If George W. Bush is elected, the international debate on matters such as climate change is going to change dramatically. That is very disappointing because a lot of the hard yards have been made, and we really need to see that the United States ratifies Kyoto and gets on with the job. If there is going to be a change of the political hue in the United States administration that is going to so upset the international balance in this debate, we have got a real problem.

At the end of the day, one of the great advantages that Australia has is that we have a track record of being able to do the research to produce ideas that can contribute to carbon emission reductions. What we do not have is a very good track record on the development of those ideas. This fits nicely into the notion of Australia as a knowledge nation. What we really have to do is look at a commitment to the type of funding that is required to develop the types of proposals that Australian intellect can put in place and ensure that they are developed on-shore because this is a developing export market. That is clear if you look at any of the literature. Australia has a great deal to offer, and it has great potential in trading terms for Australia. It is one of the service sectors where we could dominate, but that will require government to give its commitment to the notion of reduction of carbon emissions under its policy of producing results on climate change, whether that be through a continuing Kyoto process—in the hopeful belief that the United States election outcome will not prevent that from happening—or whether we do it just because we are good at it. We should not be ashamed of making sure that we put in place mechanisms and we should ensure that, in the international market, we are out there selling these appropriate mechanisms.

As I said, this has been an interesting opportunity that perhaps quite rarely arises in this place, because we are not actually deciding yes or no in this chamber tonight about this legislation; rather, we are actually floating a few ideas, discussing what might be achieved, discussing where the proposals of this legislation as they relate to renewable energy fit into the overall climate change debate and seeing what might come from a Senate inquiry into the legislation. Having said that, of course we have been lobbied by people who are acting on behalf of the renewable energy sector, and that is appropriate. I have no problem with indicating that I think this is a sector worthy of some support and worthy of some encouragement. But, at the end of the day, the opposition's position is: are these two pieces of legislation the most appropriate way of achieving the outcomes that were set out by the Prime Minister as far back as 20 November 1997 in his statement Safeguarding the future: Australia's response to climate change? That is what it is all about.

It is not that we dispute the outcome. There are many environmental groups that say that aiming only for an additional two per cent of electricity generated from renewable or waste product sources is a very low target. I am quite happy to accept that that is probably the case and that perhaps we should be aiming for higher things. Some of the evidence that has been put in lobbying documents that have been bandied around is that, whilst we have been waiting for this debate to happen—that is, between the statement in 1997 and now with this piece of legislation—and whilst we are waiting to see what we are going to do, in Denmark they have increased the amount of energy from renewable sources by three per cent already. That is off a much higher base than we have been able to achieve. This is an area where we have to take some action. I hope that whatever problems there are at the cabinet table about the future direction that this present Australian government is going to take in achieving what we signed up for in Kyoto will be resolved because this is something we need government to show capital `L' leadership on to make sure that everybody understands what we are achieving.

I accept that the government believes that this piece of legislation has the potential to achieve an outcome. There are other mechanisms around that can also achieve outcomes. Perhaps not enough credit is given to CEDA in New South Wales, which has been assisting organisations to be much more energy efficient and therefore contribute to the reduction in carbon emissions. Organisations such as that and the efforts of state governments should be acknowledged. The Greenhouse Challenge and other things at a national level are also important. I look forward with interest to what might be the outcomes of the Senate committee's investigation. I hope that, through that rigorous form of investigation, this legislation, if need be, is improved to ensure that this minimalist outcome of the legislation is achieved.

talk.start.para: —Three years ago the Prime Minister, prior to the Kyoto climate change convention, said that we—that is, Australia—should never have got on board this particular truck in the first place at the Rio conference, and that those who put us aboard that truck did not understand that the national interest and economic implications of remaining on that truck were quite serious for Australia. We had the Business Council of Australia and other groups urging Australia to withdraw as a signatory to the framework convention on climate change. There was little serious consideration that renewable energy, and encouragement of clean coal technology and emission reduction from existing fossil fuel based power generation, could offer immense new economic advantages, particularly in rural and regional areas.

speech.para: As we know, the Australian government got essentially what it wanted at Kyoto, short of jumping off the truck. It was a concession by the rest of the world to the fact that this country is dependent on fossil fuel. There was an agreement that we would aim for a target of 108 per cent of our 1990 greenhouse gas levels by 2010; or, to be precise, between 2008 and 2012. It is important to note in the context of this bill that by the end of 1997 our greenhouse gas emissions stood at 111 per cent of our 1990 levels. In May this year the Minister for the Environment and Heritage was reported to have told cabinet that the 1998 levels would be 119 per cent of our 1990 levels, while the expert projection for 2010, the year we are aiming to be at 108 per cent, will in fact be 130 per cent, according to the latest estimates. It is therefore rather an understatement for the explanatory memorandum to this bill, the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000, to proclaim that Australia faces a challenging task in meeting this initial target. Challenging indeed—so challenging that I would say the target was unattainable when set.

Electricity generation is far and away our biggest contributor to greenhouse gas emissions at 35.4 per cent of total emissions. Renewables contribute just 10 per cent of our electricity supplies, with hydro by far the largest proportion of that, approaching something like 98 per cent. So the problem is obvious. Do we have the answer in these bills? I think not. It is sobering to note that this legislation aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by encouraging, through a variety of means, an additional two per cent of electricity production to be from renewable resources by 2010. The legislation brings into effect what the government describes as one of Australia's most strategic greenhouse response measures: legal requirement for large buyers of electricity to source more of their electricity needs from environmentally friendly, renewable fuel sources. Electricity retailers and other large electricity buyers will be legally required to source the additional two per cent of their electricity from renewable or specified waste product energy sources by 2010. So what is happening to produce that alternative energy? I doubt many would regard the burning of waste forest products in power station furnaces as representing a truly clean, green alternative energy source, but that is going to qualify as part of this two per cent.

What innovative solar, wind and other sources of energy are really being developed? I went searching, and the outlook is more encouraging than I imagined. But it will not make much of a dent on that expected 20 per cent above 1990 greenhouse gas emissions expected by 2010. Forget the 108 per cent target—it has been reached before the ink is dry on the Kyoto agreement. What is happening out there to at least try to approach these targets? According to the Sustainable Energy Industry Association, $70 million has been invested in research and development in the past six months in anticipation of this legislation. The association is expecting $2 billion investment over the next 10 years. Other expert assessment is that $3 billion will be needed to meet the two per cent target. In my own area, Advance Energy has invested $18 million in a 14-tower wind farm near Blayney. It should be up and running by September, generating 10 megawatts—enough to supply the equivalent of all the households in Blayney shire, about 3,500. Advance also has a mini hydro scheme at Burrendong Dam and is planning another at Burrinjuck Dam, while it is also involved in a solar farm at Western Plains Zoo.

Elsewhere, on the Atherton Tablelands and in Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania, as we have heard, there are wind farm developments. It is estimated that six per cent of the New South Wales topography is suited to effective wind farming, and there is a growing interest in developing an industry capable of producing the blades and equipment needed to generate wind power and in fact generate jobs. I understand that General Electric is looking at possible wind turbine development in Australia. That is all very well and encouraging, and part of the potential massive economic boost renewable energy offers this country. To put our modest wind generation in perspective, it is interesting to note that Denmark generates 25 per cent of its renewable power from wind.

We have a number of companies entering the biomass generation area, and things like sugarcane waste, sawmill waste, woody weeds and specifically grown energy crops have much potential, although some question the carbon neutrality of forest offcuts as fuel for power stations. Installation of solar hot water has seen a substantial increase in recent times. On top of state rebates, extra Commonwealth incentives in this area are available under this legislation. Currently 600 kilowatt of electricity generated by photovoltaic cells is available on the electricity grid. But it is all small fry given that about 15,000 times the nation's energy use falls on Australia as sunlight every day. I remember 20 years ago listening to an enthusiastic scientist from the University of New South Wales, whose name I have long forgotten, detailing the potential for tapping solar power in Australia and, sadly, as it turned out, expecting it to be a common form of power by the 1990s.

The use of green power by consumers is rising rapidly, indicating there is demand for a vastly accelerated expansion of alternative energy development. There are 71,000 households currently buying green power, and that is rising by 4,000 households a month. As we know, there is also the development at various stages of geothermal, wave and tidal power. I know how passionate the member for La Trobe and, in fact, others in the House are about the potential of this industry in the Derby area of the north-west.

My electorate has a rich coalmining history. Coal has been among our top export earners for many years. Unfortunately, in recent years the export prices struck by the big players like BHP have severely undermined the ability of the western fields to compete. But given a fair go, with fair access rates to rail transport and coal handling facilities, the western coal can compete with any in the world, and its miners are world's best. Yet coal is under enormous pressure. The growing international agreement that greenhouse gases must be dramatically reduced places coal under increasing pressure for overseas sales. Yet there are some developments that will greatly enhance coal's saleability. I am glad the government has offered a further $6 million for the ultraclean coal project. Research by the CSIRO shows the use of ultraclean coal with suitable turbines can reduce greenhouse by between 10 and 24 per cent compared with conventional coal powered stations.

Given our own reliance—and that of Asia—on coal powered generation, this ultraclean coal will be an absolute necessity in the medium to long term. So, with the support of the government, White Industries, the CSIRO and Japanese interests, who I believe are also involved, hopefully the new pilot plant to be established at Newcastle will quickly move from pilot to full production and see the establishment of further plants along the coalfields of eastern Australia, generating a cleaner coal for a cleaner power supply. Details of this CSIRO development at Steel River in Newcastle were given earlier today by the parliamentary secretary in referring to the Public Works Committee the proposed CSIRO Energy Centre at Steel River. Ultraclean coal also has potential as a carbon reductant in the manufacture of silicon, similar to that proposed for the plant at Lithgow, and, of course, it has also been tested with positive results as a clean carbon source for use as an anode material for aluminium production, which could also be of significant benefit, assuming the proposed aluminium and silicon plants at Lithgow get under way.

This is the first attempt by a federal government to reduce greenhouse emissions in any serious way. But there is no greenhouse trigger in the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, despite the wishes of the minister. I notice the Deputy Prime Minister has bagged this idea. He reckons the states should be the arbiters of such matters. Given my experience of state based environmental assessments, particularly through commissions of inquiry into several developments, and the attitude of the current and former Queensland governments to land clearance, I shudder to think of a state directed environmental outcome. While we can mandate increases like this in renewable energy, it seems crazy that we have no mandatory energy efficiency standards for commercial or residential buildings. Insulating, clagging, energy efficient building can contribute an estimated 30 per cent savings in energy use. It has also been estimated the so-called additional two per cent of the renewable electricity this legislation aims to mandate is in fact 9,500 megawatt hours, as shown in section 40 of the bill. According to my advice, this will be much less than an additional two per cent when one takes into account the rate at which electricity consumption is currently increasing. There is a very compelling argument that the two per cent target should be aimed at the latest technologies, such as wave power generation and wind power, to give these the investment kick-start they need to become competitive and large enough to succeed long term, not only here but internationally with export potential for the component parts and, in fact, the technology and intellectual property.

I would now like to turn to making some broad comments about the issue of greenhouse emissions and global warming. As I mentioned earlier, I was intrigued by the recent debate within the government over the minister for the environment's call for a `greenhouse trigger' to be added to the new environmental laws. As I understand it, that trigger would require possible Commonwealth approval of projects that would result in greenhouse emissions of 500,000 tonnes or more of carbon dioxide over any 12-month period. Such a trigger would be added to the others already contained in the legislation. These include developments impacting on matters of national environmental significance, activities on Commonwealth land or the actions of Commonwealth agencies. As I said, the Deputy Prime Minister is of the view that it is not necessary or appropriate for the Commonwealth to effectively take over what he sees as the states' roles in the assessment and approval of major developments. He argues there are better, market based options for meeting Australia's Kyoto obligations and that a greenhouse trigger could deter investment in major wealth and job generating developments, especially in regional areas. But, while there may not be such a need for such a trigger if a `carbon trading' scheme were in place, as it stands one is not, and it looks like we could still be talking years before one gets off the ground. And at the moment the states have not shown a sufficient commitment to greenhouse gas reduction as an environmental issue. I say this with those two major projects proposed for the Central West in mind, a silicon plant and aluminium smelter for Lithgow. Both would be significant carbon dioxide emitters but, in all the environmental assessments that have been taking place, the issue of emissions does not seem to have been a major factor. We need the projects and we need the jobs but we also need to not create renewable electricity on the one hand and increase emissions on the other. There are ways of achieving a win-win situation, and it requires commitment from both government and industry developers.

But the reality is that global warming is a national issue and the part that Australia must play in combating it is a federal responsibility. The states did not sign on to Kyoto; the Commonwealth did, and it is the Commonwealth's responsibility to now deliver on the generous emission levels we have been allowed. If that means increased federal responsibility, then so be it. But, if it can be achieved through agreements with the states and improving their environmental standards, then that should not be shunned. The risk is that the closer government is to the coalface, so to speak, the more likely it is to be persuaded by people with vested interests to allow developments which may not be in the best long-term interests of local communities, let alone the national interest. The closer to the coalface pressure, the more the temptation to cave in.

In the absence of a fully fledged and effective carbon trading scheme and given the greenhouse increases we are recording, Minister Hill's proposed trigger is essential. I would go so far as to say that if we ever do get a carbon trading scheme up and running it may still be necessary to have such a trigger. I would also say that, rather than being a barrier to regional development, such a trigger could hold substantial opportunities for regional areas. I recall taking part in a conference in Bathurst shortly after the Kyoto protocol was signed. It was a conference that canvassed the opportunities for the central west of NSW that could arise from Kyoto. At that conference, there was much enthusiasm for the potential business and environmental benefits that could flow to central west areas if a national or international carbon trading scheme was set up. There was particular interest from the farm-forestry sector, which viewed such a scheme as a way of offsetting the start-up costs of plantings and addressing environmental problems such as salinity and erosion, while at the same time providing a continuing and growing revenue stream and reversing negative productivity in many parts of rural Australia. There was also enthusiasm for the sequestration potential of old man saltbush and its role in revegetating drier, saltier areas and providing drought resistant stock feed.

However, even at that early stage, the enormous complexities and uncertainties involved in turning the concept into reality were clear to many. Since that time, a lot of work has taken place around the world. While many might be frustrated at the slow progress being made in setting up the trading scheme, it is clear from the Greenhouse Office publications that work is being thoroughly done. I hope that at the conference in November in The Hague we do establish a proper international carbon trading scheme. I presume we will still be on the truck, with suitable representation—not deputies brought in from the local embassy. That conference will hopefully decide on the implementation of an international emissions trading scheme. As far as I can see, the sinks issue is proving to be the spanner in the works of the whole carbon trading concept. Working out a reliable and consistent framework for regulating sinks around the world will make or break the proposed global system. How to handle sinks is the one factor that makes putting in place a carbon trading system far more difficult than the sulfur trading system used so successfully to help with the Northern Hemisphere's acid rain problem. In the case of sulfur, there was no realistic capacity for sinks, so the trading system was much simpler.

While I welcome this measure as a step in the right direction, I am also aware of the immense challenges Australia faces even meeting the generous 2010 targets we have been given. With national electricity production continuing to increase at around three per cent a year for the next 10 years—even with an additional two per cent of energy to come from renewable sources—far more will have to be done. If Senator Hill is correct that greenhouse emission levels increased eight per cent from 1997 to 1998 and from 111 per cent to 119 per cent of the 1990 level, then clearly we have a long way to go before we even get close to meeting the target. I am confident that there are significant opportunities for Australia if such an international system is set up, particularly in terms of forestry developments in areas such as the one I represent. I am aware that, even in the absence of an international scheme, international companies have been putting money into forests in New South Wales to meet expected emission obligations. If an international scheme does not arise from The Hague meeting, I urge the government to look at the viability of setting up a domestic scheme.

I was very impressed with the contribution to this debate of the member for Bonython, and I congratulate him on his clear and detailed understanding of the state of the art so far as renewable energy options are concerned and of the wider issues connected with global warming, carbon reduction and indeed methane reduction. I agree with his remarks that this bill is technology neutral and market driven, relying on the quicker, less expensive option of biomass in preference to long-term, substantial investment in more effective employment generating technologies such as wind and solar. But it is at least a start. So, given those reservations about the conservative nature of the targets contained in this proposed legislation, I commend these bills to the House and I am interested to see whether they will receive the scrutiny they deserve at an inquiry.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —in reply—In summing up the debate tonight, let me say that the two bills before the House, the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000 and the Renewable Energy (Electricity) (Charge) Bill 2000, are the cornerstone of the government's commitment to increasing the amount of renewable energy used in generating electricity used by all Australians. They are part of a comprehensive, much larger package of commitment from this government. I want to thank all participants from both sides of the House for their contributions to this debate. It is an important piece of legislation, mandating the government's commitment to renewable energy and creating a market for new sources of renewable energy.

speech.para: No-one has denied the benefits of stimulating a renewable energy industry in order to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. Of course, the electricity generation sector is the largest single contributor to Australia's greenhouse gas emission profile. Emissions from this sector are also growing, which is why we must focus on curing the emissions growth related to our energy use. Our natural resources include, of course, abundant, high quality and low cost coal. Certainly, the member for Kennedy reminded us of that. Access to cheap coal has made a crucial contribution to the economy of this country. It has provided stable employment and low cost power for many Australians. However, it has worked against us in greenhouse gas terms. The low cost of coal in Australia has meant that many renewable energy projects have not been cost competitive. Renewable energy will simply not have an opportunity to be injected into the Australian market without some assistance, and the measures that are within this bill will produce the sorts of outcomes that are being sought today right around the world. These bills introduce a measure which will provide, in particular, a contribution to the renewable energy electricity supply in order to achieve our greenhouse gas reductions and to support the development of an innovative, domestic renewable energy manufacturing industry. The measure creates a guaranteed market for 9,500 kilowatt hours of renewable energy. We expect to be able to set a base for achieving the more difficult emission reduction targets in the future.

I would like to respond to some of the points raised by members on both sides of the House in their debate contributions. For example, the member for Bonython suggested that we should dictate which technologies and fuels should meet the targets and that we should focus on low or least-cost options. The government do not believe we are in the business of second-guessing what renewable energy technologies might emerge or be stimulated by a measure such as this. Our strategy is to promote the development of a renewable energy sector that will give Australia longer-term abatement opportunities and options. Our government has fashioned a whole range of abatement measures. In fact, our total commitment amounts to over $1 billion over five years.

This government's view is that the market should choose the technologies and fuels, not the government or a regulator. This measure is certainly not limited to a consideration of biomass, as a number of speakers on the other side seem to suggest. The member for Bonython was also worried that this is a high cost measure. I suppose that is why he was very keen that we confine ourselves to the low cost options. Let me explain to the member for Bonython that, at its peak in 2010, we may see increases in electricity costs of one to three per cent but we need to compare this with the 20 to 30 per cent price reductions for electricity to larger customers that have already been achieved in recent years through the energy market reforms we have championed. The member for Wills was concerned that we should promote solar energy use. Let me assure the member for Wills that, through the federal government's support for the commercialisation of renewable energy programs, $388 million is committed to renewable energy over five years and over $300 million of this is likely to go to solar technologies. For example, $31 million is for rooftop photovoltaic systems and up to $266 million for renewable remote area power supplies, most of which will use these photovoltaic cells. Some of the $56 million renewable energy commercialisation program will go into solar technologies. If the member for Wills is not familiar with these programs, he needs to do his homework.

Major investments in wind power now occurring in Australia, notably in Tasmania and Western Australia, are anticipated in the bill. The members for Wills and Scullin both cited Denmark as having a standard of commitment that we should aspire to. We believe that, at the end of the day, Australia's renewable electricity will be putting countries like Denmark in the shade. Let me inform these members that we have legislated to set a target of 10.5 per cent rising to 12.5 per cent by 2010. Let me stress we have legislated for that target and it has already been achieved. Denmark currently has a take-up of just 10 per cent. If you look at who, at the end of the day, is likely to be assured of an outcome, clearly we are taking our international and domestic responsibilities somewhat more seriously. Let me also refer to the member for Wills's concern about LPG gas in the transport sector. Whilst that was somewhat off the topic, let me assist him by reminding him that LPG has full excise exemption. It is supported via a $75 million alternative fuels conversion program we have recently put into place, which also facilitates conversion of vehicles over 3.5 tonnes. It is eligible for grants under the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme. We are very much concerned about LPG gas in transport and we have made a considerable amount of effort in introducing programs which will stimulate further conversion to the use of LPG gas.

The member for Shortland was concerned that the penalty is too low with this measure. In fact, the penalty was very carefully modelled. It caps risks to energy users but it provides significant stimulus to all renewables. Local government play their part in supporting renewable energies and any other possible aspect of home design or industry orientation. Local government has been pre-eminent in leading the community to understand better what our goals and targets are as a government. Local government is strongly supporting our greenhouse abatement strategies. We have had more local government authorities take up the Cities for Climate Protection program, which is supported by the federal government, than in any other country in the world. This bill will give regions new options for growth and development, which will be very good news for local government authorities. While the member for Shortland was in awe of the New South Wales Carr government's Green Power or Energy Australia scheme, let me remind her that it will produce support for only some 14,000 homes. That is very commendable, but I do not think we in the Commonwealth government should hold that particular example up and feel ourselves to be inferior. After all, if you consider what is proposed and what should be achieved through this measure, the scale of renewable energy that we have brought forward will dwarf Green Power. For example, 9,500 gigawatt hours will power some four million homes, compared with the 14,000 that we were asked to consider as a superior outcome. You can rest assured that the expectations of these measures are substantial.

We had some people from the other side doubting that the effect of the measure would be significant. The member for Scullin, for example, said, `Will this really achieve a difference in this country?' I believe that seven million tonnes of CO2 equivalent by the year 2010 is a very significant gain in terms of us being able to meet our international and domestic targets. This measure is only one of a host of abatement measures that this government is implementing. I referred earlier to the $1 billion package that will be in place over the next five years. The member for Calare was concerned that there were no mandatory energy efficiency standards for residential or commercial buildings. I say to the member for Calare that just two weeks ago the Australian Building Codes Board, the body that manages the Building Code of Australia, agreed to a Commonwealth proposal to mandate energy efficiency standards for both residential and commercial buildings through the Building Code of Australia. This proposal is fully supported by all major building industry associations. We would be happy to help the member for Calare become familiar with that marvellous new breakthrough. We can brief him. The Australian Greenhouse Office is excellent. It is the only such office in the world—one that our federal government has put in place. They would be very happy to bring the member for Calare up to speed with that recent development.

The Commonwealth has very carefully crafted this measure. It has taken two years of very close consultation with the industry. It is not something that has been rushed. It was never going to be possible to rush such an innovative and extraordinarily different measure. I remind you that this is a world first in the use of tradeable certificates for renewable energy. Therefore, it is innovative, it is at the cutting edge, it is proactive, and we believe that with the use of this measure we will be going a long way to setting a whole new standard for alternative and sustainable energy production internationally.

In conclusion, as wind farms and solar energy panels proliferate, as things like the Pyramid Hill saltworks are set up, with its solar driven saline ponds generating energy into the future, as biomass is used, as landfill is tapped for energy production, this country is going to be substantially better off. I believe this bill will be applauded by all who come to see it passed tonight. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Dr Stone)—by leave—read a third time.
Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Dr Stone:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —It is not my intention to unnecessarily delay the passage of the Renewable Energy (Electricity) (Charge) Bill 2000 this evening. However, I think it is important to respond to one comment in the parliamentary secretary's second reading summation of the previous measure. She said that I had suggested that we should target particular technologies and pick winners. That was not what I said. If the honourable member had been listening to the debate she might have understood the thrust of my text, which was to direct our efforts to those technologies which will return the best outcome from an economic and CO2 avoided point of view.

speech.para: That will involve a range of technologies and, like all government research supported programs, it would be my anticipation that we would take proposals, examine those proposals from year to year and direct resources across a range of technologies and that we would see the returns come to fruition at some future point when that research was completed. Which technologies ultimately emerge from that range of available technologies is clearly a matter for the success of the scientists and engineers and, ultimately, the commercial operators concerned. Rather than choosing the specific technology, I believe we should support through research a range of technologies according to what has the best potential from time to time—as we do in a range of government supported research programs such as the START program and other programs favoured by the current government.

In her earlier response, the parliamentary secretary did not canvass the range of issues which had been raised about some of the inadequacies in this bill and the way in which it will, or perhaps will not necessarily, target CO2 reductions. That is clearly the purpose of this legislation—at least what I understood to be the purpose of this legislation—as distinct from sponsoring renewable energy technologies. If this legislation is about renewable energy and not about CO2 reduction, then perhaps we should be so advised and the construction which the government has in the legislation would need to be totally reconsidered.

If our objective is to target CO2 reduction, which I would have thought was the purpose of this legislation, then we need to focus our attention on those aspects of it and hear from the government—perhaps not this evening; I appreciate that—in the course of the winter break, in the course of the Senate committee hearings and, ultimately, in the course of the Senate debate itself. I think that aspect is the essential feature of this bill. All members of the opposition would strongly support reduction in CO2 by Australia. Obviously, that is the critical outcome here and one which we have every pleasure in supporting in full.

We also understand the merits of renewable energy in the generic sense of that. I am sure that many of those technologies will, over time and with significant improvements in the technology, certainly come to play a significant part in our energy economy, but they can only do that if they are economically viable. In the long term, you cannot support energy generation technologies which are not economically viable. That is not a successful recipe for Australia's future growth.

The difficulty with the technologies is not only this question of economic support and the available market. The problem is that the technology is not yet competitive. Solar is far more expensive and wind is a little more expensive than conventionally generated energy. The problem is a technological one and it will have a technological solution which the government should support through research and development efforts. If it simply supports it through a broader market, we could well find that the effort is channelled into supporting biomass, for example, which will do nothing to improve the technology of solar or wind energy or of those technologies which may well succeed in the future. Alternatively, it may well support solar water heaters, which would be a very good idea and something which I would support. I would have thought we would have found a better and more direct mechanism for that. While the opposition is not opposing these bills tonight and while the government has chosen not to respond to the issue of the timing of this legislation—

talk.start.para: —We have not rushed it.

—No, the government has indeed not rushed it in the sense that it has taken two years to prepare the legislation, but it has then given the House of Representatives seven days to consider it—hardly an adequate course for such important legislation when the government admits that it took two years to draft the legislation. In that context, while we are certainly happy to permit passage of the bill this evening in a cooperative way, as is always my wont in these things, I believe that, over the next four to eight weeks, the government should address the issues that have been seriously raised in relation to this debate and take the matter further.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Let me respond to the suggestions that the Renewable Energy (Electricity) (Charge) Bill 2000 is not about reducing our greenhouse gas emissions or our CO2. This bill deals with the renewable energy sector of the market and is part of a much more substantial billion dollar package which this government is directing to a whole range of ends, including research to try to identify how we are going to significantly reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. I repeat that this is a world first in terms of introducing tradeable certificates, which are going to encourage our biggest electricity sector to look at renewable sources. I certainly commend the bill to the House.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Dr Stone) read a third time.

talk.start.para: —The extended sittings of the House of Representatives gives me an opportunity this evening to respond to several non-controversial questions raised during question time over the past few sitting weeks. I regret that a number of the members who have raised these questions are not present. My office has attempted to notify them by phone, but on extended sitting we are not necessarily able to contact everybody as easily as we might like. I will ensure that every one of the members affected gets a copy of my response individually sent to them so that they can raise it on the resumption of the House, assuming that will be in August.

speech.para: Let me provide a detailed response to the questions that have been raised with me in the last few weeks. On 7 June the member for Page and the member for Chifley asked for my interpretation of standing order 144, rules for questions, and standing order 145, answers to be relevant, respectively. I replied that I would respond when I had an opportunity. The Standing Committee on Procedure has examined both of these matters on a number of occasions. I refer members, for example, to reports of the committee of November 1986, October 1993 and June 1995. There is more than sufficient advice available to the House if it wishes to proceed down a path other than its current one. As I have indicated to the House on a number of occasions, if the requirements of standing order 144 were to be observed stringently, there would be very few questions asked in the House that would be allowed to proceed to an answer. I propose to continue to exercise discretion in applying the terms of standing order 144.

Standing order 145 relating to relevance continues to cause a degree of special interest by members. Members will be aware that I carefully note the substance of a question and require those answering the question to maintain a link to that substance. Where a question has a preamble or a quotation of some length, it is not, in my opinion, reasonable for a member to conclude with a short, sharp question and then insist that the answer be limited to the contents of the conclusion. Similarly, while all interjections are disorderly, they might invite a departure from the strict observance of relevance.

On 8 June, the Manager of Opposition Business asked me about another minister answering a question asked of the Prime Minister or the Acting Prime Minister without any obvious indication that another minister was to answer. House of Representatives Practice indicates at page 505 that it is not unusual for the Prime Minister to refer questions addressed to him to the minister directly responsible. No direct statement, request or overt public action is necessary or required. In the same vein, the Prime Minister may add to the answer of any minister, but a minister may not add to the Prime Minister's answer unless requested to do so by the Prime Minister.

The member for Melbourne asked me about any special rights the Leader of the House and the Manager of Opposition Business might have in relation to commenting on points of order. I indicated at the time, in relation to the incident to which the member for Melbourne referred, that I assumed that the Leader of the House was rising to a point of order. The Hansard record shows that this was the case. House of Representatives Practice indicates at page 277 that there are grounds for considering that a member taking a point of order shall not be interrupted by another member taking a point of order on the first point of order. It then goes on to suggest that there are occasions when a subsidiary point of order is justified. It has become the practice of the House to receive the second or more point of order before the first point of order is determined. An important consideration to keep in mind is that the chair may deliver a decision at any time after a point of order has been stated to the House. The chair has discretion to deliver a decision on a point of order whenever the chair feels in a position to do so.

Finally, the member for Calwell asked me on 22 June about the publication of notices in Hansard. As the member for Werriwa pointed out on that day, Hansard contains the details of notices given on the day on which they are received at the table of the House. However, I indicated that I thought that the member for Calwell was suggesting that the notices should continue to appear in Hansard. Underlying the attitude of the House and the chair over many years has been the consistent aim of keeping Hansard as much as possible a reflection of what is actually said in the House. Notices of motion or of intention to present a bill are not normally delivered orally in the House unless (a) given during members' statement in the chamber or (b) expressing censure of, or want of confidence in, a member. Questions on notice are also published in Hansard, together with the answer, on the day on which they are answered. The appropriate location for the publication of notices as well as for other matters awaiting further House action such as orders of the day is the House Notice Paper. This is the most appropriate location for questions on notice until they are answered. This has been the practice of the House over a long period of time, and I would not propose that it be altered. I thank all honourable members for the points they have raised.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I apologise, but I thought I also raised a question about standing order 142. Is that, as you indicated at the time, a matter for further consideration?

—Yes, it is. The matters that I dealt with tonight were the ones I considered the least controversial. I wanted members to feel that they had not been excluded from some debate on any matter that they may want to further participate in. I will come back to the member for Chifley on his question under 142.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 21 June, on motion by Dr Kemp:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 does a number of things. It indexes all aspects of higher education funding. It also includes for the first time funding in the forward estimates for the year 2002. It makes a number of technical changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme and, in addition, reallocates some unspent funds. It also implements the budget announcement to introduce a system of bonded medical scholarships, and I will say more about that later. It provides $4 million per annum for the research infrastructure equipment and facility scheme for research funding and makes some changes to the SPIRT scheme, which also deals with university research. Finally, the bill implements a name change for Batchelor College.

speech.para: In summary, the bill implements the budget changes in the area of higher education. In the lead-up to this year's budget, the Treasurer claimed on the Sunday program that the budget would direct spending to `priority areas in health and also in education'. The problem is that, when we saw the budget delivered, it did not quite live up to the Treasurer's predictions. Education certainly did need to receive a bit of priority in this budget. On my figures, there is now a $3 billion education deficit because of cuts the Howard government has made since 1996. Let me briefly remind you of them, Mr Speaker. Almost $1 billion has been cut from universities. There have been cuts in funding for vocational education and training of $240 million. There have been higher HECS charges, which strip away from students almost $1 billion. The enrolment benchmark adjustment has so far cut about $60 million from federal funding to public schools right across the country, and that continues to grow. Finally, there have been cuts to student assistance of more than $500 million.

There is a $3 billion education deficit because of cuts the Howard government has made to education across the board. In many cases, we are facing a real crisis in the area of research. Australia is the only advanced Western country where private business research and development is not only falling in real terms but also falling in nominal terms. In addition to a decline in private expenditure on R&D, we have public research declining because of the massive cuts the government has made in funding to higher education. Is it any wonder that a number of prominent Australians have called on the government to lift its research effort, particularly in our higher education institutions? Australians of the Year Peter Doherty and Gustav Nossal have been amongst the government's critics on this issue, calling for additional federal government funding for the national research effort. The Australian Research Council chair, Vicki Sara, has also made comments such as:

quote.para: The world is moving very quickly. Major investments are being made in many countries to develop competitive ideas and skills. We want to be world competitive, so there needs to be additional investment made in that research base.

speech.para: So there is a $3 billion education deficit because of the cuts the government has made to universities and TAFE, the $1 billion extra slug on students through the higher HECS charges, and the $60 million taken from public schools through the EBA and cuts to student assistance of more than $500 million. There has been a decline in Australia's national research effort because of the cuts that have been made. It causes me great concern that the government's cuts have seriously affected many university towns and communities in regional Australia. I understand the honourable member for Herbert will follow me in this debate. Let me draw to his attention the fact that James Cook University has lost $16 million because of the cuts the Howard government has made to higher education. I know my colleague the member for Werriwa was a frequent visitor to the James Cook University campus. There were no greater advocates for James Cook University's receiving a fair share of higher education funding than people like the former Labor member for Herbert, Ted Lindsay, and the member for Werriwa.

talk.start.para: —Not for long, I can assure you. Let me assure the House that the problem for the current member for Herbert is that the government of which he is part has cut funding for James Cook University by $16 million. If you go through the list, it is not just James Cook University that has been hit by these cuts. If you go through the list of universities outside the capital cities, it adds up to quite a sizeable amount. Charles Sturt University has lost $21 million, Southern Cross University has lost $11 million, the University of New England has lost $18 million, the University of Newcastle has lost $27 million and the University of Wollongong has lost $18 million. Deakin University in Victoria has lost $25 million and the University of Ballarat has lost $4 million. In Queensland, Central Queensland University has lost $13 million. I have already mentioned James Cook University losing $16 million. The University of Southern Queensland has lost $16 million, and in Tasmania the Australian Maritime College has lost $2 million. That is a reduction of $171 million from all of the universities not based in our capital cities.

speech.para: Is it any wonder that our universities in regional areas are feeling the pain of the federal government's cuts when you take such a massive amount of money from their budgets—$171 million taken from Australia's regional universities. In many cases it is the universities that are the real drivers of development in those communities. It is those regional universities that give local kids and mature age students their best opportunity to study for a degree, their best opportunity to get the skills that they need to get the high quality jobs of the future. It is this government's cuts of $171 million from our regional universities that will deny students in those communities the chance to study for a degree. It is the cuts of $171 million in regional universities, the cuts that this government has made in higher education, that will deny those communities the opportunities for economic development and new jobs.

For that reason we were hopeful that, with the Treasurer predicting that education would be a priority in this budget, perhaps there might be a rabbit pulled from Peter Costello's hat on budget night. But in fact on budget night we had only an extra $17 million provided for new education initiatives in 2000-01. That is only an extra $17 million across all areas: early childhood education, schools, high schools, TAFE and universities. That basically equates to a pittance if you consider the amount that is provided for each Australian over the four years covered in the budget. If we look at the forward estimates, the new education commitments listed on Budget Paper No. 2, page 31, it lists only an extra $62.1 million being provided over four years for education or a measly 86c per person per year—less than the cost of a cheap biro being allocated for new spending initiatives. Mr Speaker, I am sure you understand that, if Australia is just to keep pace with the countries that we compete with, we have to make sure that we are investing more, not less, in education, training and research. When President Clinton announces billions of dollars being allocated for new research initiatives, when the Canadians announce 2,000 extra fellowships to encourage research in Canada, when Tony Blair announces an extra billion pounds for research in the United Kingdom and when the Europeans and the Asians are lifting their investment in education, training and research, Australia must ensure that it is also lifting its investment just to keep pace.

On this side of the House, under Kim Beazley's plan for Australia to become a knowledge nation, we believe that we have to not only keep pace with our competitor countries but also get ahead of them. That can only take place in a country which is lifting its national investment in education, training and research. We can never make Australia a knowledge nation if the most the minister for education, Dr Kemp, can win from his colleagues in the battles for the budget is a measly 86c per person per year.

The details in this budget are important. Before I get into some of the details I will touch on a number of anomalies that flow from the introduction of the government's new tax system. A number of questions were put to the Prime Minister in the lead-up to the budget about the impact that the new tax scheme will have on postgraduate researchers. This bill deals with higher education. Many people who are receiving scholarships for postgraduate research are being hit by the changes the government is making. Before the last election the Prime Minister guaranteed that no-one would be a loser under the GST. The government, knowing that many of Australia's postgraduate researchers received grants from the government, agreed to increase the grants under the APA program by four per cent. This would mean, the government argued, that they would be no worse off as the prices for all the goods and services that they use went up under the GST.

The problem is that there are many other people who also receive grants to carry out postgraduate research and their grants were not increased by four per cent. There are many people who receive grants to carry out research from charities, benevolent trusts and universities—some of Australia's best researchers—who are going to be worse off because of the changes the government has made to the tax system. I am sure my colleague the member for Werriwa has received letters and emails from some of these postgraduate students who do not pay tax—they do not benefit from the tax cuts—and who will have to pay more because of the increase in the cost of clothing, transport and the goods and services that they need.

It was those postgraduate students who were going to be worse off and, through questioning in this House, we forced the Prime Minister to admit they were going to be worse off. Because of that, the Prime Minister invented a new assistance scheme for postgraduate students—the GST assistance scheme. It was only in the budget that we found out that this generous government was going to give those postgraduate students—some of Australia's best researchers—the measly sum of $120 to compensate them for the GST for the rest of time. The Prime Minister knows that in no way whatsoever can a one-off payment of $120 compensate these postgraduate researchers for the higher costs of the GST that they are going to pay year after year. That is the first point to make about the GST.

The second is that there are more than one million current and former students who are still paying off their HECS debts who are going to be hit by an unfair, retrospective slug because of the GST inflation spike. We all know that the inflation rate will basically double this year because of the effect of the GST. HECS debts are increased by the CPI and that means that in this year HECS debts will be indexed by the full inflation spike. That will cost the average student $700 because this government has not discounted the CPI increase by the GST inflation spike. If the member for Herbert visits James Cook University campus and explains to the students at that campus that his government is going to take $700, on average, off each of them to help pay for those Unchain my Heart Joe Cocker television ads, he will have a lot of explaining to do. It is so unfair that, in total, about $180 million will be ripped off those students because this government is going to allow that unfair, retrospective tax slug to be imposed on students around Australia with HECS debts.

The minister for education made a number of claims about this when we raised this in the House. He said that, because of low inflation, a student with a HECS debt of $20,000 would have paid $1,200 less under the coalition. But the problem is that, until the coalition doubled HECS charges in 1997, it was not possible to have a debt as high as $20,000. The minister quotes the example of someone having a debt of $20,000 being, according to him, better off under the coalition, when no-one had a debt of $20,000 until the government doubled HECS charges in the infamous Vanstone budget of 1996. Dr Kemp also claimed that a recent graduate on $28,000 would be $762 better off because of the Howard government's tax cuts. However, after the coalition reduced the repayment threshold for HECS in 1997, this graduate, who is now repaying HECS at four per cent of her taxable income, or $1,120 a year, would, under the previous Labor government's 1996 threshold for HECS, be making no repayments whatsoever. So what is the effect of this? Despite the minister for education's claims and the examples he gives, because of this government, Dr Kemp has been responsible for this year's graduates having to cope with a doubling of the HECS charges every year, much earlier repayments of that debt, an increase of the HECS debts of up to $700 because of the GST inflation spike being included in the CPI this year and GST increases on new clothing, shoes, dry cleaning, software, bus and train fares and electricity and gas bills. These people do not need a PhD to work out that that $762 tax cut is long gone because of the doubling of the HECS charges, the early repayments of their debt, the increase in the HECS debt because of the GST inflation spike and the higher cost of goods and services because of the GST. We have to hope that the minister for education can go back and do some more work on those examples that he has quoted.

One of the issues that I think we need to deal with in considering this legislation is that on many occasions in this House the minister for education makes claims about the great successes of the government's higher education policy.

talk.start.para: —He is right.

—The member opposite thinks he is right. I challenge the member opposite to consider some of the following facts. For example, the member opposite might believe the minister for education when he says things like this. This is a comment from Dr Kemp in a recent question time:

quote.para: This year the total number of domestic Australian students in higher education will be an estimated 464,700 equivalent full-time students ...

speech.para: The trouble with this is that this figure is 1,337 lower than the 1999 figure, and the minister seems to be boasting about reducing the number of Australian students at university. The second claim he made was that this figure was `a staggering 42,000 more students than in Labor's last year'. The problem for the minister is that in the five years from 1995 to 2000 enrolments grew by about 9.9 per cent, while in the last five years of Labor government, 1990 to 1995, enrolments grew at more than 19 per cent. So the minister is now boasting about halving the rate of growth in university places. I would suggest to the honourable member opposite that he look very carefully at the shonky figures that the minister for education often quotes at question time.

One of the problems we have with this legislation is that it was introduced into this House only last week. I actually think it is an insult to the parliament that at 29 minutes past midnight in the House of Representatives we are debating legislation which is important for the future of higher education in Australia. The only reason that five members of Australian House of Representatives are in the chamber tonight at 29 minutes past midnight is that this government is seeking to fill in time in the House of Representatives while they are waiting for some of their more urgent bills to be debated in the Senate. The future of higher education in Australia in many ways will help determine Australia's future. Unless we are addressing the crisis that now exists in higher education, we are not going to ensure that Australians do have the opportunities to obtain postgraduate degrees and undergraduate degrees which will help give them the skills they need to get the high value, high wage jobs of the future.

It was not that long ago that the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, in confidence in a cabinet submission to his colleagues, admitted some of the difficulties that Australia's higher education institutions now face. Last year we released a cabinet submission written by the minister which admitted in private what the minister had always denied in public. That cabinet submission contained admissions that the higher student-staff ratios, the less frequent lecture and tutorial contact, the persistence of outdated technology and the gaps in key areas of professional preparation had resulted in a perception of crisis in higher education. Dr Kemp's cabinet submission also admitted that eight institutions were operating at a deficit and that some regional campuses were at risk. So, having admitted that in October, you might have expected the minister to have brought forward proposals to his colleagues in the budget to address that crisis. The fact that he has declined to do so leads us to believe that the minister is just waiting for the opportunity to bring out his original plan from the bottom drawer of his desk; a plan to deregulate university fees at all universities, to bring in a system of voucher funding and to replace HECS with a system of real interest rate loans.

The member for Herbert might shake his head, but he knows as well as I do that that is the plan that Dr Kemp, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, took to cabinet last year. The only reason the Prime Minister tried to disassociate himself from the minister's plan for higher education was the massive public outrage about it. In fact, the only thing that was salvaged from last year's cabinet submission was the minister's plan to offer a modest increase in funding for higher education to those universities that will accept this government's pattern bargain for higher education.

talk.start.para: —Blackmail!
