—The honourable member for Werriwa describes this as `blackmail'. I will not break the sub judice laws, but there is going to be a court case, initiated by the NTEU, to determine whether the minister has broken the law by offering this pattern bargain of an increase in funding to universities on condition that they meet certain industrial relations criteria. The point I make is that, to date, that is the only part of the secret, leaked cabinet submission that has been implemented. But I am sure the minister for education has that plan there in the bottom drawer.

speech.para: The bill also includes some funding for places for the bonded medical scholarships. We are entitled to ask: where is the detail on the bonded medical scholarships? The reason I have a particular interest in this is that this is part of the Labor Party's health policy that we put to the people at the last election. I remember a debate with the Minister for Health and Aged Care on the 7.30 Report in which he described this particular proposal as `unconstitutional', and yet here we have a budget in the year 2000 in which the minister for health claims credit for an initiative that he has stolen from the Labor Party. We do not mind the minister for health stealing the policies of the Labor Party; it is in fact one of the few wins that the minister for education had in the budget that was delivered by the minister for health. You have got to feel sorry for the minister for education when the only wins he has in the budget process are those that are won for him by the minister for health. We certainly believe that the bonded medical scholarships provide a good model for encouraging doctors to work in rural and regional Australia. It is also a model we are attracted to for other areas where there are difficulties in attracting skilled professionals; rural and regional Australia, for example. This proposal for the medical area will, we think, be a success.

A number of other scholarships have also been proposed by the Labor Party recently which encourage more of our brightest students to take up a career in teaching. The proposal that I floated on behalf of the Labor Party is a mechanism to forgive HECS debts for students who receive our teaching excellence scholarships. At the moment, people who do a Bachelor of Education—

talk.start.para: —No, it is to help the government fill in time—to make sure that we are still here when the Senate finishes its work. The point I am making is that we need more of our brightest kids to consider a career in teaching. In particular, we need more of our brightest kids to consider a career in teaching in maths, science and IT, where there is a severe shortage looming.

speech.para: Professor Lawrence Ingvarson from Monash University has estimated that 25 per cent of the maths and science teachers in Victoria are not qualified to teach maths and science. This is not only unfair to the teachers but it is grossly unfair to the students and their classes. How can we expect kids to develop a love for maths and science and develop the computer skills they need if we do not have teachers who are properly trained to ensure they have an excellent education. It is those teacher excellence scholarships and investing in teacher professional development that give us the best chance to raise the quality of teaching in our classrooms across the country. My colleague the member for Werriwa is a very keen student on ways that Australia can lift the standard of teaching in schools in his own electorate, in my own state and across the country.

The last area I wanted to touch on in the brief time left to me is the area of research. As I mentioned earlier on, Australia's private research is declining in nominal dollars. Our public research is declining because of the massive cuts the government has made to higher education. The government has released a green paper on research, a white paper on research, a new strategic plan for the Australian Research Council and an innovation summit—we have had all these things—but we have not had any meaningful increase in Commonwealth funding for the national research effort. What is the point of having white papers, green papers, new initiatives and summits if you cannot ensure that Australia is going to lift the quantity and the quality of the national research effort? It is going to require some innovative thinking on Australia's part if we are to ensure that we do better than we are today, but there is no way that we can ensure that the Australian medical researchers, the Australian industrial designers and the Australian computer software designers are coming up with the new intellectual property that is going to generate for Australia the royalty payments and the licence fees that can help meet the intellectual property deficit that we are going to face in many years to come.

If we do not do something about lifting Australia's national research effort, then we will have to pay other countries more to use their inventions and their ideas. For these reasons, I wish to move the following second reading amendment:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:
(1) notes with concern that the Government has failed:

(a) to address the problems in universities which its own Cabinet submission identified, such as higher student/staff ratios, less frequent lecture and tutorial contact, the persistence of outdated technology and gaps in key areas of professional preparation, as well as eight institutions operating at a deficit, with some regional campuses at risk;
(b) to respond to calls from academics, scientists and the business community to increase significantly higher education research funding; and

(c) to produce legislation to implement its proposed changes to university research funding, due to start in six months, and legislation to make urgently-needed changes to the Education Services for Overseas Students Act; and
(2) calls on the Government to immediately address each of these major issues.

talk.start.para: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the requested amendments Nos. 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12 be made.

speech.para: These are government amendments moved and accepted in the Senate. In the interests of time, I will not elaborate further on them at this stage.

talk.start.para: —This is an important piece of legislation because it involves an agreement with the government in relation to the whole business tax package. This component, the alienation of personal services income, is an important measure on anti-avoidance, and it squared the equation in the overall package so far as the revenue neutrality test was concerned. I do not want to take a lot of time tonight, and we note that the government have accepted the amendments that they have moved. But there were important amendments moved in the Senate—which were supported in the Senate and have come here—which we think have strengthened the bill and which significantly reinforce what the Ralph inquiry recommended in this context. As well, they give stronger effect to the revenue neutrality test, because the transitional period which the government have allowed has resulted in circumstances in which less revenue than was previously claimed in the agreement with us would have been obtained.

speech.para: The amendments that the government are not agreeing to advance the position. We support those amendments. All it essentially needs is for the government to support them, in accordance with their agreement with us, and to give effect more fully to the Ralph recommendations. Unfortunately, the government are not prepared to accept them here. We recognise that point. Rather than waste time debating it here, we think the matter should go back to the Senate and hopefully be resolved satisfactorily as soon as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That requested amendments Nos 1 and 13 be not made.

speech.para: Firstly, the government rejects outright amendment No. 1, which would have seen a report on the operation of the act. We simply are unable to accept that. With respect to the Senate's request for amendment No. 13, which would reduce the period of prescribed payment system declaration from two years to one year—applying only to the 2000-01 income year—the government does not accept that amendment.

The government has had regard to the fact that payers under the prescribed payment system are currently subject to withholding arrangements and are specifically recognised as contractors under the tax laws. The exclusion of PPS contractors for two years removes the compliance burden from the new rules that contractors in the PPS face in transferring to the new tax system. The government has also had regard to the logistics of the commissioner being able to process a potentially large number of requests for individual determinations for the 2000-01 income year. The government does not agree with the suggestions of the Australian Democrats that the transitional period should be reduced to one year. The main business tax reforms are proposed to start on 1 July 2001, making that an unsuitable time to ask the PPS entities to also cope with alienation changes.

talk.start.para: —As to the reporting period, we cannot understand the logic of a government that signed up with us saying that the agreement that they were implementing would deliver in full in accordance with the press release of the Treasurer back in November of last year. If the argument is correct that the legislation enacted after the transitional period delivers in full, there should be no difficulty at all in the government accepting reporting to demonstrate that those targets are being met—no reason at all. We have heard no argument from the government as to why they are not prepared to accept a report that requires them to more specifically state how they honour their agreement.

speech.para: On the question of the transition period, this is the area that goes fundamentally to their failure on the revenue neutrality front. There have been no convincing arguments as to why the transition period needs to be the length that they argue. Again, without debating the point here, we think it is a matter that should get back to the Senate for consideration as quickly as possible, as indeed the issue of the tests which we believe, if the government were being genuine about its agreement both in accordance with the Ralph review and its commitment to us, they should be prepared to accept.

This is a circumstance in which the government reached an agreement with us. They have not been prepared to enter into any discussions with us as to why they cannot meet these points. That is disappointing, given the spirit of bipartisanship with which we entered these discussions around these issues. Given the arrogance with which the government, and the Treasurer in particular, treat this parliament and given the fact that the Treasurer has been in Paris for the last week and has flown back in no doubt jet lagged because we could not get through to his office when we tried to understand what the effect of these amendments were tonight, we think it is better to have it sent back to the Senate as quickly as possible to try to get some commonsense because we are not getting it in this chamber.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —We reject the suggestions that the Treasurer is arrogant. It is particularly interesting that as the Treasurer was in this chamber today the opposition could not think of one question to ask him.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That requested amendment No. 6 be not made, but that in place thereof, the amendments circulated on behalf of the Government, be made.

quote.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 28 (after line 33), at the end of subsection (5) add:
; and (d) 80% or more of the individual's personal services income could reasonably be expected to be, or was, income from the same entity, or from the same entity and that entity's *associates.
(2) Schedule 1, item 3, page 29 (line 12), omit “subsection (3)”, substitute “paragraphs (3)(a) and (b)”.

speech.para: The government does not agree to the Senate's requested amendment No. 6, which would replace the government's criteria with a test requiring the contractor to satisfy either the employment test or the business premises test, and the further grounds income for producing a result, supplying the equipment or tools of trade, and liable for the cost of rectifying defects. In addition, the commissioner could refuse to issue a determination if he considers, having regard to common law principles, that the work is done in an employee-like manner. Most contractors who get 80 per cent or more of their income from one source would not satisfy the criteria proposed by the Senate amendment. Further, the commissioner could effectively reconsider the whole matter of whether the individual is conducting a personal services business without having regard to any criteria laid down in the bill.

The amendments also exclude the unusual circumstances criterion in the bill which allowed a contractor to obtain a personal services business determination if, but for those circumstances, they would have met one of the tests for a personal services business. This test was important to allow contractors who normally contract with the public at large but who take a long-term one-off contract to be considered as conducting a personal services business.

The amendments by the Senate to the grounds for a personal services business determination have been proposed only for individuals seeking determinations. No amendments have been proposed for personal services business determinations for entities. The government assumes that this is a drafting oversight and, if not fixed, will lead to vastly different treatment for when income is received by an entity. The government framed the further grounds income for producing a result, supplying plant and equipment or tools of trade, and liable for the cost of rectifying defects as an alternative basis for the determination. In some industries contractors do not work in a way that would satisfy the criteria. As the Senate's amendment would require the further grounds to be met in all cases as well as either the employment or business test, contractors in those industries would be unable to get a determination.

The government moves two technical amendments to replace Senate request No. 6 which will confirm that the Commissioner of Taxation may make a personal services business determination only under the further grounds—that is, income for producing a result, being required to supply the plant and equipment or tools of trade, and liable for the cost of rectifying any defects in the work—where an individual receives 80 per cent or more of his or her personal services income from one source. This wording change is consistent with the scheme of the alienation provisions as set out in the diagram in proposed section 87(5).

talk.start.para: —We do not disagree with the technical amendments that the government is making. We do not support its rejection of the amendment proposed by the Senate. I have made reference to that before. There is no point wasting time in this chamber with a government that is not prepared to honour its agreements with us. But let us hope that we can get some sense out of the Senate and get it back here finalised.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: It is not a matter of surprise that the government's preferred position is to have the bill passed in its entirety. However, the government recognises that, due to the positions taken by the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party in the other place, this is not possible. Therefore the government, reluctantly, is prepared to support the amendments. By moving these amendments the Australian Democrats are responsible for reducing revenue by an average of $70 million per annum over the next five years. I just want to make that very clear to the House: the Australian Democrats and Labor have gone soft on capital gains tax, at a cost to the revenue of $70 million a year. The government is well aware of concerns raised about the segregation method and indicated its willingness to offer an alternative method.

The superannuation industry was prepared for us to get on with consultations to formulate this alternative method, with a view to limiting compliance costs. Instead of allowing passage of the bill, the Australian Democrats and Labor have decided to block taxation changes that would have removed the ability of taxpayers to eliminate capital gains tax through planning the time of superannuation asset disposals. Who now can take seriously Labor's rhetoric about acting tough on tax? Let us remember that it was the Labor Party that brought in the special capital gains tax provisions in 1988 that currently apply to complying superannuation funds to tax capital gains accrued in the accumulation phase. This bill was merely trying to apply these Labor Party capital gains tax provisions to tax capital gains accrued in the accumulation phase when the asset is transferred to the pension phase, an anomaly recognised by the industry. But, as I said at the outset, I am moving that the amendments be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —Far be it from the Labor Party to make an honest man of the Prime Minister but I do have to draw to the attention of the House the Prime Minister's address to the nation this evening. He said:

quote.para: ... the capital gains tax has been virtually halved, with special provisions for those in small business who've worked hard all of their lives and want to retire on the proceeds of their effort and hard work.

speech.para: The fact is that, if this bill had gone through in the way the government proposed, it would have made a nonsense of the Prime Minister's address to the nation this evening. Indeed, Senator Watson, Liberal Party chair of the Senate committee inquiring into this legislation, indicated to the Senate that this bill works contrary to the government's oft promoted capital gains tax exemptions provided to small business. Senator Watson pointed out that small businesses would be disadvantaged compared with those who did move assets into a superannuation fund and who held those assets individually, pointing out that an individual small business taxpayer can take advantage of either a 15-year ownership capital gains tax exemption or the $500,000 capital gains tax rollover exemption for small businesses who use the sale of their business to retire. Indeed, Senator Watson's view was supported in evidence by Peter McDonald, the National Director of Superannuation Australia. This was not opposed or refuted by Senator Kemp when the matter was put to him by Senator Watson.

So Labor is making an honest person of the Prime Minister concerning the issue of capital gains tax in relation to superannuation, taxation and taxation change as proposed by the government, where what it has wanted to do is require the segregation of assets supporting pension payments. Let me make the point that the government's handling of this legislation has been absolutely disgraceful. In the first instance it has engaged in selective consultation with the life insurance representatives. They have left out everybody else involved in providing superannuation. As a result, the only people who have supported the government's bill are the life insurance representatives. Everybody else—corporate superannuation funds, industry superannuation funds, do-it-yourself superannuation funds, ASFA, the financial planning association, the certified practising accountants—has opposed this government's measure.

Secondly, they bring forward a complicated piece of legislation and say, `This is going to apply from 1 July this year,' and it comes on for debate today—well, it is now actually Friday—a day or so before it is due to take effect, which makes it impossible to get the legislation right in time. All the evidence to the Senate committee suggests that we can come up with a superior agreed outcome but what it means is that income stream providers are now operating in an uncertain environment. Assuming the representations from life offices on this point are not simply a device to try to secure passage of the legislation, that is a serious issue.

So we have a situation where Senator Kemp said that he would address the complexity of the bill, that he hoped to work out a solution, that it is a complex issue. But what he wanted to do was to put the parliament in the situation of passing the bill first and sorting it out later. We and the Australian Democrats said, `Look, that is not good enough. It is unsatisfactory and not a tenable situation.' We have rejected it. We hope that the government will now go and consult with the whole of the industry—not just selective consultation with a few—and come back with a better alternative, which must certainly be available to it.

If the government wants to have a debate about retrospective capital gains tax, by all means let us have that sort of debate. If it wants to have a debate about capital gains tax on the family farm, let us have a debate about that; if it wants to have a debate about using superannuation taxation to impose an effective death duty, let us have a debate about that; if it wants to create a new layer of complexity which will needlessly disadvantage industry and corporate funds, by all means, let us have a debate about that; and if it wants to discourage income streams, let us have a debate about that. But we hope that the government will now go back to the drawing board, consult genuinely across the board and come up with a more superior piece of legislation than it has done so far.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

The government agrees to the amendments to the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 made by the Senate. The amendments made by the Senate facilitate the operation of the act by clarifying a number of procedural issues. The bill supports the government's commitment to provide untimed local calls to consumers in extended zones. It supports the commitment made by the government at the last election. The bill also commences the process of reforming the delivery of the universal service obligation, a process which the government will continue later this year with further legislation. The tender for the provision of untimed local calls is a significant issue for those people in remote Australia currently liable to pay timed rates for all telephone calls they make. The tender process will be thorough and rigorous. It will ensure the successful tenderer has an ongoing commitment and a demonstrated capacity, both financial and technical, to deliver services to customers in remote Australia.

talk.start.para: —The opposition has no difficulties with the amendments so far as they go, but regrettably in the other place the best amendments that were moved in respect of this legislation were not supported. They were opposition amendments which sought to break the nexus that the government had inextricably chosen between the successful tender of the $150 million extension of local calls to remote areas and that winner of the tender automatically becoming the regional universal service provider. I asked a question in this place during the second reading debate and the government has still not put out a qualitative reason as to why there is a difference in approach in this matter and for the pilot programs, which this legislation also sets the scene of. In those instances the government's policy correctly is that a regional universal service provider will be chosen but Telstra, if it is not chosen as a regional universal service provider, must operate in that market as a safety net of last resort.

speech.para: On the relevant department's own evidence to the Senate committee, that does not apply in respect of the successful tender of the $150 million extension of infrastructure for local calls in remote areas, and the government leaps automatically to the nomination of that successful tenderer being the regional universal service provider. That is wrong in principle, and I dare say that in the fullness of time we will live to regret it.
Amendments agreed to.

Schedule 1, page 21 (after line 13), after item 79, insert:
Insert:
(1) For the purposes of this Schedule, a broadcasting service is a multi-channelled national television broadcasting service if:
(a) the service provides television programs; and
(b) either:
(i) the service is provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in accordance with section 6 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983; or
(ii) the service is provided by the Special Broadcasting Service Corporation in accordance with section 6 of the Special Broadcasting Service Act 1991; and
(c) the service is transmitted in digital mode using multi-channelling transmission capacity; and
(d) the only programs delivered by the service are programs to which subclause (2) applies; and
(e) the service is promoted as a service that is distinct from any other broadcasting service provided by the Corporation concerned; and
(f) the service is neither a subscription broadcasting service nor a subscription narrowcasting service; and
(g) the Corporation concerned has given the Minister a written notice electing that this subclause apply to the service; and
(h) if the Corporation concerned transmits the service in a particular coverage area:
(i) the Corporation transmits another broadcasting service in that coverage area; and
(ii) the other service is a national television broadcasting service; and
(iii) clause 19 applies to the other service during the simulcast period for that coverage area.
(2) This subclause applies to the following television programs:
(a) a program (including a news bulletin or a current affairs program) that deals wholly or principally with regional matters;
(b) an educational program;
(c) a science program;
(d) a religious program;
(e) a health program;
(f) an arts-related program;
(g) a culture-related program;
(h) a financial, market or business information bulletin;
(i) a program that consists of:
(i) the proceedings of, or the proceedings of a committee of, a Parliament; or
(ii) the proceedings of a court or tribunal in Australia; or
(iii) the proceedings of an official inquiry or Royal Commission in Australia; or
(iv) a hearing conducted by a body established for a public purpose by a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory;
(j) a public policy program;
(k) a foreign-language news bulletin;
(l) a program about community-based multicultural or indigenous activities;
(m) a children's program;
(n) a history program;
(o) a program that:
(i) is produced by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation; and
(ii) deals with international news (including analysis of items of international news);
(p) a national program about rural affairs;
(q) an information-only program;
(r) a stand-alone international social documentary;
(s) a stand-alone social documentary that is produced by the Special Broadcasting Service Corporation;
(t) a subtitled foreign-language program;
(u) an occasional stand-alone drama program;
(v) incidental matter.
(3) In this clause:
drama program has the same meaning as in section 103B.
educational program has the same meaning as in Schedule 6 (disregarding subclauses 3(2) to (7) (inclusive) of Schedule 6).
financial, market or business information bulletin has the same meaning as in Schedule 6.

foreign-language news bulletin means a news bulletin the audio component of which is wholly in a language other than English (for this purpose, disregard minor and infrequent uses of the English language).
incidental matter means:
(a) advertising or sponsorship matter (whether or not of a commercial kind); or
(b) a program promotion; or
(c) an announcement; or
(d) a hosting; or
(e) any other interstitial program.
information-only program has the same meaning as in Schedule 6 (disregarding subclauses 4(2) to (7) (inclusive) of Schedule 6).
public policy program means a program that consists of a lecture, speech, debate or forum, where:
(a) the lecture, speech, debate or forum deals wholly or principally with one or more matters of public policy; and
(b) there is no editing of the substance of the lecture, speech, debate or forum; and

(c) if there is any analysis, commentary or discussion about the substance of the lecture, speech, debate or forum—the analysis, commentary or discussion has a balanced presentation of points of view.

subtitled foreign-language program means a subtitled program the audio content of which is wholly in a language other than English (for this purpose, disregard minor and infrequent uses of the English language).

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: The Senate today has passed the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Digital Television and Datacasting) Bill 2000 with approximately 140 amendments. The Senate has agreed to amendments which will enhance the role of the ABC and SBS in the digital era. In particular, amendments to the Broadcasting Services Act and the Radiocommunications Act will provide for the national broadcasters to transmit a multichannel national television broadcasting service, which will allow them to provide additional channels with a wide range of classes of programs.

An amendment is also proposed to ensure that the transmitter licences for transmitting national television broadcasting services in digital mode will also authorise the transmission of national radio broadcasting services. This amendment responds to a recommendation of the report of the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee inquiry into the bill and will allow the ABC and SBS to extend the coverage of their radio services.

The amendments will also change the provisions in the bill relating to HDTV material provided by the ABC. Specifically, they remove the requirement for national broadcasters to provide any material originally produced in an HDTV format when meeting the 20 hours per week quota of HDTV provided for in the bill, thereby allowing them to meet the quota entirely from `upconverted' material.

The Senate has made amendments to the provisions in the bill relating to program enhancements. The amendments remove the provisions in the bill relating to category B digital program enhancements and limit the extent to which a sporting or other designated event may overlap with a following program to situations where the following program is a regularly scheduled news program.

Amendments are also made relating to electronic program guides. Together, they will have the effect that, if a commercial or national television broadcaster transmits any free-to-air broadcaster's EPG other than its own, that broadcaster must transmit all free-to-air broadcasters' EPGs. Similarly, if a datacasting licensee transmits the EPG of any commercial or national broadcaster, it must transmit the EPGs of all other free-to-air broadcasters if those broadcasters request it. In addition, the amendments require that commercial and national television broadcasters must make available the information needed to compile EPGs to each other, if required to do so. The amendments made in the Senate make a number of changes to the regulatory regime for the introduction of datacasting services in proposed new schedule 6 of the BSA.

Changes are made to several of the program definitions in the bill. The definition of `education program' has been broadened to remove the requirement that educational programs be linked to a course of study or instruction. This responds to a recommendation in the report of the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee inquiry into the bill. Amendments are included to clarify that an information program can include factual information or directly related comment about a wide range of matters, can facilitate the carrying out and completion of transactions and must not have a significant emphasis on dramatic impact or entertainment.

The definition of foreign language news bulletin has been amended so that such programs can include English language subtitles or captioning and may also include discussion, commentary or analysis. Amendments have been made which have the effect of moving current affairs programs from category A television programs to category B television programs. This will have the effect that datacasters may provide news and current affairs programs which comply with the provisions relating to category B programs. The requirement that an extract from a category A television program not be `fully self-contained' is removed, as is the requirement for a 10-minute news bulletin to be `presenter based'. There are also amendments which clarify that if a program is allowed as a category A program it is also allowed as a category B program and vice versa. This will ensure that datacasters are not at risk of providing programs under one category which are then deemed to be in breach of the other.

The package of amendments includes an anti-avoidance provision to deal with the possibility of a licensee entering into contrived arrangements, through multiple datacasting licences, to avoid the operation of the 10-minute news bulletin rules. Anti-avoidance provisions to prevent Internet carriage services being used to circumvent the genre and audio content conditions are included in the bill. (Extension of time granted) However, amendments will allow the ABA to exempt content provided by a datacaster from the datacasting genre rules where that content has been selected and copied from the Internet and where the ABA is satisfied that any breach of the rules arising from the transmission of the matter would be of a minor, infrequent or incidental nature or the transmission of the matter would not be contrary to the purpose of the genre rules in clauses 14, 16, 20 and 21 of schedule 6.

Amendments will extend the types of news and related programs which may be accessed from an on-screen menu, including to allow presenters such as an on-location journalist. The amendments clarify that the genre and audio content conditions do not apply to advertising or sponsorship material and ensure that the audio content conditions in clause 21 of schedule 6 do not apply to the transmission of audio content that is incidental or provided as background to the matter displayed on the screen. The amendments insert provisions which strengthen the `use it or lose it' provisions to ensure that datacasting transmitter licensees continue to provide a service and do not simply commence and shut down the service and hoard the spectrum. Licensees must commence transmitting within one year of the licence being allocated and may only be `off the air' prior to 2007 for a cumulative total of 180 days unless there are exceptional circumstances.

The amendments also modify provisions which deny the ability of courts and the AAT to stay a decision with provisions which allow them to only stay the decision for three months. The decisions relate to imposition or variation of licence conditions, remedial directions and suspension and cancellation of datacasting licences and proceedings relating to suspension or cancellation of datacasting transmitter licences. The amendments encourage efficient allocation of spectrum so that there will be greater availability of channels for datacasting. In making or amending the commercial and national television conversion schemes, the ABA is required to have regard to the need to plan for the most efficient use of spectrum and to take into account the need for spectrum to be made available for allocation for purposes of the transmission of datacasting services. A statutory review is to be conducted before 31 October 2000 to determine whether the ABA has sufficient powers to allow the most efficient use of broadcasting spectrum, including for promoting the availability of datacasting services.

The amendments also make a number of changes to the provisions relating to statutory reviews. The completion date of all the reviews currently required under subclause 60 of schedule 4 has been brought forward from 31 December 2005 to 1 January 2005, except for the review into the length of the simulcast period. This review must be completed by 1 January 2006. Amendments bring forward the timing of the datacasting and HDTV quota reviews which were to be conducted by 1 January 2004—the completion date is now 1 January 2003. Changes are also being made to the reviews of arrangements to apply to datacasting transmitter licences after 2007. The review into the regulatory arrangements applying to the use of such licences after 1 January 2007 is also to address the competitive arrangements that should apply to those licences. The amendments also require that the review be conducted on the basis that there should be equitable treatment between those using datacasting transmission licences to provide commercial broadcasting television services and incumbent broadcasters.

The amendments introduce a number of new reviews. These include: a review, by 1 January 2002, of the regulatory arrangements that should apply to the digital transmission of community television broadcasting services using spectrum in the broadcasting services bands and how access to spectrums should be provided free of charge; a review, by 1 January 2002, of whether, in the context of converging media technologies, streamed audio and video content available on the Internet should be regarded as a broadcasting service; a review, by 1 January 2004, into the conditions that should apply to the provision of commercial television licences on or after 1 January 2007 for the provision of commercial television broadcasting licences; (Extension of time granted) a review, by 1 January 2005, into the viability of providing an indigenous television broadcasting service, and the regulatory arrangements that should apply to the digital transmission of such a service.

The access rights currently provided in the BSA relating to transmission towers and sites are amended to ensure that access can be obtained to certain associated facilities at a transmission site which will be needed to provide digital television or datacasting services. The provisions in the bill relating to the allocation of a third commercial television licence to one or both of the existing licensees have been amended to reflect the later commencement of digital television services in remote areas. An amendment is made to require that any part of the spectrum determined by the ABA to be available for the transmission of datacasting services must be seven megahertz. Provisions are introduced which allow regulations to require that, if datacasters and broadcasters provide viewers with reception equipment, that equipment must be accessible to other service providers. The amendments also require that technical standards relating to transmission, which deal with application program interfaces for datacasting, do so on the basis that these interfaces should be eligible for all datacasting service providers. There are also a number of other technical amendments and minor modifications; for example, to the objects of the BSA. The government has decided to accept the amendments made by the Senate to the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Digital Television and Datacasting) Bill 2000.

talk.start.para: —There are 137 amendments to the government's Broadcasting Services Amendment (Digital Television and Datacasting) Bill 2000 which have been effected by the Senate. Regrettably, some of the most important amendments proposed to the Senate, which would have established a workable framework and definition of datacasting, were rejected by the Senate at the urging of the government, so the main part of this piece of legislation is the establishment of a datacasting regime. Many of the amendments go to ameliorating the worst effects of the government's restrictive regime, and time will tell whether the restrictions which the government has imposed are so restrictive that we will not see a viable new datacasting industry emerging in this country.

speech.para: The second group of amendments goes to multichannelling for the ABC and SBS. I was pleased that from opposition I was able to effect 98.5 per cent of our policy to enable the ABC and SBS to multichannel. There are restrictions which the government, in its slavish devotion to content, program and genre distinctions, has required but, on the best advice of the ABC and the SBS, these enable the ABC and the SBS to effect whatever programs they currently have in mind for multichannelling. They are unable to multichannel generally in the content of sport, drama, national news and some other areas. They are, of course, able to effect these programs on their primary channels. This is a great day for the public national broadcasters, being the first of our terrestrial TV broadcasters to be authorised to, in digital format, multichannel. The review processes which have been effected by the Senate, most of those on the recommendation of the opposition, will see an orderly and early review across the range of this piece of legislation. Time will tell whether the experience and uptake of HDTV and SDTV will see the fulfilment of the framework legislation established by the parliament two years ago.

With 137 amendments in what are always, firstly, contentious public policy issues but also highly technical and detailed areas, it does require a big effort. Very many of the amendments in the end were done by agreement between the government, the opposition and the Democrats—after the government had been belted around with a baseball bat for a significant period of time to bring them to their senses, but that is by the by.

In a technical area such as this, the long parliamentary process was aided and assisted by the professional conduct not just of government officers, opposition officers and Democrat officers but also of the officers of relevant agencies and departments and officers from the various parts of the media and broadcasting industry, whether that be prospective datacasters, free-to-air commercial broadcasters, the subscription television industry or the national broadcasters. Whilst it had its moments as a parliamentary and legislative process, apart from the outcome, it was a delight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
