talk.start.para: —In speaking to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 this morning with 22½ hours to go to the new tax system for Australia, I would like to begin my address to the parliament tonight by responding to some of the matters raised by the first speaker to this bill, the member for Dobell. Some considerable time was spent talking about universities and, in particular, the university in Townsville-Thuringowa, James Cook University. There were a number of points made there. There were some suggestions that the former member for Herbert may be a better member in relation to delivering for James Cook University. I would acquaint the House with this: for some 25 years the university fraternity wanted a medical school at James Cook. The former Labor member kept promising a medical school for James Cook University. I am pleased to be able to take the credit for delivering a medical school for James Cook University when the former member was unable to do so. The member for Dobell should note that particular achievement.

speech.para: The member for Dobell indicated that this government had cost James Cook University some $16 million. The member for Dobell did not take into account the amount of money that this government has provided to allow the medical school at James Cook to proceed, to fund 60 places this year for the medical school, to fund the capital cost of the medical school—that is millions of dollars. Also, the member for Dobell did not take into account that at a time of James Cook's greatest need, when they needed an extra 450 places, it was me who delivered 450 extra places for James Cook at an annual recurrent cost of about $9 million. No other university in the Commonwealth of Australia received extra places. James Cook University did. When the member for Dobell was indicating that there may be some disquiet at James Cook, he was clearly unaware that while he was speaking the President of the Student Association of James Cook was listening to the debate in this parliament. I certainly saw no dissension from Mr Ryan Haddrick who was listening to the debate. I think that says volumes for the way that James Cook has been well looked after by this government.

I would like to discuss the importance of this bill for tertiary students and the wider institutions they attend. The bill is delivering on the government's promises. As stated in the past, the coalition government are very firmly committed to higher education in Australia. We will increase undergraduate places; we will encourage more autonomous, flexible and responsible universities; we will support the current HECS system; and we will maintain the current structure of tertiary education. University fees will not be deregulated and vouchers will not be introduced, despite the assertions of the member for Dobell. The current system of government subsidies and funded places will remain. There will be no additional loan system or real interest rate attached to the current HECS system. We certainly will explore ways of enhancing lifelong learning opportunities and we will focus on ensuring high-quality university teaching and world-class research. We will lay the foundations of future success in tertiary education by focusing on improving literacy in schools. The minister's literacy and numeracy program has been highly successful and will go on to be a success of that visionary program that Dr Kemp introduced into Australian schools.

The coalition government is committed to reaching these objectives. Budget 2000-01 outlined the government's commitment to providing an additional 100 new medical places each year. This initiative was warmly received at my university, James Cook, because it will see more practising doctors in rural and regional Australia. My home town of Townsville-Thuringowa will also reap the benefits of this initiative because the James Cook University will have a number of additional places for undergraduates for its medical school under the scholarship program. While it is expected that the 100 places might be divided equally among the medical schools in Australia, I would put to the parliament and to the minister that I think there is a special case for more students to go to James Cook. With the Northern Australian medical program and the linkages that are currently being proposed between James Cook University and the Northern Territory University, with the support of the minister, I think we can justify perhaps 20 of those 100 places going across Northern Australia, linked into the James Cook medical program and the NTU medical program. I will certainly be pushing very hard to see that. I know that those who understand why the government has put this particular program in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 will be strongly supportive of these extra places going to the James Cook University's medical school for the benefit of Northern Australia.

This initiative will improve medical services not only across the Top End but also in other regional areas. The coalition has answered the call from regional and rural Australia with a program that will ensure excellent medical attention to anyone who needs it, no matter where they might be in the Commonwealth. How is this possible? As an incentive under the scholarship program, students will be required to practice for at least six years in a rural or regional area after completion of postgraduate training. They will be required to contribute to society as a result of the government's contribution to them. Those with whom I have spoken are very supportive of the government's initiative in this regard.

Apart from this proactive commitment, the coalition government is committed to improving health services in other ways. This bill delivers part of the government's $562 million country health budget package, which is the largest effort by an Australian government to redress the historical imbalance between rural and city health. The bill will also provide additional funding of $62.8 million over three years for the Strategic Partnerships with Industry Research and Training Scheme from the year 2002. We are committed to maintaining funding levels for higher education. This year universities will receive over $5.7 billion from the government. We will continue to help universities help themselves—and that is an important point. There will be an additional $16.3 million for the Research Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities Scheme. That is also pretty good news for James Cook University. This university has a world-leading marine science facility and a facility in geology, or earth science as it is called these days, which is arguably as good as anything in the world. In addition, in Townsville James Cook has the best standards lab in Australia. This particular research funding will certainly support the Australian scientists and geologists at a world-class level.

I am also pleased to be able to report tonight that this week I have had Professor Bill Lavery here in Canberra. He is the new Professor of Information Technology at James Cook University. He and I have been working on a project to attempt to secure some support for James Cook, which currently has a very significant problem in relation to its restricted access to the outside world via the Internet. Currently the AARNeT facility—the Australian Academic Research Network—which was the basis of the Internet in Australia when it first established, has its points of presence only in the capital cities of this country. That means that capital city universities are able to connect to the Internet at extraordinarily high speeds. They are able to connect at speeds of 155 megabytes per second. Currently James Cook's connection to the outside world is two megabytes per second. By 9 o'clock in the morning that pipeline to the Internet is chock-a-block with data—overloaded. Professor Lavery and I are moving heaven and earth looking for government support to try to get that particular blockage unblocked. I am determined that, one way or another, we will find a way to make sure that James Cook is not inhibited. We can help not only the Townsville campus but also the Cairns campus and the Mackay campus at the same time. I have given a very strong commitment to the university that I will do whatever I can to assist in that process.

The previous Labor government locked tens of thousands of qualified students out of university by funding only government-set enrolment targets. Labor discriminated against Australian students by denying them the right to pay fees and to do their course of first choice—a right Labor gave to foreign students, puzzlingly enough. Labor's HECS scheme was unfair because students in courses with lower income prospects or lower costs paid the same amount as those in courses with higher income prospects or higher costs. The coalition government has increased access to universities for young people. In 1999 university enrolments reached a record high under coalition policies, with 45,166 more students in 1999 than in Labor's last year in government—an eight per cent increase.

Universities can offer fee paying places to undergraduates, so the capable students who would otherwise miss out can now enrol in their course of first choice. There was some deep suspicion about that particular policy, but the reason for the suspicion never materialised: there have not been situations where you get this so-called fees for degrees. Universities that I know have maintained their standards, and I think it has been a great outcome. Certainly at James Cook University there is every will to try to attract as many full fee paying students as possible but also maintain its standards and take on the non-full fee paying students. The unmet demand for university places has certainly been slashed under coalition policies, and that is very welcome.

We offer graduates voluntary tests so that employers, universities and students can have a common assessment of student liabilities. We are pursuing a strategy of increasing total university resources by encouraging private funding of universities. With respect to a faculty that I am aware of—the science faculty at James Cook—a good proportion of its income comes from outside sources, from the private sector. I am certainly pleased and proud to be able to say that my son is an honours graduate from that particular faculty. He is currently doing a PhD from that faculty over in Canada. I am certainly very proud of him. His involvement with the university allows me an insight into the first-class quality teaching available at that particular faculty, and the dedication of the staff in providing that first-class academic environment is to be warmly applauded.

The strategy of increasing university resources with access to the private sector gives universities access to larger amounts of revenue and increases their independence. That is an interesting point: it increases their independence. In James Cook's case, that has been very good. The total annual income is up $900 million since 1995, Labor's last full year. Also, the Australian Awards for University Teaching have helped give greater status to university teaching. We have implemented a new policy and funding framework for university research which will help to keep our best and brightest Australian researchers, and their ideas, in Australia. Total research funding for higher education is up from $399 million in the last year of Labor to $447 million in 1999. That is not a bad increase.

Finally, the number of university students from overseas continues to increase, despite economic difficulties in some of our key markets. It is interesting that the greatest number of students from the United States—you would probably know that I would want to tell you—are at James Cook University. That is because of the very great interest in tropical marine science, in which we lead the world. Of course, it helps to have the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Australian Institute of Marine Science co-located in Townsville, so we are currently building a centre of excellence, in this country and in the world, in tropical marine science in Townsville. All in all, it is an outstanding show of support for tertiary students and for the higher education sector in general.
It has been my privilege to support this bill tonight—or this morning. I think this may be the latest time that I have spoken in the Australian parliament.

talk.start.para: —Don't make it worse.
—Thank you, Member for Werriwa. I am certainly looking forward to 22 hours from now, when we see the introduction of the new tax system for Australia. I will be very proud to see that.

—The member for Herbert obviously gets his kicks in funny ways if he is hanging out for events in 22 hours time. I had prepared copious notes on the inadequacy of higher education policy in general terms. I had planned to address issues on both sides of the chamber, but something more important has come up.

speech.para: I am going to take my lead in this debate from the member for Moreton. He gave one of the finest speeches in this place on higher education in an earlier debate when he addressed the problems with the teaching of journalism in Australia's universities. It was a fine speech, and I am pleased to follow in his footsteps. The member for Moreton, Mr Hardgrave, used examples to make his point, and I want to do the same.

Too few journalists are taught the benefits of diligence and thoroughness. This is a problem in our universities and in the teaching of journalism in higher education in this country. Of course, there are some exceptions to this rule. I think most honourable members would agree when I point to the diligent and thorough reporting of the likes of Michelle Grattan and Malcolm Farr, in our very own press gallery—regrettably, almost unexplainably empty at this hour. They check their facts until they drop and, as practising politicians, we welcome this.

Unfortunately, there are plenty of examples of how not to undertake journalism and plenty of examples of the problems with the teaching of journalism in higher education. To make this point, we just need to look at the recent example of the reporting of events in this parliament. I refer, of course, to the disorderly conduct which followed question time on Wednesday of last week. In the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday of this week, Gerard Henderson, who is well known to people in the chamber—particularly the Minister for Employment Services—reported on this particular incident and made two terrible mistakes. The first was that he said that the employment minister was suspended from the House because of his `sanctimonious windbag' expletive.

In fact, the minister was suspended from the House not because of any accusation levelled against the Leader of the Opposition but because of his decision to turn and move in a rather menacing fashion towards the opposition benches. Gerard Henderson has got it wrong. He is too lazy to check the Hansard, which clearly makes this point. He is too lazy to report on these matters first hand and too lazy to know what is going on in the national parliament.

His second error relates to my good self. He makes the claim that I made a speech in the adjournment debate last Thursday. I did no such thing. I made my contribution regarding journalists' ethics the previous night in the Wednesday adjournment debate—again an instance of Gerard Henderson being too lazy to check the Hansard, too lazy to check his facts and too lazy to know what is going on in the national parliament. For a pedant, he sure makes a lot of errors. For someone who prides himself on picking other people apart, he sure makes a lot of errors. One would normally expect, when it comes to reporting on the Minister for Employment Services, that a Santamaria protege would be accurate in reporting the actions of another Santa protege. Unhappily, Santa's little helpers are no longer helping each other. This highlights the problem in higher education in this country in the teaching of journalism. The member for Moreton has made this point.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Far be it from me to interrupt the flow of the member for Werriwa's rhetoric, but I think it is important that we debate the bill, and the bill has very little to do with journalistic standards.

(Mr Nehl)—I thank the minister. I have been listening very carefully to the contribution from the honourable member for Werriwa. He has been talking about the need for improvements in higher education in the teaching of journalism and he is illustrating his case with examples. There is no point of order.

—I am pleased to move in the footsteps of the honourable member for Moreton who on numerous occasions has made the same point on higher education legislation. We need to lift the standards of journalism and the best way to do that is to improve the teaching of journalism in Australian higher education.

speech.para: There is more than one Henderson in the journalistic game. There is also Anne Henderson. It raises the question of what it is about the Henderson family that produces so many basic errors of fact. Some time ago, I reviewed Anne Henderson's book Getting Even. I have the book here. I must say I am tempted to echo the words of my former colleague Ros Kelly: the only thing I can endorse about this book is the cover. It has nice photographs on it of the members for Lindsay, Dickson and Gellibrand and also Senator Stott Despoja. The only thing I can endorse is the cover of that book. I certainly cannot endorse the number of errors. I found 30 errors in the book, once Anne Henderson challenged me to take up further research about these problems. Mistakes were made with respect to the female franchise in Australia, the number of women who stood at the 1903 election, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, the New Zealand Labour Party, Margo Kingston, the electoral margin in Dickson, the 1975 coup d'etat, a number of members in the New South Wales parliament—it just goes on and on and on. So many errors have been made. There is even an error relating to an interview with our good friend Christopher Pearson, well known to members in this place. There were so many errors—30 in total. That is a remarkable and, indeed, shameful error-prone book produced by Anne Henderson. It is very hard to understand how these pedants are so error prone in their own work. It reinforces the point, made so well by the member for Moreton in previous debates, that we need to lift the standard of the teaching of journalism in Australian universities.
I notice that this particular problem regarding events in the chamber last Wednesday extended to that normally reliable journal the Sydney Daily Telegraph. Piers Akerman made the point:

quote.para: Mr Abbott was tossed out after he called Mr Beazley a sanctimonious windbag.

speech.para: Again, that is a straight error of fact, and anyone going to check the Hansard record would see that. The problem is that Mr Akerman has been too lazy to check the Hansard, too lazy to report on parliament first-hand and too lazy to go to the facts to get a proper understanding of what has happened in the national parliament. The truth was that the minister was suspended for other reasons. It had nothing to do with his accusation on the Leader of the Opposition. Mr Akerman then went on to point out that I levelled some remarks at different journalists in the adjournment debate last week. He writes:

quote.para: It was just the sort of parliamentary behaviour that he—

speech.para: meaning me—

quote.para: had become so critical of by the end of the week.

speech.para: In fact, I was not critical of that sort of parliamentary behaviour. My criticism was of parliamentary behaviour that was outside the standing orders. My contribution in the adjournment debate on Wednesday last week used language that was within the standing orders. In fact, the Speaker, who was in the chair, saw no breach of parliamentary standing orders and certainly no need to take any action. Again, that was a basic error of fact by Mr Akerman. Again, he was too lazy to check the Hansard, too lazy to find out what was going on in the national parliament and too lazy to lift the standard of journalism in this country. I make the point made consistently by the member for Moreton.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. You have extended a fair degree of tolerance to the member for Werriwa, but his remarks have nothing to do with the bill before the House. He is really guilty of being a sanctimonious humbug, frankly. I think he should be called back to the subject of the debate.
(Mr Nehl)—I thank the minister. In calling the member for Werriwa, I am sure he will be speaking about the content of the bill in great detail.

—According to Mr Akerman and Mr Henderson, the minister would be thrown out for such language. That was the error in their initial report. The fact that no action has been taken against the minister just confirms the nature of their mistake. As the member for Moreton has suggested, this House should diligently monitor the standards of the Australian media. This is an important issue in the public interest. On this legislation, we do need to lift the standard of teaching of journalism in Australia's universities.

speech.para: I have noted with interest the extensive commentary and strongly held views of Laurie Oakes regarding the disorderly behaviour which followed question time on Wednesday last week. What Mr Oakes's viewers and readers should appreciate is that he was not present for this incident. He was not in the press gallery above the chamber and therefore did not witness the full scale and series of events. In fact, in my 6½ years in this place, I have never seen Mr Oakes in the press gallery above the chamber. He is the Norm of Australian politics: he never watches in person, only on television. He is too lazy to lift up his lard and walk to the other side of the parliamentary building. The Packer organisation's chief political reporter has no appreciation of the House of Representatives first-hand.

This again makes the point that in Australia's universities journalists should be taught to be more diligent and more thorough and to lift themselves up and report on matters first-hand. This is a basic standard. I know the member for Moreton has expressed the concern on a number of occasions that this standard has not been met in the universities. Indeed, laziness is the weeping sore of Australian journalism. I have pointed to several instances of this laziness tonight. I have mentioned Laurie Oakes, Piers Akerman, Gerard Henderson and Anne Henderson, and last week I had cause to draw the House's attention to the laziness of Jack Waterford in his appalling column on Greg Wilton in the Canberra Times last Saturday week. This is an appalling standard in the Australian media. Journalists think that they have made it in their profession when they no longer have to do research first-hand or report on the parliament first-hand. It is a problem that should be corrected by the way in which journalism is taught in our universities. I can only endorse the way in which the member for Moreton has consistently raised this matter in higher education bills.

Of course, this House cannot legislate against laziness, but it should be willing to enact privacy legislation to guard against the wilful slurs and errors which arise from lazy journalism. I could give other examples, as the member for Moreton has in the past. But I think on that one incident last week, which was a very high profile incident in the press—the suspension of the Minister for Employment Services and the subsequent reporting—I have proved that journalistic standards leave a lot to be desired in this country. Some very senior people do not go to the trouble of checking the Hansard, checking the facts and understanding what actually went on. The minister was not suspended for anything he said to the Leader of the Opposition; he was suspended for moving towards the opposition benches in a menacing fashion. I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on the action you took. I wish your efficiency in these things were reflected in the efficiency of the Australian media and journalistic reporting. I wish it were reflected in the efficiency and standards of the teaching of journalism in Australia's universities.

In my remaining remarks I would like to join with the member for Dobell in levelling criticism against the government for its higher education funding cuts. This is causing enormous distress and loss of services at the University of Western Sydney, which serves my own electorate. The government should be condemned for its cost cutting to higher education at a time when throughout the Western world nations are investing more in higher education. The University of Western Sydney has had cost pressures placed on it and, to its great credit, it has responded in a sensible fashion. It has decided it can no longer afford its federated structure. Under the leadership of Vice-Chancellor Jan Reid it is moving to a unitary structure. This has been forced on it by the federal government. There is a massive reorganisation of the university under way. While this would not necessarily have happened in different financial circumstances, the fact that that reorganisation is moving forward under sensible planning and sensible leadership is indeed a credit to the Vice-Chancellor, Jan Reid.

So I support under these difficult circumstances the decision to move from a federated to a unitary structure at the University of Western Sydney. I support the vision of the university leadership in trying to apply as much of their work as possible to regional development issues, to equity issues, to trying to lift students from disadvantaged suburbs into higher education. That university now has the leadership and direction it needs to achieve each of those goals.

One of the most exciting aspects of the university's development is the establishment of the Whitlam Institute. This is something that I raised some time ago with Minister David Kemp, but he did nothing about it. In this country we should replicate more the American practice of establishing, in their case presidential, in our case prime ministerial, libraries. Gough Whitlam has generously decided to donate his papers and prime ministerial material to the University of Western Sydney. The university of course covers the great arc of electorates and areas that Gough represented in his 26 years in the House of Representatives, right through from the Sutherland region to Campbelltown and then north to Toongabbie and Blacktown.

So the catchment of the University of Western Sydney broadly takes in the catchment of the seat of Werriwa through the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. It is so appropriate that Mr Whitlam would decide to donate his papers to the University of Western Sydney and they responded with the establishment of the Whitlam Institute and, we hope, the forthcoming Whitlam prime ministerial library to be located in the Parramatta district. There has been a fundraising committee established. Researchers have been notified. I believe that the institute will find an excellent focus on urban and regional issues, on welfare issues, on the whole question of new geographies in the labour market. The whole issue of urban policy—which is one of Gough's great legacies, of course—will find new expression and new relevance in the work of the Whitlam Institute under the coverage of the University of Western Sydney.

As someone who has been fortunate enough to have followed Mr Whitlam into the seat of Werriwa, I have been very delighted indeed to be part of the organisation and urging for the Whitlam Institute. I look forward to an ongoing role with that fine body. In particular, I would like to see it, along with other research groups in the university, develop Australia's leading expertise in urban and regional policy. I understand that recently the Australian National University has downgraded its urban policy unit. It is not going to give so much priority to that research area. So there is a gap in our national research framework, and that would be ideally filled by the University of Western Sydney. The region has experienced enormous population growth, enormous urban and planning issues in recent decades. It really is an excellent laboratory for this sort of higher education research. The fact that this can be conducted under the coverage of the Whitlam Institute, remembering the great legacy in this policy area of Gough Whitlam, is something that is very good for the region indeed.

These things are happening despite the government's funding cuts. Some universities, particularly the one which serves my electorate, are finding innovative ways to of doing better with less. But the point is, of course, that they could do so much more work if they had more resources from the federal government. This is not an area where our universities should be expected to do more with less. They really do need an increase in federal government resources so they can fully fund their research institutes, so they can increase their student numbers and so they can increase their tertiary participation rates from disadvantaged suburbs. The fact that these things are not happening is a shame on the nation, and in particular a shame on this government.

The government has, indeed, a strange set of priorities when a member such as the member for Herbert can say in his concluding remarks on a higher education bill that he looks forward to a new indirect tax coming into place in 22 hours time. Would it not be great if members could stand up in this place and say quite truthfully that they look forward to Australia having the best higher education sector, the best universities in the world, the best research, the best undergraduate teaching and the best student participation? Shamefully, we cannot say those things in this parliament because the government has the wrong set of priorities. The only thing members opposite can say is that they look forward to this French socialist 1960s tax coming into place in 22 hours. What we should be talking about is Australian higher education excellence coming into place for the coming century. It is a bad set of priorities indeed on the part of the government and one which, according to every indicator, goes against it in the public sphere. One hopes that when elections are called in 15 months time the Australian people will punish the government severely for this inappropriate set of priorities.

talk.start.para: —I will say right from the outset that I look forward to Australia's tertiary institutions leading the world. A little later in my speech tonight I will actually outline a tertiary institution that is, in fact, one of the leaders, if not the leader, in the world. So I do not accept the member for Werriwa's comments. I do aspire to the same thing that he aspires to, as all Australians do: we aspire for Australian institutions and Australian students to be the best. But Labor keeps peddling this story that the coalition government has cut funding. Mr Speaker, you know as I do that, in fact, funding increased in real terms between 1996 and 1999, and it will increase further in the period 1999 to 2002. As well as that, funding per fully funded student place has also increased since 1996. We can spend a lot of time being distracted, and for a person who claims to be so committed to tertiary education and the promotion of it, the member for Werriwa spent very little time on that subject. I thought you, Mr Speaker, and the Deputy Speaker before you, were extraordinarily lenient to the member for Werriwa in terms of relevance.

speech.para: The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 is about increasing the number of doctors in regional Australia. Regional Australia is a passion of mine—I am not ashamed of that. It is an area in which I grew up. We aim through this bill to deliver 100 new medical places, beginning in 2001, for students holding bonded scholarships. It is part, of course, of a $562 million country health project—a fantastic allocation in this year's budget, an allocation which is unprecedented and builds on the $200 million provided two years ago. It is part of one of the biggest, if not the biggest, rural packages ever handed down in a budget by any government—a $1.8 billion allocation to regional and rural Australia across a number of areas but, as we are discussing tonight, most poignantly in the areas of regional health and regional provision of doctors. This allocation is aimed at improving the level of tertiary education. When we combine that with the issues relating to regional Australia, the government is rightly proud of its initiatives to assist communities in rural, regional and remote Australia to turn around what has been a challenging, even dark, period in their economic and social history.

This government has been ably assisted by the rise in strong leadership from within those communities—leaders who have identified the needs of their communities; in typical bush spirit, harnessed the spirits of those communities; and, through innovation and dogged willpower, sought a new and better future. Those leaders will include our regional universities. Most city based Australians would be surprised at the expertise, capabilities and innovation of universities outside the metropolitan areas. These universities are often the largest employers in the region and in my electorate of Groom and in my city of Toowoomba they are far and away the biggest employer, employing some 1,200 people in full-time positions. These universities inject tens of millions of dollars into regional towns, educate and train people to serve the bush and are treasuries of national and international leadership in scholarship, research, development and in the productivity alliances of government and industry.

This leadership is no better demonstrated—and I am not biased at all—than in the electorate of Groom and in the city of Toowoomba. Like so many regionally based universities, the University of Southern Queensland has risen from humble beginnings—it used to go under a completely different name, the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education—some 30 years ago to not only be a leader in regional Queensland but also be a national and international leader in exporting education to the world and in the field of distance education. This is the university in Australia that is expanding our concept of e-commerce. We are familiar with e-retailing, e-share trading and e-banking and we can add e-education, a vital but overlooked e-commerce component being pioneered in Toowoomba. This is not a revolution; this is an `e-volution'. This university has the rest of the world paying attention to its ability to take education and training to where people live and work throughout Australia and right around the globe. It is a pathfinding new way of enabling people to learn in their own time, in their own place and in their own style, without requiring people, especially in the bush, to disrupt their lives, leave their families and go to brick and mortar universities—or perhaps, should I say, the sandstone universities of the big cities.

USQ is the future—I have seen it and I know it works. I will explain it in a little more detail. The defining characteristic of the University of Southern Queensland is that, of its 19,000 students, nearly 75 per cent do not occupy the campus. They study where they live. Through its innovative distance education program, including through the Internet, USQ—as it is affectionately known—comes to students. Most of them are mature age people working in metropolitan, regional and rural Australia and wanting professional development and workplace upgrades without disrupting their families, their lives and their lifestyle. Last year, this university was awarded not one but two prestigious international prizes of excellence for being the world's best dual-mode university. This means that it was the world's best at providing people with flexible alternatives to having to go on campus to study. Mind you, USQ also provides quality on-campus education. These awards were made by the International Council for Open and Distance Education, a peak body representing distance education providers from 130 countries worldwide and backed by UNESCO.

While talking about awards, I should also mention that the university is a national export winner. Surprising everyone, including the New South Wales Premier, Bob Carr—and he has had a few surprises lately—USQ Vice Chancellor, Professor Peter Swannell, arrived in Sydney last October to claim two prizes at the national multicultural marketing awards organised by the New South Wales Ethnic Affairs Commission. The awards were in recognition of this regional university's ability to provide a world-class university experience to people from a variety of cultural backgrounds. Remember: this is a regional university from Toowoomba that was rated the best in the world and the best in Australia for its commitment to serving people from all cultural backgrounds. Necessity is, as they say, the mother of invention and, faced with competition from bigger metropolitan universities, 25 years ago USQ developed its niche strength as a provider of distance education. Now it services thousands of students in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Canberra and beyond and has one of the largest enrolments of students studying offshore of any Australian university.

Like the rural and regional communities it serves, USQ turned to self-reliance born of a commitment to exporting, innovation and entrepreneurialism to safeguard its economic future. Twenty-five years later, the time of USQ has definitely arrived. Governments around Australia should take notice of how this university operates and serves the community. We are looking for better ways to grow our regional and rural communities. I suggest USQ provides a model that works and can be applied across Australia. It provides flexibility to communities where the pursuit of quality education, lifelong learning, strong family life, hard work and ambition are priorities.

As a university which comes to the people, USQ has developed a multimillion dollar infrastructure to deliver education on campus, by post and over the Internet. Students receive study guides and other printed material, CD-ROMs and audio tapes, which are supported by an extensive network of liaison officers. These are people who live throughout the regions and metropolitan areas and who provide practical support to distance students. In this model, students can attend live lectures and tutorials in a study centre or by video and phone conferencing. The USQ campus at Wide Bay provides a dramatic example of how the latest technology can be utilised to take education to the people where they live and work. Speaking of technology, the University of Southern Queensland has taken up the challenges and opportunities posed by the revolution in telecommunications. As Senator Alston can attest to, as a result of his visit to USQ this year, being regional can be a distinct advantage in exploiting the benefits of new technology. If ever there were an example of why Australia must continue to pursue telecommunications reform, the University of Southern Queensland is it.

USQOnline is the university's program of undergraduate and postgraduate courses delivered wholly over the Internet. Students around the world enrol, study, access reading material and communicate with their lecturers and fellow students—all on the Net. Global online education is estimated to grow to $US6 billion in the next few years. Australia, through the successes of programs such as USQOnline, currently has a market advantage. We are a world leader in this field. Wasn't that what the member for Werriwa was asking? However, the rest of the world is catching up, and I have been informed that, over the next few years, it is possible that prestigious universities in Europe and the USA will compete online with Australian universities for students in all countries, including those in Australia and particularly those in regional Australia.

Australia must nurture its export strengths in distance and online university education. We must also advance our leadership in online workplace and professional development. This has immense potential for our regional communities and as an export earner. Through its business arm, INDELTA, the University of Southern Queensland partners private and public bodies in the online delivery of training courses to the workplace. Recently, I read in the Sydney Morning Herald—I do not often read that paper—that INDELTA had been engaged by the global finance and insurance company Zurich to provide online professional training to the company's financial advisers throughout Australasia to upgrade their professional qualifications. Regional and rural business operators are also getting their first e-commerce experience through INDELTA. A system of e-commerce portals acts as an incubator for individual small businesses to join together and test the waters of the e-commerce ocean. In the not too distant future, many a regionally based commercially successful performer will look back on this as the beginning of their global e-commerce business empire.

USQ is a university poised to take advantage of the next wave of communication technology—the provision and export of learning opportunities through digital television and datacasting—and excellent legislation was carried today by the government. I could go on further about USQ's regional and rural focus: its niche research and development record of linking with industry to develop practical outcomes; a reputation for professional agricultural engineering; its record of educating and training students to live and work in regional and rural Australia; its work in educating remotely located Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders; and, its commitment to providing practical support to people from a variety of disadvantaged backgrounds who have not studied, are disabled, or who need writing and language skills, aimed at enabling them to pursue university education and realise the ambitions and new directions.

I will close on another example of USQ's commitment to technological innovation, and its commercial entrepreneurialism. The two are connected. In the search for new space age materials, fibre composites have been identified as having great potential. Their qualities of strength and lightness are already used in boat and aircraft building and sporting equipment. I am sure people have used a tennis racquet containing carbon fibre. USQ is using fibre composites to build bridges to the future, literally. Professor Gerard Van Erp leads USQ's fibre composites program and has been very successful in attracting industry support for his research and development of fibre composites for the engineering and construction sectors. Australia, through the University of Southern Queensland—and where is the member for Werriwa?—is acknowledged as a world leader and innovator in this field. Just as steel and concrete revolutionised the construction industry, so fibre composites will take the industry to a new level of sophistication. Bridges, pathways, trucks, construction girders, railway sleepers, even indoor ski slopes can be made stronger and lighter than with conventional materials.

The days have gone when universities can depend on the public purse to totally fund their operations and, contrary to what the member for Werriwa says, they accept that challenge. They understand the responsibility they have to find extra sources of funding. In the interests of developing a self-reliant university sector, our government has encouraged universities to become innovative, to develop industry and community links, and to explore exporting opportunities in order to supplement government income. USQ, of course—and I am still not biased—is a success story in this area and points the way to a successful future. It should be noted that the university is the lowest publicly funded university in Australia and has been put into this position by what I believe to be an unsatisfactory and disadvantaging policy by successive past governments. In fact, this university should be rewarded with a revised funding model that rewards universities which are commercially entrepreneurial—such as USQ—with regional funding and special regional headquartering.

I have mentioned USQOnline. This program is delivered through global web infrastructure developed by the company NextEd Ltd. This company comprises international venture capitalists who came to the University of Southern Queensland because they identified it as the best in its field—hear those words, member for Werriwa. USQ, through INDELTA, is a financial partner in NextEd and aims to commercially profit from the company's expertise in putting the course programs of education providers around the world, including other universities, online.

USQ was the first Australian university to establish a campus in Europe, in partnership with its communities, and last year the USQ European Studies Centre in the German city of Bretten was opened. This followed an approach from the Bretten City Council. It is no wonder that the Australian government has chosen the profile of USQ, and specifically USQOnline, to display at the Australian pavilion in Expo 2000 in Hanover. I had the pleasure of unveiling a poster which is displayed there. USQ is the only Australian university on display at Expo 2000. I am sure this House will congratulate USQ on its many successes.

I have often spoken to Vice-Chancellor Professor Swannell who, I must say, is one of the world's most forward thinking and best communicators in the Australian university sector. His proposals for a new funding model for our universities is certainly food for thought for all members. Professor Swannell is urging the Commonwealth to look even harder at rewarding quality, self-sufficient and efficient universities which undertake entrepreneurial activities with a view to generating private income. According to the vice-chancellor, this would come in the form of seed funding for innovative income-generating projects. Practical support of this sort would, in turn, enable universities such as USQ to invest in additional innovation and would result in even less reliance on the public purse. What better example is there of a university being innovative, a leader, internationally competitive and at the forefront of international teaching than the University of Southern Queensland? This is the sort of university that this legislation hopes to promote and I commend it to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 I rise to support the amendment moved by the shadow minister, the member for Dobell. The purpose of the bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 in a number of ways: to adjust grants for funding year 2001 for price movements, to set the maximum grants available for funding for the year 2002, to vary the maxima for operating grants for the years 1999 and 2001 to reflect revised estimates for the Higher Education Contribution Scheme, and to provide additional funding for measures announced in the 2000-01 budget concerning research programs and university places for students on bonded medical scholarships. The debate on higher education funding is an excellent opportunity to examine the record of this government and this minister. If a report card was being issued, this minister would surely receive an F and the government as a whole, at best, a D minus. The report card of the minister, Dr Kemp, would make very interesting reading, I am sure. Next to maths would be the comment `Has some trouble with basic arithmetic' and, in the general section, `Cannot or will not play with other children. Needs to learn to share.'

speech.para: I begin by asking a philosophical question. Why do democracies exist? How do they come about and to achieve what purpose? One of the main reasons the general population wanted a say in how their state was governed, the main reason that people took control of government—and sometimes by force—was because they wanted their children to receive an education. Prior to democracies existing, education was the provision of the rich, the nobility—those who could afford to pay. Illiteracy amongst the general population was extremely high. There was no such thing as a public school, despite the title being used in England. People took control of government in order to be able to provide a decent, funded public education system. This is something that has been fought for for centuries. Public education is a basic tenet of democracy. It is why democracies exist. Without it, democracies die. Indeed, the minister in his second reading speech said as much when he stated:

quote.para: A strong university system is essential to providing Australians with the skills and knowledge required to build a prosperous, democratic society.

speech.para: My question to the minister is: why are you cutting funding to the university system? How can you make a strong system if you are reducing the funding available? Without public funding, our universities become, and indeed are, small, elitist institutions where the average Australians could never think of going and only those with a capacity to pay could be part of the system. This is why the bills that concern education funding are vitally important. They are basic to our way of life and our system of government.

Higher education grants are legislated for calendar years within a rolling triennium framework. There are many different types of grants available, though the biggest slice by far is the operating grants for higher education institutions. There are two sources of funding for these operating grants. The first is the Commonwealth government and the second is the students themselves. The main way a student can pay his or her share is through the HECS system, either upfront or later on through a levy on their fortnightly pay packet. Of course, if you are rich enough and do not have the marks to qualify for university through the normal channels, you can simply buy your way in. In other words, rich kids get two bites of the cherry: if they do not get there on their merits, they get there on their money, thus creating an inequality of opportunity.

As parliamentarians, we often rely on the Bills Digest, prepared in an unbiased way by the Parliamentary Library to inform us of the details of each piece of legislation. I would like to thank the Parliamentary Library for providing me with the draft of the Bills Digest for this piece of legislation early this week. The library put in a great effort to produce this digest in the way that it did. This bill was introduced to the House last Wednesday, 21 June, and we are expected to debate it today. This government has operated with unseemly haste this past fortnight, with legislation being introduced one day and debated the next. As it is now past 2.30 a.m., I seek leave to continue my remarks when we return.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

para.inline: House adjourned at 2.32 a.m. (Friday) until Monday, 14 August 2000, at 12.30 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —A few short weeks ago the member for Ballarat was on his feet in the adjournment debate singing the virtues of the Ballarat AFL side which claimed a victory over the Bendigo side. I am delighted to say that last Saturday the tide turned. I use the word `tide' very loosely. In fact, the Bendigo Football League gave the Ballarat team a sound thrashing, and it was well deserved.

speech.para: This is probably one of the explanations for the look of absolute bewilderment and astonishment on the face of the member for Ballarat. The other explanation is that the game was contested in probably the most appalling weather conditions you could imagine for the Ballarat side. It was actually a fine, sunny day. That made it very difficult. Of course, this caught the Ballarat team completely off guard. They are used to playing and training in Ballarat by splashing about in that swamp over there that they call the city oval. Could you imagine trying to play football in Lake Burley Griffin or, worse, maybe even in Lake Wendouree? That is what it is like trying to play football in Ballarat. In fact, it is rumoured that Ballarat footballers develop webfeet early in their careers. Obviously, they were at a distinct disadvantage in the freak conditions that prevailed on that particular day.

I am delighted to inform the House of that magnificent victory. I congratulate the Bendigo team and, in particular, Mr John Walsh, the league chairman, and my good friend the team coach, Mr Neville Massina, as well as all the players and officials for what was a great victory. I am delighted we turned the tables on our archenemies, Ballarat. Bendigo is always the premier city. I know the honourable member for Ballarat will be in this place very shortly to try and refute that argument, but I do not think it is possible for him to do that. I congratulate the team. It has really put the Bendigo side on the map. I think Bendigo will only go on in leaps and bounds. Every time we meet in the city of Ballarat, provided those freak weather conditions of a nice fine sunny day prevail, the Bendigo team will always triumph. When the Ballarat squad comes over to Bendigo and enjoys the Bendigo weather of bright sunny days, which is normal for Bendigo, we will beat them again. I congratulate the team and thank them very much.

subdebateinfo.title: New England Electorate: Award for Community and Business Partnerships

talk.start.para: —I rise today to congratulate the New England Institute of TAFE, based in Tamworth in my electorate, and its partner the Toomelah Cooperative Ltd for winning the Prime Minister's Award for Excellence in Community and Business Partnerships 2000 on Monday night. This award recognises and showcases examples of leadership in business and community connections that provide solutions to those in need and ensures the social and cultural vitality of the Australian community. This recognises that the two groups have coupled the energy and creativity of community organisations with the expertise and innovation of the business sector to achieve mutual goals. The Prime Minister's Awards for Excellence in Community and Business Partnerships are an integral part of the Howard-Anderson government's commitment to supporting community and business organisations working in partnership for the benefit of the Australian community.

speech.para: The Euraba paper mill at Boggabilla in north-west New South Wales—which is in the electorate of Gwydir, the electorate of the Hon. John Anderson, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services, and which is adjacent to my electorate—commenced commercial production in May 1999. Established under the guidance of production manager Karen Backus and Boggabilla TAFE arts and media teacher Paul West, and with financial assistance provided by the Toomelah Cooperative, the mill employs nine senior Gamilaraay women to produce unique handmade Australian paper from waste cotton rags and other natural fibres for both national and international markets. After only one year, the project has already proved commercially successful, with orders from a range of corporations. The project aims to provide a sustainable alternative to generational welfare dependence and also to provide employment, training and technical expertise and opportunities as well as to promote tourism and reconciliation.

Through his involvement in the project, Paul West has been awarded a Churchill Fellowship to investigate indigenous paper making enterprises in Egypt and Ecuador and their relationships to Western training and marketing facilities in the UK and North America. The information gained and networks developed will be used to benefit the paper mill.

This was a great effort to win this award. I would like to encourage more joint ventures between business and community groups throughout regional and rural Australia and, in particular, within my electorate of New England. This partnership has shown great initiative to develop such a strong success in such a short period of time. I would like to once again congratulate the New England Institute of TAFE and the Toomelah Cooperative Ltd for winning the Prime Minister's Award for Excellence in Community and Business Partnerships 2000.

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Member for McMillan

talk.start.para: —I would like to make a statement in relation to my being misrepresented. I sought leave yesterday to make some remarks but I am very keen to get them into the record, so I will use this opportunity.

speech.para: In a media release dated 30 June—which, as I said yesterday, is amazing considering that today is 29 June—the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Liberal Senator Judith Troeth, said the following in relation to lifetime health cover:

quote.para: I note that the member for McMillan, Christian Zahra, has recognised the benefit of the Government's policies and taken the opportunity to join a private health fund. I would encourage all Gippsland residents considering taking out private health insurance to follow Mr Zahra's lead and take advantage of the extended cut off date for Lifetime health cover.

speech.para: The statement implies that I have recently taken out private health insurance in response to the government's policies and the taxpayer funded advertising campaign they have run in relation to this issue. This is not true and I can demonstrate this easily.

Firstly, my statement to the Registrar of Members Interests records publicly that I took out private health insurance last year, whereas the government's `Run for Cover' advertisements started only in April this year. Secondly—and anyone who can read, watch television or listen to the radio could have told Senator Troeth this—because I am 27 years old, I do not have to make a decision in relation to taking up lifetime health cover until I am 31. This makes a mockery of Senator Troeth's suggestion that I have somehow sought to benefit from the government's lifetime health cover policies.

My family and I have long been associated with the Yallourn Medical and Hospital Society, which is a community-run, not-for-profit health fund that has operated in the Latrobe Valley for more than 70 years. Last year I joined Yallourn Medical not because of the government's ham-fisted, bullying advertising campaign but because I wanted to show my support for a widely respected, not-for-profit health group which does good work in my electorate.

I have spoken to the CEO of Yallourn Medical and he has told me that he is aghast that information relating to my support for his health fund has been used to score cheap political points. Maybe next time Senator Troeth will get someone with two or more brain cells to explain to her her own government's policy before she issues public statements impugning my reputation and attributing motives to my actions which are demonstrably untrue. Senator Troeth should be ashamed of herself.

talk.start.para: —It is always a pleasure to follow the member for Personal Explanations, who spends most of his time talking about himself rather than his electorate of McMillan. Today I would also like to talk about the member for Bendigo. Bendigo had a lucky win last weekend—and I do acknowledge that and congratulate them. What they have not done, though, is scoop the pool at the Victorian Tourism Awards, basically because people go to Bendigo only if they are lost, then they move on very, very quickly.

speech.para: I would like to congratulate a number of my constituents who did win awards at the 16th annual Victorian Tourism Awards. The Ballarat Wildlife Park was a very big winner in winning the regional attractions award, and I congratulate Greg Parker, managing director of the park. Montrose Historic Cottage and Eureka Museum won the heritage and cultural tourism award for the second year in a row. Last year they went on to win the national, which was very good. Indeed, Laurel Johnson, a good mate of mine, said:

quote.para: We are chuffed. It is absolutely amazing when you consider we are up against the big guys in the industry.

speech.para: Other local winners included Daylesford's Lake House in the tourism restaurant category. I encourage anyone who is going to Daylesford to go the Lake House; it is a sensational meal in a sensational town. The Grampians Pioneer Cottages received an award for unique accommodation, John Dalton from the Ararat Rural City Council was a winner in the individual tourist industry employee category and the Ballarat Goldfields Holiday Park received a merit in the camping and caravan parks section.

While I am talking about great people coming out of a great area, I would like to congratulate Jennifer Kelly, who this week was a finalist in the Telstra 2000 business women's awards. Jen Kelly is a great person, and it was great for her to be in that area. I would also like to talk very briefly about another terrific group in my electorate, the Stawell Gymnastics Club. They received $3,000 through the Rural Communities Program which will go towards purchasing further equipment for the organisation. The club was formed by a group of voluntary committee members whose aims are for children to have fun, develop skills, interact socially and learn lifelong abilities. Congratulations to the Stawell Gymnastics Club and to all those people from the Ballarat area who received awards under the Victorian Tourism Awards and to Jen Kelly, who I think is a shining light for regional women. She runs her own agency in Ballarat and is a woman who has great respect in Ballarat and throughout Victoria. Congratulations to all those people.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Neighbourhood Watch

talk.start.para: —There are two days to go until the implementation of the government's GST, but there are already victims. On 15 June this year I received a letter from Miss Robyne Hobson, the area coordinator of the Campsie/Lakemba Area 4 Neighbourhood Watch. It states:

quote.para: Dear Mr Hatton,
I am writing to inform you that Campsie/Lakemba Area 4 neighbourhood watch group has decided to close. The decision to close has been brought about by the GST.

After seeking advice from the Australian Taxation Office, we recently applied for an ABN. However, in addition to the issue of an ABN, we have now also been registered for GST, and have been given a tax file number. Our ABN application stated that we are a community service organisation, but we have been registered as an unincorporated organisation. Of course, we could appeal—at $505 on each count.

This (and every other) neighbourhood watch group is run by volunteers. We have been prepared to contribute much time and effort to try to bring benefits and improvements to our community, and to help reduce the incidence of crime.

However, with the imminent arrival of the GST, we now find the additional burden of complying with the GST—in terms of accounting and reporting—are most unreasonable—particularly for a group run by volunteers. We have come to the place where we have said: “Enough is enough!”

Consequently, at a meeting held last night, it was resolved “that this neighbourhood watch group cease to function by the end of June, 2000, and that action be taken to wind up the group's affairs before then”.

I don't know whether it was the intention of the federal government to cause the demise of volunteer-run groups, but surely this will be the outcome for many such groups as they try to come to terms with the GST. The details of the GST are very complex, and most volunteer-run groups do not have the time nor the skills to comply with all that the GST demands. I understand, even at this late stage, that the rules are still being written and rewritten. Where does this leave volunteer-run groups—who do not have access to free GST seminars, tax office rulings, industry updates, etc.?

Maybe the Labor opposition can use this information to try to make the government see the consternation the GST is causing. Rather than unshackling people, I believe the GST will shackle people even further. Perhaps the difficulties for volunteer-run groups under the GST can be addressed when Labor comes into office.
We are sorry that our neighbourhood watch group has ended in this way, but we needed to move quickly, otherwise we would have been caught in the endless paper chase called “the GST”.
Thank you for your help, and representations made on our behalf, over the past three years. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last Thursday I received a call from Minister Bruce Scott. `How would you like to join me for an exercise off the coast—in your electorate—Jo?' he asked. `Great,' I said. `When?' That was the start of what was an excursion into the world of Navy defence. Within 24 hours I was on my way to Fairbairn in Canberra where my first encounter with an HMAS Albatross Sea King was enacted. I knew I would be okay, though, because we were piloted by a couple of local heroes, Commander David Gwyther and Lieutenant Commander Murray Lindsay. `Here, Jo, wear a flying suit as we'll be cold,' I was advised. Sure, but they just do not make flying suits the size of this MP. Just as well I had worn my winter woollies!

speech.para: We all got on board—Minister Bruce Scott, Mr Brad Fallen, Commodore Rowan Moffit and Lieutenant Sean Leydon. Within minutes we were flying over the Gilmore electorate and it was a sight to behold: beautiful country, pristine beaches, estuaries and rivers. We really do have it all. Then it was on to Kiama, where we met up with HMAS Sydney, which, together with HMAS Brisbane, was in the midst of war drills together with the Black Hawks and Learjets of Albatross. We landed on board the Sydney with absolute precision, had a quick inspection of the radar section and the ship and crew, and then it was on to the Brisbane further out to sea.

Inside the Sea King, I was given another brief explanation to remind me of what was to happen. However, nothing really prepared me for what lay ahead. I had had no time to think when the door opened and I was told to move to another seat. The next minute the minister had gone—disappeared out of the helicopter. Then it was my turn. With my arms outstretched, the harness was slipped over my head, under the arms and clipped onto the hook, and I was told to sit in the open doorway. `It's okay, ma'am, the clips are quite safe,' I was assured. Next minute, I was given a shove and I was out the door. In my panic, I almost succeeded in taking the officer with me—and he had no harness or clips. Seriously, it was a great thrill to be hoisted above the Brisbane and lowered into the arms of the many personnel below who I do not think believed that they were seeing a pollie hanging by a thread!

We had lunch on board with all the crew, and what a fine bunch they were. I was so proud of the individual achievements, as they were in explaining every detail of the ship. Minister Scott spoke to them all, heard about their highs and lows and wanted to know all about their families and the issues that affected them as members of the Navy Defence Force.

Then, guess what? It was time to prove it in reverse: what goes down, must come up. You guessed it—this time I was to be winched to the top. Dangling on a rope, swinging in the breeze, I was finally dragged back into the Sea King. What a day. What a tremendous crew. And how brave they were to have someone like me there—a complete novice who does not know starboard from port, but who now understands a turboboiler and the conditions associated with operating it.

I `dips me lid' to you all. Australians have every reason to be proud of our Navy. Thank you, Minister, for what I thought was to be a ride to see the ships and instead, for me, was a whole new experience. Suddenly, being a pollie was not so bad.

debateinfo.title: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2000 will remove an anomaly in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 in relation to schedule 1 land. Currently, the act allows the Governor-General to grant title to a contiguous Aboriginal land trust to a public right of way on land not contained in schedule 1 of the act that has ceased to exist. The anomaly arises as no such procedure allows the grant of such lands if they are contained within schedule 1 of the act.

speech.para: This amendment bill will correct that anomaly by allowing the minister to recommend to the Governor-General grants to such lands contained in schedule 1. The amendment is technical and uncontroversial in nature. It has the support of the Labor Party because it has resulted from a process of negotiation involving indigenous and non-indigenous stakeholders, a process which resulted in the informed consent of all parties concerned. That informed consent followed consultation between the Northern Territory government, the Central Land Council and two Aboriginal land trusts involved with the issue. All parties arrived at an agreement and, as part of that agreement, the Central Land Council and the Northern Territory government wrote to the government requesting this amendment.

Such agreements as this amendment bill has resulted from are the preferred way for moving forward on indigenous issues generally. Negotiations do not always lead to solutions, but are vital in any process where a balanced solution is sought.

I was pleased to hear the minister in his second reading speech on this bill illustrate the government's new-found commitment to `assist in achieving negotiated outcomes in respect of the land rights act'. That is in Hansard of 1 June 2000, at page 15,818. He went on to set the benchmark for his government regarding consultation with indigenous Australians:

quote.para: The government has the assurance of all parties to the negotiations that representative views of all Aboriginal people concerned have been obtained and their wishes taken into account.

speech.para: The government must apply its own benchmark to any of its intended future amendments of the land rights act. We on this side of the House, as an effective opposition, have no choice but to ensure the government lives up to its own benchmark. The government already has on the record the views of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory concerning their land rights act. They are happy with its operation generally and do not want any change to it without their informed consent. It is their act; a piece of Commonwealth legislation that has successfully returned land to its traditional owners.

The minister has given the government's new-found commitment to consultation and taking into account indigenous views. In the past, the government has gone out of its way to ignore the views of indigenous Australians. This has been most evident in its treatment of native title, indigenous heritage protection, the stolen generation and a number of other issues that go to the centre of indigenous life. The opposition welcomes the minister's commitment to indigenous consultation and assures the government we will be keeping it accountable for that commitment. We have pleasure in supporting the bill before the House.

talk.start.para: —I have pleasure in speaking in support of the government's initiative. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2000 allows disused public roads to be included in the adjacent Aboriginal Land Trusts at Hermannsburg and Haasts Bluff. In passing, I mention the beautiful pottery on exhibition from the Hermannsburg community in Parliament House. It has attracted a lot of attention and it is well worth looking at.

speech.para: The bill corrects an anomaly in the act and shows the government's continuing commitment to improving the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Rights Act where necessary. It is particularly pleasing for me, as chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, that the government is demonstrating in a very practical way its intention to bring the parties together on such issues. Under previous governments of other political colour—the same colour as that of the shadow minister who just walked out—issues went through lengthy legal proceedings before the courts costing millions of dollars before they were resolved. Those wasted millions could have been targeted to better improve the prospects of young Aboriginal people in education and they could have addressed health, unemployment initiatives and training. It is very refreshing to see the commitment of Minister Herron and the Howard government to resolve issues where possible by sitting down with the various interested parties. In fact, 99 per cent of issues can be resolved with goodwill and trust between people.

This is not a new-found initiative of the government, and I very much regret the previous speaker's cynicism in that regard. It is, in fact, a deep commitment that the government has had since it was elected a little over four years ago. There are many demonstrations of it. In fact, this is not the first amendment bill that I have spoken on in this place where land has been transferred by agreement. I did it just a few months ago. This morning I looked at a media release by Senator John Herron dated 9 June 2000. This mentioned the return of 4,450 square kilometres of cattle station in the Northern Territory to its traditional Aboriginal owners in a ceremony which the minister presided over at Heartbreak Hotel in the remote Gulf country. The community was very pleased to see that happen.

On 21 February 2000 the very same minister announced the return of the romantic never-never country—immortalised in Jeannie Gunn's literary classic We of the Never Never—to the traditional owners. The ceremony was held on 23 February 2000. Incidentally, it is almost a century since that wonderful classic book We of the Never Never was first published. The Howard government has demonstrated its commitment to respond to traditional owners and to facilitate the transfer of traditional land to the traditional owners, land they have used and enjoyed uninterrupted for centuries. We saw this commitment demonstrated so wonderfully in that ceremony.

It is fair to say that the minister demonstrated in the most practical way his determination to deal with issues regarding the future of land councils in the Northern Territory when he decided to refer the report of John Reeves QC on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act to my committee.

The minister specifically charged the committee with the responsibility of consulting with Aboriginal people and non-Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory about the recommendations in the Reeves inquiry. The minister made a deep commitment, which has been demonstrated to be sincere and accurate, that he would not make decisions on John Reeves's wide-ranging recommendations until after he had received the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and after that committee had comprehensively consulted with the affected communities in the Northern Territory. That is a very obvious illustration that the government is not acting unilaterally. In fact, it is pausing and consulting with all the affected players, including the Northern Territory government, on major issues to do with the Northern Territory. That is quite different from what was represented by the shadow minister a moment ago.

The recommendations of the committee were contained in a report which was tabled a few months ago called Unlocking the future: the report of the inquiry into the Reeves Review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. That report accepted many of the recommendations of John Reeves but rejected very strongly many others, and those recommendations are being considered now by the government. As chair, I particularly appreciated the contributions of members from all political parties—including the next speaker, the member for the Northern Territory—to what was a very vigorous and interesting inquiry. The recommendations from government and non-government members of that committee were generally unanimous.

There were two or three very substantial issues on which the members did not agree but, because the members wished to put a report to the parliament which would help government and the communities, they agreed that each view on those key issues would be contained in the report. It was the unanimous decision of the committee that the views of both the non-government and government members should be in that report. The committee unanimously recommended that both views would be put to the people for consultation and for them to respond to those substantial issues. I think it is a very good example of how effective the parliamentary committee system is in Australia. On very passionate issues—and the member for the Northern Territory is understandably very passionate on many issues to do with his electorate—members can put their views yet work together constructively under an agreed set of principles. That is just what we did.

We agreed on a set of core principles before we embarked on analysing each issue. Those core principles were a guide and assistance to all of us because we kept going back to them. We said to ourselves, `We cannot agree necessarily on a particular issue, but we are united on the core principles of equality before the law, equal rights, respect for property rights, harmony and all of those things. If we are all agreed on those, let us go back now to the issue where we have disagreement and test it against those core principles.' We did that and I think it has been very helpful. It has not solved all the problems—there is never a simple solution to some of these things—but I think it has shown a way forward.

As a member of the government I was very troubled by some of the recommendations of John Reeves. Those concerns are reflected in the report. For example, Mr Reeves recommended in good faith—he is a very good man whom I admire for his courage—that the management of the freehold land—for that is what it is—of the Aborigines in the Northern Territory and the rents and income from those lands be transferred into a central controlling body made up of the Northern Territory government, Commonwealth government representatives and representatives of the traditional owners of the land.

Just pause and step back from that.
