Whilst he meant it in good faith, because he was concerned about the effectiveness of how some of the rents are applied for the benefit of Aboriginal people—which is a separate issue— where in Australia could you go to, say, a non-Aboriginal community of freehold owners and say to them, `By the way, we do not like the way you use all the rents you get from your farms, your shops, your motels and your office buildings, so we are going to take control of those rents and take the decision making process out of your hands and put it in the hands of a central body which knows better than you'? I know he put it forward in good faith, because he was trying to address some of the urgent issues of disadvantage of Aboriginal people, and he thought that if we could channel all the money in a targeted way the problem would be solved.

In my humble view, one of the great problems with the way in which the affairs and interests of Aboriginal people have been managed in Australia by well-meaning non-Aboriginal parliamentarians is that they have supplanted the right of Aboriginal people to make their own decisions. In fact, they have put the Aboriginal people into a mode where they have to rely too much on government and on welfare. The human spirit develops and handles issues and problems better if the responsibility for those decisions is primarily your own and not someone else's. Mr Reeves wanted to do that and the committee strongly recommends against that; it is just not right.

The committee did, however, recommend that the management of income from Aboriginal freehold land through the land councils should be made more accountable and transparent, and that the granting of money from freehold land for programs should be on a targeted basis and subject to performance measures so that accountability on the ground would be better measured. The committee also recommended that advice be obtained from the Commonwealth Grants Commission, for example, on how to better manage the allocation of substantial funds through royalties and the like for the benefit of the Aboriginal people. Those recommendations I am sure are being considered by the government and by the Aboriginal community.

One of the trailblazing recommendations we made—contrary to Mr Reeves, who said there should be 18 separate land councils—was that the Aboriginal people who own the land should make the decision about how many land councils they want. After all, it is their freehold land. If they want 30, fine; if they want five, fine—we should not impose the number on them arbitrarily. In fact, one of our recommendations was indeed revolutionary. We even had the temerity to say that, furthermore, if a group of Aboriginal owners and their community decide they do not want to manage their land through a land council, they should be able to opt out and adopt a different system of community management—for example, the local government community method that we are so familiar with in other parts of Australia. We were quite bold in saying that, but it seems so obvious: if you own the land and it is freehold land, why should the government impose the model of management? Why should there not be a range of choices for the owners to choose from?

I would wager—and I am confident of this—that, if Aboriginal people are given the opportunity to make a choice and to evaluate, they will respond very well. Like all other communities in Australia, they will occasionally make mistakes—you have to have the right to make mistakes to get on in the world—and they will learn from them. It is far better than the present system which, while well meaning, requires Aboriginal people to actually wait for the orderly management of issues through statutory bodies which have to respond to ministers and, in many cases, to get the permission of ministers to go forward and do things.

Another recommendation that I was very keen about—and I thank the committee for their full support—related to our wish that the management of land through the traditional Aboriginal approach involving trusts be assisted by their being able to grant long-term leases to individual Aboriginal people. For example, in Canberra an Aboriginal family could obtain a 99-year lease over an area of land and go to a bank or building society and apply for a housing loan, so that they could get a loan and build their own house. Rather than relying on the statutory public housing system to provide housing for Aboriginal people, why not give them the right to do that? I have spoken to quite a lot of traditional Aboriginal people and they like that idea. They think it is great.

When we visited Bathurst Island and met with the Tiwi people—fantastic people—they were putting into operation that principle over their traditional land. They were looking at granting long-term leases, not only for housing for individual families but also for commercial enterprises. So an Aboriginal family with a small business could go to a bank and get a loan for their workshop. Why? Because they had a long-term lease over the workshop which therefore provides security that they can borrow against. Under the present system, they are inhibited from doing those sorts of things because the title that they have is a right to occupy, and the traditional ownership system says that they can do so. But it is not an identifiable, targeted right; therefore it is not one that can be borrowed against.

We put those ideas forward. I hope that, after consultation, the government will be able to come to an agreement and bring in amendments to the act which will facilitate that sort of approach. There are lots of opportunities. This bill is another concrete example of the government's good management and positive approach to assisting Aboriginal people to manage from the ground up, to free them of the shackles of the lawyers—albeit a worthy profession—to get them out of the courts and around the table, and to diminish the role of government in their everyday affairs. I wish the bill a speedy passage.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to contribute to this debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2000, which effectively involves a land swap—a deal between the Northern Territory government and the Central Land Council on behalf of the Ltalaltuma Land Trust to do with land around the Tnorala reserve in Central Australia. I will make some comments about the contribution by the previous speaker, the member for Indi, shortly, but I want to deal with this question of agreement. The fact is that until recently the Northern Territory government has been the cause of most, if not all, of the litigation which has occurred over land rights matters in the Northern Territory.

speech.para: The previous speaker, the member for Banks, talked about the federal government having a role in this matter; fortunately for me, I have a bit of a corporate memory in relation to these issues and a lot of involvement in them. I say to the member that he is not only ill-informed but clearly needs to understand the history of land rights in the Northern Territory and the role which conservative governments in the Northern Territory have played which has caused division in the Northern Territory community over land and Aboriginal issues generally. That invariably has caused land claims to be sent to the Federal Court or to the full High Court where, in most cases, the Northern Territory has lost. The Northern Territory government has used money which has been made available to it from the federal purse to pursue this litigation, at great cost to the Northern Territory community.

The previous speaker correctly pointed out that this money would have been far better spent on providing infrastructure, educational services, health, housing, et cetera. But this was a decision freely made by the Northern Territory CLP government—a conservative government. The Chief Minister of that government for some time was Shane Stone, who is currently President of the Liberal Party of Australia. I suggest to the previous speaker that instead of railing about what governments at the federal level have done, what he ought to understand is that most of the intransigence over issues to do with land and land rights in the Northern Territory is a direct result of the stupidity, arrogance and obdurate nature of the CLP government in the Northern Territory over many years. That is a matter of fact and a matter of record.

In this particular instance, we have a road swap. Let me put it on the record that this was not an initiative of John Herron but an initiative which arose out of a discussion and arrangements between the Central Land Council and the Northern Territory government. Indeed, I have in front of me copies of the correspondence between the Northern Territory government, through Denis Burke, the Chief Minister, and the Hon. John Herron, and a copy of a letter from David Ross, who was then acting director of the Central Land Council, to John Herron, pointing out that they jointly requested that the act be amended to accommodate an arrangement which they had freely entered into. This was not an initiative of John Herron or the federal government.

What it is about is a need to improve road safety. The Northern Territory government sought to improve road safety, to upgrade a road and to improve user amenity around Tnorala. To do this it needed to realign the Namatjira Drive and to open an access road from the realigned Namatjira Drive to Tnorala reserve. But that required access to Aboriginal land. So they agreed to a land swap: effectively, Aboriginal land was made available for that purpose and then, on the other side of the coin, the Territory government agreed that:

quote.para: (a) the Redundant Namatjira Alignment;
(b) to the extent that the Existing Tnorala Access was not included in the deed of grant of the Land—that road, and
(c) the Katapata Road,

should be closed and granted to a land trust or land trusts for the benefit of Aboriginals entitled by Aboriginal tradition to the use or occupation of that land, with the intent that the roads referred to should be granted to the Land Trust that holds the contiguous Aboriginal land.

speech.para: In effect, what we are doing here this morning is giving that agreement some life and completing the loop by ensuring that that land is transferred to the land trust or land trusts.

I was interested in the other statements which were made by the previous speaker. I will not take much of the Main Committee's time, but I do think it is necessary to respond to some of them. I must say that I note his support for the idea that Aboriginal people should be able to make their own decisions. I note his support for the unanimous view expressed in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The very first recommendation of that report—which, as he properly pointed out, was unanimous—was that there should be no amendments to the land rights act without the informed consent of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

In this instance we have an amendment to the land rights act which is with the informed consent of those people whom it affects. But the view of the previous speaker is clearly at odds with the view of the person who is currently sitting next to him in this chamber. Last night, when we were discussing an issue to do with the tabling of the report of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation raised very serious questions, from his point of view, about this whole question of informed consent. I say to the minister that he should read both reports and understand where they are coming from. I suggest to the minister that he should adopt the view, at least insofar as this issue is concerned, of the person who is currently sitting next to him in this chamber. He might like to have a discussion with him about why it is important that Aboriginal people should have the right to determine what happens on their land.

I note that the previous speaker referred to the right of Aboriginal people to determine what sort of management should happen on their land. What he needs to know, again by virtue of what is happening currently in the Northern Territory, is that the Northern Territory government has embarked on a process of seeking to promote the idea that local governments on Aboriginal communities should be amalgamated. That is being taken to the point, I am informed, where these communities have been told that, unless they adopt an approach in this regard which is okayed by the Northern Territory government, it will be forced upon them.

That directly flies in the face of the view which has been expressed by my friend who spoke before me. I would say to him that he should see and understand the contradictions in what he said. The people at the bottom of this process of causing division over issues to do with Aboriginal land have invariably been conservative governments, both here and in the Northern Territory—but particularly in the Northern Territory. Here we have an instance where I am informed, reliably, that Aboriginal community leaders have been told that, unless they agree with this approach of the Northern Territory government, it will be imposed upon them. I say to the member that that flies directly in the face of the view he has expressed here this morning, a view which I support. You cannot have it both ways. I would say to the government that they need to go away and have a discussion amongst themselves and perhaps counsel their friends in the Northern Territory conservative government about the way in which they should be dealing with these issues.

There is a clear conflict of views between those people in the government who clearly support, as evidenced by this unanimous report, the idea of informed consent and those in the government, such as the minister, who clearly do not. There is a clear contradiction of views between the views of the government members who say that Aboriginal people should be able to decide how to manage their affairs and their land, and those of the Northern Territory government who clearly say that they should have the right to determine how governance is managed on Aboriginal land. They are just two examples of contradictions. I know you have an interest in this area, Mr Deputy Speaker, and you would understand that I am saying that you cannot straddle both sides of the street. In this instance I suggest that there are some members of the government who are very precariously situated on a very thin strand of wire and it may have some implications for them at some time in the future.

Let me conclude by saying that this is an important thing we are doing this morning. It is far more important than I think we give it credit for. I do want to say to those people who are involved in this arrangement that it is important that the public acknowledge that this is an arrangement entered into freely by parties where there is an exchange of land. The intent of this exercise is to ensure that the general public gets access to what has hitherto been Aboriginal land for the purposes of road alignments, and that land which used to be for road alignments becomes Aboriginal land. I recall the days of very tormented discussions with members of the Northern Territory government when I was an employee of the Central Land Council. The Northern Territory government would come to a meeting and ministers would give undertakings about what it was they were prepared to concede or deliver, and invariably it did not happen. No sooner had you walked out the door than the deal had changed.

I hope that we have moved on to new and better things. I am pleased that the previous speaker supports the unanimous recommendations of the committee of which he was chair. I hope that those recommendations are picked up by the government and that the minister at the table will understand the import of them and, before he seeks to comment on them, might actually read them.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: — in reply—I thank the members for Banks, the Northern Territory and Indi who have contributed to the debate. Can I just say that the government is proud of its record in returning land to Aboriginal people. Since we came into office there have been 12 land claims settled. This is an average of three a year and it is one of the highest rates since the enactment of this legislation. Even more impressively, about half of these were achieved through negotiation and agreement without the need for costly legal processes. The main purpose of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2000 is to give effect to the Tnorala road swap agreement which was recently made between two Aboriginal land trusts—Hermannsburg and Haast's Bluff—and the Central Land Council. Under the agreement the Northern Territory will acquire the land that adjoins two public roads passing through two land trusts. In exchange each of the land trusts will be granted land title to adjoining land which contains disused public roads.

speech.para: The land council has given an assurance that it has identified the relevant traditional owners affected by the proposal. The proposals were subject to a series of consultations and, in November, the Northern Territory Department of Transport and Works and the traditional owners agreed about the construction of new roads in the area and the closure of others. This agreement is reflected in the road swap agreement before us. The land rights act requires that land over which there is a public road be excluded from land grants. It also provides specific procedure for granting of land where the road is closed. This procedure under the act as currently drafted applies only to land granted under section 11 of the act; that is, the land that has been granted as a result of a hearing before a land commissioner. It is an anomaly in the act that, if land has been granted as a result of an agreement reached without a formal hearing—land included in schedule 1 under section 10—adjoining land where a public right of way once existed cannot be included in the grant even where the right of way ceases to exist. This bill will correct that anomaly.

The bill includes an amendment to the land rights act to ensure that land may be granted to Aboriginal land trusts holding land granted under the agreement and included in schedule 1 under section 10 of the act in the same way as land granted under the land claim hearings process conducted under section 11 of the act. The amendment will have the additional benefit of enhancing the efforts of the Northern Territory government and land councils to achieve resolution of land issues by means of written agreement rather than prolonged and costly disputation. That reflects the government's continuing commitment to assist in achieving negotiated outcomes and to improve the act for the benefit of all parties.

I said previously that we have an outstanding record of returning land to Aboriginals. I am pleased to note that two more land grants are expected in August. I believe we will have an outstanding record in indigenous affairs generally. We have consistently demonstrated our commitment to addressing disadvantage suffered by indigenous people by delivering improved outcomes in health, housing, education and employment. In 2000-01, we will again expend a record amount—$2.3 billion—in targeted indigenous assistance programs. We are working with indigenous people to build a better future, economic independence and self-empowerment. Land is an important feature of that, and this bill will contribute to continuing effective and efficient administration by the government of the land rights act.

I want to thank the opposition for their assistance in ensuring the quick passage of this bill through this chamber and to thank members for their contributions. These matters need the agreement of both sides to achieve that outcome. In this case it is useful because the opposition, presumably, coincidentally come to the same view as us that this is the appropriate outcome. I do not imagine they would be agreeing to it if it was not, nor the facilitation if they were not of that view.

There was a discordant note injected by the honourable member for the Northern Territory, who is no longer here to hear any response. He suggested there was some disagreement between the member for Indi and me. When I spoke in another chamber, I was talking about native title legislation. Here we are dealing with Northern Territory land rights legislation that was implemented by the Fraser government, which is operational and which we want to ensure operates effectively to produce beneficial outcomes for indigenous people. We seek to do so cooperatively. But cooperation requires exactly that. You need to come together and produce an agreement. If you cannot get agreement, what then happens? Presumably, the view of the member for the Northern Territory—and I am not sure what he means by the term `informed consent' in this context—is this: if you don't give me what I want, you do not get agreement.

There will be no progress in relation to the implementation of land claims and there will be less progress under the Northern Territory land rights legislation if that is the approach that is taken. Governments ultimately have to be able to produce a resolution of these matters. It is not in the interests of indigenous people to have these issues forever unresolved, nor is it in the interests of the Australian people to have these issues forever unresolved. Of course, in the native title legislation what we were seeking to do was to introduce certainty to the outcome after we had been involved in negotiations over very long periods of time.

talk.start.para: —And before title was granted.

—Absolutely. The fact is that in relation to the native title legislation we now have a workable scheme. The test is not for us in the government; the test is for the opposition. The scheme provides a basis for the state governments to be involved and we have procedures for Queensland which the Queensland government, a Labor government, has developed. We do not know whether the Labor Party at the federal level is going to support the scheme developed by their colleagues in the state of Queensland or whether they are going to seek to knock it off. Of course, if they do knock it off, ultimately it leads to further disadvantage to indigenous people. It means delay. It means that issues are not resolved. It produces uncertainty. That is the test.

speech.para: The opposition spokesman who addressed this issue a little earlier was on the Sunday program many weeks ago. It was one of the more memorable Sunday programs—I think I should get the video and replay it almost every week. It was the plaintive voice saying, `But Laurie, Laurie, let me off. Don't press me on these issues anymore.' All Laurie was asking was, `If you are, in principle, opposed to native title legislation because it allegedly breaches racial discrimination legislation, then in government—if you ever get there—you are going to have to do something about it. It is something on which you are expected to have a policy.'

talk.start.para: —We have and we will.
—You don't, and I suspect you won't.
(Hon. J.A. Crosio)—Direct your comments through the chair.

—The policy at the moment is that we are going to discuss these issues. The member for the Northern Territory who spoke earlier might tell me we are going to get informed consent from indigenous people. The question is: if you do not get consent to what you propose, are you proposing to give all that they require, which means a veto forever and a day in relation what happens to Aboriginal land or native title? If that is your position, you really need to state it. If that is what your policy is about, you need to state it.
—Sitting in the chair, Minister, I do not have to state anything.
—No, Madam Deputy Speaker, I was not asking anything of you, I do not think. I was talking about the opposition.
—No, you were saying, `You will have to.'

—And I should not refer to the opposition in that way—as `you'. My colleagues in the opposition need to think very clearly about where they are going. Some members of the opposition produced a report which was tabled yesterday in the House of Representatives. In that report they gave expression to the non-policy, and the recommendations spelt that out. `Let's sit down and have a talk about it.' Not, `We see this as being wrong in principle and it has to be amended and we know what amendments are required to address what we believe is racial discrimination.' It did not say that. Of course, the opposition do not want to say that and we know why they do not want to say that; it is because, at the end of the day, they do not want a policy on this issue. They want to be able to oppose what is there but offer no solution, no future directions.

speech.para: Well, you will not be able to get away with that. The people of Australia will know. The plaintive cries, `But Laurie, but Laurie,' will not carry the day. This goes to the issue that was raised here. At the end of the day, does informed consent mean a veto—that is, that you can do nothing if one group is not prepared to negotiate? We are prepared to sit down and negotiate; we are prepared to sit down and talk; we are prepared to negotiate reasonable solutions. They can be achieved as they have been in this legislation. It is a model. But if it cannot be resolved then the legislation ultimately needs to provide a basis for resolution, and that is what is required in the native title legislation.

I thank honourable members for their cooperation in relation to this legislation. I thank the opposition for their support, even though they could not resist the occasional barb, and I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Mr Wakelin:

motion.para: That the House take note of the paper.

talk.start.para: —This report by the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs is, I believe, a landmark report. All members of the committee were committed to presenting a strong report that recognised the problems experienced by indigenous Australians and which, hopefully, would put in place some strategies, some strong recommendations, that would help to resolve the problems and lead to a better future for indigenous people in our country.

speech.para: The chair of the committee was very even-handed and committed to the way in which this report was written, and worked hard to see that we got a consensus report, as did all members of the committee. This was my first experience of working on a committee in this place, and I was really impressed by the dedication, not only of members of the committee but of the secretariat that supported the committee. I mention in particular Jim Kennedy, who was very instrumental in writing the report and who has been with the committee through two parliaments. Jim was seconded from OATSIS. I mention also Bjarne Nordin, who left the committee just before the report was completed.

When we think of the health of indigenous Australians, we cannot separate it from the social issues that impact upon indigenous Australians. Only 2.6 per cent of indigenous Australians, around 10,000 people, are older than 65 years. It is really sad to think that, before the age of 65, 97.4 per cent of the indigenous population will die. I believe that is an indictment on our society. Other indicators that show the level of disadvantage of indigenous people in Australia include the fact that the population—and this links with the fact that very few people are over the age of 65—is much younger and is growing at a much faster rate. Twenty-three per cent of all indigenous Australians are unemployed. If it were not for the CDEP, that figure would be 34 per cent. More than half of those aged between 20 and 24 are unemployed and 60 per cent of indigenous Australians earn less than $12,000 a year.

These are all really important health indicators because we are finding, more and more, that there are a number of social determinants that establish the health of people. The figures that I have read out show how disadvantaged indigenous Australians are. It is going to be imperative for these issues to be addressed if the health of indigenous Australians is to improve.

We need to look at the issues of housing and nutrition. In 1996-97 it was estimated that there were 12,000 homeless indigenous people. Seven per cent lived in dwellings with more than 10 people living in them. During the committee inquiry, we visited a number of areas and to say that the housing was second rate is really underestimating the situation. It is unacceptable that we live in a country where people are still living underneath and between sheets of corrugated iron. In those dwellings there is not one family but two or three. I do not see how, as a society, we can allow that to continue.

There are some very good recommendations in the report in relation to housing. I urge the government to embrace this report and to accept the recommendations, because some of those recommendations could really change the direction in which we are going. Poor nutrition leads to the diseases that are so common in the indigenous population—diseases of the circulatory system, respiratory diseases, diabetes and cancers. Once again, poor nutrition is a symptom of poverty, a symptom of a society where people are living either in remote communities where they cannot access good quality food or in metropolitan and urban areas where they are forced to buy poor quality food because they can afford nothing else.

It is important to state here that the majority of indigenous Australians live in cities. We think about indigenous people living in remote areas in the Northern Territory, but 28.5 per cent of all indigenous Australians live in New South Wales. The largest proportion of indigenous Australians live in Sydney, followed by Brisbane and the northern part of New South Wales. The one thing that is constant is that they all have the same level of health: they all die earlier than white Australians and they all suffer from the same diseases. Until we recognise the fact that it is not just an issue in remote and rural Australia, we will not be able to come to terms with the fact that it is an issue that impacts on all indigenous Australians.

The first thing we, as a nation, must do is help indigenous Australians heal. We must make a commitment to reconciliation. We must recognise the culture of indigenous Australians. Indigenous Australians are a people who have had their culture ripped from them. They are Australians whose culture has been undermined. They are Australians whose culture has been torn apart. The importance of land in that culture needs to be recognised. It needs to be recognised that to be a whole person, to be able to be a healthy person, you must have a healthy base to build on: you must know who you are, what you are and where you are going. Once you establish those facts then, as a group of people and as a person, you can move forward. As a nation, we need to recognise that.

In the little time I have remaining, I would like to talk about the very important recommendations of the report. We need to make a greater commitment to the framework agreements and to community control, because it is through community control that indigenous Australians will be able to say in which direction they want their community and their health programs to go. A lot of duplication currently takes place. A lot of areas are not properly funded. We need to make sure that funding given to communities has some security attached to it so that a community knows that they can plan for the future and that, if they commit to a program, to a direction, that program will receive long-term funding.

Another important recommendation is for Aboriginal people to have a voice in cabinet through the minister, and that needs to happen as a matter of priority. The issues of employment and education also need to be addressed—and addressed urgently. Education, employment and the creation of opportunity will ensure that indigenous people will have the economic ability to enjoy good health. The gap between people who have and have not is growing in Australia and, as the most disadvantaged people in our community, indigenous Australians are in the worst position. I implore the government to pick up the recommendations of the committee. I thank those who were involved in this report for their dedication.

talk.start.para: —Like the previous speaker, I am delighted to be able to speak in taking note of the report entitled Health is life: report on the inquiry into indigenous health. In my mind, the report is a visionary blueprint for dealing with probably one of the most complex issues that faces Australia today—the appalling track record of governments, both state and federal, in dealing with the complex issue of indigenous health. As the honourable member before me said, this has been a real labour of love for committee members. The report has taken 2½ years across two parliaments, and most members of the committee have almost dedicated their lives to ensuring that this report—170 pages in total, with 126 pages of text and 44 pages of appendices—sees the light of day.

speech.para: Madam Deputy Speaker, you know that I rarely speak ill of those opposite, but I want to place on the record a concern I have that government members in this place are not—to my mind, anyway—really giving of their best when it comes to committee work. I am involved in a couple of committees—one on family and community affairs and the other on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. It worries me that for members opposite the electorate takes precedence over committee work. In the three terms during which I have had the privilege of serving my electorate, I have come to the realisation that, despite what members think, constituents appreciate the fact that, when members are away from this place, they spend some time dealing with complex issues which transcend individual electorates.

In the presentation of this report, we are coming up with initiatives that will benefit people in not only my electorate but also the other 147 electorates in this country. Having said that, I would like to quote from Professor Ian Ring's submission to the committee during the taking of evidence. He said:

quote.para: A way needs to be found of harnessing a national effort for a very complex range of issues in a very complex system of government. In the circumstances only the Commonwealth can provide the necessary leadership and coordination.

speech.para: The first recommendation we made in this visionary blueprint was recommendation 1, which reads:

quote.para: The Commonwealth accept that it has the major responsibility for the provision of primary health care to Indigenous Australians:

the Commonwealth must assume responsibility for developing, in collaboration with the States and Territories, an efficient, coordinated and effective mechanism for the delivery of services and programs which impact on the health and well-being of the Indigenous population.

speech.para: Without a Commonwealth responsibility, we will have exactly the same thing happening as we have seen since the very first report, almost 23 years ago, by this House. We will see, as the previous speaker, the member for Shortland, spoke about when she highlighted the appalling statistical evidence, that our indigenous brothers and sisters are being short-changed beyond belief. It is interesting to note that in our report we highlight just what has happened in other countries—for example, New Zealand, Canada and the United States—in their endeavours to deal with this very complex issue.

The word `holistic' is mentioned countless times throughout this report, and that is done for a very good reason. Indigenous people have a concept of health that is not like that of Anglo-Saxon non-indigenous Australians. On page 67 of our report there is a quote from the National Health Aboriginal Strategy Working Party which encapsulates this holistic approach:

quote.para: Health is not just the physical well-being of the individual but the social, emotional and cultural well-being of the whole community.

speech.para: And there is a quote from Tracker Tilmouth on page 35 of the report which says:

quote.para: We also have a belief that health is achievable only when the people who suffer the greatest disadvantage have ownership and control of the process and the programs that are directly related to it.

speech.para: As I have said, this is a complex issue, but one that I believe is resolvable both in the short and long term. It is complex because of our federated state. We are endeavouring to impose a medical model on a race of people whose boundaries transcend state boundaries and whose cultural beliefs are not the same as ours. It is also a complex issue because we have a vast number of players involved in delivering services. We have got the Commonwealth government, the state and territory governments and local government; we have got the various arms of the medical profession—GPs, specialists, nurses, Aboriginal health workers; and we have got the hundreds and hundreds of indigenous communities themselves.

It is further complicated because we have three different groups that we are trying to concentrate on. There are those in the very remote areas of Australia whose needs and wants and aspirations, while basically those of all indigenous people, are, to my mind, different from those of people who are closer to Western society, the people I call the fringe dwellers—those who are living on the outskirts of large cities in Western Australia, New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. Then we have another group of people who, although part of the indigenous community, have different problems and yet have greater access to the range of services. Yet, as the previous speaker said, the health outcomes are all the same, and these are for the urban dwelling indigenous people of Australia.

Those of us who have been on this committee for the last 2½ years have seen, as I have often said, the good, the bad and the ugly of indigenous communities and the problems they face. As I said earlier, it is a solvable problem; it is a long-term solvable problem. It is probably going to take 20 years. I honestly believe this wonderful document, Health is life: report on the inquiry into indigenous health is a blueprint. I would like to think the minister himself is busily pouring over it during the six-week break while we are away. According to my reckoning, he has got three months to come up with a government response to our 35 recommendations.

The good thing about our report is that it is a bipartisan report. It reflects an honest belief by all members of the committee that we are, as federal legislators, responsible in the end for what is happening to our indigenous brothers and sisters. One of the complexities about the whole issue to date is that the buck does not seem to stop anywhere. The Commonwealth, state and local governments and the medical profession have had the opportunity to shift responsibility and the consequent funding requirements needed to ensure that the indigenous people have been getting the best of medical services.

In this fine report, we deal with a whole range of issues: housing and infrastructure services, training of medical workers, the Commonwealth's responsibility, framework agreements, nutrition, education, health professionals. It is a very fine report. I hope the minister, when he comes up with his response, acknowledges that this whole issue of indigenous health can be solved. It is not one of the impossible tasks. It is one that all governments need to acknowledge as one of the great shames of our current Australian society.

We are entering the Centenary of Federation, 100 years of federal government. As members of this House and as the general community read some of the horrifying statistics that are enclosed in this document, we must all accept some of the shame and responsibility for what has happened. In a spirit of bipartisanship, the medical profession, local, state and Commonwealth governments need to take on board our 35 recommendations. They must not duckshove responsibility. They need to accept it in the terms of our recommendations. When we leave this place and look back, we will be able to honestly say—as I know all members of this committee have said in private and, in some cases, publicly—that this was one of the finest reports not only from the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs but from this whole parliament.

Finally, I commend the report. I compliment Jim Kennedy who was seconded from OATSIS to be the guiding spirit to the committee members. I congratulate all the people across Australia who gave up their time, energy and effort to make submissions. I pay a tribute to the workers who probably will never read my comments and the comments of the rest of us here. I would like to think there is a warm and fuzzy feeling in their stomachs today. These dedicated people in some of the most rural and remote areas of Australia are doing service that would shame and embarrass most of us. With those few words, I am very proud to take note of this report.

talk.start.para: — It is a pleasure to have the opportunity to speak to the motion to take note of this report of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs entitled Health is life: report on the inquiry into indigenous health. I place on record some thanks that were unable to be stated when the report was tabled. I place on record my appreciation of the work done by the secretariat of the committee. In particular, all committee members would like to place on record our thanks to Jim Kennedy who, as an officer of OATSIS, was seconded to the inquiry. He gave generously of his knowledge and experience. We also appreciated his comradeship along the way.

speech.para: Another person from the secretariat I would like particularly to thank is the previous secretary, Bjarne Nordin, who has left the services of the Department of the House of Representatives. He was the original secretary when the committee was first put in place when we reorganised the House of Representatives committee system. Bjarne was involved in a previous inquiry into this matter by a House of Representatives committee some 20-odd years ago. So, for Bjarne as an individual, it was a revisiting of an issue. I know that he, like the committee, was driven by a desire to try to get things right, to put in place a set of recommendations that would mean that we would not have to return to inquire as to what has happened. We also acknowledge the efforts of the other people in the secretariat who provided administrative support, because it was a long inquiry. We thank the present secretary of the committee, Trevor Rowe, for his patience as we tried to finalise the report.

At the time of the tabling of the report in the House, I briefly thanked all those who assisted the inquiry. There are so many people that it is very difficult to mention individuals. They gave generously of their experience. For some, it was very difficult to share what this issue meant to them, because it was something that was very spiritual. Much of what they were sharing with us came from within.

I want to take this opportunity to highlight the assistance that we received from two people in particular. One of those is Puggy Hunter, the chair of NACCHO, the National Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation. He shared a lot of his experiences with us. I think that was very important in assisting committee members to have an understanding of the issues involved in the inquiry. The other person whose help I want particularly to highlight—and this is more because of how she assisted me in a personal sense to understand the issue—is Dr Ngaire Brown, the indigenous health adviser to the AMA. I think indigenous Australians should be very proud of what Dr Brown has achieved. She would not perhaps look upon her efforts in that way because she is a very modest person. She goes about her work with great professionalism and does not look for any special credit. On this occasion it is appropriate that we highlight her particular assistance to the inquiry. As I said, I have named only two people, but there are so many people who could be named who gave so much assistance to the inquiry.

The basis of the health status of indigenous Australians is highlighted by the report and has been highlighted in contributions today. I do not want to go over that. I simply say that, however the comparison is made with respect to the health status of indigenous Australians, whether it be between those that live in an urban situation and those that live in a remote situation, the health status of indigenous Australians is appallingly worse. That is what drives our desire that, out of this inquiry, we see some positive action.

The other matter that I want to highlight briefly is that the report not only talks about improving relationships between the different spheres of government but also emphasises the importance of involving the communities themselves in determining what is really required in indigenous health. In order to make sure that that happens, we must build the capacity of the communities to help themselves. I want to share with the Main Committee a quote by somebody who is involved with a community that has had some great success and which is now used as a great model. That person said to the inquiry:

quote.para: I believe we, the Tiwi people, have taken 20 years, and our capacity building has been mainly through the developments of people that have an interest in our island. We have had a lot of learning experiences and most of them were through mistakes. I think you would agree that each mistake that we make has made the Tiwi people stronger in regard to controlling our land.

speech.para: That was said by Marius Puruntatameri, who is a member of the Tiwi Health Board. That statement he made to the inquiry is very important, because often there is a lot of criticism because people can quite easily see things that go wrong. But what Marius was definitely indicating was that indigenous people, given the opportunities, can achieve. They understand when they have done something wrong or it does not work. They do not need to be patronised and told that these things have happened. They are continually learning. If we look at the environmental health program Tiwi For Life, if we look at the Tiwi Island's involvement in case management, the point is that they are achieving, and they provide a very good example of what can be achieved by a community when it is given the opportunity.

Another program that I particularly want to highlight is one that emphasises that there are aspects of primary health care and of the environment in which indigenous people live, and that there are mechanisms that can assist in improving that environment. I refer to the scheme that is conducted by the Ngnampa Health Council on the AP lands in South Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will have to excuse my appalling pronunciation of this health review: the Uwankara Palyanku Kanyintjaku, which thankfully is known as the UPK, which is much easier to remember. The UPK was about an assessment of the conditions within the community. It decided that there were certain essentials that the community required. When I read out the list, you will think, `This is very simple.' But the point is that it has been put down; it has steps that give the community a chance to monitor the process; it sets the path for what they have to do.

They look at improving the health status through the washing of people, clothes and bedding, removing waste, improving nutrition, reducing crowding, separating dogs and children, controlling dust, temperature control, and reducing trauma. But, for each of those, the community has been trained to monitor itself and, where possible, to take remedial action with the assistance of professionals. A lot of what has been done by Ngampa Health is in that model. They have professional health workers who are trying to assist the community to achieve things. For instance, they are adapting a form of care for their elderly that is appropriate to their community. They are examples of the ways in which we can see the way forward in indigenous health.

Another thing I want to highlight from the inquiry is that we place emphasis on the importance of Aboriginal health workers. Aboriginal health workers have to be recognised because they are doing valuable work; they need to be recognised by being given status. That is one of the things that is always of concern. There are cultural considerations because sometimes the most appropriate person to become the health worker does not have sufficient status within the community. But that is for the community to work out. The Aboriginal health workers have to be assisted with their training. It has to be recognised by the other health professionals that they have a very proper role, that they have an important role. I hope that the highlighting of their role within the report will lead to that greater recognition.

Finally, I wish to highlight particularly one other recommendation from the report that relates to the setting up of the Independent National Council for Indigenous Health Affairs. It is something that might be the circuit breaker in not requiring us to come back for further inquiries. I unashamedly say that this could be an important vehicle for informing the public about indigenous health status and for making sure that governments and the public at large have their eyes on this as an important policy matter. It should be a lobby; it should be an advocate for indigenous health. It is not a body designed to take away the responsibility for direct action from communities themselves. I believe it will ensure that, importantly, non-indigenous Australians do not forget that we have a requirement to make an effort to improve Aboriginal health.

As the honourable member for Franklin has acknowledged, this is a long-term thing but we have to see progress. We cannot see this, as measured by whatever indicators we use, as being a static thing—that as the health of the general populace goes up, the health status of indigenous people still lags behind. We want those two lines to come closer. As others have said, this is an important report. I hope honourable members outside the committee will use it as something that assists them in an understanding of the position of indigenous health.

I conclude by saying that—and it is not a political statement—it was clear from the inquiry that one of the things that underpinned the need to advance indigenous health is to do with the relationships within the Australian community between indigenous and non-indigenous peoples. I wish to highlight recommendation 2 which says:

quote.para: Australian governments continue in their earnest attempts to conclude a meaningful reconciliation with indigenous Australians.

talk.start.para: —It is hard to know where to begin. Here we are in the Main Committee, with half a dozen members of the parliament, discussing what I consider to be the single most important health issue facing the nation. I would firstly like to acknowledge and thank all the members of the committee. Whatever political party and whatever electorate they came from, everybody worked in a spirit of goodwill on this. I would also like to thank the secretariat and the Australian taxpayers, who financed our investigation. They, of course, deserve more thanks than anybody else.

speech.para: In one of my trips to the Northern Territory in 1994, I went to Yuendumu, a community about 300 kilometres north-west of Alice Springs. I met a fourth-year Dutch medical student who was doing an elective. I asked her, as you might, `Why did you choose to come to Australia to do your elective?' and she said, `I wanted to see medicine practised in a Third World environment.' It seemed an indictment on us that a young person living in a European country would travel to Australia to see what she thought of and described as Third World living conditions. Throughout the course of this inquiry, and certainly in my other experiences with indigenous Australians, you cannot help but feel that may be true. I did some work with World Vision in Tanzania, Kenya and Zimbabwe in 1995 and, even in the slums of Nairobi, those people, with the exception of those with AIDS, do far better than indigenous Australians, despite all the resources that successive governments have given to them.

I turn to another more recent experience at the other end of the spectrum. I had the privilege of being able to assist Minister Peter Reith, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, on the indigenous employment strategy. We sat in a hotel room in Melbourne with about 50 CEOs of the top companies in Australia, each of whom, to their credit, had committed themselves to supporting indigenous employment initiatives. We went around the table and each described how their company could assist in the employment of Aboriginal people. The CEO of Anglican retirement villages and nursing homes said as an aside, quite legitimately, `At some point, all of you in this room might need the services that we provide.' So when it came to my turn, I made the observation that the reason we were there to encourage indigenous employment was because most Aboriginal people will not live long enough to need the services that they provide.

The circumstances which underwrite this report, and the people whose lives we shared and touched as we went to these communities, who so freely and willingly told us in constructive terms what we ought to do, can be summarised by the fact that, in our country, indigenous Australians have a life expectancy which is 15 to 20 years less than will be enjoyed by my children. To put that into perspective, that equates to countries like Haiti, Ghana, India and Papua New Guinea. Our nation is unique amongst developed countries in that we have not made any inroads at all into reducing the difference in life expectancy between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and non-indigenous Australians. For that, I think all of us stand condemned, despite the significant efforts undertaken by governments of all political persuasions.

An Aboriginal baby that is born today still has only a one in three chance of living to the age of 65 and, despite significant advances in the last quarter of a century, is three times more likely to die in the first year of life. An Aboriginal man who is my age—I am 41; my kids think I am half dead—is 10 times more likely to die than I am. Half of those premature deaths can be attributed directly or indirectly to the consequences of alcohol abuse. One in three Aboriginal people will suffer from diabetes. If Aboriginal Australians in the Top End of Australia had access to the same health care that any of us expect, one in five would be under the care of a renal physician. That is just one small snapshot of what underwrites this report.

There are some recommendations in particular which deserve support. I strongly support the member for Scullin who spoke before me with respect to the proposal for an independent national council for indigenous health affairs. What we are trying to do is to embrace the Prime Minister's vision of practical reconciliation. The real issue in reconciliation is: why is it that a baby that is born in an Aboriginal community today has, as I said, only a one in three chance of living to the age of 65? That is the real issue. This takes the model for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, which has made substantial gains over the last decade, and applies that to Aboriginal health. So you bring people who have respect and expertise from a whole range of disciplines in Australian society—from business, societal health, administration, Aboriginal people—and you give them the resources and the political support to be advocates for seeing that proper programs are supported by governments of all persuasions to advance improvement in Aboriginal health.

Recommendation 6 is that the minister with responsibility for Aboriginal affairs go into cabinet. Just imagine for a moment, Mr Deputy Speaker, that all Australians, wherever we live, all basically had the same expectancy of life and the same health outcomes. Just imagine for a minute that, within six months, we arrived at the position we now have for Aboriginal people. We would declare a state of emergency. The Commonwealth would be taking over state responsibilities, we would have all sorts of people out there trying to advance an improvement in this. Instead of that, we languish, despite the good things that have been done by the present government and the previous one, and we are still not making the progress that we ought to. So one of the recommendations is to put into cabinet the minister who is responsible for Aboriginal affairs, including the health of Aboriginal people; as well as to provide an annual report to the parliament and to give the emphasis to this area that it deserves and that I think most Australians want.

One of the other pivotal recommendations in this report is recommendation 25. I am at times accused by some of my colleagues of being an idealist. I take that as a compliment. I think once you lose your idealism you are irrelevant. I am accused at times of wearing my heart on my sleeve. Again, I tell my kids that they ought to behave that way. I am convinced that the thing that is killing Aboriginal people is welfare. It is the way that we deliver resources to Aboriginal people which is destroying them. I remember going to Maningrida. It would have been in 1993, I suppose. I was getting on the plane to leave when I turned to the chairman of the Aboriginal council and said—they were just getting things together to deal with alcohol, petrol sniffing and all sorts of problems which I will not repeat—`Was it always like this?' Upon reflection he said, `No, it wasn't. We used to have a market garden here. We used to build our own dwellings. They were fairly modest. Most of the problems we have here now were not here.' I asked, `What happened?' He said, `When Mr Whitlam got in he started sending money.' That is a very good example of very good intentions on the part of the Whitlam government—and on the part of other governments, including ours—to send resources to people living in completely different circumstances from that which we enjoy.

If you fly across Central Australia at night, you see a whole lot of blinking lights down on the ground. I remember the first time I saw them I said to the person who was with me, `What is that down there?' We were in the middle of nowhere and there were all these flashing lights on the ground. I then realised that they were televisions. People who are living in a community that does not have water that meets basic World Health Organisation standards of acceptability are watching television—with the same advertising and materialistic imagery that my kids are receiving on the upper North Shore of Sydney. And then once a fortnight, with good intentions, we send in resources for those people by way of individual income support payments

Recommendation 25 picks up on the things that Noel Pearson, to his credit, has been talking about—that is that, if we really want to turn around Aboriginal health, apart from the very good recommendations in this report, we need to change the way in which resources are delivered and managed by Aboriginal people in their own communities; that if an Aboriginal community is prepared to volunteer to do so and if there is $25,000 a fortnight, for example, going into a community in the form of income support payments, then the community agrees that it manages most, if not all, of those resources on behalf of the people in that community. It is a bit like a development program where the community then sets its own objectives for one-, three- and five-year development for educational outcomes, immunisation rates, the design and building of housing, and reticulated water and sewerage programs. The contract that the Commonwealth enters into with those communities is to actually deliver more resources to them. It is not about cutting back money; it is about delivering more money but ensuring that the people themselves have control of it. The assistance we provide is by way of engineers or architects who help them to design their own dwellings.

If you go to Aboriginal communities, you will find that the ones that are really looked after are those where the Aboriginal people themselves have built and painted their own dwellings and organised their own health service. They are the models we need to start to embrace. We ought to have the courage as a society to say that a young Aboriginal woman who lives in Arnhem Land who, at the age of 15, has two children and drinks a third to half a cask of wine a day and plays cards might as well be living in a different world, let alone in a different country from the one that we live in. I say that as a person who has the greatest commitment—in fact, if you go back to my maiden speech you will see it—to do something about this issue. That was one of the reasons I came into parliament and, if it is the last thing I do, I will do it. We have to have the courage to step outside the square. You do not impose these models on any community: if no Aboriginal community in Australia wants to do it, it does not happen. But if there are five who do, we ought to be prepared to do it and let it happen.

The other thing that I would like to support is the concept of reconciliation, in recommendation 2. Pauline Hanson was a lightning rod for the grief and anger that many of us feel about changes in our country we neither understand nor, in some cases, want. But, under Mrs Hanson's concern—to put it politely—about resources given to Aboriginal people, there is a critical question that remains to be answered: why, despite impropriety, greed and nepotism in the management of Aboriginal resources in many parts of Australia, have contemporary governments decided that the circumstances of these people are so great that we have established and maintained specific programs for them? It goes back to where I started, in terms of a snapshot of the health of these people.

If we are going to improve and lift the health, living conditions and, frequently, existential despair of indigenous Australians, we have to understand our past. We have to understand what happened, why it happened and the impact that they had on us as much as we had on them. That is what reconciliation is about. It is not about assigning blame, it is not about contemporary generations feeling a sense of guilt. It is that we have a shared history, whether we like it or not. It is interesting that Thomas Jefferson said that the relationship between non-indigenous North Americans and the American Indians would need to be built on respect and fear, because he knew that North America would be built on the sacrifices of the indigenous North Americans.

It seems today that much of our relationship with indigenous people is built on fear, but much less respect. We can deliver all of the resources we like into Aboriginal Australia—as we should—but unless people feel good about themselves, about the way they relate to one another and the way they relate to us, if not the rest of the world, then it is an exercise in futility. Very subtle but powerful forces influence the way any of us feel about ourselves. We could have hot and cold running teaching hospitals—as my colleague from Parramatta has suggested some people might want in country areas—and all of that, but if any of us have poor self-esteem, if people do not feel a sense of goodwill towards themselves, how can we expect their lives to improve in any meaningful sense?

I commend the report to the Main Committee. I despair that our priority is such that we are stuck in this little room talking about this, albeit with goodwill from both sides of the parliament. One day, perhaps, our priorities as a nation will change, and perhaps some of the Aboriginal leadership will start to focus a little bit of its attention away from things like treaties to some of the recommendations in this report, because these are just as important as the things that they are arguing for—and perhaps more important.
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Anyone who is from Victoria knows the huge impact that electronic gaming machines have had on our state. In the nine short years since 1991, Victoria has gone from the state that spent the least on gambling to the one that spends the most.

speech.para: The effect of these machines is not the same across the board, unfortunately. They disproportionately hit people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds. For example, the City of Whittlesea, which is in my electorate, has three times the Victorian state average of gaming machines. The residents of Whittlesea, a city with a population of approximately 100,000, put the staggering amount of $64 million through these machines last year. It is estimated that the losses of problem gamblers account for 20 to 30 per cent of total losses. Problem gambling affects the individual, their family, their job and their home. But it affects the local community too, in lost economic opportunity to traders and in dealing with the effects of problem gambling through support services.

Last year, as part of his campaign to give himself a human face—perhaps as part of the long haul to his ultimate leadership bid—the Treasurer decided to focus on the evils of gambling and the distress and misery it was causing local communities. However, despite this concern and rhetoric, nothing was really ever done about problem gaming, and I suspect that nothing really will or perhaps can be done by the Commonwealth. In that void though it is pleasing to see that some local governments have taken up the issue and are displaying great leadership after seeing the economic and social devastation that problem gaming is causing.

The City of Whittlesea in my electorate has worked with local welfare and community support organisations and local gaming venues to produce a local charter for responsible gaming. The local charter is a voluntary agreement between these parties and sets out a range of initiatives that will promote responsible gaming and limit the occurrence and negative impact of problem gambling. The main objectives of the charter are to ensure that gaming venues provide their services in a responsible manner in safe, pleasant and healthy environments. It provides the opportunity for continuing dialogue through the responsible gaming forum, a forum comprising gaming venues and local welfare organisations, about how gaming is impacting on the local community.

The signatory gaming venues commit to regular participation in the forum and to responding to issues raised by the local community members about gaming. The charter contains a number of practical measures for gaming venues to comply with, such as a policy of encouraging large payouts by cheque and offering a broader range of leisure activities at the venues other than just gaming. Appropriate signage encouraging people to take a break from gambling is to be displayed on or near the electronic gaming machines. Where complimentary refreshments are offered, as is common at a lot of gaming venues, it is required that the signatory venues provide it in an area away from the machines to encourage breaks.

The charter also concentrates on informing gaming venue staff about the issues surrounding problem gambling and requires senior staff to attend information sessions with local problem gambling support services so that they can make referrals to these support services when required. The venues are required to support self-exclusion agreements where people who believe that they have a gaming problem can voluntarily request that they not be admitted to venues. This can be to a specific venue or to all the venues in the City of Whittlesea.

The local charter is a local community response to the devastation caused locally by problem gambling. I commend all the parties involved in its formulation and I hope that it will be a success in dealing with some of the problems that I have outlined. I feel that this charter can be a model for other local communities and I would encourage them to examine it and to formulate something appropriate to their community to deal with this complex and perplexing issue.

subdebateinfo.title: Hinkler Electorate: Tanna, Mr Reginald Gabriel

talk.start.para: —In a fortnight significant for its tragic events—the sad departure of our colleague, Greg Wilton, the death of our greatest poet, Judith Wright, and the unspeakable events surrounding the Childers backpacker fire—another equally profound event has touched the people of the Gladstone district in my electorate of Hinkler, and that was the untimely death of Reginald Gabriel Tanna—Reg Tanna, as he was known to his friends—CEO of the Gladstone Port Authority.

speech.para: It is hard to describe the shock and dismay that this caused to those who loved and admired him so widely in the Gladstone community, to say nothing of his loving family. I had the privilege of knowing Reg Tanna, first at school at the Christian Brothers in Warwick where he was some years ahead of me, and then the privilege was renewed some years later as Gladstone's local member. He was the son of Malek and Mary Tanna and brother to seven children, five of whom survive him. They were a hardworking family in the very best traditions of the Lebanese and Australian ethic, establishing their Warwick fruit and vegetable business in the days of the Depression. Reg excelled at primary school and the brothers recommended that he be sent to Nudgee College in Brisbane, where he emerged as dux in 1951. Other academic successes followed and he graduated with honours in civil engineering at Queensland University in 1955. Reg never forgot the sacrifice his family made and nothing gave him greater pleasure than to renew family contacts, as I readily remember when the Gladstone coal facility was named the R.G. Tanna Coal Terminal in his honour in 1994. I remember the thrill of some of his family being there on that day.

Reg was CEO of the Gladstone Harbour Board and Port Authority for 34 years. It would not be an exaggeration to say that he grew up with the port authority and it developed under his able and highly focused vision. The wider development of Gladstone, now the powerhouse of central Queensland industry, was dependent on an efficient port and the ever changing and increasing demands made it necessary that this port moved with the times. Reg Tanna was equal to that challenge, and it is now Australia's fastest growing port.

Few sections of Gladstone life escaped his caring attention: Lions, Blue Nurses, Hibiscus Gardens Hostel, the Red Shield Appeal, TAFE and the Central Queensland University Advisory Committee. As well, he was a devotee of the local tennis association. He was honoured in the honours list of 1991 with the Public Service Medal.

We have reflected in the last fortnight on the unfulfilled dreams of many, especially of our colleague Greg and of those young people at Childers. In Reg's case, it was no less so. He was actually within weeks of his retirement—the retirement that he and his wife, Norma, so eagerly anticipated. But, then again, he had a deep faith and would have seen his Maker's higher purpose. Reg never missed his Sunday Mass, regardless of where he was anywhere in the world.

My own memory of Reg Tanna was of a gentle, humble and caring person whose sense of fellowship was all embracing, regardless of your station in life. I can well remember him leading the songs and the Christmas carols at the port authority's annual Christmas party—hardly the role you would think for the CEO, but nevertheless the one he always took on. My thoughts go out to his family: to his wife, Norma, his children, Catherine, Michael and Tony, and to his extended family in Warwick, especially his brothers, with whom I grew up.

talk.start.para: —On Sunday, 25 June, we had in my community the blessing and opening of the new and refurbished school buildings for the Patrician Brothers College, Fairfield. The first school began in Fairfield in 1953 with 170 pupils in years 4, 5 and 6. From six classrooms in 1953 the school has grown to 50 classrooms with over 1,400 students ranging from years 5 to 12. This college has always operated as a regional school with designated feeder parish schools.

speech.para: The college has, through its teachers and students, built an excellent relationship with the local community as well as excelling in the academic and sporting fields. It has strong links with the local business community and offers one of the broadest vocational education programs in the state of New South Wales. I congratulate Brother Bernard Bulfin and his team of dedicated teachers. It has not been easy over the last six years, with the rebuilding of the college, to have a construction site and school functioning in one and the same area.

I, along with many invited guests, attended last Sunday's opening. Parents, students, both past and present, as well as many community people, applauded when Bishop Geoffrey Robinson blessed the buildings. Senator Helen Coonan represented the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp. It would have been appreciated if her briefing had at least acknowledged that the building work had commenced prior to this government taking office.

The new buildings have provided a unique environment and I know the college will continue to go from strength to strength. The project has been developed and completed through the work of the Fairfield Cluster of Catholic Schools Management Committee, led by Father Raymond Gatt, a truly remarkable man. They have worked very dedicatedly over these last six years.

There was on the day a presentation to 11 people who have given more than 365 years to education and service. I believe their names should be placed on the record of this parliament. They are: Ron Borg, 27 years; Wayne Burns, 26 years; Kevin Bourke, 46 years; John Cusack, 28 years; Laurie Cassar, 34 years; Vince Lourey, 36 years; Roberta Goehner, 30 years; Pat Smith, 28 years; Robert Turnbridge, 25 years; Brother Richard Doheny, 40 years; and Brother Bernard Bulfin, 45 years. That is a truly remarkable achievement, not only in education but also in service.

In the time I have I would like to commend this school. In 2003 we will see 50 years of continuous education that has been provided from what was a dream many years ago. We had never seen a college of such wonderful dedication achieve it. I would like to put on the record the first five lines of the statement the staff of Patrician Brothers College made together in 1995. It said:

quote.para: Patrician Brothers College, Fairfield is a Catholic school community of staff, students and parents working together through supportive structures and a relevant curriculum to provide a sound education, aiming for excellence and catering for the needs of the whole person.
The College provides a safe environment whereby our culturally diverse community is nurtured, the individual presence of each person is valued and the sense of belonging and hope is fostered.

speech.para: There are another four paragraphs just as equally binding I could go on with, but I do not have the time to do that. I just want to commend that also to the House. As far as Fairfield Patrician Brothers go, we in our community particularly are very proud of them. I think it could not be said any better than in the words of the last verse of their school song that the boys were so proudly singing on Sunday. The verse goes:

quote.para: Blue and blue the colours of Fairfield
Blue and blue, we delight in our past;
St Patrick is the strength of our College
Forever this spirit and our hearts will hold fast.

speech.para: Congratulations for what they have achieved. I congratulate all of those wonderful people whose names are too numerous to mention for their work, finance gathering and coming together to give voluntarily of their time to raise the money when they did not meet the budget. I would like to mention the Commonwealth government's just under $5 million, and the $12 million it took to complete the complex from the Catholic education funding.

More importantly, I would like to congratulate the community spirit within that area over these last six years of rebuilding. It is really something to witness and enjoy. I understand there are certain building and design architects going around now looking at how complexes can come together through design and showing a precedent on how this has come about. All of these buildings have now formed a wonderful pattern with an internal courtyard where the school, as a whole, can gather and attend assemblies or important events like the one last Sunday.

I am certainly very proud to have represented this school over all of my political career. More importantly, I am very proud to have a school of such calibre nurturing the students who are going to be our future leaders. I can only say to those teachers, `Keep up the good work. We acknowledge your work, even though at times you may feel frustrated in what you are doing. More importantly, the boys that you have taught in the past and those you will teach in the future certainly appreciate the dedication and the education that they receive at Fairfield Patrician Brothers College.'

talk.start.para: —As a clearer picture is now emerging of the outcome of the parliamentary elections held in Zimbabwe last weekend, I take what I trust is an appropriate opportunity to report on my recent participation in the Commonwealth observer group. The Commonwealth had made public earlier last month its deep concerns about the situation in Zimbabwe, referring to the ongoing violence, loss of life, illegal occupation of property, failure to uphold the rule of law and political intimidation in the run-up to Zimbabwe's parliamentary election. After securing an invitation from the president of Zimbabwe for Commonwealth observers to be present, the Commonwealth formed an advance team of six, comprising representatives from Malawi, Ghana, Trinidad-Tobago, New Zealand, Canada and Australia. I attended from Australia. A much larger team was formed to arrive on 9 June and to stay until next weekend. It included Senator Sandy Macdonald who is part of that group still in Zimbabwe.
