speech.para: The mandate of the observer group was to consider the various factors impinging on the credibility of the electoral process as a whole and to determine in its own judgment whether the conditions existed for a free expression of will by the electors and if the elections reflected the will of the people. This meant that the Commonwealth team had to examine not only how the elections were conducted on the polling and counting days last weekend but also the pre-election period and the climate in which the election was staged. The advance team was able to observe the pre-electoral processes, including stages of the campaigns of candidates from the ruling Zanu PF party and the main opposition party, the MDC, as well as the independent candidates.

I was deployed with Mr Shyley Kondowe, the director of the Malawi Institute of Democratic and Economic Affairs. We travelled to Manicaland, which is to the east of Harare around the town of Mutare near the Mozambique border. Then we moved onto the province around the town of Masvingo to the south of Harare. We met with a wide range of Zimbabweans, from electoral and party officials to representatives from civil society to farmers and farm workers. We met with war veterans; we attended rallies; we met with people from all walks of life. We were not hindered in our tasks in any way. I felt that all Zimbabweans we encountered welcomed the presence of the Commonwealth observers.

On occasions I felt that our presence had a positive, calming influence on the rather tense environment. I recall one day when my Malawian colleague and I sat in on a meeting of several hundred war veterans and supporters who had invaded farms in the Honde Valley and surrounds and a group of commercial farmers. Much of the meeting was conducted in the Shona language, but the atmosphere was highly charged and the exchanges between the two groups were rather agitated. At one point in the meeting, the war veteran leader, a man adorned in bike chains, suddenly broke into English and announced that there were two Commonwealth observers at the back of the hall. He invited us to address the meeting. Mindful of the fact that we were there as observers and not as participants, we tried to resist the invitation but there was insistence. As I was manoeuvring my Malawian colleague to the front, he was nudging me forward. I found myself addressing a rather eclectic group on the strong relationship between Commonwealth nations, the ties between Zimbabwe and Australia and emphasising that our presence as international observers was in order to report on whether the pending election would be in the spirit of the democratic principles held dear by Commonwealth countries. I did not exactly get a standing ovation, but the tension did seem to melt away and we were all invited to morning tea by the local school teacher, the farmers and the war veterans. So it was quite an experience.

Sadly, though, we did find serious shortcomings in the election preparations, particularly in relation to the integrity of the voters roll and the voter registration process that had been undertaken. The Commonwealth observer group will be publishing a report in the next few days. The chairman of that observer group, General Abubakar, issued an interim statement last night in which he indicated that the report will draw attention to the inability of a substantial number of electors to cast their ballots, inconsistencies in polling day procedures and the like.

More important are the concerns as to the nature, the duration and the scale of politically motivated violence and intimidation. I certainly observed examples of this in varying degrees. As a member of the observer group and as a member of our parliament, I also deplore such intimidation and violence. One can only conclude that the incidents of violence did have an impact, as did the intimidation, which prevented open campaigning in some areas, notably by opposition parties. We should be greatly encouraged by the seemingly high voter turnout on the two polling days. The results indicate a significant shift in the development of democracy in Zimbabwe. There are demonstrable signs of hope for a brighter democratic future.

talk.start.para: —Today in the Senate a report on the Brisbane Airport Corporation master plan has been tabled. I take the opportunity to thank Senators Woodley, Mackay, Gibbs and Quirke for their excellent efforts on that report. Unfortunately, I can be less generous about the contribution of Senator Mason from the Liberal Party. In fact, I describe the tabling statement used by Senator Mason earlier this morning in the Senate as extraordinary in its level of insensitivity to the legitimate interests of tens of thousands of residents of inner Brisbane affected by the Brisbane airport.

speech.para: Furthermore, on the one hand, Senator Mason's statement says that the Senate inquiry was a waste of time, a waste of the Senate's resources, politically driven and unnecessary. On the other hand, in the text of the Senate report, the bulk of which the government has signed up to, we find an extraordinary range of fundamental criticisms and attacks on the process over which the government has presided in putting together the Brisbane Airport Corporation master plan. On the one hand, the Liberal Party are saying that this Senate inquiry into the Brisbane airport is a waste of time and resources. On the other hand, they are saying in the text of the report, which they have supported, that there are major deficiencies in the consultation process, major deficiencies in terms of the non-provision of draft flight paths to the Brisbane community and major deficiencies in terms of the proper examination of runway alternatives. I do not think Senator Mason knows precisely whether he is Arthur or Martha on the Brisbane airport issue, nor does the Liberal Party.

He raised three charges this morning in his extraordinary statement to the Senate. Firstly, he said that this inquiry is politically driven. If that is the case, there are 10,000 people in the suburbs of inner Brisbane who have signed petitions against the Brisbane Airport Corporation master plan. There are more than 4,000 registered objections against this master plan. There are hundreds of people who have provided written and other submissions to the actual Senate inquiry itself.That does not constitute political motivation. The bottom line is that you have a fundamental groundswell of community support for a look at the issues at stake in something which is going to fundamentally affect people's quality of life.

His second charge is about the operation of section 94(5) of the Airports Act. The Senate inquiry clearly demonstrates that when it comes to the operation of the provisions of the act in that category, if an approved master plan exists and it recommends a particular runway option, there is no way in God's heaven that a subsequent major development plan can recommend a runway option which is incompatible with that advanced in the master plan for that particular airport. Yet Minister Anderson, the federal transport minister, said precisely that when he issued his February 1999 approval of the Brisbane Airport Corporation master plan. He said that runway alternatives could be examined at the major development plan stage. The Senate inquiry report and the legal advice which it obtained fundamentally disproves that proposition.

The third extraordinary claim by Senator Mason this morning in his tabling statement was that it was hypocritical of local members such as myself and Mr Swan to raise concerns about the Brisbane Airport Corporation and the proposed construction of a parallel runway because the problem had not yet arisen, that in fact there is a way to go and that the construction of the proposed runway is a long way off. What I would say to Senator Mason is that the Brisbane Airport Corporation in its master plan says that it needs this new runway capacity by the year 2006. There is a three- to four-year construction timetable for a runway. That means that we are barely a year or two away from fundamental decisions being taken about the commencement of this construction. That is not a hypothetical concern. It is a real-time concern for hundreds of thousands of Brisbane residents in terms of the impact on not just their quality of life but their property values as well.

The bottom line is this: we are elected to this parliament to represent the interests of our people—10,000 people who have registered their objections through a petition, 4,000 who have articulated their fundamental concerns through their signing of submissions to the Brisbane Airport Corporation itself and those in their hundreds who have written submissions to the Senate inquiry as well. These are real people in the suburbs of Brisbane who have a real and legitimate concern about their future. My job as an elected member is to argue their interests. Mr Swan's job as the member for Lilley is to argue the interests of his constituents as well. That is what we will have done in this exercise. That is what we will continue to do until we draw our last breath. We will not faintly be intimated by this extraordinary statement of arrogance by Senator Mason on behalf of the Liberal Party that these concerns should not be reflected through a properly conducted inquiry of the Senate, which has just concluded.

talk.start.para: —Honourable members will be aware of an important inquiry undertaken in 1997 by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into the wartime sinking of the HMAS Sydney in November 1941. Its report on the loss of the Sydney released last March acknowledged that unanswered questions remained in relation to the mystery surrounding Australia's worst naval disaster. The committee also concluded that further research and rational debate into the loss of the Sydney should continue. It is in the spirit of that conclusion and also as a token of respect to those families and people affected by this tragic wartime loss that I speak today. In particular, I would like to place on record the considered views of my constituent Mr Ian Nicholson of Yaroomba in Queensland who has taken a special interest in this matter.

speech.para: Ian told me that he was interviewed for entry into the Royal Australian Navy at the time that Sydney was reported missing off the coast of Western Australia. As with many others, the loss of a gallant ship and all its 645 crew members left an indelible mark on him and ever since then for almost 60 years he has sought an explanation for the disaster. In Ian's words he believes that, `It is as important as ever that this matter is publicly recorded to at least counter the unreliable German claims and to help ease the grief and hurt that many of the Australian next-of-kin, their families and descendants suffer.'

During his long and distinguished career in the Navy, Ian acquired a wealth of knowledge about the operational procedures of that wartime period, particularly in communications in which he specialised. Ian was twice appointed director of naval communications and had various sea postings, including commands of two of the RAN's guided missile destroyers, before he retired in the rank of commodore. So he is well qualified to comment on one of the findings of the inquiry that he finds most contentious, which is that the Sydney probably did not break radio silence. This is a significant point to Ian and also for others aware of wartime procedures. No signals from the Sydney indicate to Ian that she must have been convinced of the professed identity of the German warship that she was intercepting before coming to close quarters. This means that the German warship Kormoran must have deliberately enticed the Sydney to draw close by masquerading as an allied merchant ship called the StraatMalakka. To have done this, he says, the Kormoran must have known the secret call signs of the allied merchant ships. While I understand the committee did consider this point, it was later discounted because of lack of any documentary evidence, and that clearly was the proper course for it to take. Ian Nicholson feels, however, that the committee took a too-academic approach to its inquiry, with only a professor of history assisting and not one or more experienced naval advisers with knowledge of wartime organisation and procedures.

In particular, he is concerned at the committee's consideration of what he considers to have been impossible communication capabilities for that period. It is a shame that the inquiry could not look further into the question of call signs because I think that, on the balance of probabilities, it could well have been what occurred. In Ian's view, only such an intelligence coup can explain why Sydney did not break radio silence to check the merchant ship's identity and why other security alert measures were not activated.

Ian also reports that this explanation is supported to a large extent by the official British naval historian, Captain S.W. Roskill, who in later years stated that the Germans held some of our secret call signs in 1941, and this was brought to the attention of the committee. However, there can never be absolute proof of this explanation, just as it can never be absolutely refuted by any documentary evidence. It is clear that we do not know the whole story yet, and maybe we never will. However, it is important that every scrap of intelligence continues to be diligently added to our existing storehouse of knowledge in relation to this matter, which is why I have spoken today on behalf of Ian Nicholson.

Notwithstanding that we do not have closure of this matter, it is also very important that our future generations know of the bravery of the Sydney's captain and its crew. I therefore join with Ian in commending the committee on its recommendations that HMAS Sydney memorials be erected in honour of these brave Australians.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 15 February 2000:

quote.para: Has his Department or the National Road Transport Commission given consideration to all new vehicles, including sedans and station wagons, being supplied with beepers similar to those equipped to vehicles such as buses and trucks which are activated when vehicles are reversing.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The issue of whether to mandate the fitting of audible reversing alarms to all vehicles was raised with the Federal Office of Road Safety (FORS) and the National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) in 1995 and was put to the consultative body that assists with development of the Australian Design Rules (ADRs) for Motor Vehicles and Trailers. The consultative body comprises relevant Federal, State and Territory regulatory authorities as well as representatives of industry and consumer groups. They reviewed data provided by the Victorian Coroner of fatalities caused by reversing vehicles between the years 1988 to 1993. There were 17 occurrences in this period and all involved heavy vehicles or forklift trucks. Eight of these cases involved trucks that were fitted with audible reversing alarms.

The consultative body noted that the problem was predominantly a heavy vehicle issue and that nearly half of the occurrences involved vehicles that were fitted with audible reversing alarms. It was concluded that audible reversing alarms did not appear to be particularly effective in preventing accidents. The NRTC and FORS decided not to proceed with the proposal for mandating audible reversing alarms. Since that time, no new evidence has been presented to suggest that the issue should be re-examined.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 4 April 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims by the Automotive Association of Australia that the funding of roads of national importance continues to be at the expense of the national highway system.

(2) Do Budget papers from 1995-96 to 1999-2000 show that funding for the national highway system component of the total expenditure on roads has decreased while funding for roads of national importance has increased.

(3) According to Budget estimates, will funding for roads increase by $27 million, or 1.7% over the period 1996/97 to 1999/2000 while the Consumer Price Index will increase by 3.2% over the same period; if so, will there be a real decline in federal road funding.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware of claims along these lines made by the Australian Automobile Association.
(2) The Budget papers do not show funding for the National Highway and the Roads of National Importance separately.

The amount expended on the National Highway varies from year to year according to the need for investment in new capacity and maintenance requirements and within the Government's overall funding priorities.

The Government, in response to calls from the community to broaden its road responsibilities, has instituted the Roads of National Importance program to fund important links off the National Highway. The Government has provided additional funds to meet its commitments to the Pacific Highway, the Great Western Highway, the Pakenham Bypass, Geelong Road, Main Road 92, the Mt Keith to Wiluna Road, the Mitchell Freeway and the Gladstone Port Road. Of the $1,240 million allocated to current RONI projects, $980 million is additional funding.

(3) Due to changes in the Government's spending priorities, additional funding was provided to the roads program in 1999-00. Total Commonwealth road funding in all categories was $1,597.3 million in 1996/97. The estimate for 1999/2000 is $1,652.9 million. This represents an increase of $55.6 million, or 3.5% over the 1996/97 figure.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 13 April 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the UN sponsored referendum on the self determination of Western Sahara due to be held in July 2000 will proceed.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the US Department of State 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices released on 25 February 2000.
(3) Has he made appropriate representations to the Government of Morocco concerning the human rights abuses outlined in the report referred to in part (2).
(4) Will Australian Government Ministers receive, formally or informally, Polisario Front representatives who do not hold Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic positions.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The UN-sponsored referendum on self-determination for Western Sahara, which was to have been held in July 2000, has been delayed. The United Nations Secretary-General stated in his Report on the Situation Concerning the Western Sahara of 6 December 1999 that the problems posed seem to allow little possibility of holding the referendum before 2002 or even beyond. The conduct of the referendum, to indicate the wishes of the population of Western Sahara on the question of independence or incorporation into the Kingdom of Morocco, is the responsibility of the UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO). On 24 February 2000, the United Nation's Security Council extended MINURSO's mandate for a period of three months, until 30 May, to allow the Secretary-General's special envoy to review' existing impediments and identify solutions to achieving an early, durable resolution of the long-running dispute. MINURSO's inability to resolve a range of outstanding issues (comprising agreement on the voter appeals process, protocols for repatriation of Saharan refugees, and security conditions required for voting) has stalled the referendum to date.
(2) The Minister for Foreign Affairs is aware of the US Department of State 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices released on 25 February 2000.

(3) The Australian Government remains committed to the promotion and protection of human rights internationally and as such is concerned over the human rights situation in the Western Sahara. The Government has made representations to the Moroccan authorities on individual cases of alleged human rights abuses in the Western Sahara. These representations were made via a longstanding arrangement whereby Amnesty International “Urgent Action” cases are considered and, where appropriate, pursued by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on behalf of the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group. The Australian Embassy in Paris, which has responsibility for Morocco, has made representations to the Moroccan authorities on these cases and will continue to do so where appropriate. Human rights issues more generally are also raised with the Moroccan authorities during the Embassy's scheduled visits to Morocco.

(4) Australian Ministers do not usually receive, formally or informally, representatives of either the Polisario Front, a West Saharan liberation movement, or members of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, as Australia does not recognise either as the legitimate government of the Western Sahara. Australia considers the Polisario Front to be representative of an important body of West Saharan opinion, but does not regard it as the sole representative of the West Saharan people. Australian Parliamentarians and officials may meet Polisario representatives informally.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force: Point Cook Sale
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1545)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has a timetable been set for the disposal by the Commonwealth of the site of the RAAF Base Williams at Point Cook; if so what are the details.

(2) Has the Defence Estate Organisation (DEO) defined a heritage precinct for RAAF Base Willams; if so, (a) which buildings at, and features of, RAAF Base Williams are included in the heritage precinct, (b) what guidelines have been used by the DEO in its definition and (c) what expert advice on heritage matters has been considered in its definition.

(3) Is the entire site of RAAF Base Williams on the Register of the National Estate and classified by the Australian Heritage Commission as historic; if so, on what basis has any part of the site been excluded from being part of the heritage precinct defined by the DEO.

(4) Does the heritage precinct defined by the DEO include (a) the runways, (b) the Parade Ground of 1930, (c) the War Memorial of 1938, (d) the RAAF Chapel, (e) Building 95, the Waterplane hangar of 1915, (f) Building 2 10, the aeroplane hangar of 1914, (g) Building 104, the battleplane hangar of 1917, (h) the hydroplane and seaplane jetty dating from 1916, (i) Building 488, the single officers quarters erected in 1914, (j) Buildings M004-006, MO 10 and M026, (k) Building MO 11, married quarters, erected in 1915-1916, (1) Building 18, the former Single Officers' Mess dating from 1918, (m) Building 23, the Single Officers' Quarters of 1918, (n) Buildings 24 and 27-29, single officers quarters of 1929-1939, (o) Buildings 41, 42 and 46, airmen's quarters, 1928-1939, (p) Building 33, the new Officers' Mess of 1937, (q) Building M027-M028, CO's Married Quarters of 1937-38, (r) Building 87, the Base Squadron Headquarters of 1929, (s) Buildings 91 and 92, the Aeronautics Schools of 1922 and 1939, (t) Buildings 93 and 96, the Air Navigation School and Wireless School erected in 1939, (u) Building 101, the seaplane hangar erected in 1927, (v) Building 100, the seaplane squadron headquarters erected in 1938 and (w) the one and two storey weatherboard houses of the Vernacular Style employed by the Commonwealth between 1914 and 1939.

(5) If a heritage precinct has been defined, what (a) protection from demolition or inappropriate renovation and (b) guarantee of public access to the buildings within the heritage precinct does inclusion in the heritage precinct provide after the property is disposed of by the Commonwealth.

(6) If any of the buildings or features referred to in part (4) are not included in the heritage precinct defined by the DEO, what protection do such buildings or features have from demolition or destruction after RAAF Base Williams is disposed of by the Commonwealth.
(7) What consultation process has there been with serving or retired members of the RAAF regarding the definition of the heritage precinct by the DEO.
(8) What consultation process has there been with local or State Government regarding the definition of the heritage precinct by the DEO.

(9) What consultation process has there been with the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Council of National Trusts or the National Trust of Victoria regarding the definition of the heritage precinct by the DEO.

talker.name: Moore, John, MP
Mr Moore
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. Point Cook has been identified in the Defence Reform Program (DRP) for disposal in the medium term (2001-2006).

(2) to (4) Point Cook has been listed on the Register of the National Estate (RNE).Although not all buildings, infrastructure or features are listed, many are of heritage significance. A heritage study was undertaken of Point Cook by Australian Construction Services in 1994, and this will be provided to a qualified heritage consultant for further review as part of the disposal process. The product of this review will inform judgements by Defence on heritage issues associated with the site. In arriving at final decisions on heritage values, Defence will consult widely with the Australian Heritage Commission (AHQ and other interested stakeholders.

(5) and (6) Defence has obligations, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act (1975), to ensure the protection of the National Estate (`...those places in the natural, historic, Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander environments which have aesthetic, historic, scientific or social significance, or other special value, for present and future generations'). This includes liaison with State heritage authorities regarding the possible registering of sites of heritage and environmental significance under State legislation where a property is transferring from Commonwealth ownership. This will be pursued with Heritage Victoria. The extent of public access will be a matter for the future owner. However, it is anticipated that there will be at least some form of access to any heritage precinct due to its heritage link to the birthplace of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF).
(7) At this stage there has only been consultation within Defence.

(8) None. Although this aspect will be addressed as part of any disposal process, as local and state authorities will be responsible for land planning issues once the property is no longer owned by the Commonwealth.

(9) There has been preliminary consultation with the AHC. As part of the disposal process, the department is required to provide a Section 30 referral under the AHC Act (1975). The heritage study will include consultation with the relevant heritage authorities.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Taxation Office: Land and Accommodation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1292)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 April 2000:

quote.para: (1) Does the Portfolio Budget Statement for the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) for 1999-2000 state that the value of the ATO's holding of land and buildings will progressively be reduced over the next 3 years from $3,022,000 to $2,948,000.
(2) What are the changes in the ownership of land and buildings that result in this reduction.

(3) With respect to other accommodation for the ATO, for (a) 1996-1997, (b) 1999-2000 and (c) 2000-2001 (i) what is the total expenditure on rental or leased accommodation, (ii) what sites does the ATO rent or lease, (iii) are any sites that the ATO is renting, leasing or owns currently unoccupied or not in active use for current activities of the ATO; if so, which sites, and (iv) is the ATO entering into any new leases for accommodation whilst holding unoccupied accommodation.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) The reduction is due to depreciation on staff houses over the 3-year period.

(3) (i) The total expenditure for rental or leased accommodation, including rent and outgoings, is as follows: (a) 1996-1997: $175,324,320, (b) 1999-2000: estimated at $172,080,000 and (c) 2000-2001: estimated at $180,495,000

(ii) (a) 1996-1997: refer to Attachment A (b) 1999-2000: refer to Attachment B and (c) 2000-2001: variations to the ATO's property portfolio include vacating two sites on lease expiry and the acquisition of a number of additional leases to meet the needs of Tax Reform.

(iii) (a) 1996-1997: unoccupied space existed in five locations for more than six months in the following sites: (1) 15 Lake Street, Cairns, QLD, (2) 55 Gordan Street, Mackay, QLD, (3) Vic Pde & Cambridge St, Rockhampton, QLD, (4) 36-38 Conway Street, Lismore, NSW and (5) Sutton Street, Cannington, WA. Of the 21,000 square metres at Cannington, 1,065m2 was unoccupied space and 635m2 was sub-leased.

Space in a number of sites was not in use for activities of the ATO due to being identified as surplus to requirements. Space at the following sites were sub-leased under commercial arrangements: (1) Sutton Street, Cannington, WA, (2) Cnr William & Francis Street, Northbridge, WA, (3) Cnr Pulteney & Flinders Streets, Adelaide, SA, (4) 190-202 Collins Street, Hobart, TAS and (5) Computer Centre, Battye Street, Bruce, ACT. The term of these sub-leases coincides with the expiry of the ATO leases.
(b) 1999-2000: unoccupied space existed in two locations for more than six months in the following sites: (1) 2-14 Meredith Street, Bankstown, NSW and (2) 1230 Nepean Highway, Cheltenham, VIC.

The ATO continues to sub-lease space previously identified as surplus to requirements which cannot be used for current activities of the ATO in the following sites: (3) Sutton Street, Cannington, WA, (4) Cnr William & Francis Street, Northbridge, WA, (5) Cnr Pulteney & Flinders Streets, Adelaide, SA, (6) 190-202 Collins Street, Hobart,TAS, (7) 1230 Nepean Highway,Cheltenham, VIC, (8) 100 Broughton Street, Geelong, VIC and (9) Computer Centre, Battye Street, Bruce, ACT. The term of the sub-leases coincides with the expiry of the ATO leases.
(c) 2000-2001: The unoccupied space referred to at (iii) (b) (3) to (9) will continue to be sub-leased during 2000-2001.

(iv) (a) No additional space was leased while holding unoccupied accommodation in 1996-1997. (b and c) No new leases will be entered into while holding unoccupied space. While a number of additional leases are envisaged, space previously identified as surplus in Bankstown and Cheltenham will be occupied by ATO staff.

subdebateinfo.title: Review of Service Entitlement Anomalies: Recommendations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1486)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) What were the major recommendations of the Review of Service Entitlement Anomalies in respect of South East Asian Service 1955-75.
(2) Will the Government implement the recommendations.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Report of the Review had a total of 53 recommendations, the major recommendations being:

. the service of the naval component of Far East Strategic Reserve (FESR) between 1 July 1955 and 31 July 1960 be treated on the same basis as all other FESR service thus granting them qualifying service and recognition for the award of the General Service Medal (GSM) with clasp Malaya and Australian Active Service Medal (AASM) Malaya and the Returned from Active Service (RAS) Badge;
. all ADF members who served in FESR be eligible for the Australian Service Medal (ASM) with FESR clasp on the same basis as applying to the seagoing naval component of FESR;

. Radio Operators at Kranji and Chai Kang on loan to Commander-in-Chief Far East Station (CINC FES) from 11 May 1960 to 5 June 1962 be allotted and thus qualify for the appropriate medals and repatriation benefits;
. official uniformed war correspondents and artists attached to 2 RAR be awarded the AASM 45-75 with clasp Malaya;
. the criteria for the AASM 1945-75 with clasp Malaysia be amended to include the service of HMAS Vampire during the Indonesian confrontation;
. service on the Thai/Malay borderfrom 1 August 1960 to 27 May 1963 be considered “warlike” and personnel concerned be eligible for the appropriate medals and repatriation benefits;

. RAA and RAAF members be allotted for period 17 August 1964 and 30 September 1967 in respect to service on Malay Peninsula and Singapore and Confrontation with eligibility for appropriate medals and repatriation benefits;
. ADF personnel seconded to Royal Malaysia Armed Forces during the period of Confrontation be retrospectively allotted with eligibility for appropriate medals and repatriation benefits;
. service by ADF personnel on secondment to the Royal Malay Armed Forces be eligible for the ASM with clasp FESR;

. the Australian Army Air Dispatch personnel attached to the British Army 55 Air Dispatch Company Royal Army Service Corps (RASC) or the Miscellaneous Australian Detachments Unit of the Far East Land Force (FARELF) during the relevant military campaigns be allotted and eligible for appropriate medals and repatriation benefits;
. service with FESR at the RAAF base in Ubon Thailand from 26 June 1965 until 31 August 1968 be classified as “warlike” and be eligible for appropriate medals and repatriation benefits;

. ADF personnel attached to Thailand on Exercise OBSERVER after 31 August 1968 until November 1968 should be classified as on “warlike” service and be eligible for appropriate medals and repatriation benefits;
. the Australian Civilian Surgical and Medical Teams operating in Vietnam during the Vietnam conflict be deemed as performing qualifying service for repatriation benefits;
. RAAF nurses attached to Aero Medical Evacuation Flights to and from Vietnam during 1964 to 1973 be awarded the Vietnam Medal;
. QANTAS air crew on ADF chartered QANTAS flights to and from Saigon during the Vietnam conflict be given “designated civilian” status and be eligible for the AASM with clasp Vietnam;
. merchant mariners who served on the ships Jeparit and Boonaroo during voyages to Vietnam be eligible for full repatriation benefits;
. the ASM with clasp `Special Operations' be awarded to Defence Force Radio Operators and Radio Mechanics attached to the Australian Embassy in Vientiane, Laos, between 1959 to 1964; and
. ADF Medical personnel deployed to East Timor during the 1975 Civil War be awarded of the ASM with an appropriate clasp.
Full detail is contained in the report which is publicly available.
(2) In the last Budget the Government announced that eligibility for qualifying service would be granted to:
. about 1800 Royal Australian Navy personnel who served with the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Malayan Emergency;
. RAN radio operators who served at Kranji Wireless Station and RAF Base Seletar in Singapore between 11 May and 31 July 1960;
. ADF members who served on the Thai Malay border immediately after the Malayan Emergency, between 1 August 1960 and 27 May 1963;
. Army and Royal Australian Air Force personnel who served on the Malay Peninsula and in Singapore during the Indonesian Confrontation;
. members of the ADF seconded to the Royal Malaysian Armed Forces during the Confrontation;
. personnel who served at RAAF Base Ubon in Thailand between 26 June 1965 and 31 August 1968; and
. merchant mariners who served with RAN personnel on HMAS Boonaroo and Jeparit during the Vietnam War.
In addition eligibility for disability pensions will be extended to some 1500 veterans who served aboard HMAS Sydney, Vampire, Parramatta and Yarra in Borneo during the Indonesian Confrontation.
These veterans are expected to be able to apply for benefits from 1 January 2001.
In respect of awards, eligibility for the Australian Active Service Medal 1945-75 has been extended to:
. RAN personnel who served with the Far East Strategic Reserve (FESR) during the Malayan Emergency. These personnel will also be eligible for the Naval General Service Medal;
. official, uniformed war correspondents and war artists who served with ADF personnel during the Malayan Emergency;
. ADF personnel awarded the General Service Medal 1962 with Clasp `Brunei' for service during the Indonesian Confrontation;
. RAN personnel serving in HMAS Vampire during the Indonesian Confrontation;
. ADF members serving on the Thai Malay border immediately after the Malayan Emergency, between 1 August 1960 and 27 May 1963;
. ADF members seconded to the Royal Malaysian Armed Forces during the Indonesian Confrontation;
. Australian Army Air Dispatch personnel serving with 55 AD Coy RASC or `Miscellaneous Australian Detachments unit of FARELF';
. personnel who served at RAAF Base Ubon in Thailand between 26 June 1965 and 31 August 1968; and
. QANTAS crew members who served on RAAF charter flights during the Vietnam War from 1964-73.
Eligibility for the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 will be extended to:
. Australian Army, RAAF and land based RAN personnel who served with FESR for periods of 30 or more days after the Malayan Emergency;
. RAN radio operators who served at Kranji Wireless Station and RAF Base Seletar in Singapore between 11 May and 31 July 1960;
. ADF members on secondment to the Royal Malaysian Armed Forces after the Indonesian Confrontation;
. ADF members detached for duty in the Australian Embassy in Laos between 1959-64, and
. ADF medical personnel who served in East Timor during the civil war in 1975.
Eligibility for the Vietnam Medal has also been extended to RAAF nurses who served on Aero Medical Evacuation flights during the Vietnam War between 1964-73.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Taxation Office: Superannuation Guarantee Payments Investigation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1492)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many businesses are under investigation by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) for non-payment of Superannuation Guarantee payments.
(2) What is the usual time taken to respond to notifications of non-payment of superannuation guarantee.
(3) When was the ATO first notified by workers or their representatives from the Wide Bay Brickworks concerning unpaid Superannuation Guarantee levy for them.
(4) What action did the ATO take after receiving that notification.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) There are currently around 15,500 businesses under investigation by the ATO regarding Superannuation Guarantee (SG) compliance. This number includes the ATO's actions following up individual Employee Notifications plus industry and regional projects on high risk SG compliance areas. The number also includes employers surveyed under the ATO's annual SG compliance project.

(2) The ATO aims to initially respond to all notifiers within 28 days of the receipt of an Employee Notification of Insufficient Employer Contributionsform. The response contains an acknowledgment letter explaining the ATO's process in dealing with the notification.
(3) The ATO was first notified by workers from Wide Bay Brickworks concerning unpaid SG via an Employee Notification of Insufficient Employer Contributions form received on 17 September 1997.

(4) The ATO is unable to disclose information on the specific action that was taken regarding Wide Bay Brickworks due to privacy and secrecy provisions. However, I am advised that this matter was promptly dealt with.

As information on the receivership of this company is now on the public record, the ATO can confirm that a proof of debt has been lodged with the Receivers and Managers to ensure that the superannuation entitlements are covered. The ATO has also sent standard liquidation letters to all notifiers listed in the records.

talk.start.para: asked the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 11 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Does the Minister's Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals can apply for funding in Tasmania; if so, what are the programs.

(2) Does the Minister's Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) AusAID

Yes, the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) administers the Government's overseas aid program and provides many funding opportunities for businesses, community organisations, and individuals located in all Australian States and territories. AusAID awarded around 1,600 contracts in 1998-99, of these the value of those awarded in Tasmania was $2,474,934.75 million.

Australian companies and individuals are engaged to manage and deliver most of the Government's aid activities. These include activities in the health, rural development, professional training, food aid, infrastructure, governance and education sectors. The nature and duration of the activities can vary from short-term consultancies for designing or reviewing activities to major implementation contracts.

Several other AusAID-managed programs provide funding opportunities which the Australian community can access. These include: regional initiatives with the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN), the Youth Ambassadors Program, Non Government Organisations (NGOs), and the administration of the Australian Development Scholarships Program.

(2) Business opportunities are normally advertised in the national print media, usually `The Australian', and where appropriate, other state and regional newspapers. In addition, some opportunities are also published in the Commonwealth Gazette and on AusAID's Internet Site (www.ausaid.gov.au). AusAID pays for all advertisements.

The Youth Ambassadors for Development Program places young Australians on development projects to exchange skills with local counterparts overseas. This program has been advertised in the print media throughout Australia. In Tasmania these advertisements were placed in `The Examiner' and `The Tasmanian', and also on Radio stations TTTFM and 7LA.

To access Government funds through the NGO schemes, Australian NGOs need to be accredited with AusAID. In general AusAID does not advertise NGO funding opportunities in local media. Accredited NGOs are informed directly when funding rounds occur. However, information about how to apply for accreditation and funding rounds are provided on AusAID's Internet website. Also, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) often provides information relating to AusAID's NGO program to member organisations.

Further information, including specific details about contracts awarded to Tasmanian companies and individuals last year is available in the “Business Participation Australia's Aid Program 1998-99” booklet which is available from AusAID.

(1) The Australia-China Council (ACC) fosters people-to-people relations between Australia and China. It receives $636,000 pa from the Parliament and is supported by a Secretariat based in the East Asia Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra. The objectives of the Council are to promote Australia's national interests in China through furthering a greater awareness of Australia as a technologically sophisticated, multicultural, open and liberal society, oriented towards Asia; and to build a greater awareness of China in Australia, with particular emphasis on customs, cultural and ethical values, business priorities and contemporary issues.

The Council supports activities in the areas of education, business and culture. Most of the Council's resources are dedicated to on-going programs. The Council does occasionally consider funding proposals for activities relevant to its objectives from community organisations, businesses and individuals. The Council welcomes opportunities to partner private organisations in its activities.

(2) Information on the ACC's activities is made available through its web-site (www.dfat.gov.au/acc). Advertisements have been placed in DFAT's publication Asialine. Paid advertisements have occasionally been placed in the Weekend Australian.
Programs and grants provided to community organisations, businesses or individuals in Tasmania:

Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) - EMDG scheme is available to aspiring and current Australian based exporters that meet the eligibility criteria specified in the EMDG Act 1997. The grants are designed to assist export marketing efforts through a rebate of up to 50% of eligible export promotional expenditure incurred.

Export Access Program - Austrade manages delivery of the Export Access Program to assist small and medium sized enterprises in developing the marketing aspect of their export capability. Successful applicants receive assistance from designated service providers who receive funding through Austrade. Austrade does not make payments direct to successful applicants.
Austrade advertises funding programs in print media.
EMDG - A number of advertisements are placed in the Hobart Mercury and the Launceston Examiner leading up to 30 June (closing date for registration) and 30 November (closing date for applications).
Export Access Program - Austrade has advertised during 1999-00 in the Australian Industry Group Exporters Guide and Marine Industry News.
(b) All were paid advertisements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 11 May 2000:

quote.para: Further to question No. 1550 (Hansard, 20 June 2000, page P16520), has action been taken by his Department in relation to the recommendation that the provisions of the Sydney Airport Curfew Act that provide for the transfer to a Badgerys Creek airport of those freight operations which currently occur during the curfew hours at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport should be reviewed and the review should be based on an assessment of the environmental and economic costs and benefits of transferring those operations to a Badgerys Creek airport; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Government is currently considering how best to meet Sydney's future airport needs. The recommendations on the Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement made in September 1999 by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage are being taken into consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 11 May 2000:

quote.para: Further to question No. 1552 (Hansard, 20 June 2000, page P16520) concerning the recommendation that Australian Standard AS2021-1994 should be reviewed having regard to the applicability of the standard to communities affected by a new airport and to communities subject to a significant change in the noise environment as they would be if a major airport was to be built at Badgerys Creek, has he taken action to review the standard; if so, when will the review be finalised and adopted; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

talk.start.para: — The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Government is currently considering how best to meet Sydney's future airport needs. The recommendations on the Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement made in September 1999 by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage are being taken into consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has he received signed copies of the return section from a United Firefighters Union of Australia pamphlet outlining concerns with the direction of aviation fire fighting services; if so, how many.
(2) What action has he taken in response to the campaign.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. Eighty-six (86) to end May 2000.

(2) No action is required from me at this stage. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) is working to finalise by the end of June 2000, the safety regulatory framework for the entry and exit provisions and minimum safety standards for rescue and firefighting service providers. CASA issued a Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) in February 2000 to enable and encourage industry feedback on the proposed regulations and the responses are presently being evaluated by CASA. The Union's comments will be considered by CASA in that context.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 31 May 2000:

quote.para: Futher to my question No. 473 (Hansard, 1 June 1999, page 5731), what progress has the Government made in using social capital indicators in the performance measurement for Commonwealth agencies, as part of the move to accrual budgeting systems in the 2000-2001 Budget.

talker.name: Fahey, John, MP
Mr Fahey
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The evaluation and reporting of performance is an important facet of the government's accrual budgeting framework.

Ministers and agencies have the primary role in determining desirable outcomes, the outputs necessary to achieve them, and developing indicators of performance. There is an implicit recognition of elements of social capital in a number of agency's indicators. For example, an important dimension of the effectiveness indicators identified by the Department of Family and Community Services is community capacity as revealed through community skills, knowledge, leadership, partnerships and networks.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did Australia accede to the 1979 UNESCO Convention on the Recognition of Studies, Diplomas and Degrees concerning Higher Education in the States belonging to the Europe Region on 6 August 1986.
(2) To what extent are Australia and New Zealand sharing or contemplating membership of UNESCO and Council of Europe conventions on education.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: — The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Australia will sign the Joint UNESCO/Council of Europe Convention on the Recognition of Qualifications Concerning Higher Education in the European Region, 1996 (known as the Lisbon Convention). The Executive Council (ExCo) approved on 15 December 1999 Australia's signature of the Convention. My Department will shortly draw up and complete an appropriate instrument of full powers to enable Australia's Deputy Permanent Delegate to UNESCO to sign the Convention on behalf of Australia, subject to ratification.
My Department has been informed by DETYA that they are not aware of whether New Zealand is also contemplating signing the Lisbon Convention.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2000:

quote.para: What were the (a) names, (b) positions and (c) qualifications of the persons who represented Australia at the World Education Forum in Dakar on 26-28 April 2000.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: — The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Australian representatives to the World Education Forum were Ms Susan Pascoe, delegation leader, and member of the Australian National Commission for UNESCO (Ms Pascoe is President of the Australian College of Education, and Coordinating Chairperson (Curriculum and Support Services) of the Catholic Education Office in Victoria); Mr Robin Davies, Counsellor, Development Cooperation, Australian Delegation to the OECD, Paris; and Dr Geoff Masters, Executive Director, Australian Council for Educational Research (ACER), and member of the Australian National Commission for UNESCO's Education Network.

Other Australians were engaged in a working capacity by UNESCO for the World Education Forum. These included Professor Colin Power, former UNESCO Deputy Director-General For Education, Dr Warren Mellor, UNESCO Senior Programme Specialist, Global Action Programme on Education For All, and Professor Malcolm Skilbeck, former Deputy Director General for Education, OECD, Paris, and former Vice-Chancellor of Deakin University.

subdebateinfo.title: A New Agenda for Multicultural Australia Statement: Response
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1626)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 8 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say what has been the response in the ethnic communities and the ethnic media to a new agenda for a multicultural Australia as promulgated by the government in December 1999.
(2) Has there been a response from the mainstream media and from Australian mainstream institutions to the new agenda; if not, is he able to say why not.
(3) What resources has the government put in place to promulgate the objectives as set out in the new national agenda for multicultural Australia.
(4) What appropriations were included in the 2000 Budget to promote the objectives of the New National Multicultural agenda.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The response from the ethnic communities and ethnic media to the government's multicultural policy statement, A New Agenda for a Multicultural Australia, has been positive. To date, over 10,000 copies of the New Agenda have been provided to institutions across Australia, and demand remains fair.

(2) Coverage of the New Agenda in the mainstream media has been limited. Coverage is likely to increase as the Council for Multicultural Australia becomes fully operational. As far as I am aware, the response from mainstream institutions is positive.

(3) The Council for Multicultural Australia will assist the government in implementing the New Agenda. In doing so, it will work with Commonwealth departments and agencies, other levels of government, the private sector and the wider community. An Inter-Departmental Committee on Multicultural Affairs has also been established, chaired by my department, to work with other Commonwealth agencies to advance the New Agenda. It aims to provide a better coordination of multicultural policy at the Commonwealth level and to develop joint ventures and partnerships on multicultural policy and programs between Commonwealth agencies.

(4) It is expected that, in addition to existing resources directed to multicultural affairs, $1 million per year will be expended to implement the New Agenda. For 2000-2001, these costs will be absorbed by my portfolio.
